This game is agony. It's the Dark Souls of management simulations. I spent more time in this game than I did DS1,2 and 3 *combined*.

It's also one of the best examples of in-game mechanics reflecting in-game story, Exemplified in the boss battles quirks, or even more meta-narratively (Cognition filter, or how the gameplay it feels like an endless cycle of pulling yourself through a bed of glass shards reflecting the in-story reality).

This is not a fun game, it's not even particularly engaging, but there's depths to the gameplay and story that are truly gripping.

--
My advice to players:
Retrying a day, and more importantly Resetting to a checkpoint (5 day check) AND resetting back to the start (day 1 of 50). WILL and MUST occur, repeatedly. Accept it. Embrace it. Doing the early days over again is EASY relative to the later challenges. You will only make your suffering worse if you don't use all 3 resets and frequently, or you keep trying the 24hr day resets without going back to a 5 day checkpoint of a full-resets. Look up how to use 5 day resets to 'learn' a monster and gather EGO gear..because once you have it and know it, *it stays with you*.


Do the side-missions as soon as you are able, and do the boss battles. They're game-changing and some are so powerful it's worth instantly reseting to day 1 to play WITH the improvements.

I recommend you do play with mods though, particularly ones that let you save your agents on resets, or ones that improve quality of life.

I love SCP. I love management games. I love stories with a thick layer of sci-fi mystery. However, after playing this game for a bit, it didn't take long for it to get on my nerves from a gameplay and design perspective. I will be the first to admit that I have probably barely scratched the surface of what this game has to offer, but in all honesty, that is all that was needed for me to dislike and refund it.

I find the graphics, UI, and overall design of the game very unappealing. The animations are very stiff and clunky and remind me of what you would encounter on those cheap early 2000s free game websites, where you would find a bunch of poorly made Mario knock-offs. It was either that or Space Cadet Pinball back then, so you would just spend the afternoon scrolling on that website in the hope you would encounter something that vaguely resembled a quality game.

The UI of this game is weirdly confusing because of the many different statistics vomited randomly on the screen, and it doesn't help that even the tutorial rapidly starts to throw absurdly complex terms at your head, making the whole thing unnecessarily confusing right from the start. And then the music... boy... it has been a while since I've encountered a game with a soundtrack that burrowed its way into my brain... in such a bad way. It's very repetitive and relatively short, stopping after a minute or so, followed by complete silence and then abruptly starting again, over and over. I prefer more mellow or catchy melodies, especially in my management games, so I can just happily hum along while enjoying my management duties.

So yeah, as a fan of SCP and management games in general, I don't really get why this game is rated as overwhelmingly positive. In my short time playing this game, I have very few positive things to say about it. One of which would be that the written, mysterious backgrounds of the 'SCPs' are fun, interesting, and creative. But yeah, I'm afraid that's pretty much where the praising stops.

Maybe it's just not for me. Maybe this game is positively review-bombed because of some online following or meme I'm not getting. Whatever the reason for my distaste is, I thought I would share my 2 cents concerning my personal experience with it. For me, this is just not the SCP management game I was hoping it was.

One of my favorite games to date. I completed it (nearly) 100%, with my own added challenge to try completing ever day without a single agent dead, I almost did it if it was not for day 49. Only had to "reset" once as well.
It is very addicting to manage the abnormalities, unlocking information on them, reading their stories, and becoming attached to your agents, But what really kept me going despite any hardships was the story which I think is amazing, I love the characters and it is the best story-gameplay integration I have seen and experienced for myself, it is also the way the gameplay is shaken up a bit to remove repetitiveness as you learn to grow accustomed to it.
So yea, I recommend if you like management games with an awesome unraveling story.

[h1][b]FACE THE FEAR, BUILD THE FUTURE.[/b][/h1]
[hr][/hr]
I'll try to keep this review [b]spoiler free[/b], because there is a overarching plot in this story that builds up into this grand finale of a stage play, and it's best to go into this game blind to experience it yourself.

If you're into management sims that has punishing-but-satisfying gameplay and turns into an RTS when an abnormality (the game's term for the monsters) breaches their containment, or if you're just a fan of cataloging and managing monsters beyond your comprehension, then this game is for you.

[b]The Gameplay[/b] is punishing. Yeah, that's no exaggeration. Lobotomy Corporation, at the very start when you have none of the abnormalities researched, is a game of trial and error. You will not be able to beat the game on your very first try. Think of it as a rogue-like, but when you die, you can still restart the day. Eventually though, you'll hit a major road block, i.e: an abnormality might be too strong for your employees to handle, that or a certain abnormality breaks out because its guidelines conflict with another abnormality's requirements.

But that's strangely the fun of it, because when you restart to the first day, certain progress doesn't get lost. Sure, your employees and your abnormalities may be lost, but your research progress on abnos, the missions you complete that continue the story for each department and their respective rewards, the EGO Weapons and Suits you get from abnos, they all stay. So you have this slow climb of power, and at certain points, you may not even realize you do. 

You'll know which abnormalities to take with you and which you shouldn't because of conflicts that might arise, or you might even take them on purpose because you want a challenge, or you simply want to watch your employees absolutely decimate them with the new gear you got.

This game can be punishing, but it's rewarding, that triumph you feel when you overcome an obstacle you never managed to hurdle over until now. That's what pulled me into the game, and if this intrigues you, I highly suggest you get the game.

Just be ready to hear the first five notes play again and again until enough employees die and abnos break out.
Speaking of which, this leads me to the next section:

[b]The Music[/b]. It's phenomenal, there's no questions about it. Each warning (there's three) perfectly represents the situation you're in, and the music during cutscenes really sell the atmosphere they're trying to go for. The only thing I have a problem with is the music when there's nothing happening in the game, also known as Neutral 01 to Neutral 04. They are all identical in melody. Actually, it's the exact same song, but the difference between all four neutral sound tracks are the additions of instruments into each one. This can work in its own right, but most of the time, you won't even notice the difference during gameplay until you pay attention to it.

Otherwise, the music is great. Crazy impressive for just 10 people working on the game.

[b]The Story[/b] is great. That's all I can really say about it without going into spoiler territory. It can be pretty surface level at some points, but as you keep progressing, you become entrenched in the Lobotomy Corp's worldbuilding and its religion and [spoiler]stage play[/spoiler] theming. It leaves off a lot of questions to be answered in their sequel game [b]Library of Ruina[/b], and I cannot recommend this game more because of the story.

The background art, the abnormality artwork and the EGO items, they're all really good. They're not pure masterworks, that award goes to Library of Ruina, but for what it is, I like it. [spoiler]There's even a reason later as to why your employees look the way they do in game[/spoiler].

Overall, this game gets a 9/10. This game is absolutely worth its price, and I would have paid more if I could. I hope you enjoy the game as much as I did. Just remember to face the fear so you can build the future.

And one more thing, if this review sells you on getting it: If you find a small bird with a red stomach, a long bird with a scale on its neck and bandaged face, and a big bird with many eyes, let them all escape at once. You'll get something cool out of it.

Just be ready, because there lives a beast lives in the black, dusky forest.

Have you ever painstakingly worked harder and harder, barely scraping by until Day 46, only to quit out to the main menu and redo the tutorial? Just to see if you're doing it right?

Turns out, they lied. The real game wasn't managing the Abnormalities. It was managing the constant deplete in energy, the repeated Ordeals that just get more difficult to predict and adapt, meltdown after meltdown after meltdown, praying something doesn't go wrong. That the Mimic won't just snap one day and eat your innocent Level 5 Employee at only -6 Overload, relapsing the entire 2 Hour Day. That you won't have to deal with the invulnerable worms next dusk. That the Meltdown doesn't target the ONE ABNORMALITY you can't deal with, much less ALL OF THEM. That the tiny white clothed girl doesn't just so happen to wipe out half your facility with a single attack unleashing two of the meanest abnormalities you have under containment, triggering a chain reaction of every other abnormality breaking containment, slaughtering all your employees through proceedingly more intricate methods. What was I talking about again? Right, Red Riding Hood Sucks. Did I mention White and Black are now my least favorite colors? I'm pretty sure the facility layout is based on the rings of hell. I survived undertale with the help of a tree, but everyone else died and the mimic killed me later anyway. Can someone tell me if the Memory Repository takes your Egos away too? Man this plot is kinda confusing.

Anyway, the game is pretty fun. If you're easily drawn into fictional worlds, have a life, and enjoy persevering through un and im possible odds, you'll find that this game is not for you! You will not win, the game won't let you. You'll quit within the first 5 Hours, 10 Hours, 50 Hours, and look back on it as a failure. You'll tell yourself you'll finish it one day, and never will. Even if you do manage to get one ending, you'll never get the others. Even if you get the endings, you'll never get all the abnormalities. Even if you 100% the game, you'll never be satisfied. You failed. Everything was for naught. How do we escape this hell we live in?

Fun Game.

||Edit||
Now that I've doubled my playtime, I've learned the truth. This game isn't hard, it's actually kind of easy. In fact, I'm gonna say it, the game is only hard because the hitboxes for literally everything are terrible. That and you have literally no direction for how your supposed to properly manage the corporation. No, I'm not talking about the Abnormalities, if those guys are giving you trouble, it's either because you don't know how to read or you're bad at the game described as "Managing Abnormalities". What I actually mean by "manage" the corporation is grinding your employees to their max capabilities at every moment of the day, completing the Records Department Research, and his Core Suppression if you're feeling real spicy, then restarting from scratch to construct your own personal army of roided up psychopaths to bonk all your problems away at a moment's notice. Once you understand this absolute truth, you'll realize that Lobotomy Corporation is actually an easy game and the only reason people say it's hard is because the Tutorial is obscure enough you don't know what you're doing half the time, you've no way of telling if the work you're doing is actually training your employees properly unless you download a mod for that, and because the majority of these people are a bunch of pathetic babies who don't understand that to enjoy a game you need to spend the first 80% of the playtime grinding at 2 am hating yourself and everything around you. Essentially, if you have less than 30 Hours in this game, your opinion is irrelevant, and you need to get off the computer grandpa. Yes, I understand you need to feed your family, but this game has a very deep and complex narrative that absolutely requires the 100 Hours of filler inbetween it all and you need to suffer through every second of it. Anyway, just like most people recommend, if the game is that hard for you, just mod it. There's a very handy dandy guide here on steam that is actually quite simple and concise to the point in which you'll only spend about 10 Minutes setting it up. Of course, it won't help you, it will only make the process much less frustrating. Just remember, if you use the Super Agents Mod, you better lock your windows because oh boy do I feel abnormal tonight. If I'm being at all serious, if the ending for the game wasn't so painstakingly difficult to reach, I probably would've capped my playtime out at 70 Hours, but man do I love jumping through hoops. You should do it too! Ignore the flames and angry man whipping your behind, that's just a feature. Anyway, I'm shooting for around 160 Hours, after that, I'm gonna assume I've absorbed everything this game has to offer, because if there's a Secret Ending D, it probably wasn't worth the extra 40 Hour Grind anyway. I'll just look the ending up on Youtube.

One of the worst games I've played in a long time. Textbook example of how not to make a tutorial. I ended up skipping the later parts because it took so long. The UI is pretty, but not very intuitive and super inefficient. The game as I understand is also translated to english, and that is very obvious when playing it, as the words used are often very weird and make little sense. 

The writing itself is infuriatingly bad. After spending way too long in the tutorial just reading, I have to read super awkward dialogue from an AI which describes how it looks in great detail, which I can obviously just see by looking at the picture. And this kind of pointless waste of time reading continues as I'm told how to drink champagne from a glass. It is also filled with logical inconsistencies that makes you wonder if the translation is super off. 

The gameplay itself consists of you gambling on which colour you think a certain abnomarlity wants. My first attempt I guessed the wrong colour and instantly lost the game without being able to do anything about it. The description of the game was not lying when it said "and watch as it unfolds", as it seems you cannot actually influence what is happening at all. You can just watch your guys die slowly. Thankfully the game lets you reset the day so I could gamble on another colour, which was correct that time. Once you know the correct colour for the abnormality, then you basically just tell your guy to go in there and do that colour, wait 30 seconds and do it again until the day is complete. I managed to complete 4 days of this exact gameplay with 0 new mechanics opening up or anything before I just could not get myself to play anymore. 

If I were to guess, then the interesting part of this game is the SCP-like descriptions of the anomalies. Maybe I was just unlucky, but all 3 of those I got were incredibly uninteresting. One of them was literally just a dog, with a page of text explaining that the dog is cute. The other had 2 shrimps wearing pants next to a vending machine. Not sure what the deal with the shrimps were, but the text described 3 different colours of grape soda that you could get from the vending machine, with 3 different ways to phrase that they give you energy, making it feel like I'm wasting my time reading nothing once again.  The third one was almost interesting. The lore was that it gained energy from having sins confessed to it. The description describes 3 levels of sins. Level 1 being a harmful lie, and level 3 being a horrible sin you'd tell no one and bring with you to your grave. That piqued my interest, but as the level 3 sin was explained, it turned out to be a guy who dressed up as a deer in a forest with a group of friends. Apparently the writers think that dressing up as a deer is so horribly sinful that you'd never tell anyone about it (Except the friends they did it with???). 

I do not understand what anyone could get out of this game, unless the writing is leagues better in its original language and you can read that. If you can't, then I'd advise you save your money and time

Lob Corp is a buggy, poor optimised mess that is literally designed to have you throw your head against a wall again and again, working things out by trial and error until you get a good enough outcome. The real challenge of the game, however, comes in the late game where the bulk of the gameplay is micromanaging your units so they don't get shredded.
It is messy, it is aggravating. And at it's worst when the attempts at a day get long enough to surpass an hour of playtime, you'll want to pull your hair out when something slips your mind a hour and an half into an attempt and half of your facility instantly dies.
The game is merciless, the gameplay is a little jank, and the later days are completely unforgiving. I don't wish half of the jank in this game on my worst enemy, there's no glory to be had here. I wouldn't even consider most of it too difficult, but walking on eggshells for an hour straight really builds on the pressure and hammers in each and every mistake you make.

That said, it's probably one of my favourite games period, for how gripping the setting is and how well the gameplay is integrated into the plot. The light at the end of the tunnel is absolutely worth it, the question is whether or not you're willing to sink the time into finishing it. If you don't like real-time management games, it isn't for you, but if you're alright with the genre I'd recommend giving it a shot and experiencing it for yourself. Even if you regret it, you'll come out the other side a little more well-rounded than before.

If you do decide to play it, I'd recommend touching up on the 10X speed mod, the performance mod that fixes the memory leak, and the mod that tells you the Ordeals for the day at the beginning on Nexus Mods.

First of all the price is DEFINITELY worth it if you're interested in management simulator type games as my entire playtime is how long it took to beat the game ONE TIME.

I loved the premise of being in a facility having to deal with deadly monsters, suppressing them, and gradually upgrading your employee from working with said monsters. The creativeness and uniqueness each abnormality brings to the table always kept surprising me, even the way every character had such an important role to the story and ending of the game, even when I would be convinced a certain character wasn't very important I was always proven wrong. The game is a ton of trial and error learning and improving and just a single day in the game can take HOURS if you chose an abnormality too difficult to deal with currently. Another interesting thing about this game is that every facility anyone ever makes will be different, there is plenty of different combinations that could be in ones facility for better or for worse. The story is also very amazing and immersive, I feel like i'm actually on a mission to finish what Carmen started and to finally free everybody from the cycle of pain that is the Lobotomy Corporation. As i'm a sucker for lore in games this is where i found most of the enjoyment, being interested in the story also helps deal with how much of a low point the gameplay eventually reaches.

For the things i dislike about this game, the game play will inevitably reach the point where it is essentially spamming working with certain abnormalities just to get your employee's stats up. This is a process that is not fast by any means even on the fastest game speed, you also cannot tell if your employee had their stats increased until you end the day, so you pretty much have to just guess if you worked enough, and sometimes you wont resulting in you having to once again spend more time stat grinding. Another issue that's mainly just a petty one, is that some abnormalities have certain quirks or conditions that can lead straight to instakills since you wont know about them until they happen once or you get lucky, leading to having the restart the day and can be very time consuming if you're decently far into a day. Of course the game is meant to be this way and is part of the difficulty and learning that it requires. Another issue is that the game can definitely lose its charm once you research most of the abnormalities as a big part of the fun i found with the game was discovering and learning about the new abnormalities, instead of just working with the same ones over and over. The gameplay gets pretty repetitive at this point and you will most likely just be more focused on wanting to be finished with the game. 

tl;dr
The game is worth the price if you're looking for a management simulator or you like SCP, the game has great story and is very immersive. The game has plenty of gameplay taking days to finish the game once, the gameplay gets repetitive though later on and the game is very hard.

With that being said I definitely recommend this game, it was a great starting point for Project Moon and for the other games they make or will make in the future. 9/10 game

[i]Lobotomy Corporation[/i] is one of those increasingly common experiences that I could characterize as the 'save scummer's roguelike,' alongside the likes of [i]Fear & Hunger[/i] and [i]Pathologic 2[/i].  These are all games where the actual "skill"/"gameplay" elements are fairly minimal, and instead the player is treated to a gauntlet of Meaningful Choices™, the results of which could determine whether you get stuck in an inescapable fail state 4 hours of wasted gameplay later. In these kinds of games, the player's primary resource economy is accrued [b]knowledge[/b] over repetition: through subsequent and seemingly arbitrary failures, the player is equipped with hundreds of things [i]not[/i] to do, and so is steadily shepherded into making the correct choices to move further and further each time.

Whether this game will vibe with you or not is already probably clear to you based on what kind of gamer you are. I've been increasingly falling out of love with this kind of experience, myself, due to market over-saturation and the growing sense that they're intentional wastes of my time, but I'm still giving [i]Lobotomy Corporation[/i] a thumbs-up of my two available choices since I think it's a bit more transparent about what it demands of you than some of these other 'timewasting failure'-type games.  Consider this "thumbs up" maybe 51% to 55% of a recommendation. 

[h1]What is Lobotomy Corporation?[/h1]

[i]Lobotomy Corporation[/i] is, 'vibe' or 'ethos' aside, a facility management simulator with control elements from a RTS title. The facility in question is the titular Lobotomy Corporation, a sprawling prison for eldritch and supernatural threats. If you're familiar at all with [i]The SCP Project[/i], you should be recognizing the SCP Foundation, and that's not an accident. The game is [b]very[/b] blatantly a [I]SCP[/i] riff, albeit with a heavily -- how do I put this -- "Manhwa Webtoon" presentation, complete with [i]Madoka Magica[/i]-styled magical girl outfits for your little employees and a poorly-translated, jargon-filled misery-porn storyline that takes itself way, way too seriously.

Coming at the game as an American player, the game's overwrought, melodramatic daytime-TV storyline, cutesy art style, and heavy reliance on clicky micromanagement strike as extraordinarily 'Korean,' but this foreignness to my own sensibilities accentuated, rather than detracted, from the core hook of the game: its mysteries.

Every 'day' that passes in [i]Lobotomy Corporation[/i], the player is given a choice of three new monsters to add to their facility. Initially, the player has absolutely no knowledge of the monster, up to and including what they even look like. Employees then have to 'work' with the monsters in your facility, in one of four color-coded interaction options not unlike a Hasbro Bop-It™.  Do this a requisite amount of times to fill up a power meter. When the power meter is filled, the day ends, although if you're feeling risky you may instruct your employees to keep playing Bop-It™ indefinitely afterwards because it will make them progressively better at pressing the associated colored button in the future.

However, each monster has some kind of gimmick, or frequently multiple gimmicks, that will cause them to do terrible things to your little employees if you don't know the warning signs. Most commonly, the monster will break out and start killing people if the wrong Bop-It™ button color is pressed. However, some of these gimmicks are considerably more esoteric, like a monster that gets jealous whenever any other monster is worked with and so you have to keep working with it to mollify it, or a monster that turns the employee working with it hostile and so you need secondary guards around to then pacify that employee.

At first, these will seem completely arbitrary to the player; as arbitrary, indeed, as playing Bop-It™. As the game goes on, though, the player will accrue the knowledge of what to do and what not to do for each monster, while the monster gimmicks get exponentially more complex, and the gradually-increasing dozens of monsters in the facility make every subsequent day more heavily micromanaged. Near the end of a single run of [i]Lobotomy Corporation[/i] (about 60-100 hours, terrifyingly), the game resembles [i]Starcraft[/i] more than [i]Prison Simulator[/i], with the player feverishly hotbuttoning around and rapidly clicking to put out dozens of fires, personally ordering every single one of dozens of employees because there's no automation features.

On the surface, this game is the absolute biggest waste of time I could ever recommend to you. A roguelike-styled game that takes 100 hours to complete? And you restart everything if you lose the facility? TwoDee, are you [i]high[/i]?

Well, the game's Rewind system cleverly salvages this.

[h1]Rewind, Rewind, Rewind[/h1]
Unlike your typical "go back to start with nothing" roguelike game loop, [i]Lobotomy Corporation[/i] gives the player the ability to rewind several days back, a welcome reprieve if you drafted the wrong monster and it wrecked your facility. It also has the standard 'go all the way back to the start' option, although curiously both this and the several-day rewind can be initiated at [b]any[/b] time, and not just after losing the facility.

This is because, although both options remove your monsters and kill off your employees, you [b]keep[/b] everything else: facility upgrades, purchased gear for your employees, and -- most crucially -- knowledge of what each monster does. The game seems designed around the [i]strong[/i] intent that you'll revert the entire save file at least once: several permanent facility upgrades are locked behind devastating boss encounters that can gut your staff and put you in a poor position to go on and win the game, and two of those boss battles late in the game are mutually-exclusive, meaning two playthroughs to the endgame are necessary to obtain both associated facility upgrades.

On the second, and third, and fourth and so on run of [i]Lobotomy Corporation[/i], the player can breeze through the early levels, accruing power freely like how a "New Game Plus" works in most conventional RPGs.  This puts the player in a better position for the endgame, and each subsequent reset allows the player to accrue more stuff, more skills, more [i]monster facts[/i]. It's a deceptively forgiving system for this kind of unforgiving game, giving the player a massive and potentially game-winning consolation prize for the pain of having to restart everything.

This does return us to the biggest problem of [i]Lobotomy Corporation,[/i] though: it really wastes your time. By the time you're factoring progressive restarts into your power-building strategy to eventually take on the crushingly-difficult endgame, you've sunk hundreds of hours into this facility micromanagement sim and are just ready for it to be over. There's light at the end of the tunnel, but it's a hundred miles away, like a speck on  a black horizon.

I didn't have the endurance to finally power through and finish [i]Lobotomy Corporation[/i], even if I enjoyed the process of discovery. Maybe you can incorporate this knowledge into your run, and win where I didn't have the patience to.

[h1]In Conclusion[/h1]
[i]Lobotomy Corporation[/i] is an Extremely Korean facility management roguelike about putting frilly tutus on the [i]SCP Foundation[/i]. It does not respect your time at all, but it at least has the good sense to do some fun things with all of the time it steals, like your clingy friend who likes to drink. Although the gameplay itself is not particularly engaging, the process of discovery is, and the game puts a cushion on its sharp 'losing is fun' design philosophy by giving you some nice perks [i]for[/i] losing.

If a little bit of masochism and a lot of time investment sounds great to you right now, then I can wholeheartedly recommend [i]Lobotomy Corporation[/i].

While normaly i would write an entire essay talking about this game, i'll just say the best things about it.

Not only the characters have lots of backstory, but EVERY SINGLE abnormality have their own story.  Story is 10/10

Now [b]gameplay[/b]. While i normaly don't play any management games (deffinetly not because i'm bad at them), Lobotomy Corporation managed to make every day fun. Now here is a very important part: [u]this game is hard[/u]. This will make lot's of people stop playing, but for me it was a motivation, because nowadays every game seems to be too easy, or just not fun to play. So yeah, keep this in mind.

As the finall [b]tip[/b]: DO NOT GET THE TRAIN. I had a luck that i didn't get it in my first gameplay but i know that it makes most people restart entire runs to day 1. And also be wary of a doctor from old days, because he isn't what he seems to be.

I like this game. I really do. I've nearly gotten one of the game's endings. I'm so close. But before I finish this game, I need to get this off my chest.
This game is a fucking nightmare. It is from hell. This game is an agonizing slog that will take years off your life because you realize 20 hours into your run you cant do the boss fights because of an abnormality you picked 15 hours ago. It is a massive grind. It is soul crushing and agonizing and miserable and stressful and hateful and starts to require an ungodly amount of micromanaging to clear certain threats. The core gameplay loop stops being difficult and becomes EXTREMELY repetitive, especially if you picked up abnormalities like Magic Girl or Ticket to Hell that force you to constantly micromanage some malarkey, and when you're zerging a tough anomaly every healthbar stacks on top of itself and you cant tell if someone's low so you have to get the stacking healthbar mod, it's mandatory, and while you're at it get the detailed statistics mod because "Very High, High, Common, Low, and Very Low" are terrible denominators once you find out that an Abnormality's response to two different interactions can be rated "High" but that's a 15-20% difference, which is EXTREMELY IMPORTANT if you have an abnormality that only wants a very specific result. 
This game is very micro-management heavy, but it is almost completely lacking in any form of meaningful automation tools. That means you have to keep re-assigning agents to abnormalities, you have to keep an agent in every hallway prior to a red dawn ordeal, and while there are abnormalities which punish repeated assignments, the overwhelming majority of abnormalities can safely be spammed with the same approach by the same agent ad nauseum. While WAW and ALEPH abnormalities punish overuse by decreasing success rates, and for some of them it's severe enough to force you to stop using them, but a lot of them can be safely milked for all they're worth, as the Qliphoth meltdown resets their exhaustion. This forces the player to utilize a wide array of abnormalities to consistently make quota, because with each meltdown 
the game gives you a chance for a free go at one of your most lucrative abnormalities, or a forced interaction with an abnormality that poses a significant risk to your agents or the facility as a whole. Unfortunately, with the game's meta progression, the Qliphoth meltdown gets nerfed significantly, to the point where it removes a lot of the fun decision making, and it also drags out each day's run time because you're not getting the surplus of energy that meltdowns trigger.
Meeting the quota is never a struggle. the real challenge is when the game wants you to make it to a certain level of Qliphoth meltdown, with two of the game's quests involving you taking on a midnight ordeal, which are very challenging fights that are very punishing, that if you screw up bad enough can send you back 20-30 minutes. 
But I really like this game. It's really, really compelling. The setting is really unique, despite wearing its inspirations on its sleeve, and the worldbuilding is always incredibly intriguing and makes you desperate for the rare glimpses you get into the outside world as you unravel a horrifying, Sisyphean loop that is sustained by blood and tears. It's also the only SCP management type game I can think of, and for all of the problems I have with this game, it has provided me with an experience completely unlike any other game I've played, for better and for worse. I am very excited to be able to move on to the rest of Project Moon's catalog because they all take place in the same world, and I'm desperate to dive more into this setting, but I want them to one day try this SCP management formula again, because there are so many different directions to take this concept, there are so many improvements to be made, there could be a passionate modding scene if there was a toolkit available to this fanbase, I really want to one day see a redo of this game, with all of the budget and experience that Project Moon has gained on full display.

I really wanted to like this game, and I've tried restarting my playthrough multiple times. The characters and many of the anomalies are very interesting. However, I was constantly frustrated by needing to figure out each anomaly through trial and error and replaying each day until I could get through the day without any employees dying. I felt like I was save hacking, but there didn't seem to be any better alternative.

The anomalies should have more meaningful clues or start with enough context that I don't need to just restart the day enough times to try all the work+agent combinations until something works. Some anomalies were just annoying. I had one that needed to be interacted with every two minutes or it would kill random people. I found dealing with such things to feel more like a chore than meaningful interactions.

The straw that broke the camel's back for me was an anomaly I got on day 21. It looked like a gray box with circular saws for hands. Nothing I tried would generate any energy boxes, so I couldn't get any clues to how to work with it. It just escaped every time I worked with it for every work type, and I had a level 5 agent working with it. Maybe there's some magical combination of stats I need to work with it, but I don't want to keep restarting my day until I get the lucky combination...

Since I've finished this game after many, many hours of CBT, I can finally write a review about it.

First off, this (hard as ♥♥♥♥) game is a madhouse simulator. You're basically trying to farm energy from a bunch of psychotic monsters called abnormalities (like SCPs) that are about as stable as my last relationship and just like exes - unpredictable and dangerous. All abno's can ruin your life if you don't pay attention, each of them having their own risk level and a set of (initially hidden) rules or guidelines that you are asked to follow to make sure they don't escape and/or kill your personnel. Later on, any 'accidents' in your facility can lead to a chain reaction of death and decay which will force you to restart the day (sometimes causing you to waste 20-40 minutes :D). Btw, for the true ending you'll have to restart YOUR ENTIRE RUN once or more since it requires you to have researched ALL abnormalities! ALSO, RNG CAN BE A ♥♥♥♥♥.

This game is a real ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ excercise in patience, and frankly I would not recommend anyone play it. BUT, if you do decide to go through all the pain and hardship... you'll find yourself strangely rewarded. The story is great and is surprisingly deep and intricate. Every abnormality feels unique, and seeing your facility grow in size and complexity over time feels like you're always progressing. The music goes mega hard. There are mods out there that either fix bugs, add some QoL, new abnormalities and armour/weapons, etc.

In the end, LC isn't just about surviving through all the days; it's about embracing the insanity that goes with it. It's a rollercoaster ride through a nightmare that you (eventually) can't help but enjoy. It's stressful, it's overwhelming, but damn, it's satisfying.

Although I'm sad that it ended, it was worth it.

If you're reading this, you likely already know what you're getting into, but in case you don't, well...

Lobotomy Corporation is a game about failure. You WILL fail. Repeatedly. You will have to do days over and over again. Sometimes even weeks over again. And, eventually, most people will need to restart from day 1. 
But, that's fine. This game isn't exactly fair. But, it's still pretty fun, if you like to manage stuff.

With all that out of the way, now I'd like to discuss the mechanics, story, art, and other things like that.
The actual mechanics of the game are pretty simple - Click on work to do. Find out if it's good, or not, learn about that thing, repeat. Occasionally, die, or kill things by sending people after it. Pretty simple, but alot of trial and error, and alot of repetition.
The story is pretty nice - I've not finished the actual "true ending" yet, but I know of its existence. I don't want to touch on it too much, as it's very spoiler heavy, but I think it's a neat world, and the other games in the series expand on it.
Personally, I love the artwork in this game. I love how it is contrasted with the darker tone of the game, as well as the violent deaths your agents will be having. I also quite enjoy the sections in the game where the art changes to be more realistic, rather than cartoon like. Overall, I think it's good.
The balance is pretty bad, both in and out of the players favor. Some abnormalities feel way too strong for their class, while others feel basically like a non-issue for how dangerous they are considered. But, at the same time, the magic missile rifle exists, and it really funny. But, being more serious, basically any abnormality that deals pale damage early in the game is quite strong, and should be avoided, at least until you get a few high level employees (Judgement bird destroyed me when I first got it, and since then I've been scared of Pale damage).
Some abnormalities are also not difficult, but rather annoying, such as Plague doctor, as it constantly moves around. As far as I'm aware, there's only one other abnormality that moves around, however. Don't touch me also exists, and should be interacted with frequently, as it's incredibly funny.

All in all, if you've read all that, I take it you're already knowledgeable enough, or have a decent enough interest in this game. In either case, best of luck, managers. You've got some PE boxes to generate.

This game is extremely varying in its enjoyability ranging from being pretty fun micromanagement to straight up masochistic, mainly due to the abnormalities you get. A few of the final days are complete garbage regardless of what you have, though. I think generally you'll have more fun than not, but when you get a bad pick it may ruin your entire run alongside your mood (for a bit). I had to do a 2nd run in order to beat the game and when I originally was forced to restart my original one, it was due to the fact that I had about one of the worst facilities you could have [b]AND THEN[/b] got a specific abnormality that made it impossible for me to beat the day I was on. In case you're curious, it was [spoiler]WhiteNight on day 16 alongside Army in Black which I got the day before; I was unable to manage either of them.[/spoiler] Anyway, I obviously wasn't very happy. In fact, I dropped this game for about a week after that because my interest in it temporarily dropped to 0 after getting fucked over that much. 

However, my 2nd run is the reason why I still recommend this game regardless. I had a [b]TON[/b] more fun with it compared to my previous one, partially due to how I decided to treat abnormality picking. I streamed the game to friends (who have played the game themselves) mainly for fun, and whenever it came time to pick an abnormality I asked them which ones to avoid choosing, just in case there happened to be any at all. Then, I selected whichever one seemed the most interesting to me from the vague descriptions in-game out of the options I had left (unless I could only pick 1 of course lol). As for [spoiler]the tool abnormalities[/spoiler], I searched up what they did and picked for myself. That's just how I chose to enjoy the game and while I don't think anyone necessarily needs to do something like this to have fun, it really helps if you are afraid of getting unlucky, [b]ESPECIALLY[/b] if it has happened before to you like in my case. Also, I would recommend to anyone playing the game for the first time to immediately download the "more detailed info" mod at the very least. It has QoL changes that very much should be in the vanilla game.

With all that aside, Lobotomy Corporation is worth a shot. It's definitely one of those games that clearly isn't for some people, but I still think anyone should try it out because it has a lot of charm to it that may interest you enough to like the game, even if you aren't normally into micromanagement games of its type. In my opinion, if you aren't having fun by at most day 15, then it's likely not for you. If you are into it though, good luck. This is definitely not an easy game. I almost wanted to quit a few times and just watch the rest of the story on YouTube because some of these days were not very fun at all (only a few, but they SUCK).

To date, Lobotomy Corporation is the first game I've ever played to have:

-given me multiple lesbian panic attacks
-given me multiple ACTUAL panic attacks
-has made me write entire essays worth of contingencies, strategies, and game plans for a single ingame day
-has repeatedly sucker punched me after i dare think the thought "Surely it can't get worse than this"
-has made me laugh, cry, and stare blankly at my screen in terror and concern
-has kept me up at night way more times than i care to admit

Storywise, it's one of the best games I've ever played for the characterization and worldbuilding alone, but in terms of gameplay it's a spaghetticoded laggy nightmare. I would not recommend playing it without casual and optimization mods, as the second half of the game can become extremely grindy and punishing (and the memory leaks tend to make certain missions extremely aggravating.)

Also, don't try to 100% the Seed of Light in your very first blind run. Not even out of spite. I've lost so much of my lifespan to this game due to my own hubris and I'd never wish it upon my worst enemy. Cool monsters, though!

You got these weird korean scps you need to play simon says with to gather energy and unlock their information, if they escape you gather all your little dudes and beat the living soul out of the monsters. Just watch a funny lobotomy video on youtube and move on. This is not the SCP game you are looking for. This is an "experience" game. The experience being grinding and suffering through a clunky awful game for 100+ hours and that's the point of the game kinda.

good

Lobotomy Corporation is a management game in which you must send your employees to work with "abnormalities", which can be not just monsters, but also strange beings, objects or even phenomena. Working with them generates energy, and your goal is to meet a daily energy quota to finish a day and advance to the next.

The game's strongest aspect is its very unique atmosphere. There's a very wide variety of bizarre entities, ranging all the way from the weird and funny to the incomprehensible and nightmarish, each one with its own lore that you gradually unlock as you work with them. The game has a very mysterious and ominous vibe to it, and an intriguing story that'll always keep you wondering what's next. On top of that, the soundtrack is also great; there aren't many songs overall, but those that the game does have are quite memorable and fit the dark, bizarre atmosphere very well.

Each abnormality is unique and has its own set of guidelines that you'll slowly uncover as you work with it, and you'll learn the most effective ways to deal with each abormality, and how to avoid your employees dying a horrible (perma)death when working with them. However, the game lets you retry each day as many times as you want, so you have an infinite supply of time to figure things out and master the game.

As you work with abnormalities, you also unlock extra equipment for your employees: first there's armor that not just helps protect them when an abnormality breaches and must be suppressed, but it also protects them during the work itself, as the simple act of working with an abnormality already deals damage. Second, there are weapons that help you suppress breaching abnormalities and other enemies that occasionally appear. Third, there are "gifts", little items that give each employee a small bonus in certain stats. Therefore, the game encourages you to work with all abnormalities and unlock all equipment associated with them. However, you need to be careful, because, If an employee dies, you lose their equipment and must get it again.

Due to its high difficulty, the game has some systems that help you grow stronger and more prepared for the endgame. Namely, if you restart the story mode, you actually keep all the equipment you got, and also all the information you've gathered on abnormalities, as well as any general upgrades you've unlocked. Therefore, it's a good idea to occasionally restart the game because you'll be stronger each time, and it never feels like grinding, because there are so many different abnormalities to discover, and it's impossible to see all of them in a single run. So every new restart feels fresh and fun, especially as you become more experienced and manage to beat the first few days more easily.

All in all, Lobotomy Corporation is a very unique game with an amazing atmosphere and engaging gameplay, and it presents you with a tough but fun and rewarding challenge. It'll pull you into its bizarre, intriguing world and keep you coming back to learn more and master it.

a high quality game with such a steep difficulty curve that you will likely be barely able to get past day 7 on your first attempt. out of 50. however, as a wise man once said, adapt, and overcome. if you are looking for a easygoing and slow game, first of all, why are you looking at a project moon game, and second, this is definitely not for you. but if you want difficulty, suffering, the level of rage where you want to grab a sledgehammer and absolutely DESTROY your computer, this may be the right game for you. also, just a few warnings: 
1. if i didn't make it clear already, this game is HARD
2. clearing every mission of a department is helpful, but also will produce a new challenge  later on unless you are already past the point i'm referring to when i say "later on" (i cant remember which day)
3. if multiple abnormalities seem to share a common theme, it probably means they affect each other or have a special effect when you have all of them (i'm talking about you "birds" (also yeah watch out for the birds. and unless you want to do a memory repository, don't let all 3 escape at once))
4.employees are super easy to kill so make sure you stock up.
5. some work types will have a special effect when its used on a certain abnormality, and its usually a negative effect. so yeah watch out.

anyways i hope you enjoyed this review of Lobotomy Corporation. the game that will make you want to actually get a lobotomy due to the suffering this game causes

edit: Im not really good with making serious reviews but Ill try just this once for this game. 

Despite everything it made me went through, this game is one of my favorites. The days may be rough and challenging but each time I got access to a piece of the lore by completing them to figure out what is going on in this place, I felt pretty good. Mostly everything included in the game is canon to the universe,the ordeals forshadow the future, the abnormalities are all unique with their own cool designs and mechanics that will make you either love them or hate them. This game also have a banger responsive ost when things dont go your way. Its a management game and things will go south pretty quickly if you dont pay attention to the abnormalities in your facility. Every choice you will make is going to be bad and thats on you, Its how you weight them with your experiences through the loops that will make you a better manager.

Personally what I love the most is that the whole point of the game is trying to make things right. As you continue your grind toward the end of the game and develop each departements to get to the next layer, you get to learn more about the sephiraths. They are in a way your assistants as well as being your tormentors. Their traumas and guilt will be redirected toward you and you will have to overcome them in special events that you can trigger when you feel ready for it called : core suppresions. They can range from pretty fun once you get the gist of it to extremely painful but despite that really enjoy the sort of bond that you can make with them as they finally come to their own realization and change their point of view to hope toward another future.

Even though all of this may sound great its a pretty hard game to recommend. All of project moon games have a difficulty spike and this one will test your patience as you will make mistakes because of your lack of knowledge. You will have to restart either the day, the facility or memory rep a lot of times to make it through the end. For that I recommend using mods to better the quality of life like chesed fixed if you are able to make it to that departement, perma agent but mostly the one that allows you to see the stats percentage of each work types (i always forget that mod name sorry). It wont spare you from the suffering that this game brings but it should at least alleviate the pain a little bit. After all this facility is your own prison and you will have to discover the point of all of this by yourself(or with the wiki if you dont feel like it lol).

I recommend that you get this game on sale, you may like it, you may hate it or perhaps you may persevere and come to love it. I wish that you give this game a chance as well as other ones. Project moon are really great with their story telling and I only wish that you enjoy their universe as much as their fan do.

With this i wish you all best of luck if you do pick it up.
(if i made grammar mistakes i apologize ive been up for more than 24 hours)

CW/TW-- Discussion of [spoiler]  Suicide, Self harm, Drug addiction [/spoiler]

This hidden gem offers a unique and interesting world and gameplay that kept me invested enough to do a full playthrough despite the game's steep learning curve and difficulty. 

For pros, i would say that the visual style, gameplay loop, horror elements and interesting post-apocalyptic world were very fun and kept me very engaged. The game is very SCP containment breach meets management sim, which is something i haven't seen done  before. 

That being said, there are definitely some real negative things about the game.
The most striking thing to me was the lack of trigger warnings for the shock content in the game. To be very frank, I would not recommend playing this game if you are sensitive to topics of [spoiler] Suicide and Self harm. [/spoiler] The way that the game handles these topics is very insensitive and poorly handled. [spoiler] Suicide [/spoiler] is a massive focus of the game's story and is shown in graphic detail in several different ways- even in the gameplay itself. There are also items in game that make very insensitive remarks to [spoiler] self harm, [/spoiler] which made me very uncomfortable. 

This game features many different types of horror in the stories of it's various monsters- from slasher-type monsters to purely psychological-horror inspired entities- but for every unique, interesting and familiar take on horror one might also find something done just for shock value, which i think takes away from the experience. If you love shock horror and don't care about the game's insensitive handling of topics of mental health, [spoiler] suicide, self harm and drug addiction [/spoiler] (perhaps if those things just don't bother you), i would recommend the game. 

Another quick thing to mention is that i would not recommend this game at all if you are looking for a casual gameplay experience. This game is incredibly difficult- and, without the heavy use of a wiki, will result in many, MANY failed runs before you will likely be able to get too far. The difficulty spike as you progress is a straight-up vertical wall, and the game does not hand-hold you with tutorials. It can be very difficult to understand and learn if you haven't played before. 

Overall, I would recommend Lobotomy corporation, but please remember to be safe when dealing with the  triggering topics and content of the game, as i do not believe the game properly warns the viewer of the sensitive topics that it fumbles around with constantly, and could cause significant discomfort in the wrong person.

[h1] This review contains no-spoilers, Tl;Dr at the bottom [/h1] 

Lobotomy Corporation is one of the most fun games i have ever played, its also one of the hardest, that "difficult" tag is not lying during your first play through you WILL have to restart the week, that being you lost a lot of employees or you got an abnormality that is too difficult to contain, your first play through will have at least one restart (and that's where i find some of the charm of this game), so this is a basic review for someone who has stubble onto this hidden gem of a game

[h1] Whats the premise of the game? [/h1]

This is a Tycoon/manger simulator that is based of the SCP foundation, each day you get a new abnormality, varying in difficulty, to competed a day you need to work on abnormality (4 types of work, some are better than others on certain abnormality) to get Enough E-box to pass the day, using said E-box can be researched to discover more about the abnormality and its habits or use to acquire armour and weapons, with some armour/weapons being able to deal more damage/take more damage while doing less/Being vulnerable to other, there are several other cogs that make this game work that im not getting into, if you want a new-player guide/you are expecting a new player guide, this isn't it (i might do one if this review goes well)

[h1] Whats the Story of the game? [/h1]

(Without getting into spoiler territory) a basic intro into this game, you are the new manager of lobotomy corporation, a company that uses AIs and employees to farm Abnormalitys for their energy, your new job is to insure nothing goes to shit, i could explain more but this is a story that's better if you don't know anything going into it

[h1] Should i get it? (rating) [/h1]

Absolutely, although i "complain" in the beginning that the game is rage inducing, pretty much all of the time it was your fault, you didn't read something correctly, you didn't suppress that threat immediately, you were lazy and didn't check all the abnormalitys for danger and for that and

[*] a great sound track

[*] Amazing visuals

[*] A good game play loop

[*] Creative and unique designs

[*] and unique remixes of already created Characters (fairy tales)

Lobotomy Corporation is a 9/10, 

Tl;Dr: Lobotomy corporation is a very fun but rage inducing game that i think alot people should try

UPDATE:
The more I play Lobotomy Corporation, the more I hate it. I don't think it's fun that the fanbase wants everyone to look up the wikipedia. That takes me out of the game. I like to [i]discover[/i] how things work, but everything here just feels cheap, unfinished, and full of padding.
Additionally, I feel like this game is wasting my time. You are encouraged to play perfectly, or reset days, and there are plenty of possibilities that you can get stuck rerolling the dice on whether something dangerous is going to break out and kill everyone, the further you go. If you don't play to an A or S rating, you WILL get stuck, eventually. Plus, the vague epitaphs of the SCPs you unlock are rarely clear on what danger grade they are. You can't even see it until you unlock enough information on them, which is only available after working with them, which is only available after many resets of trial and error. This is [i]why[/i] fans direct newcomers to the wiki, but it's just bad design.
I've seen a post in the forum complaining how the game is too easy, and they're on Day 19. 
First off, the more SCPs you get, the more likely you'll get harder ones.
Secondly, I got to Day 17, and have at least two world ending difficulty SCPs in my facility that make it nearly impossible to manage. At this point, I'd have an easier time if I restarted to Day 1, but again, that's just not fun. The story wouldn't change, considering that it's a visual novel narrative, unlocked by progressing missions for each department.
Yeah, definite thumbs down. As cool as the concept is, and as much as it hurts to say this, Lobotomy Corporation is just a bad game.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
I'd give this a mixed button if it existed.
I want to give this game a thumbs up, but its "Gotcha!" mechanics piss me off. There'll be a lot of stuff you can only do through trial and error, and while some of that is fine, there's so much of the game that is pure trial and error. The problem is, when all is going well, the end of the day goes to hell, where you had no warning on what was about to happen. This forces you to restart entire game days, or lose your items and advantage for future runs. If employee deaths were less punishing, this wouldn't be so bad, and further encourage exploration without resetting the day. However, Lobotomy Corporation encourages resets. Lame.
Some elements of the UI are cumbersome. There's unnecessary headache.
All this said, the story is great so far. The concept is interesting. I just think the execution of gameplay is sub-par.
[strike]Additionally, this game does not save after every day, so you can't just play it in short sessions. You have to put an hour or two of your time in every game, or leave the game open.[/strike]
IMPORTANT: Sometimes the save system works, and sometimes it doesn't. It might be more consistent by going back to the menu at the beginning of a day. After you "Begin Management", Reset the Day, then Go Back to the Menu.

Originally, I thought I was going to dislike this game, and truthfully, I did! However, after progressing further in the game, I realized: "Holy moly wait this game is actually so good"

It has the perfect amount of lore to keep you interested and keep you progressing through days, the perfect amount of gameplay - both strategically and difficulty wise - and learning all these new Abnormalities and what they do is a great feeling. Sitting there with the game paused for minutes on end, just thinking of what to do in order for your Agents to not die a brutal death is a wonderful feeling, and the stress gained? It's such a great feeling as well.

Overall, while Lobotomy Corp may not be for everyone, it's definitely a game worth checking out if you're a fan of the SCP Foundation, or just a fan of strategic games like Civilization or Fallout Shelter.

What sells me on this game the most is how amazingly unique and different it is.

So... it turns out that the Koreans really love SCP stuff. Like, there's even a Korean comic about SCPs. It's all the rage around artist types, and thus this game came to be.

This game is a strategy game visual novel management sim.... a heck of a bunch of genres to deal with, and oh goodness does it do them right. At first, it seems to be a visual novel mixed with a type of management story and the sim gameplay to go along with that fictional setup, but as the game continues, it slowly evolves into a real time strategy game with RPG elements within the architecture of a simulation game and a visual novel. This is because you are dealing with more, things get tougher, and you learn to use strategy to balance your teams to deal with threats, which vary and can ruin your day.

I was suggested this game by a guy on the internet. In poor English described it as Korean Evangelion. If this sounds like the start of a good horror story, that is because it is, because this is actually inspired by SCP stuff rather than Evangelion, although they both use the same references to some awesome effect. This game is a messed up good time and partial bad time. It is actually far less horror than I thought, and am pleased to know such.

How it plays? It is a point and click sim game inspired by SCP stuff. You farm monsters and abominations for their energy and stuff. It is kinda crazy and I love it thus far. Very point and click, and the menus to a bit to get used to, but I love this game. However, as I said at the beginning, this is also much a strategy game with great complexity.

The big problem though is that it is tedious and it DRAGS. The random assortments of creatures you deal with, the grind of unlocking things, and the forced replays only to get the ending are painful, and getting the true ending is even more absurdly difficult, only for it to bait you with a sequel.

I would recommend this game to anyone. It broke me. It rebuilt me. I'm ashamed of what I became when I played this game, yet, never before have I gained such power. NO ONE is meant to play the game the way I played it. I should have reset to day one the moment I got D-01-106 at day 12, as noon or dusk events would inevitably kill clerks which would inevitably release the bitch who would then kill everyone. We were too weak then to fight back.

And, and yet, somehow, I persisted. I ascended. I rushed execution bullets. Starting waiting for clerks to overlap so I could take out 3 or so at once. Would spend the first few qliphoth levels spamming bullets just so I could clear out all the clerks. Once they were gone, then the true day could begin. By day 35 I had trauma-bonded with my nuggets and refused to let any of them die, and we were past fearing what a mere army could do. Memory reposited more times I could count in order to 100% the abno records without having to do a full reset, and to do the "boss" missions without losing an employee. It was madness. It was unhealthy. I should have just let them all die.

What did I do it for? What hollow satisfaction? When I spent two hours in the winning attempt battling T-03-46 with a single surviving employee I knew in my heart that once this challenge was conquered there was nothing left but to reposit one last time and then finally take on the end game. By god, I did it. But I was empty. What left did I have to live for?  My friend told me there was a sequel. With tears in my eyes, I realised maybe it didn't have to be the end.

But then, as I examined the steam store page, horror filled me, greater than hearing the popping buzz of a bee or the drop of second trumpet ever could, greater than hearing "I love you" repeating in an eerie childish timbre.

[h1]Every abnormality has a weakness. The wise manager trains for what they will face.[/h1]
Lobotomy Corporation takes places in a parapsychology research company responsible for supplying energy to a metropolis called The City. You are the manager of the aforementioned facility and your responsibility is the training of your agents and ensuring the production of energy. The energy, denoted 'Enkephalin/PE boxes', results from the interaction between your agents and eldritch creatures called abnormalities. Each abnormality has a work preference, and it is your job to discover their preferences to facilitate the efficient energy flow.

[h2]Some may fall, but their knowledge lives on.[/h2]
One of the essential parts of the LobCorp is that your agents are disposable. Your main progression comes from the gear you acquire from the abnormalities you work with and the missions you complete that are given to you from your subordinates. Another part of the game comes from training your agents, your agents gains stats depending on the danger level of the abnormality, the damage they receive and how successful their work is(how many PE boxed they produce). You are going to be resetting a lot, which also resets the stats of your agents, so it takes less priority until you collect enough gear and complete the missions.

Lobotomy Corporation is a long-winded journey that rewards you with great lore that piques your interest, including very memorable characters that are sure to leave a mark on you. It took me about 143 hours to completely finish the game in a blind playthrough, and despite the hardships that I had to face I can say with the confidence that every single minute of my playtime was worth it.

I genuinely really wanted to like this game as a big fan of SCP-style stuff, and I do think this game's story and lore is its greatest strength. If that's all that you're looking for, and you can stomach the grindy aspects of Lobotomy Corp, then I would absolutely recommend this game to you.

For me though, the grindiness just isn't to my taste. The game isn't mechanically diverse or complex enough to really differentiate days from each other in the same way that other roguelikes like Binding of Isaac do, and the management aspect of the game becomes very simple once you've trial and error'ed your way through the different monsters' traits.  

It ends up being very repetitive, especially given how long days end up getting near the end. There are various boss fights and random combat events to spice up each day, but the combat feels too clunky for those to be enjoyable, at least for me.

A lot of this is personal preference however, and ultimately I don't hate the game. If Steam had a better rating system, I would probably rate this game as mixed, or 3/5.

This game is very stressful. But that's part of what makes it so good. And if you mess up, its not fun. but thats not necessarily a bad thing.

Its very much about management but not just numbers, you have to memorize each abnormalities info to a T or else you're pretty much ****ed. And that's like, 50 at a time.

Its incredibly hard. But its also really rewarding once you know what you're doing.

The translation especially for the abnormality texts is really off. Its charming, but kind of hard to understand whats going on for quite a few of them, or maybe I'm just illiterate.

And once the energy cap required for day end increases into the hundreds it can get pretty boring, especially on repeat playthroughs which is needed for completion as its a soft-roguelike.

The art style is cute and simple but I kind of wish it was a bit more disturbing or less restrictive for the abnormalities in particular, cause the horror isn't really there for most of them, at least in my opinion.

The story is really interesting and engaging, but it being locked behind tons of incredibly hard challenges is a bit annoying, I can imagine its worse for people who aren't too used to management games or extreme difficulty in general.

Its good, especially for a studios first game. Im pretty excited to play the next installment in the universe. But its a bit exhausting to put dozens of hours into a game like this, but I realize that's my fault, lol.

[h1]All of Project Moon's games have excellent ideas, but poor execution.[/h1]

Lobotomy Corp. and LoR both suffer from extreme mechanic bloat, poor pacing, frustrating mechanics, pointless grinding, and a complete lack of elegance. It really is a shame, because they're also some of the most interesting and creative games that I've ever played.

[h2]Bloated Mechanics[/h2]
There are so many different ideas, it feels like the game is going all over the place. Both games feel absolutely overwhelming when starting out, unless you spend the time to read everything. Usually, this isn't a problem, but both games introduce many mechanics, often without a proper tutorial. There are many mechanics that are one-offs, or entirely redundant. LoR is especially guilty of this, introducing a new Keyword almost every new invitation in the mid-game, and not adding any useful support pages for existing Keywords. Lobotomy Corp isn't free from this either, as the novelty of adding a new anomaly to your facility wears off after you collect enough boxes to fully understand how to manage them (usually before the day even ends).

[h1]Poor Pacing & Pointless Grinding[/h2]
It's no secret that Project Moon games have poor pacing, with sharp difficulty spikes. Again, this usually isn't an issue with most games. I spent 4 hours learning all of Margit's attack patterns in Elden Ring, because I decided to rush through the game as a low level wretch. Even if it was difficult, beating him was immensely rewarding because I could feel myself getting better as time passed. In both Lobotomy Corp. and LoR, most problems can be solved if you spend enough time on it. If you want to play efficiently, both games get boring very quickly. In Lobotomy Corp, there are multiple situations in which you can hard lock yourself into losing the game and you lose about 2 hours of progress because of it. Not only that, but you really have the option to grind for E.G.O gifts and boxes if you want to unlock everything by the next day. I want to be managing my anomalies, not waiting for drops when I know there's no risk involved. Still, this pales in comparison to LoR's book system. Even after multiple revisions, it's still incredibly grindy. The decision to not have all of the pages unlock once you beat an invitation is absolutely awful from a design perspective. The game is already quite long for an indie title, and adding in grinding heavily takes away from the experience. It only serves to slow the gameplay down, so you're not absolutely overwhelmed by the next new crazy mechanic that's just right around the corner. It gets even worse when we get to the bosses. Boss fights can take up to an hour, and you're rewarded with nowhere near the number of books that you need to actually get all of the useful cards that you want. It's a massive grindy time sink for literally no reason. The [spoiler]Purple Tear[/spoiler] pretty much made me quit LoR because of the amount of time I would need to spend grinding in order to beat the next invitations.

[h1]Frustrating Mechanics & Lack of Elegance[/h1]
This is probably my biggest issue with Project Moon's games. The amount of time you spend not playing the game usually exceeds the amount of time you're actually doing stuff. This is a shame, because the stuff that you would be doing if you were just playing the game is usually quite interesting. Having individual decks for all of the Librarians is interesting, until you realise how much time you just spent creating 15 decks so you can beat the next invitation in LoR (of which I can usually beat first try). To a lesser extent, this is also visible in Lobotomy Corp., as every single agent has their own resistances and you need to pay attention what goes where, depending on the abnormalities they're going to be working. If you want to win, it's a whole bunch of reading, and not a lot of playing.

I just want to say that I really love both games. I love the world, I love the music, I love the ideas in both games, but they have so many issues which make it impossible to recommend them. There are so many roadblocks put in place for you to just not enjoy the game, which wouldn't have a harmful effect on the game if they were removed. You're punished by playing optimally, because it just ends up in optimising all of the fun out of the game. It's a known meme that LoR players don't know how to read, but perhaps they're better off that way - they have less to think about, and would rather think it's all decided by dice rolls.

But in all seriousness, you probably won't finish this game and that's okay. Long story short, Lobotomy Corp is an incredibly consistent yet frustrating game of Simon Says. Do exactly this and that, and you'll do great, but if you deviate even a little, forget something, time to start over. 

The game does a fantastic job of layering rule upon rule that you'll need to integrate into your workflow and it's a lot of fun to manage, but it requires 100% of your attention at all times. The challenge is good, but it's a pretty extreme challenge after a certain point and I personally decided to give it up around Day 30 as I was getting to a point where it took me a dozen or more attempts to progress another day. Plot's great, characters are great, absolutely recommend it if you're willing to put in the work.

Lobotomy Corporation is an incredibly unique game: 

I enjoyed every second of the game and is definitely worth your time. It can be very difficult, but, getting past those difficulties feel like a major victory. I didn't expect the game to be so captivating in it's gameplay, music, and story along with the many different abnormalities and problems the game throws at you. I highly recommend this game if you like management + horror elements, and, have a good amount of patience and pain tolerance :D
fun but hard :sob:

Lobotomy Corporation is an anti-capitalist sci-fi horror rougelite + monster management sim. ProjectMoon calls out The Cabin in the Woods as a core inspiration and oh god it shows in such a fun way. The game places you in an underground facility where humans experiment on and extract energy from monsters known as “Abnormalities”. There’s over a hundred funky little freaks each with harrowing backstories and super interesting designs. Each day you choose from 3 monsters to unlock, and you have to figure out how to extract their energy without dying in the process.

The gameplay loop is real good for sure, but I couldn’t actually beat the game. I put 20 hours in and saw that it would apparently take 100 hours to beat, and I’m not that strong-willed lol. I’m not a speedrunner and I’m not the kind of guy who looks at really complex puzzles (like the extra stuff in The Witness) and goes “oh yeah, I’ll make 100%-ing that game my life for the next 4+ months” 😂

But despite the length, I really did enjoy my time with it! I ended up watching the rest of the game on youtube because I haaaad to see how it ended!! The meta story of the game uses Kabbalah and Jewish mysticism in the same way Neon Genesis Evangelion used Christianity as a basis for its crazy apocalyptic world building. Its so creative and engrossing and I wouldn’t shut up about it for at least a month
This game is [i]almost[/i] as punishing as real life.

Review coming from someone who beat the game with the true ending 

Lobotomy Corporation is an incredible concept that is horribly horribly botched in execution. 

There are so many tiny things that pile up to make the experience worse. 
The performance is TERRIBLE
Tons of information is needlessly hidden, forcing you to either repeat the same operations over and over through trial and error or endlessly consult the wiki (I did the latter and am very glad I did)
The balance is all over the place, and is generally very unfair and hits you with a bevy of cheap tricks that aren't communicated to the player well

The good is there though. The story is excellent, the setting is fascinating, the characters are super interesting and get a ton of depth. The soundtrack while limited and repetitive over 100+ hours, is REALLY good, and the setup for the sequel is amazing. 

I can't in good faith recommend playing this game to anyone, but I am very glad that I played it if only because it'll make me enjoy playing Library of Ruina (a good game) a hundred times more
