How to survive anything*/how to become the Taliban (Spoiler Free)

Before you send brave freedom fighters to glorious battle against the infidel (Before you start a bad ordeal or open up the cage of a funny Aleph, or worse)
Purge the infidel from your own land (Kill all clerks with execution bullets)
If thou does not have the righteous tool of allah, and the infidels gather strength from the blood, pray to him (If you don't have execution bullets and a abnormality that escapes after deaths, pray to god and hope you can take the domino flood like bigweld)
Send the weak and vulnerable to sanctum (Send all low level employees into a single elevator)
Gather the mighty and zealous (Gather all high level employees in a different elevator, maybe with one or two scattered around abnos that are at risk of breaking out and would lead to domino flood)
Ensure that the infidel does not grow more powerful as you strike them down (Make sure that they don't absorb/are immune to certain types of damage, split em up into either a seperate strike team or just condemn them to the crying corner where the low levels are)
Send forth the righteous call for Jihad (Send one employee to open the door/start the event)
Engage in prayer to Allah, and he shall grant his protection to smite the foul agents of Shaitan (Bullets pierce your employees, letting you grant a shield to all of them at once if they're stacked together in an elevator)
Ensue in glorious battle using all means for the glory of allah, he has granted us the mighty caverns and mountains as our shield (Use strike force as situation calls, whether that be just slowly clearing the facility department by department, hit and run, or some cheese, elevators let you move to dodge attacks the fastest)
The weak and fragile should not be forgotten, for they shall sow the seeds of allah for tomorrow (Keep an eye on the weak/crying corner if they are at risk, move up/down the elevator to dodge/run as needed)
Allah's mighty Malāk shall come to the aid of the faithful if they only call and serve Allah (Use mercenaries liberally, farming energy is usually rather simple and safe)
Allah shall grant victory to those that eternally fight for his glory (Lobotomy corp is a hard game, and even with a good strategy it could take some tweaking/retries, to get it all right. Patience is required for many of them, never fight face-face unless you have an overwhelming advantage)

*Do not let the infidel sneak and lurk where he shall sow his seed of heresy (If the ordeal/abno teleports around and causes meltdowns, you do have to split up and cast a wide net)
**Those who have not properly done the rites of Allah shall find themselves broken and bleeding with his absence (Actively train your employee's skills, don't end the day as soon as you get the energy required. More boxes = more xp)

This game has drilled a hole into my skull and now lives rent free inside it.

You may mistake this game by it's steam page with a visual novel, it's not. In the review section, players care so much about story and are ready to pick apart single dialogue for hours - but it's not because there's all there is to the game - story dialogues are just a reward, a few lines of story, for going through the daily grind and near impossible challenges. 

The game starts pretty slowly and controls might be awkward at first, but they're actually very, very simple. It's just there probably isn't a game you've played before that's similar to Lobotomy corp and therefore it doesn't feel intuitive, it's not something you've done before. But you get used to it.

Figuring out with abnormalities and meeting energy quota isn't all there is - you can actually continue the day after meeting energy quota and you absolutely should - because you can train your employees that way. You can use LOB points for that, but you will eventually run out of those that way. So, the grind is the optimal way. I'd complain if it weren't the part of the story.

The abnormalities themselves have each their own rules - some apply facility-wide, some apply during working with the abnormality and some - during suppression. Breaking them usually ends up in abnormality escaping or killing employees. Some abnormalities could look similar in behaviour, but there are ones that start breaking the 4th wall and ones that do something you would never expect. There's an abnormality that has a progress bar (it looks like a clock, you'll know when you see it) and it fills up each time an employee works with it. I decided that I don't want to see what happens when it fills up, so I started the day over to reset it. When you see that it did not reset after starting a day over, or starting a week or the game over, you will shit bricks. And you just wait until the clock goes to 12.

The music might sound odd, but Lobotomy Corp absolutely O W N S it (even though not in a legal sense).
There isn't a single time in the game where any other soundtrack would seem more appropriate. Everything just FITS

There are also Sephirot missions. They ARE the story, they unlock new upgrades that make the game easier and you should prioritise doing them first. 
Some missions might look truly (but not the grinding kind) impossible. You might even think that something isn't translated correctly or it's mistyped [spoiler]or the Sephira giving the mission has gone mad[/spoiler], but every mission requires of you exactly what it says. 
But when you actually manage to pull the stunts required of you, you will feel fucking invincible. 
It's as though you are able to do anything now... Until you see the next mission. 
And it goes like that until the very end. 
And it feels totally awesome.

There will be boss fights, too... Just not in a sense they usually are in other games. Let's say that there are gameplay features that you really shouldn't be taking for granted and it's those features that give you an edge against whatever comes your way. 
But could you manage without them?
Boss fights hold a lot of surprises and some really good design. [spoiler]For example you literally cannot win against Malkuth - girl with a notepad, without having a physical notepad yourself. mind == blown. [/spoiler]
They managed to surprise me EVERY TIME, right to the last day. 
And the plot did so even a bit after the last day. 

Speaking of plot, the game manages expectations very, very well. Expectations getting flipped upside down is the most satisfying part. Can't talk about it without getting into spoilers though. I warned you:

You might think that the game is about monsters and that it's the part we have to uncover. 
[spoiler]But it's actually everything else. The story, the characters, the city above and it's troubles.[/spoiler]

You probably think that abnormalities are some alien creatures that ended up here somehow and we need to contain them. 
[spoiler]They're actually more human than anybody in your facility. And we are MAKING them to exploit them later![/spoiler]

[spoiler]You probably think that Angela is plotting something against you or the corporation after playing a few days 
It's MUCH more complicated than that. I don't know what to tell you. Play the game.[/spoiler]

After playing for some time, you will start to think that restarting the day and the memory repository is an awkward implementation of a save game feature. 
[spoiler]You couldn't be more wrong. It's actually an essential part of both the gameplay and the story by design. It brings another layer to the gameplay and explains A LOT story wise when you find it out.[/spoiler]

You might think you're a manager, clueless and fresh to the company and you should do what Sephirot and Angela tell you, like what Malkuth instructs you to do on day 1. 
[spoiler]You're actually A, the founder of the company. And the Sephirot, including Angela, are here against against their will, just because you willed it. And they're waiting expectantly, for you to pull them out of their misery and lead them somewhere.
[/spoiler]

[spoiler]The facility literally turns upside down on day 50. It actually looks like a tree that way. Then it sprouts from the surface and emits light. 
It just ALL MAKES SENSE in the end - the tree of light, the seed, the goddamn cactus on a desk eventually bearing a flower. And it's only one example of many.[/spoiler]

Buy and play Lobotomy Corporation. And I'm not giving you a fucking choice.

Everything insta-kills, it's a matter of time before you go mad with RNG obsession.

Great game, but word of advice: do NOT go in blind. Abuse the wiki. Look up what you're getting before you choose which anomalies to keep. The majority of anomalies are fine, but the ones that are bad are BAD. You will not have a good time if you choose one you aren't equipped to handle. Not to mention, the learning curve is pretty steep, but once you get the hang of it it's hard to put down.

General gameplay advice though, while you're learning the ropes, do NOT use the fast forward tool. It is not your friend. That is the devil whispering in your ear, telling you "it's going so slowly, I should just fastforward while all my guys are heading off to work." Next thing you know, they're all lying dead on the floor and you have to start of the day Again.

[b]This game will bully you with impossible situations.  Restarting from Day 1 is NECESSARY.[/b]

A few things carry over each time: The names/details of abnormalities you've fully studied, and Core Suppressions.  Without spoilers, Core Suppressions are 1 of 9 boss fights that you will challenge on certain in-game days, and these will unlock permanent upgrades and protect a part of your facility from RNG.

Your strategy will be to, in each run, learn as much about different abnormalities as you can, challenge a core suppression, and restart.  The game will get easier and you'll get further into the story, because when you're provided with a list of abnormalities to add to your facility each day, you will know how to handle them and the lethal combinations the game will try to bait you into. 

Very good game and story, but will drive you crazy.  If you are a perfectionist, you will [b]suffer.[/b]  
There is no such thing as a perfect run.  The employees you come to care for and raise will be slaughtered by situations you can't foresee or control.   Like balancing a bunch of spinning dinner plates, once one falls, the rest can and will too. The game drills into you the sense of "acceptable losses", and how you can't save everyone, and doing so otherwise is completely mad.  You will waste senseless amounts of time if you try to save everyone, and you need to learn to swallow your pride and handle the losses you'll face, and recognize when the game is telling you to restart or try a different approach.
DO NOT SUPPRESS SHIT WITH MAGIC BULLET IF ANY OTHER AGENT IS AROUND!

Loved this game when it was released, but the company that made it has betrayed its roots. Don't spend your money; you can probably find a better version of this game somewhere else online for free, without all the problems mentioned below.

Issues: Text and UI are jank, bugs and glitches exist in the game that the devs never bothered to patch up so you need to download mods to fix them, coding is so spaghetti that having certain Abnormalities in your facility by end-game will lag out your PC no matter what your specs are.

These were problems I was willing to overlook for a small indie company with great fan communication and plenty of goodwill to spare, but not in a company that fires its own employees because a bunch of review-bombers told them to.

Even if you do not like the game, i highly advise just doing a little cheating instead of watching a playthrough on youtube and robbing yourself of the experience completely, as the feeling of being the one behind the controls is VERY important to the narrative.

There were once the days I used to look forward for your next games even if they're not the best in terms of bugfixing and optimization, and that I suck at them, just because the writing is good. Those days are kind of lobotover now.

FOR ANYONE HAVING TROUBLE WITH MEMORY LEAK: There is an option within the game which can fix everything as the cost of your in game progress. I have no clue how to make a new review, so I'm editing this one. Despite putting over 70 hours into this game and making careful preparations for every day, my dumb small brain cant seem to fucking remember fairy festival's "fun" little quirk. those green bastards have a higher kill count than every abnormality I have combined. 10/10 would forget again. 

On a serious note, I love this game through hell and back, this game has taught me how expendable your little nuggets are and not to be attached even if they were your first nuggets. I myself would reset if even a single agent died, but as days passed and time went on, I ignored their deaths, I did get very frustrated at myself, but in the end I simply moved on with the day and replaced them quite instantly. The more departments you open, you will inevitably gain more abnormalities and even more employees, that means more things to keep track of and even more of your nuggets will die eventually from either a higher class abnormality breaking out or even from your own fuck ups. In the end, everyone you see in the facility is expendable, able to be replaced easily, you may even find yourself in more frustration from losing the aleph gear the agent had. Obviously this doesn't apply to every manager here, including me, but just because I said all this won't stop me from making sure to ensure the safety and longevity of my little nuggets and I hope my fellow managers will do the same. (except the clerks, for some god forsaken reason they just looooovvvveee to pick a fight with anything and anyone, including world-ending entities that are unable to be logically understood.)

and of course some of you might not want to read all this, ***TL;DR - your little nuggets are the very reason you can sit in your office comfortably so treat them well, but at the end of the day they are expendable and don't feel so down about losing a few of them. Except clerks, those guys hate everything and are also suicidal apparently.

This is an exceptional experience that dares to challenge you in ridiculous ways. It is both frustrating and rewarding to play blind. It will literally destroy your mental and physical health. I've left a positive review, however I really would not recommend playing this game unless you're an experienced gamer without AHDH who is good at optimization and willing to whip out the wiki after a couple days in.

If you're trying to play this game to prepare for Library of Ruina but you're a casual gamer, give it a whirl on sale for 10-20 in-game days but, for your sake, watch a story video on youtube for the rest, or just read a synopsis. The true ending/epilogue is Not possible to do for most gamers for these reasons:
[spoiler]
- There will be Bosses that hard punish you for Pausing the game, which is a fundamental mechanic for not losing your mind keeping track of all the abnormalities you need to keep in check
- You will randomly forget one of the 50 "If you break this rule your Agent simply dies" abnormalities in your massive base
- Each day will get exponentially longer as you have more Agents, more facility levels, more abnormalities, and higher quotas to fulfill, AND there is no save state/quick save for the game so you could for example lose 2+ hours of work for a single day (multiple times) because of one random screw up you forgot about and have to start it all over, with different RNG
- And all this aside, the game is simply just hard. You HAVE to optimize or else you will fall behind. You can start a new run with some things that you've earned but idk, who has that kind of time (a complete run will take you 70-100 hours allegedly)
[/spoiler]

tldr: Wait for sale, go in blind (but open up guides and wiki once you feel mentally stressed), and stop and watch youtube / read a synopsis after you hit a wall. Unless you're a pro gamer without ADHD with months to spare, in which case go nuts. Its a very interesting experience, it just comes at a mental and physical cost irl!

The theme is cool. It's fun to see the monster designs, they make you wonder what they're capable of.

Sadly the gameplay loop is barebones and punishes the player for playing the game without providing any significant decisions to make.

Losing high level characters is basically the fail state of the game, it slows down the progression to a halt and you have to start the day, or the last 5 days over again. 

This game has no such thing as "playing well". Doing everything right means that you don't die and there's no way to gain a sense of momentum. The rewards are passive equipment and stat upgrades. 
You gain nothing special, and when you lose what you have you won't even feel an ounce of regret or sadness, but the stifling obligation to start over.

The arbitrary stat types (Instinct, Sanity, Temperance, Justice) are obscure and have no effect on gameplay or your playing style other than dealing different colors of damage and taking care of different colors of monsters in a rock-paper-scissors way. Being better at something barely changes the way a character plays. The way you approach a creature is nearly always the same. This is a game of 4 categories and lacks any meaningful mechanics.

This is like a base management game without any base building. No planning involved at all.
The combat is as shallow as an idle game minus the fun skills and unique equipment.

The events that happen randomly have no relevance to the creatures you contain in your facility. The monsters that spawn during an event, unlike your monsters, won't give you any information about how you deal with them. So it is not even trial and error but pure luck and confusion at that point.

There isn't any real reason to have multiple monsters other than the fact that the game forces you to do so. Otherwise you can just generate energy from a single one, they're basically cows that you have to milk and all they give you is the same milk. Although each monster visually has very distinctive features, this doesn't reflect into the gameplay. Your characters don't recieve their powers, don't gain experience from taking care of a type of entity. They don't specialize, they mean nothing to the player.

There is really not much point exploring this game. I can't see why you wouldn't just open a wiki page and play it that way. Or you can just read the wiki and skip playing altogether.

In perseverance, there is both agony and triumph. Perseverance is the key to Lobotomy Corporation, in both navigating its gameplay and fulfilling your role in its intricate story.

You've probably already learned this from the other reviews, but to reiterate: this game is [b][u]HARD[/u][/b]. While the first few days may seem like a cakewalk filled with repetitive gameplay, you will soon find yourself entangled in a double-layered web of a quickly thickening plot and an ever-expanding facility containing deadlier monsters. The challenges ramp up significantly as you encounter story-relevant "boss battles" that can push you to the limits of adaptability. This game will slap your carefully planned routine out of your hands and laugh as your employees die horrible deaths as they scramble to suppress monsters that you [u]SWEAR[/u] you were monitoring carefully, but weren't. You will even come to find that certain basic game mechanics that you absolutely took for granted have turned out not to be a right, but a [i]privilege[/i] (here's looking at you, Atziluth residents).

The experience can seem punishing and unforgiving. The roguelite mechanic is integral to progressing past seemingly impossible roadblocks. Whether you activate the "memory repository" and rewind to the beginning of a week, or restart completely from Day 1, your facility and employees will be reverted/wiped, but the gear you have bought and information you have learned will remain intact. Sometimes, the only way to overcome the game's challenges is to reset and return with more experience in mind and better armaments in hand.

Personally, what pushed me to power through all of the trials and tribulations the game has to offer was its intriguing story. With every cutscene, you are left to piece together the past and ruminate on the future lying ahead for everyone involved with the corporation. There is a glimmer of hope hidden underneath all of the chilling, depressing, and forlorn moments in the plot. The way it ties into the gameplay at times does make you feel that you are "facing the fear" to "build the future" (ha ha). Your own experiences managing the facility can also end up as entertaining anecdotes; you will certainly find several in other reviews.

Lobotomy Corporation is certainly not for everyone. It is a game of trial and error, of accepting your failure, and of persevering in search of the light at the end of the tunnel. Those who are not fans of management games may find the basic gameplay loop to be boring. Those who hate trial and error may find the virtually-necessary resetting to be tedious and overly grindy. Those who dislike stories that are vague and metaphorical may find the plot to be overly convoluted, drawn-out, or outright confusing. And anyone can be a victim of the game's programming, which can be... jank at times (memory leaks are a commonly reported issue). For what it's worth, I was able to complete the game with almost no issues, but your mileage may vary.

If you're someone who enjoys glory through struggle as well as management games, then give Lobotomy Corporation a whirl (I recommend going in blind). You will likely quickly come to learn whether you love it or hate it.

This game is great, however, the community is not. At all. 

Since this game is extremely hard, but has a very worthwhile story, the hardcore fans are very purist about it, and will think any modifications to this game is heresy or something. And I'll be honest, playing this game plug and play is simply not fun. You need at least some quality of life mods, bug fixes and the optimization mod to properly enjoy this game. I would also say downloading the 2 mods that speed up the game, after you've gotten the hang of the gameplay, are necessary. But those could be considered cheating.

It's just sad this game is so difficult, and borderline unfair at times, cause it will deter more "Casual" players despite the extremely great story. I do recommend this game, but don't listen to the fan base on the "Correct way to experience this" if you find it too frustrating or slow paced, install mods to speed it up and make it slightly easier to manage.

This game is not an easy game by any means, but every moment of struggle is well worth it. After experiencing this game due to a recommendation from a friend, I can gladly and eagerly affirm the thousands of other reviews to this game that raise this game up in glory. This game really is all about learning lessons, be it from learning the hard way when working with abnormalities or making the hard decisions during the story. Admittedly, I went into this game with my own reservations along with it also being my first management simulation. As I began to play, I was gently introduced into its mechanics without the game forcing all of it on you at once, and because of that, I was quickly put at easy, this of course was aided by the wonderful story that Project Moon carefully and intricately poured into this game. If you do buy this game and find yourself to be at a weird inbetween on whether you enjoy this game or not at the beginning within the first few days, I implore you to hang onto a faint light of hope and continue as I assure you the story is more than worth the effort to enjoy. Good Luck Manager. Face The Fear, and Build The Future.

edit: Okay so after an additional 3 hours I can safely say that, while I definitely understand what the game is going for, it isn't for me. However, it's evident that a lot of love went into this game, and I don't regret buying it. Project Moon is a great example of what happens when an indie team full of genuine passion breaks onto the scene and makes a hit. LobCorp is a wholly unique game that I can't really compare to anything else. Even if you're like me, and you think you won't like the game, PLEASE do pick it up and at least try it. At worst, you can likely refund it and get your money back. You're genuinely doing a disservice to yourself by not trying the game at least once.

I don't know how to put into words how much I like this game. Not saying its my favorite game ever as if I cannot understate that, but I know I loved this game and it's hard to explain...

To start, this game has multiple different layers of gameplay. At Lobotomy Corporation's core, it's a monster management type of game (I don't actually know of any other monster management types of games, but they probably exist?). The main gameplay experience is encountering new types of monsters or anomalous items (Abnormalities), working with them to find out their unique abilities and behaviors, and stopping them from slaughtering everything they come into contact with. 

As everyone has already said, think SCP management game. 

As the game progresses, you will encounter new abnormalities and have to respond to them accordingly while accounting for all of the ones you already have in your facility and any potential ways they can interact with each other. One abnormality may seem completely normal and passive, but then working with a different one may trigger something to happen with or because of the first abnormality for example. It can get complex and quite difficult with the correct collection of abnormalities. 

While dealing with the abnormalities themselves, you will also have to take care of Ordeals, which are scheduled events of enemies invading the facility in ascending difficulty; as well as complete bonus objectives relating to the story's NPCs (the Sephirot/Sephirah). Completing these bonus objectives unlocks optional [spoiler](but required for the true ending)[/spoiler]  challenges to complete as well which will reward you with minor and or major boons for the rest of the playthrough if they are overcome. Some of them are extremely difficult though, and will only get harder as you complete more. 

In summary, you have to research new abnormalities, deal with existing ones, overcome the ordeals, and complete the Sephirah challenges. Well to be fair, all you HAVE to do is generate enough energy each day by working with any and all non-tool abnormalities, but that's not the real experience of the game of course. 

That's putting it plainly though. You will be tested and challenged and quite possibly be put into situations where you cannot realistically win. Good thing though - you can restart from day one and keep most of your progress, including abnormality dissolution and E.G.O. equipment (weapons and armor). The game is hard, possibly the hardest I've played and 100% completed, taking me 171.5 hours and there's only 50 days/levels in the game. 

The abnormality design is really good. I simultaneously was excited for and dreaded each new one all the way until the last. There are sentient and non-sentient (tool) abnormalities, extremely dangerous and mostly passive abnormalities, as well as helpful ones too. 

The story was fine. I didn't pay close enough attention though because it took me 171.5 hours and about 3 and a half "playthroughs" (quotes because they were basically mandatory for 100% completion and not full playthroughs like most games), but from what I gathered it's about a nearly apocalyptic and chaotic world where power and influence seem to mean everything and no line is too far to be crossed. 

The game can get buggy at times and the UI can be difficult to work with but not to a point where it can make things too hard to deal with, just uncomfortable. The game will also get lower and lower FPS as the days go on which will make it harder to control things, but it wasn't unmanageable. 

Soundtrack was good, really good at times, but for the majority I had my own music playing (as you tend to do after so much time). 

Difficulty is optional if you don't really care about 100% completion or the story that much. If you don't care it's pretty normal. If you care about the story it can be QUITE difficult. If you want 100% completion be prepared to spend nearly an hour on each level near the end and have to retry a good amount of things dozens of times. I played pretty much completely blind and without guides so that was just my experience. I honestly wouldn't discredit people if they needed some help coming up with a strategy for some of the challenges in the game and looked some things up, though brute force actually came through for me some times.

Easily one of my favorite games, definitely top 10. Could never have imagined how long it would take or how difficult some of the challenges were going to be 171.5 hours ago.

Upon reading more reviews I should mention that the game's difficulty is not the typical blend of "hard". Some people are going to find that forgetting to press a button every 120 seconds and multiple people dying because of that is not hard but tediously mundane and that's okay. If mechanics such as those turns someone away from the game then it's no one's fault, it's just not something they want to deal with. This game is much more unique than others and not meant for the majority of people and is not relaxing at all, which is the point of reviews and gameplay videos.

(Library of Ruina is the direct sequel to this game btw)

Lobotomy Corporation is a game where you have to research and contain more than 100 entities called "abnormalities" for 50 days. Sounds like hell, right? The difficulty  is rising in geometrical progression and it becomes harder and harder to keep everything under control. I would recommend this game to anyone with a healthy nervous system, otherwise it will be difficult to stay sane. Personally, I enjoy this game. I got baited into playing this game because a friend thought I would love the world that Project Moon had built after seeing it through Limbus Company, parading it as essential to understanding the basics of what is just Korean SCP. He was right, I did like IP a lot better after this game, but I will say full stop that if someone got you into this game cause the PM lore is amazing and you should get into it, get off this steam page and go watch a story recap. This game is not worth only the story if you can't get through the gameplay.

The game is a management sim, and some give it the title of roguelike because of the mechanic to restart to checkpoints or the whole game with your acquired information. You manage monsters with 4 types of work and occasionally they break out. This work is required because the game is divided into days that need an energy quota from that same work each day. Progressively, the quota and the risk of the monsters you handle increases. There's a small equipment system, and that's it. That's the whole game.

This game at face value is all about information. If you look things up, the experience will be spoiled drastically, as the mystery of figuring out what you have to deal with be it monster or otherwise is an exhilarating feeling. However, playing blind is also grueling because you end up throwing bodies to figure out exactly what you have to deal with, or you get blindsided midday and have to reset 30 minutes of progress. People that moan about the difficulty of Project Moon games are exaggerating, but this game isn't easy. The last few hurdles the game puts you through are challenging, and many people get stumped at the last stretch. If you know everything that is contained in your facility, by all means you have every right to handle anything that the game throws at you.

If you don't enjoy RTS games or at least the kind of gameplay that comes with them, don't play this game.
If you don't want to spend hours upon hours retreading days of progress, don't play this game.
If you don't like problem solving or strategizing with the bullshit this game sends your way, don't play this game.
This game is only worth it if you want to personally earn and learn the lore of Lobotomy Corporation.

For that specific reason, this game is definitely worth it, or maybe consider it on sale.
The few gripes I do have:
Replaying days is boring and a waste of time once you get far enough and reset, it's just speedrunning to the end of each day without the action to action planning you might have done the first time around.
The game isn't designed to be beaten in one go, and you should know that before you play.
Things like [spoiler] WhiteNight and Apocalypse Bird [/spoiler] are completely optional and can be missed if a player is ignorant or simply skilled/lucky enough. No clue if there should have been things hinting at them or their consequences.
[spoiler] The fucking idiots that designed the last two departments need to be fired. [/spoiler]

At 279 hours I have officially completed the game in its entirety.

Is this game hard? Yes. It is a game about trying, essentially, to trip up the player. It's a rube-goldberg machine of carefully calculated dick moves. There's an evergrowing list of rules with each abnormality you get: some very simple, others frustratingly complicated, but there is a list for each. For any rule, there is an abnormality with the exact opposite rule: some will punish you on Bad results, others on Bad or Neutral. Some will punish you on [i]only[/i] Neutral, some on Good or Bad results. The game will generously keep track of these rules as you discover them, but you are drawn endlessly into the web. You will get comfortable with these rules in time, but just as you get comfortable the game will begin to alter the deal, and your prayers that it not be altered further will fall on deaf ears. "Is it hard?" You know in being a Korean game it reminds me a lot of Starcraft and the Korean fascination with that: Starcraft is desperately hard, but if you know what to do, and can perfectly execute it, it's easy. If you can't, well, you'll endure. Restarting and Resetting are major game mechanics without which the game cannot actually be completed (literally it is not possible to complete the game in one run without at least one memory reset).

Is it interesting? [i]Desperately.[/i] The story told by Lobotomy Corporation is one I very much enjoy and one that draws you, the player, in as the participate. There aren't choices to make though; rather, the only choices are the ones you come up with to meet the challenges. For the game weaves the story and the difficulty together, as you, the Manager of this strange facility, desperately try to comprehend what it is that you are doing here and why.

You will come to love your agents, you will suit them up in a variety of colorful equipment, and you will send them to their horrible deaths over and over and over. Decapitated, eaten alive, flattened like a pancake, ripping off their own head, dragged to hell, digested by spiders, turned *into* an interdimensional spider, turning into a giant mushroom, turned into a small slime, turned into a large slime, vaporized, pulverized, incinerated, frozen, ground into meat chunks, killed by their fellow agents after they lost their minds and had to be put down, executed with impunity by the manager... and this is not even nearly close to the many deaths you will see them suffer. You will reset and do it again. The charmingly horrible deaths are a balm of sorts: I remember a desperately frustrating death, but watching the individual in question lower themselves into a bath full of blood and grimly deciding I needed to keep going with the day is part of the experience.

This game can be clunky, it's not exceptionally polished, there are infrequent graphical glitches and a few bugs that I had to go and install mods for (it's not necessary to do so, but I wanted to). This game will not be an easy experience, but if you are willing to Face the Fear, and Build the Future, you will enjoy it. I think that this game is [u]unrelenting[/u], and absolutely uncompromising, but slowly bending it to your will until you stand at the end over a pile of corpses and regrets in bloody triumph is one hell of an experience and one I am so glad I decided to play.

One of the best management simulations with a rich story. If you like SCP related games you'll love this game. Lobotomy Corp. also builds the foundation and atmosphere for ProjectMoon's other titles, Library of Ruina and Limbus Company. ProjectMoon goes HAM on the lore aspects and soundtrack of the game.

Content advisory. This game touches on many dark themes and topics such as suicide/murder/drug use.

Pros : 

The world ProjectMoon has created with it's 3 games is nothing short of incredible. Multiple story arcs and endings give Lobotomy Corporation good replay value. Well worth the $8.50 USD sale price.

The OST for this game is an absolute banger. Whether or not your little homies are getting eviscerated or you're watching a dialogue intermission about how one of your empathetic decisions caused the massacre of everyone in an entire sector, the music does an amazing job at setting the tone.

Create your little guys and try to keep them alive... I promise you, you wont. But then again, you can always restart the day... Or turn back time... In a world where nothing is seemingly impossible due to monsters(Abnormalities) born from the sins of mankind, you're always within arm's length of a different possible outcome. However, the price is almost always too great.

The monster management is fun and pretty unique. Every abnormality has it's do's and don't's. One of them likes peeking out from a keyhole and is a little shy. If you watch him, he'll breach and turn your employees into a bloody mist with his sawblades. But if you pan the camera away so he's off-screen he's completely docile. Each new subject is rather fascinating in it's own unique way.

Strategy is key with management and suppression tactics. The E.G.O equipment researched from abnormalities acts as sort-of a rock-paper-scissors mechanic to exploit weaknesses as well as protecting your "little guys." More sectors opens up more perks for employees and containment cells for abnormalities. After later sectors open you'll have access to direct intervention via "bullets" you can shoot employees and abnormalities with which can buff, heal, or kill. Then there's the Rabbit Protocol... for when the big F-U is neccesary.

Check out the Manga, Wonder Lab, which ties into the lore of Lob Corp. Trust me they go hard on the lore and this manga is pretty damn good.

Also check out the [ Limbus Company ] Official Promotion Video. The OST track from Mili - In Hell we Live, Lament Feat. Kihow from Myth and Roid goes hard.

Oh yeah... The Cons : You goan' die.

TLDR : Yes. 9.5/10

I find it pretty difficult to recommend this game to people because of a few main reasons. One, the sound design is poorly balanced and sounds really really bad in a few key areas (looking at you red dawn). Two, the gameplay is very repetitive and also has a very bad case of savescumitis, which only worsens as the game progresses to the point that I really don't recommend to anyone to commit to finishing it. And finally, a lot of aspects of the gameplay, in particular the difficulty are quite CBT and not in the fun ‘throw yourself against a problem until you figure it out’ way.

	On the other hand, the game is incredibly creative, interesting and above all UNIQUE. In my opinion video games are at their best when they do things that other games dont do, and to do that one must take risks and potentially fail. Lobotomy corporation took a risk and for the most part didn’t quite stick the landing. It still made something memorable and hopefully the concept of an esoteric monster facility management sim can be taken and iterated upon by another developer with more technical skill and time.

	Let me go over the flaws again before I dig into some particularly interesting concepts and design decisions I like. The sound is atrociously balanced. Some sounds are too quiet or nonexistent (there should be audible feedback for employee deaths besides the sounds of their various kills, like how Frostpunk has a church bell that rings once for every death. If you’re not focused directly on an employee when they die, there is no way to tell besides the toast on the left hand side of the screen, and if they’re a clerk you get no notification at all!), and some sounds are way too loud! The sounds for the different fixed events, that being the dawns, noons, dusks, and midnights are much too loud and earrapey. Some idle sounds of monsters are also too loud, namely Nothing There (which like, I understand being that Nothing There is supposed to be very threatening, but they dont need to be that loud to do that!) but also a few others. That said the sounds themselves are usually just… fine. Some stand out goods, some stand out bads, but mostly everything is just how it should sound and nothing more. 
	I dont really need to go too far into the game’s bad case of savescumitis, just that its there and it is a lethal case. Thankfully the game does give you quite a few ways to save over and reset from your mistakes, but I feel this is more of a bandage for a wider problem of unforgiving gameplay rather than a positive. 
	And as for that difficulty, oh god. Losing anyone is a HUGE negative due to the time cost involved in getting each employee even up to snuff. This really overlaps with darkest dungeon where employees are supposed to be disposable and you’re not supposed to get attatched, but conversely to that goal, employees are very very expensive to train. Even with all of the bonuses you can unlock to improve employee training speed (one of which requires a quite difficult boss!) it can still take a good 30 or so REAL TIME MINUTES at max speed to fully train ONE employee in ONE in game day. And that entire time you are generating risk of death, and micromanaging to avert the risk of that employee dying, or worse. You can multitask and train more than one employee at once, but there aren't that many abnormalities in the game that are good for training employees, and no gym or equivalent slow training. All employees MUST be live trained at ALL times. You can spend your employee points to strengthen the employee's stats but it's very expensive and really not worth it. So you spend a ton of time on each employee so that you can have a base of workers and warriors that isn't muppets… and then you get blue midnight or some shit and they all die instantly because you didn't pause the game the instant that you sent Urist McUseless to go train on One Sin. And then you reset the day. Hence the bad case of savescumitis. 

	But what’s really good about this game? Well, its fucking cool. All of the monsters feel esoteric, weird and interesting and it's super fun to learn how they tick and how you can incorporate what they do into your gameplay loop. I’d go into examples but that kinda takes away from the fun of it all, and plus I’d be restating what you could easily read on the wiki if you actually care.
	The story is also a highlight, being a pretty interesting concept although not the best written. The characters are fun and interesting, there’s an element of mystery and also quite a bit of that sweet sweet ludonarrative harmony (*gags*). Lots of the themes in the game and how frustrating it can feel is mirrored in the gameplay, and vice versa. Elements of the gameplay are integrated well into the story, such as the cognition filter explaining why the game looks the way it does. (Which also is incorporated into a cool abnormality! If you know, you know.)
	The old testament theming of the game is also quite interesting and unexpected for a game like this. The first abnormality you get in the game kicks off this theme, and is iterated upon by the most threatening one. The characters are themed after biblical (angels? I don’t know much about this. Might be more jewish rather than christian as well.) and it's well implemented. The story also goes into this in interesting directions, in particular the themes of suffering and original sin being mirrored in gameplay somewhat. The theming of this game is original, intentional, and tightly woven into the experience. Very well done.

	Speaking of, by far my favorite part of the game is the warning level. If you fuck up in some way, either by letting an abnormality loose or having employees die, the warning level increases which plays BANGER MUSIC and also has some minor gameplay effects. For the most part, the warning level is a gameplay way to signal to the player how messed up the facility is and also cause a snowball effect of failure. I don’t like the snowball factor that much, but it is in the end interesting which is the end goal of any game. 

	
	So yeah, kind of a messy review. I really can’t say I recommend picking up this game off of steam. If it was free, I’d say it has interesting ideas that are worth experiencing, but if you want a game from this company of a similar or higher quality level that's actually worth your time and money, I’d more recommend Library of Ruina… even though I despise it and everything it stands for due to it being a Turn-based RPG card game deck builder. 

	Overall, here are my generalized scores that arent really relevant to anything but my own general thoughts on the game. Don’t compare these to scores from other people or even myself on other games. 

	Personal scores: (Overall about a 7-8.5 that fluctuates depending on how cool i think nothing there is that day)
		Fun: 6/10 dwarf fortress does CBT better
		Autism-ility: 8.5/10 was my hyperfixation for a while 
		Aesthetics: 7.5/10 accurate corporate hellscape 

	Somewhat objective scores: (Worse than the sum of its parts due to its overall low budget and poor usage of that budget. About a 4 overall)
		Sound design: 4/10 red dawn.
		Game Feel: 5.5/10 aggressively mediocre but buggy. Commanding an army of goobers is never not satisfying but it toes the line in this game due to how janky combat is.
		Game performance: 3/10 holy fuck how do you fuck this up that bad
		Writing: 8/10 story stuff is fine but the stuff that's hidden in flavor text is great
		Horror score: 8/10 can be actually spooky at times
		Art: 7/10 has a style and is just… fine. Game looks bad. 
		The grind: 2/10 is real. And bad. 
		Theming: 8.5/10 Goes for something particular and nails it even though it's not that fun of an idea.

Lets start off by saying that this is a pretty niche game and is definitely not for everyone. If you want a casual game to play without too much worry, this is definitely not it. This is one of those games where you get better at the game from failing over and over again and learning from the failures.

The best way I can describe this game is... do you remember that laboratory from Stranger Things? Where they discover monsters, ghosts, and supernatural beings and then they experiment on them? Yeah, this is that. You play as a manager and you manage your employees by placing them in a cell with a supernatural being called "Anomalies". You place them in a cell and pray to god that the monster is in a good enough mood so they don't either rip your employees head from their shoulders, make your employee kill themselves, or make your employee kill others. 

Every monster has a "catch" or gimmick that you have to discover and then follow in order to keep your employees safe and make it to the next day (level). Every day you get a new monster, so the real trick is to juggle as many gimmicks as you can so you can make it to the next day without any casualties. 

There is definitely a learning curve and it is true that the game gets easier the more runs you do. Definitely pick it up if you like puzzles and don't mind a little cartoon horror

all in all a great management game and one of my favorites

Lobotomy Corporation is a game where pale twinks in suits form friendships with floating skulls to generate electricity, and then everyone dies somehow.

You play as The Manager, that bizarre mythological figure always invoked by angry customers, despite never being summoned. You have been tasked with running the eponymous Lobotomy Corporation, an ever-expanding underground power plant that harnesses energy from a collection of objects and entities, known collectively as Abnormalities, in order to feed the world's insatiable need for power. In the meantime you discover that the dangers of managing these unstable Abnormalities is only slightly less than the real existential danger that is our current crippling dependence on fossil fuels.

Confusion can be said to be LC's primary gameplay mechanic. Nothing in the game is ever truly explained to you, and what you don't know can very much hurt you. What [i]are[/i] the Abnormalities? What do each of the four kinds of "work" you can do with them actually entail? How does this generate electricity? Why does electricity come in boxes? What is a Qliphoth Generator, and why does nobody seem at all concerned about the fact that it seems to melt down every single day? What was it, exactly, that killed literally every employee in my base at the exact same time?

Making matters worse is that the writing deliberately goes out of its way to make this more difficult. Unlike, say, the SCP foundation (who uses clear, unambiguous language and hides information with trade talk and redaction), LC filters everything through the sort of floaty, high-minded, not-at-all-how-normal-people-talk sort of speech that you tend to find in works whose authors [i]really[/i] want you to know that they read books, sometimes. My AI director, who's supposed to be answering my questions, can't even give me directions to the bathroom without launching into a 40 minute tirade about the philosophy of striving for the future, interspersing a dozen pell-mell references to Judeo-Christian mysticism, and asking me for the hundredth time if I believe I have somehow grown, spiritually, from taking on this job.

The result of all of this is an environment that is 100% hostile to you, as a player. It's designed to make you fail repeatedly, until you finally manage to piece together what the hell your job even [i]is[/i] and whether or not you should make friends with the spooky audio recording you keep locked in a cell. Make no mistake: I mean that last sentence in possibly the most positive way. The penalties for failure aren't really that severe; you just get sent back to the start of the next day with your own personal knowledge of the situation more or less intact. Once you manage to piece together the lingo, you can start to get a sense of how the game wants you to proceed. Every new piece of info you unlock reinforces or refutes guesses you were already forming through trial and error. And every new Abnormality under your care becomes a new knife to juggle, increasing the danger while also making the resulting ballet of agent actions all the more impressive to behold.

In short, LC is a good game with a competent premise, encouraging experimentation and discovery and being just the right amount of tense. I would definitely recommend avoiding wikis and walkthroughs, wherever possible, and really enjoy the sense of desperate helplessness the game seeks to instill in you. I give this game an "Ergo Proxy is my favorite anime you guys let me tell you all about it" out of 10.

Lobotomy Corporation is very unique in the fact that it can stress out, frustrate, and throw the player into despair in many different ways. However, this game was an amazing experience in nearly every aspect for me. The many different Abnormalities of the game at various different stages meant your facility was constantly changing to adapt to the newcomers as you progressed through the game, as well as the missions you are given throughout each department, plus the story. God, the story of this game is phenomenal, and keeps you going through the struggles of each day, each restart, and definitely rewards you throughout. In my opinion, Lobotomy Corporation is 100% worth the money and your time.

TL:DR - Great story, great mechanics, and I love Gebura.

I think most of the game is pretty solid conceptually, the trial and error of figuring out what's going on with a new abnormality or tool is kinda fun if you don't mind starting days over a couple times to get your footing. Keeping containments under control is a bit nebulous, sometimes I feel like I've gotten a breach without really understanding what or how it broke out, but for the most part as long as you've got enough invested in its research you can suppress a breach without too much issue. But where the game really falls apart in my opinion is the ordeals. Every day for the most part at a random point, some kind of monster will spawn in multiple places throughout your base. There's no information on what kind of damage they do or how they attack or really anything at all as far as I can tell, and since they're completely random there's no real way to prepare for them at all. I've had multiple days where some new ordeal just shows up and the monsters murder a bunch of agents before I have any idea what they even do. It just really pulls me out of what is otherwise a pretty fair trial and error experience.

It's times like this I wish steam had a "neutral" option for reviews. Lobotomy Corporation seems like another case of a really cool idea ruined by poor execution and design choices. At first glance it has all the right ingredients for me to pour several, replayable hours into it: solid base-building mechanics, good artstyle and music, and an intriguing paranormal setting that's basically the SCP universe in everything but name. 

Instead, I couldn't get past some of the more questionable design choices. It has haphazard UI scaling and font sizes, and there's an overuse of SCP-like jargon that only made things more confusing and harder to keep track of since it's not using actual SCP terminology. 

I really like the idea of this game, but it just didn't click with me because of some of these questionable design choices. Personally I find that UI design and "readability" can make or break an otherwise solid game, but if these things don't bother you so much, I still would recommend at least giving this a try so see if the core concept clicks with you despite the confusing aesthetic choices

If you are looking for a challenging management game and you are patient enough to learn through trial and substantial error, you will love this game. I'd recommend just beginning the game with little knowledge and start reading specific parts of the manual when necessary.

So I went into this because I had been interested in it vaguely for a few years now, and it is on sale. However, what I didn't realize was that the first out of THREE tutorials would be filled with at least 7 different gauges and weird-worded things to keep up with.  This isn't a game.  It's an exercise in reading.  And trying to keep up with at least 7 made-up terms that make no sense whatsoever.  I own over 400 games on this platform, and none of them are as convoluted and ridiculous to try to understand as this is.  It is totally absurd.  I didn't want to buy a book on fantasy.  I wanted to buy a fun game that I could play and try to get better at.  This is an exercise in like college-level memorization.  Idk that I've ever had as much information thrown at me hapharzardly as this game.  And that's saying a lot, since I've played a lot of early access titles.  I cannot begin to explain how confusing and absurd this game is right out the gate.  I'm sure if I spent like 5 hours learning it, maybe I could make some kind of sense of it.  But that's not at all what I thought this was, or what was displayed on the store page.  

This is not fun.  It's not a good game.  It's just an absurd amount of things to try to keep up with for no apparent reason than to make it difficult.  Like there's no story at all.  There's no reasoning behind anything.  It's just "interact with this anomaly to earn points but also unique anomaly points and qhipholphy points to unlock information about it which gives you fortitude points for your agent but watch out for doomagoodness points because then your anomalies might escape where you need gmod weapons and suits to bring it under control which you get from spending qhilophinous points on the anomaly after you have your agent interact with it in one of the four possible ways that they can interact.  Also there are points on your agent and the anomaly to say what will work and what won't work for this specific anomaly."  It's completely ridiculous.  I'd rather read an encyclopedia than "play" this "game."  

And that's after 12 MINUTES OF GAMEPLAY. THERE ARE TWO MORE TUTORIALS TO GO THROUGH!!!!!  I can't even begin to explain the absurdity of this garbage.  I can't believe it has the positive reviews it does.  The UI is ugly, the gameplay is absurd.  

"git gud" I hear people screaming.  I own over 430 titles on this platform and have enjoyed most of them.  I'm not a plebian moron.  This is not for the faint of heart.  And it certainly isn't something to just buy on a whim to have fun with.  This is an investment of time and effort to make any sense of it.  And people should know that.

Edit:  If you notice, even the positive reviews speak negatively of it and the same problems I mentioned here.  Find the common thread through the reviews, and you'll see it.

If you're familiar with SCP Foundation then this is a different take on it. Though here instead of escaping a compromised facility we're playing the manager and command agents around to perform work (end result being energy production for which we have meet the quota every day). As you can imagine this kind of operation can go horribly wrong in many ways...and oh boy it sure does. Every single Abnormality is dangerous in some way and it gets ever crazier with each new day as our department expands getting new additions. We can either go through trial end error to get necessary research on each "subject" to manage them properly or try to check the wiki online, although that doesn't guarantee escaping dire consequences of sometimes merely having some Abnormalities in the facility. To make things more tense we will be attacked by random Abnormalities just entering the facility on daily basis so we will have to focus on more than our own containment chambers.
I presume it's part of the appeal that we will face a lot of failure, will have to restart a day or whole 5-day period to perhaps select more manageable Abnormalities. I can tell we can either focus on our agents to keep them high level and well equipped or just keep hiring new lambs to slaughter in containment chamber as, in the end, produced energy is all that matters (or does it?). Even though things roll out very slowly and consistently it will become overwhelming for someone not very into this idea of Management Sim and certainly feel grindy given we are always doing the same thing but more with extra strings and chances of things going apocalyptic attached each time. 

I haven't made it that far myself given as it turned it's a bit too much for me but there is some truly deep lore in here. Story is certainly a great focus in here and upon looking it up I have no doubts about it. Between each day we have visual-novel style of dialogue with various AI's helping in the facility, always keeping the creepy and uncertain tone of this entire operation. It sure is to keep the player on their toes at all times.

Sadly I can't say more given it's not as for me as I thought but if it seems it might be for you I say go try it. I can totally see what it's going for and it's very much well done - a beautiful, apocalyptic mess for a gameplay and grant mystery to unravel for a story. On perhaps a plus side there are no achievements so nothing to worry to be stressed over if it affects anyone.

Fun so far. Finished the first 9 days and it has been mostly trial and error. If you like the feeling of managing a project that is not going well then I would recommend the game. Definitely gives you the stressful feeling of needing to pay attention to many things at once that will fail if you do not. Neat setting so far too.

Update:
Everything I said before still stands. Have gotten much further into the game and begun to make major progress. Still enjoying the game around ~50 hours deep so would strongly recommend trying this game. It is very much not for everyone as it can prove to be difficult and stressful but if you laugh it off you will probably enjoy. Would recommend playing it blind as using outside resources diminishes the experience.

PART 1: i dont even know what to really say about this game to be fair. art looks neat, people say that the story is interesting, but the game is such a chore. a lot of abnormality-specific mechanics are somewhat hard to grasp, there are 50 days, and the quest on day 3 seems just absurdly long. i want to see why the game is liked so much, but sitting thru the long ass days and quests, then having half of your team die out of nowhere is just too much to stomach. ill try again in the future, but as of now, thats where my review stands
PART 2: ive tried it out again, and its still ass. Good news: you dont have to beat every quest in a row. another good news: even after resetting to day 1, your research doesnt reset. Bad news, the games even more of a slog than i first thought. ive bashed my head for 2 more hours and made barely any progress. whenever an employee starts panicking, i just restart the day, since its virtually impossible to stop them sometimes, since every employee has the same movement speed. bashing my head against every scp to find out how to treat them without loosing half my staff is repetitive and boring. one of the only redeeming qualities is the art and character design in this game, but i dont enjoy the characters themselves, since they act like feelingless bastards that care only about the company(ik "that they are AI", but still, wtf).

Conclusion: there are a lot of games where the fans say "this game makes you feel horrible, but we love it". the difference here is that this game has no redeeming qualities. MAYBE the characters develop. MAYBE the story becomes interesting... MAYBE. but banging my head against a wall, slogging through day after day in hopes of the game becoming good... i cant recommend that experience to anybody, not friend, nor foe...

Lob Corp, the game that sent me down the PM rabbit hole that ultimately made me PM's personal little bitch and further proved that a toxic relationship would be my undoing because I cannot peel myself away from this game as it infiltrates every passing thought I ever had. Exposure to this game will corrode your very mind.

Lobotomy Corporation is a cute little management simulation made by a handful of students, spare change, and a dream. As it says on the tin you manage monsters, keep them happy*, and stop them from breaching. With every passing day you learn a little more about the world that Project Moon has beautifully expanded and its denizens, every character and abnormality has a story to tell. Just as you think you have it all figured out, boom, more story and possibly murder**

!!!  Just a little warning to all future lob corp players  !!!
1. You cannot complete everything in your first run of the game, but worry not, resetting to day one keeps all your mission progress and collected items and research, it took me many a day 1 reset to get what I needed done
2. Daily resets are your best friend when it comes to learning with how to handle a new dangerous creature, you sacrifice some people, acquire knowledge, scribble it down or commit it to memory, and restart the day. You will lose research progress but you get your little lambs back and you have your actual knowledge to fill in those gaps. There are a LOT of factors that can be taken into account with handling abnormalities so there is no shame in restarting the day
3. READ, project moon fans are well known for their inability to read, I can confirm that this is true for I am illiterate. This game has a massive story*** and it's all very charming, but reading the information presented to you will help you fulfill your duties as a manager. Better get to exercising that brain of yours my friend, it's your greatest weapon in this game.

tl;dr: save yourself the trouble, this game is mindless grind in the worst kind of way, watch a youtube playthrough before you play Library of Ruina if you want the lore before you play it.

This game is cool. It is not good. I enjoyed my time with it, but I would never ever recommend it to anyone I didn't hate.

The aesthetic the game is going for is SCP. The reason SCP functions as it does, with as little faults as it has, all without breaking the veil, is because the Site Directors are able to delegate tasks. If the site director had to direct each and every researcher to *perform research* on a given SCP they are assigned to, via some kind of PDA, the Foundation would never have gotten more than one Site.

That is to say, a Chain of Command is NECESSARY for the proper and smooth operation of ANY operation, especially one that deals with anomalies, or "abnormalities" as this game calls it.

You play as a Site Director who has never heard of delegation, or is otherwise not allowed to engage with the concept by your AI boss. In the beginning, when you only have one sector to oversee, it seems fine! its just 3 or 4 abnormalities to look over. It might even be a little fun, researching each abnormality as they get dropped into your sector. Like unboxing some weird, supernatural lootbox. You live and learn, sacrifice a few employees in the name of the greater good, but at the end of the day you're a net positive for humanity. You get the personal satisfaction of laying the anomalies bare, knowing all that they are, and how best to suck them dry so Joe Shit the Ragman can watch TV in the gutter.

Then you get another sector to watch over, with the same nitpicky oversight that one would expect of an overseer of a single sector of XK-class anomalies.
"Well," you think, "it's only another sector! It's a single player game! Surely it is balanced around one person playing it!" 
So you endure the more difficult, but still manageable workload.

Then there is another sector. With the same amount of abormalities.

"Okay, this is kinda a lot for one person to handle." you think.

So you endure, mostly crutching on your fully researched clutch of anomalies to meet your energy quota for the day, while still trying to do what you can to research this new and infinitely more volatile class of anomaly. 

Then you get another one.
And another one.

And another entire floor after that, a clone of what you started with, with twice the amount of anomalies dropped per day, while youre still desperately trying to milk your original MAYBE 6 or 7 that you're confident enough with to milk dry (STILL manually milking btw, 3 clicks per ~20s, PER ANOMALY, (4 per sector, and you have 18 anomalies total at the point that you get a new floor, including the 2 it gives you when the new floor is forced on you) while remembering they exist, while also trying to manage deaths on the newer sectors, and managing escapes from anomalies you haven't had the chance to research yet). 

If this is hard to follow, its because it FUCKING IS HARD TO FOLLOW. It's not hard in a fun "oooh, okay so I have to do this to get this to do that" way, its hard in a "ok so i have to trial and error every anomaly that's dropped into this place, restarting 10-25 times per anomaly, if I want to not replay the story sections 800 times each attempt by playing until you literally dont have the manpower to play anymore then restarting from day 0, doing EVERYTHING again with the same research levels, arms, and armor, I got from losing the war of attrition with the game last run" way.

From what I hear, Library of Ruina is pretty good. If you're playing this game to understand that game, do yourself a favor and just watch a youtube playthrough. This shit is NOT worth it, I've been trying to play this game on and off since June 22, 2018, because every time I look at it I think "Surely it wasn't as bad as I remember!" and every single time, it is, if not worse.

tl;dr: save yourself the trouble, this game is mindless grind in the worst kind of way, watch a youtube playthrough before you play Library of Ruina if you want the lore.

I Have Been Lobotomized - In-Depth Review By Satanick "Sataneko" S.

I have a lot of experience with this game. More so than the (at the time of writing) 41 hours of playtime displayed. Project Moon seems to have created a unique management simulator, which I will not deny them so, but this game has had increasingly negative effects on my mental and physical health. At this moment, I type these words with half of my thumb and my chin. That is just about all that is left of my body.
The title "Lobotomy Corporation" is only a guise to hide the damaging effects it has on your neurons and muscles as you play, almost as if you were the one working with The Little Prince. Something has taken root inside of my body. It has eaten me from the inside out. It began with my head, taking all I had and leaving me with apathy, traumatic memories of the "game", and vivid hallucinations of all the five senses. I have witnessed things no one else has seen. 

Would you like to personally know how CENSORED appears without the managerial filter? 

Exactly.

I have sustained chronic damage in every way possible due to this horrific nightmare of a digital experience. Please, for the love of God, or WhiteNight, or Flesh Idol, or whatever in this world you pray to, do NOT buy this game. It will take everything you love and turn you into me- There's nothing there.

Stay safe,
Nick

Genuine, honest-to-god review of my favorite game, since I think I somewhat qualify as an expert:

TLDR: Game is fun for certain kinds of "people," but its design flaws are glaring, and you have to have a lot of patience to see the good parts that make those flaws worth it. Get it on sale, though. 4/10 for the average person, 10/10 if you're genuinely unhinged like me.

This game, simply put, is not designed well. It has mechanics that, in a vacuum, seem interesting and have potential, but the way this game is put together becomes frustrating rather than challenging. There are plenty of examples of this happening, but I think the most blatant is the Abnormality Managerial Tips, which I'll focus on in this review to avoid spoiling any story stuff.

Abnormalities (the monsters you're containing in this game) all possess some form of "special ability" that will activate when certain conditions are met. These range from harmless things like escaping containment and killing some nameless clerks, to instantly killing the employee you've spent three hours grinding up to max stats, to just outright slaughtering a whole department, if you're not far enough into the game to receive tools to deal with them. The intended way to get around this is that there isn't one. Whenever you gain a new abnormality, you chuck your strongest goon into the meat grinder (sometimes literally) and see what happens, until you have all the information necessary or everyone is dead. Once this happens, you promptly restart the day if the losses are worth more than the time you've spent, now armed with the knowledge you've gained.

That sounds fine when put in this way, but the real issue comes from the more esoteric abnormalities. Sometimes, you will receive an abnormality that has abilities so esoteric, annoying, and unmanageable that you will elect to simply "leave it alone" and pray qliphoth meltdown (another game mechanic, but honestly this one I like) doesn't hit that containment unit. In fact, there is a... certain abnormality that everyone just simply knows not to take after their first experience with it. It sucks to manage, has many elements of random chance, frequently causes unpreventable deaths, and if I didn't also add that it was very, VERY loud I'm pretty sure all those characteristics could be applied to quite a few of the abnormalities, by most people.

Mind you, these complaints about the manageability of abnormalities are coming from me, someone who has memorized every single preference, ability, drop, and piece of equipment of every single abnormality, has put over a thousand hours into a game with very little replay value, and knows everything well enough to fully expect anything the game can throw at me. These complaints are not for me, they're for jonathan.coolguy.2007, the average joe that got lured into playing this games by one of my fellow basement nerds, because this game is, as I said, poorly designed. If you're not willing to put up with that design, don't buy this game. Watch someone play it (even badger content creators to play it PLAESE PLEASE PLEASE PELAE ELASE LEASEPL-) because that's much funnier. If, however, you are willing to put up with bad translation, random bullshit beyond your control, hot koreans, and reading the entire Torah to understand the references this game makes, then I really do recommend giving it a try, though you should wait until it goes on sale to buy. Even I know $25 is too much, iirc the price is because the original translators totally ripped off the devs.

WARINING! WARINING! WARINING!
Manifestation of gameplay spoilers due to this being a retelling of the story, from my experience.
WARNING! WARNING! WARNING!

Lobotomy Corporation is a game that puts up a heavy facade. You take the role of X, the newly appointed manager of the titular company, Lobotomy Corporation. Your role and goal is to extract energy from "abnormalities," which are monsters that range from sweet old ladies, to skin stealers. To help you with this, you're given an android assistant named Angela.

The game goes along smoothly, you meet department heads known as "sephirot," and by this point they all should seem decently friendly, besides Yesod. That is, until the cognition filter breaks down, giving you a small peek in to the true nature of the facility. Right after that, you get a call from a mysterious man named B, who tells you that the company is not even half of what it seems, sowing seeds of distrust in you, and growing weeds of doubt, weeds that Angela wants to pluck. 

Now with your new sense of doubt, you progress more through the game. By this point you should now see "core suppression requirements" on a bunch of the sephirot's mission pages. Unless you know what you're doing, you most likely will not see any core suppression until 60-100 hour in. I got lucky and realized dusk ordeals weren't nearly as much as they were made out to be. Core suppressions are the boss fights of this game, adding a new layer of difficulty on an otherwise normal day. And the more you beat, the more you learn. 

Soon you learn about the man named A, and the more you learn about him, the more heartless he seems. You also learn of a woman named Carmen, who seemed to be the opposite of A in every way besides intelligence. You learn that Carmen died somehow, how she wanted to change the world for the better, and how she wished to help every person in the city. You learn the sad tale of Elijah, a girl who died out of desperation for attention, Gabriel who was driven mad, Giovanni who was deceived, Michelle who was overwhelmed, Enoch and Lisa who were taken in, only for Enoch to die at the well-meaning hands of Carmen, Kali who died defending in vain, Daniel who betrayed, Garion who was just doing her job, and Benjamin, who left A after Carmen's death.

After learning all of this, you begin thinking that A is the villain of the game. But he's the protagonist, as Angela finally reveals who A truly is, and who she truly is. A is you, and Angela is an imperfect copy of Carmen. A has put himself in to a time loop to get the perfect scenario for the "seed of light," a strange object which holds the power to accomplish Carmen's dream, and bring a "well" to everybody. 

Day 46-47, X meets Abel, another version of him representing a part of his mind that thinks nothing will ever change. Abel tells A to either overcome what he has not, or to stay with Abel and accept defeat. X, of course, does not, and perseveres through the day, all 4 upper layer sephirot going in to meltdowns. 

Day 48, X meets his second counterpart, Abram, who represents his guilt and grief for Carmen. Abram tells X that Carmen is dead and gone, to stop carrying on her legacy, and to just let the facility crumble, with his last moments being with Carmen's extracted nervous system. X ignores him, defeating the red mist a second time, and advancing on, almost ready to finish the seed of light.

Day 49, X meets Adam, the version of himself that represents his god complex. Adam is tired, and wants to finish the seed of light project early. This wouldn't accomplish Carmen's goal, and instead would create an imperfect seed of light, turning every single person in to abnormalities, instead of allowing them to manifest their true selves. X goes through his hardest trial yet to deny Adam, but does succeed.

Day 50, X meets Ayin, the true, original A. Ayin has a short conversation with X, and then sends him off to finish the seed of light. After the day has passed, the facility flips over to get the sephirot in their proper positions (Keter being at the top, and Malkuth at the bottom), and a beam of light shoots from the facility after it breaks through the ground. This beam is the tree of light, sprinkling it's seeds across the city, bringing the perfect ending to the game, which honestly made me cry. However, Angela has a different plan. (I won't say any more, as it will spoil certain elements of the sequel, Library of Ruina. I will say what's said in lobotomy corporation, though.) Angela, filled with anger from the torment she's been put through due to the time loop, wants to live a normal human life. She turns off the tree of light, taking the light for herself and using it construct a library, where she may accumulate knowledge of the world, the city, everything. 

10/10 game, and I don't give that out lightly. Well, at least I don't when I'm seriously reviewing something. It is a jankfest, there are bugs at every corner, but those are easy fixes with mods made to debug the game. Play this game if you want to cry form happiness, conclusion, closure, anger, disappointment, practically every emotion that can make you cry in this game will make you cry. After you're done, play it's sequel, it's somehow better than this.
