I have a lot of respect for the people who made this game, and I'll more than happily play their other products, but I just had too many problems build up as I went through the game, but incase you do get the game my best advice to give would be this.

Don't be afraid of replaying/restarting, even from Day 1.
The games expects you to use memory repository, and the only thing you will lose from going back, even to day 1, are the employees that you hired, and the abnormalities you obtained.
However any items and/or information you obtained from those abnormalities is kept.
Mission progress/completion is also kept, even from Day 1 resets, this makes replaying the game significantly easier, so do not be afraid of this, or losing employees.

With that said, I actually have a fair amount of nice things to say about the game, so let's start off with the

+++Positives+++

The thematics of the game are great!
I thought the general aesthetic worked really well, both for budget reasons and as an intentional style.
But beyond graphics, there's a lot of horror vibes, the store description doesn't lie with what it's inspired by, I really liked the SCP vibes throughout.

Speaking of SCP's, the Abnormalities are numerous and varied, I loved how different a lot of them were, and it was surprisingly satisfying figuring out how to manage them all and in the end, profit off them.

The story was also pretty neat, though I can't go into depth about it.
I found my eyes glazing over it a smidge with how it was worded at points, but overall I liked how dark it was throughout and how things played out with all of the characters.

Lastly, the music was also pretty cool at points.
For the most part it was kinda samey unless things were going wrong, but when things WERE going wrong, it got pretty good.

Now onto the 

---Negatives---

The games performance is terrible, specifically as you progress.
What started out perfectly smooth devolved into low framerates as the facility expanded, to the point where even loading screens came close to crashing the game if I clicked or alt tabbed.
This is a problem when you're faced with combat, because when particle effects happen, the game practically freezes momentarily, but everything is combat has particle effects.
Damage prompts, insanity prompts, blood splatters, everything will cause lag if you use large groups.
Now while small groups have their benefits, being discouraged from using a large group because the games performance will just die along with all my lower level employees, feels terrible.
But even outside of combat, scrolling across the facility is laggy, animations get less smooth and for the late game objectives specifically, it just feels awful.

To go more in-depth on combat, it's really simple. You select employees and you can tell them to either go to a location, or attack something, and later on in the game you get bullets, which let you manually target people to give them shields, health, sanity or just kill them if they start to become troublesome.
But my problem with combat is that it's too simple, I cannot tell an employee where specifically I want them in a room, I can only tell them I want them in that room. So when I'm fighting an enemy and I want to move them to the other side of said enemy, I have to select the employee, tell them to go into a room on the other side of the enemy (assuming there even is one, otherwise their only option is to either get hit or leave the room entirely), wait for the employee to move, select them again and tell them to attack the enemy.
It's tedious, it's clunky and it's one of the reasons I disliked when the game decided to delve more into combat specifically.

Speaking of those objectives from earlier, throughout the entire game you're given missions from different people in the facility, culminating in a final objective from them. These started off perfectly fine, but the last few in particular were just awful.
I will spoil three of these in particular but these are not major plot spoilers, just gameplay ones.
[spoiler]Starting with the Disciplinary Team, I don't understand why they had boss fights be the days objective instead of just collecting energy, the game is not built for boss fights as it just devolves into kiting attacks over and over, even with your best units. But for your units which aren't the best, you just kinda have them on the side, lest they die and ruin everyone elses sanity.
It's a boring fight which you cheese either via kiting, or through some other method, such as unleashing Abnormalities to the work for you, which sounds like a smart use of mechanics but it's pretty dull [/spoiler]

[spoiler]Next is the Record Team, this one is just dull. It takes away your ability to pause and manage things (to an extent), but it also removes your ability to speed things up, opting to speed things up gradually as the day goes along. I find this extremely boring, as most abnormalities don't use time as a mechanic, so it just makes the day go extremely slowly, and if you need to restart, you'll feel every second crawl on by. [/spoiler]

[spoiler]Finally we have the Extraction Team, another mission that requires you to finish a boss fight instead of getting enough energy, so what this means is more kiting to avoid attacks. The gimmick with this boss is cool, you cannot hurt the boss until you deal with specific Abnormalities that get put into a meltdown state.
Once they're vulnerable, you have a good chunk of time to wail on them. There are several problems here. She can place her meltdown effect on abnormalities which are already on cooldown, meaning you need to wait unnecessarily before you can send someone to deal with it, and when the boss becomes vulnerable, they stop for a long while, even if they're in a doorway transition where you cannot reach their model. If you do not deal with them in this state, there is a good chance they'll throw out more meltdowns again, all because you literally could not reach them because the game didn't allow you to.[/spoiler]

And going back to general gameplay, I really wish the game had more automation.
A lot of days, I was just going through the motions, it would've been nice if there was some way I could just automatically send people to go do the jobs I would like them to do. Replaying days felt boring, because very little changed, and as the facility expanded, the fatigue really set in.

And speaking of the facility, I mentioned how I loved the variety of abnormalities earlier, but sometimes the game can give you some abnormalities you're just not able to deal with at points.
Some will get out because you have too many clerk casualties, one will get out because you don't have enough clerk casualties, some will get out because your employees are too underleveled or undergeared and in the worst case scenario, you're getting them on days where a checkpoint is set and going back to said checkpoint fixes nothing. Going back isn't bad, but the reason for it can definitely feel bad.

>>Conclusion<<
Overall, there was a lot I like about the game, and it started off real strong, but it just became so tedious and annoying with what I wanted from me later on.
It's not devoid of quality, and it definitely appeals to some people, but I find that it was more annoying than anything else in the later game for me to recommend this personally.

I have never been so furious and upset due to factors quite literally out of my control. However the story setting and sequel is in my opinion perfect. I can not recommend not playing this game more. However if you are willing to go through hell. This and it's sequel are perfect

Great visuals, great soundtrack, great concept. Game is simple to understand mechanically but becomes ridiculously, punishingly hard to the point where you will likely not complete it unless you both know the game inside out and also get fairly lucky with the RNG; speaking of, Lobotomy corporation gives you a choice of three options every handful of days or so which slowly become more and more "pick the least miserable one." the longer the game goes on. as a plus it is also fairly easy to mod and it's super easy to customize your in-game agents with your own assets you drew yourself by simply dragging the images into your game files; agents only have one skin tone, however, which may pose challenges for certain types of custom made agents if that's a concern you have.

one thing I will say is that if you are into the game series for the story you will fucking struggle. Lobotomy corporation will dump huge cut-scenes full of text dialogue in-between days (that are about 5 hours of footage all together! holy shit!) that in the moment you want to skip to immediately get to the game play, and/or may not even unlock all of because the games so damn hard you never get to the text dumps at around day 40ish. Made even worse by the fact that Lobotomy corporation is /essential/ to understanding the plot of the two other games in the series (Library of Runia and Limbus [?] company) so you have to either watch 5 hours of just text dump dialogue in a youtube comp or struggle through lobcorp in order to play runia and limbus.

great concept and great game on its own, it just suffers from the fact that its sequel is much more lax; meaning people who play lobotomy corporation because they want to understand runia may walk away frustrated because the grueling rouge-like punishment is nothing like the other two games in the series.

Steam's user reviews are an incredibly useful metric for gauging game quality. They're rarely far off the mark relative to the game's actual quality. Which is what makes Lobotomy Corporation so interesting; it holds a 94% positive ratio and yet I cannot for the life of me understand why. There is nothing about the game that is at all conducive to a fun experience; if anything, it is explicitly, PAINSTAKINGLY designed to waste your fucking time. Made it through this agonizingly long day after tinkering around with that innocuous new thing you got and learned some of the rules of? Oh wait, after the end of the day, it just fucking kills your mook. Whoopsie! Better restart if you don't wanna make what's yet to come even more painful! Oops, forgot one obscure rule of how a baddie works and now your team that otherwise passes the gear check gets wiped out? Restart!

And that's the entire loop. There's no relief to any of it. You play the same days over and over again so as not to trip over the tiny roots that made you fall neck-first last time and all that awaits is more of the same except there's now even more esoteric rules piled on top that you haven't deciphered yet without restarting the cycle of endless save scumming. It's a dreadful, unforgivable lack of respect for the player's time. And being a roguelite (i.e an almost universally terrible genre), you're expected to repeat this fucking torture multiple times. Where is the fun in any of that? Suffering is fun when you know there's a light at the end of that tunnel. Lobotomy Corp doesn't have a light at the end of that tunnel, it's just an endless fucking tunnel. There must be a massive audience of people who have given up any and all respect they have for their own time because a game that in no aspect exceeds a 4/10 should not be sitting at a 94% positive review score.

I can break down the experience of LobCorp into two separate, distinct stages: discovery and completion. During the "discovery" phase of playing the game, each new abnormality, mission, and even new day is able to be approached with an abundance of caution and curiosity. You are, after all, still figuring out How Stuff Works™ and the game is willing to allow you to fumble through messily enough with a bit of sass and a knowing grin - just don't mind the knife being held behind their back, it's probably nothing. Even when ultimately you come into a predicament that necessitates use of a Day 1 reset: the seed of discovery keeps the player engaged and curious as to just what might come next. A good thing, then, that the answers can be more delightfully twisted than expectation may lead one to believe. It's compelling in a way that genuinely kept me playing long hours into the night past when I should've gone to bed.

The same cannot be said of the second stage: completion. This will come at different points for different folks in their own games - when the veil of mystery has been pulled back enough that all that remains is an intricate puzzle to be placed together over the course of an hours-long grind of known figures and punishing setbacks. Here, where the nervous tension of not knowing if your favorite Agent might be speeding towards an early retirement is replaced with the dull monotony of watching progress bars fill and hoping that (maybe this time around) circumstances won't end up in disaster, is where LobCorp truly becomes a test of will (and navigating sometimes-fiddly controls). Maybe, perhaps, you'll eek out a win and then rewind the ol' Repository so as to not lose quite so much progress as the End of Day screen dutifully reports. By the fourth or fifth time you're doing this: the aforementioned possibility of just looking up the damned story becomes that much more enticing.

I enjoyed LobCorp, but it's definitely not a game I would be surprised to hear someone tell me that they gave up on mid-way through. My own file ended up utilizing a few quality-of-life mods to make the tedious climb back to the final chapter something that I could complete before my interest in the game truly snuffed out from sheer burnout. At time of completion, I was happy to resign the game to fond memories and hope that the sequel has a bit less tedium and just as much unique creativity.

To end this review, I'll share with you what originally sold me on giving this game a chance: there is boss fights. How the hell do you do that in a management sim game? The answer may surprise you! (It sure as hell surprised me.)

Very fun and interesting game! Not as hard as it looks, either.

EDIT: One thing that needs to be mentioned is that there's a bug that will cause the game to crash after about 1 hour of playing the same level. It gives an 'Access Violation' in memory, which is caused by a programming error that makes the game use up more and more resources until your RAM is all filled up, which crashes the game. To fix this, I installed the 'Optimization Mod' from nexusmods.com. 

In terms of gameplay, I absolutely recommend buying this game. In terms of the overall product, it irritates me that this bug (which actually prevents you from finishing the campaign, since the levels get longer as you go) has been around for years and the devs have refused to fix it despite numerous reports. So, buyer beware I guess...

[h1]Three things to understand about this game (no spoilers):[/h1]

[b]1. Go in blind![/b]
Don't do any research, if you can help it.  A majority of the joy of this game is learning it and exploring it.

[b]2. This is a Korean game.[/b]
If you don't have experience to know what this means, it is incredibly difficult and you will grind it a lot.  You'll spend a lot of the time doing the same thing over and over hoping for improvement and defeat will be brutal.  Go in expecting the worst and have fun with it.  (I mean, really this sort of difficulty and grinding should be expected by the theme.)

[b]3. This is a Roguelite game[/b]
This is something I didn't really consider at first.  Roguelites require you to fail fail fail and, as you progress, you'll get to keep a little bit of something for the next try.  Don't be afraid to rewind back.  Yeah, it sucks having to grind through the same stuff again, but you'll have more stuff, a better idea of the game, and the opportunity to make new choices.  Getting attached to what you built and sticking with it when you hit a wall and can't progress is only a recipe for depression.

As of this moment, I think I'm around the early game stage and I can already tell that this game would mentally and emotionally devastate me from both the gameplay and the story. Definitely gonna have fun with this one :DD

Despite the difficulties and frustration this game can cause, Lobotomy Corporation has easily become one of, if not my favorite game. Somehow, it's able to make you extremely attached to workers meant to be disposable. It's magic. All of the characters in the game are great, and I've gotten very attached to them. The gameplay, when not frustrating, which it usually isn't, is very fun, and I absolutely love it. And, despite how difficult the game may be, it's also forgiving. Every 5 days, you reach a Memory Repository day, and you can rewind to it at any time, keeping any gear you obtained. This can be HEAVILY abused to obtain High Level Gear, I would know, I've done it before, and with no regret whatsoever. One thing that does pain me about the game, however, is having to force myself to get desensitized to Agent deaths. Every time a death message pops up, I'm very tempted to press the retry day button, though I force myself to go on. That is, unless the death is one of my Department Captains, my little scrunkly wunklies. The Abnormalities are very interesting, too. I haven't seen a single design I dislike, and, for the most part, any deaths caused by Abnormalities are due to your error. For the most part. There are a few RNG parts and unfair mechanics. I also love Laetitia. And Der Freischütz. All in all, I would say that the game is AMAZING. It's story is /very/ intriguing, and I find myself extremely eager to learn more and more about the Lore. Easily my favorite game.

Lobotomy Corporation touts itself as a mix between a buisness/monster simulation and a roguelike game. This description is incredibly misleading. When you think of a "simulation", one would assume that there would be different aspects you control in the game, but those mechanics are completely shallow. And the "roguelike" aspect only comes from the selection of artifacts or monsters you choose from when given the opportunity to do so.

As far as the whole simulation aspect is concerned, there's very little of it. You can "hire" employees, change their equipment and decide what they do, based on the department they work in. That's it. There's really no management of resources, or selections of departments or tools or anything like that.

As far as the game goes, it's very simple, each successful day completed you choose from a new "abnormality" (which is labeled under a serial number). Then you spend the day trying to understand it by studying it while maintaining and containing all of your other abnormalities.

Studying a abnormality is completely a game of guess work and can completely ruin a game until you know what's going on with it. Unless you've watched play throughs and understand what they do and what they need, all you can do is blindly click.

After you complete research of a abnormality, it's just a matter of grinding energy and packages from them. That's it. The first couple of day(s) can be fun, but the longer you play, the longer you realize that's there's actually very little gameplay holding this game together. And it gets boring very quickly.

For almost $25.00 for a "indie" game, I would have really expected a lot more based on what they actually advertise. In some instances I would actually argue their STEAM store page may be misleading and possibly false advertising.

If you can get this game for $5.00 then fine, take a chance. But at full price this game is a full blown rip off.

Lovely, stressful pseudo-RTS permadeath SCP manager game.

It's one of those games like papers please where the game tells you to do something then keeps adding new instructions to remember. Except instead of just GIVING you new instructions you have to learn them through experimentation and trial and error.

You unlock the instructions by interacting with an abnormality long enough to be able to buy small chunks of information about it. The game forces you to interact with randomly chosen abnormalities in the facility, meaning if you don't guess new abnormalities' gimmicks in time you could easily end up with a containment breach [strike]or worse[/strike]

When an abnormality escapes containment, the gameplay style shifts from a papers please memory game to permadeath RTS until you recontain or figure out how to reliably plan around the abnormality. Some of the REALLY messed up abnormalities will willingly recontain themselves after they finish their objective. Oftentimes the wrong abnormality escaping can turn a normal day into a bum rush for meeting the quota to finish the day as the state of the facility gradually escalates in danger.

Unfortunately sometimes the transition between music is jarring, especially during boss fights which use the same over the top actiony theme only for the first phase of every boss, when the first phase usually includes 3 minutes of careful setup while the game is paused.

The visual novel story is also very good, but there are a few times where a good story beat is ruined by the translation being a little crusty, even after the retranslation. Without spoiling anything, a lot of the characters have developed some of their more wacky personality traits as a reponse to the "high employee turnover rate" or from negative experiences with other members of the company.

Lob Corp is a roguelike Monsters Inc SCP RTS Windows 12 on DVD toaster management game. 
You play as the manager of a perfectly normal and humane power company and your goal is to manage the facility to make sure your workers are able to efficiently meet the energy quota each day. At the end of each day, you get to choose a Friendly Creature to put in your facility, which You Cannot Ignore :] and have to work with and discover more by spending points that you get by working with it. What's that? You don't want to touch the weird slime creature after discovering it will infect your entire facility with Love and Kindness after working with it? Too bad! After certain amount of works, some containments will get a ticking time bomb to force you to work with them, lest you wish for the Friend to escape and turn the clerks and agents into raspberry jelly across the halls of the facility. 

The game also has a really good story, which slowly reveals to you what is actually going on in this corp and the backstories of each character you meet. 
In the beginning and right at the end, the game is definitely tough and you will encounter situations that you are unprepared for very often, so RESET DAY is a button you will get acquainted with very well. Also don't play this without optimisation mod, that's one of the flaws this game has with a few more but I don't think it's a good enough reason to just say it makes the game not worth playing.
It's definitely a niche game and it's not for everyone but I recommend at least giving it a shot. Story itself is worth reading so.. and it has a very good soundtrack, which is also different than your normal OST.

After giving it some thought, I have come to the conclusion that trying to properly "finish" this game would be an exercise in severe boredom & tedium, not to mention how it would be an unfun timesink of several more hours. After reading some of the almost comical requirements to actually 100% the game (e.g. to get the "true" ending), I've decided to call it here. If I could give a "meh" review I would, but a negative review better conveys my current stance on the game better than a positive one.

My honest recommendation to people considering LC is to please THOROUGHLY research the game (possibly including a bit of spoiler material!) before deciding to play it till the "end". I will try to avoid spoilers below.

PROS:
- The lore/story (as badly conveyed as it is, in my personal opinion) is fairly interesting. This is a very lively world and everything is not at all as it seems when you first start playing. Also, the reset mechanics are tied into the story itself.
- The ideas/characters put into this game are very creative. What you do see of the AIs is somewhat endearing
- The management is initially quite engaging. You have to keep track of a lot, but it is rewarding to clear days with no deaths and well trained agents.
- The research/upgrades in the game make a big difference and are quite distinct from one another, unlike in some other games where its just a "+5% damage" type of system
- The Boss fights are mostly quite varied and challenging, mostly in a good way though this breaks down a bit at the end.
- Some of the music tracks are quite good, others get repetitive quickly.
- The four damage types + weapon/armor variety helps to diversify combat.

NEUTRAL POINTS:
- Music can get very grating after long sessions. This can be turned off, obviously.
- This game would massively benefit from the workshop, but no such allowance was made. Fortunately other modding is possible.
- Sound effects are meh.
- Graphics/artstyle choices are... meh. They don't endear me or push me away from the game. Up to personal preference whether you like or don't like the cartoony aesthetic.
- Some players have reported very serious issues with the possesion mechanic not working properly (e.g. some people that should be able to be un-possesed cant be, and so you have to reset). I have not encountered this so far, but be wary.


=== NOTE ===
Thankfully, some of the issues that will be outlined in the CONS section can be fixed with mods. In fact, issues that can be fixed, or at least ameliorated with mods will be marked with a "[Mod full fix]" or "[Mod partial fix]" tag for your convenience in the CONS section below. However, I am judging the game on its own merits, and not on the those of the modders that gave their time & effort to fix its many problems.
===========

CONS:
- surprisingly Sub-standard controls. The game has the manager exert very indirect control of agents, and No control of clerks whatsoever. This will often lead to completely unnecessary damage/breaches/deaths that are frustrating setbacks or outright resets. As an example, a major strategy in the game is to put agents into elevators so they can be grouped up and thus fight anomalies in clumps of melees & ranged squads... Instead of just letting the player group them in some custom arrangement.

[Mod partial fix] - You can speed up time in this game, but not nearly enough. Eventually even 2x/2.5x is wildly insufficient for how tedious much of the management phase becomes. 

[Mod full fix] - Very poor conveying of (VERY important) statistical information to the player. Part of the game is, obviously, to let the player become a manager of a huge, byzantine facility and make the best of it. LC, however, takes this to excessive lengths. The game plays around with giving the player access to information as part of research/story progression (HP/SP of agents/abnormalities as part of a research from one of the AIs). LC, however, does NOT give info on Shield HP/SP, NUMERICAL HP/SP of agents/abnormalities, NUMERICAL Use-Speed/Range of weapons, NUMERICAL success probability with fully understood abnormalities... This is extremely important information to properly manage the facility!

- Very poor conveying of spatially-related information. The game will not notify you if someone in the facility is taking damage / in combat, nor will it tell you how they died. I suppose this could be a deliberate design decision, but it is one that is hugely irritating to me personally. I much prefer the Rimworld method of alerting you to threats. ALSO, agents can Stack on top of one another, and then you cant easily see their HP/SP

[Mod partial fix] - Many models do not display the correct weapon your agent is holding, which can cause confusion in the middle of an important suppression.

- Again, personal opinion, but the way the story is conveyed is very, very poor. Others might not mind this more "scattershot" type of storytelling.

[Mod partial fix] - Unacceptable performance issues that can cause memory leaks. I was shocked to see >95% RAM utilization (out of 32gb DDR5) by this game one night. Be aware you will probably have to limit your play time to a few hours to avoid this. There is also generally poor optimization.

- No spoilers, but a good number of the ordeals/bosses in this game are simply boring timesinks that are occasionally frustrating and generally tedious exercises in kiting for minutes on end. Late game can be pretty egregious in this regard

- No spoilers, but some abnormalities are genuinely run-enders if you are unlucky with their placement, or just rely on frustrating mechanics to not cause immense damage (Like getting "Normal" results only). Getting enough abnormalities that care about agent/clerk deaths can cause spirals that go on to cause resets as well, though this is eventually mitigated with execution bullets.

- Eventually ~75% of your abnormalities will be completely ignored in favor of more dangerous (more energy producing / more efficient training) abnormalities. I feel this is a missed opportunity wherein we the player have no reason whatsoever to interact with the vast majority of the facility. 

[Mod full fix] - This game is already painfully tedious and (imo) pointlessly time consuming after enough time has gone on that the players has a good grasp of the game. Why can't I queue actions? Some consider this part of the management process, I consider this forced, boring busywork.

- You have no idea how long an agent has been using a tool abnormality and so have to: 1. guess or 2. using a separate abnormality as a makeshift timer or 3. use a real world timer (hope you are not at 1.5/2.5x speed 
 in game!). This has genuinely been a huge headache on every run.

[Mod full fix] - Training employees is a near complete guessing game. Perhaps I missed something, but until I read the wiki outside the game itself, I had not idea how my agents stats were being changed as a result of work/suppression/gifts. This is, again, very important information that the game doesn't tell you. I feel like Im seeing a rather unfortunate trend for a MANAGEMENT game.

- This one is subjective, but I feel the way clerks are handled is very strange and could have done with a some overhauling. Essentially clerks provide you with buffs, some of which are fairly important. But eventually you will probably have to cull very large portions of them (usually with execution bullets) to prevent abnormalities from breaching as a response to too many clerk deaths from abnormalities or other events. So you can:
1. Not cull employees, and so risk breaches, which will probably kill clerks and reduce/lose buffs.
2. cull employees, and so diminish breach risk, but also reduce/lose buffs.
The player is put in a situation where they have buffs when they LEAST need them (start of day), and dont have them when they MOST need them. (middle/late into day).

Lobotomy Corporation is a difficult game but one I enjoy immensely.

It's a good game to play if you enjoy challenge and have the time to sink into it. 
It's also good for those who enjoy fantasy, management, SCP, as well as watching your little nuggets grow and become the ugliest and strongest possible <3
There is no more joy than watching them grow extra eyes on their cheek, maybe where a literal face mask... yuck! But aw!

The game play is engaging and feels rewarding.
While it definitely has a bit of a problem where if you don't know what you're doing the first time around you may have to restart the whole cycle (which can take a while depending on how you play, and it often requires a bit of grinding), it has the tools to let you explore, try again, and slowly figure out what each abnormality can do.
As you figure out what each one does, you're rewarded with an increases in stats, information, story, and even weapons/accessories depending on the abnormality.
When I see the little ugly nuggets smack their silly pink goo and feather bullets(?!) at each abnormality and destroy them you can't help but feel a bit of pride.

As a reward for progressing and surviving you get to learn the stories of each character, and if you play your cards right, you can learn so much more about them.

I'll get to the point. The game is probably the HARDEST game I've every played. Seriously. 
Just to explain the game, the game is about harnessing energy from monsters. The more dangerous the monster is, the more energy produced. The monsters can escape and kill your employees either by escaping and attacking them or using special abilities they have. They escape if the little number located out their containment cell goes to 0. Some monsters have no number and just has a cross. 

Enough of the explanation, several factors make this game really hard. 
First reason: The gameplay is original so you can't use knowledge or skills from other games. This means that even a heavy gamer's skill in this game will be as close to a light gamer. 
Second reason: RNG. I just hate RNG. No. Just no. All games do have a bit of RNG no matter what, but this game, oh this game. I fucking hate this game's RNG. There are things called, "Ordeals" and these things are based off of RNG. The midnight Ordeals will make you suffer and cry if you are a little noob like me and if you played this game, it probably is safe to say that the green one is the easiest Ordeal.
Last reason: Overall time consuming. This is probably the biggest one. You would have to reset the day if an employee with really good armour dies.
This is an absolute gem of a management game. Lots of love and care into every little detail. Not for everyone, but if its for you, you'll treasure it for years to come.

First management-type game I've ever played, and I have to say that this game is definitely worth playing. The more I learned about the abnormalities the easier it became to contain them. It's pretty fun learning about them too. Forgetting about one little thing in this game however could lead to one or multiple of your agents dying, it's definitely unforgiving. One thing that was really relieving is that if your first run that you sunk hours into goes to hell, you can keep playing the game and not feel like everything is over. The knowledge and equipment you earned from from your last run is saved into your next playthrough, and you can improve on the mistakes that you made before with each run-through. Definitely a game that you can sink tens or maybe even hundreds of hours into and still enjoy playing it.

This game is not for everyone. It will beat you senseless through repetition, trial and error, and the sheer horror contained within it. It is a game that asks the player whether they truly think it is worth it to simply continue to see an ideal through until the very end, no matter the pain and suffering that is along the way. If you feel like you can withstand a plunge of over a hundred hours into such a task, and be rewarded for your trials only at the very end, then the game is worth looking into for you. This game is as close to human suffering condensed into a product as you can get, you can start off likening your employees to humans in your head, seeing your nuggets complete each day and trying your hardest to keep them alive. Eventually, something will snap in you, and they change from individual to expendable. A way of putting this game simply is that it is training for middle management. 
So basically this game is mainly for those who see suffering as the path to growth, and if you can accept that, this game will be great for you.
Now, finally, after having spent almost five years in my off and on run, I can continue onwards into the Library.

The first Project-Moon type game.

Everything about this game, the SCP inspiration, the abnormalities, the characters and story, the management gameplay, the ball-bustingly vertical difficulty, and the soundtrack, are amazing. 10/10 Lobotomy Corporation turned me into a masochist.

Gameplay wise I probably wouldn't recommend this game to anyone.

HOWEVER: narrative, setting, music, design and practically everything else wise, this game is fantastic. If you manage to get through the monotony of grinding, the unexpected wipes waiting for you at any moment, and the many difficulty spikes required to face in order to reach the end (multiple full runs are practically guaranteed to happen due to how the game is built), then you will receive a genuinely engaging story that believes in you to overcome the challenges it throws at you.

This has not been my first exposure to Project Moon verse, that title would go to Ruina. Realistically speaking, this should have been played first purely for it's story, as you get to see exactly what happened to the characters here that made them what they were in Ruina. If you ever plan to get into these games, start here, see if you like it, watch a story compilation on youtube if you don't, but give it a chance. I have fallen into a Project Moon rabbit hole, and this game is one of the many good reasons why.

A fantastic concept ruined by difficulty that is only meant for masochists. Average playtime of this game is roughly 90~100 hours for a lot of folks, because a lot of that time is spent grinding employees and redoing days (or weeks, or even going back to day 1) when things get really unmanageable. This game reminded me a lot of Pathologic in that sense: its obtuse and difficult and meant to break you in ways you did not think were possible. Lobotomy Corp's ordeals and abnormalities (and when you have to deal with so much at once) really feel both overwhelming and unfun. I do not shy away from a difficult game but it does not really become that much more manageable the further you go, and eventually you will hit a wall where you have to redo more than you are willing to do anyway.

The story and music in here is top notch, but not worth the effort. If you've looked at Ruina and thought you should play this before, you really don't have to and I'd actually recommend just playing Ruina and reading/watching the story of Lobotomy Corp, the Sephirot and the abnormalities. Its an experience that won't take you dozens of hours and involves far less ball-busting.

The gameplay is fairly simple to grasp. You have an Abnormality who is sitting in a nice little Containment Cell. You have an Agent who needs to gather energy from it. You chose what type of work to perform, and that's it. You watch the little guy go and hope for the best. If you're a good manager, this game will become routine, almost tedious in its design. If everything is performing as intended, all you do is schedule your little guys to do their little works and once you've got enough energy you move on to the next day to continue the story. But not everything goes as you want it to.

Every single Abnormality has its own list of rules that must be obeyed. This Abnormality kills you if your work time takes too long. This one gives you a gift, but if you work on another Abnormality while carrying its gift you die and turn into a horrible monster. This one doesn't like Repression work. That one hates employees with high Temperance. These are all rules you'll have to tuck away into your subconscious as you play the game. Forget any one rule, and you're likely to have an employee die. I once had spent a few hours on a single day trying to grind my employee's stats to maximum for upcoming challenges. I had one employee work with a safe abnormality who gives a little healing orb for doing work. It's not an abnormality that's good at training stats however, so I sent that employee to work with another to finish off her stats. To my dismay I forgot that anyone carrying the orb is likely to die if they work on any other Abnormality. Not only that, but any employees who got the orb throughout the day ALSO die when that happens, causing 5 deaths in my facility of 20 employees.

But this is where the game really starts to shine in my opinion. You can Retry at almost any time. Those 5 employees are back under my care, as though nothing had ever happened. I was a bit aggravated to lose my employees, but it was my fault. Fundamentally, Lobotomy Corp does not present the player with impossible tasks. There is never a case where an employees death is a requirement to progress. Some challenges can be made easier by throwing a few corpses at it. One of the hardest challenges in the entire game can be made trivial if you're willing to commit to sacrificing a single employee, but it's never a requirement to progress. A deathless run is more than doable. Everything comes down to player knowledge. In that way this game is a little bit like Outer Wilds. Your own knowledge is one of the strongest weapons at your disposal.

But then it gets even better. Every 5 days the game saves to something called the Memory Repository. Any gear you've unlocked, quests completed, research gained, and upgrades acquired persist when returning to the Memory Repository. That one sacrifice to cheese one of the hardest encounters in the game? That employee too can come back. The challenge will still be cleared. And you will have new resources available further challenges even easier. You can go through a week, farm a bunch of high level gear, and return to the start of the week with everyone alive and now decked out in the high level gear you just earned.

And so eventually we return to the status quo. My entire facility is now flooded with Level V Agents with maxed out stats and EGO Gifts. My facility is so powerful we can set dangerous ALEPH class Abnormalities free for fun and easily suppress them without a single lost employee. And so the game has returned to that tedium I mentioned before. If you're a good manager, nothing will go wrong. If nothing is going wrong, then all you're really doing is farming energy and moving along. The game has two ways of co this fatigue. Ordeals, and Missions.

Missions are challenges set forth by the other characters in the game. Most of these are pretty easy, but some can be quite challenging. One of them is Suppress 3 different ALEPH Class Abnormalities in a single day. For someone like me with a small army of super units decked out in the best gear thanks to judicious use of time travel, this is fairly trivial. But for most players this is a wall that will be nearly insurmountable. They also reward you with permanent upgrades.

The second mechanic is Ordeals. These are essentially uncontained Abnormalities that appear randomly throughout the day. The game gives you a warning before they spawn, and the player themselves must trigger the event by performing work. The first time you encounter an Ordeal it will likely be a nightmare. You won't understand what these clowns are. you won't be in position to stop them, and you won't understand why Der Freishutz just shot a bullet down a hallway and killed half your employees. Eventually you'll learn that the clowns spawn in random hallways, but only one per department. You'll learn that their goal is to either breach or trigger the special ability of an abnormality in their hallway, and you'll learn that you can easily hard counter them by placing one employee per hallway ahead of time. And that's only  Crimson Dawn, one of the easiest Ordeals to handle. Thankfully though every single Ordeal save one is just like this. They have a very obvious counterplay, and once you understand it you won't lose an Employee to it ever again. Except for Violet Midnight. If you see Violet Midnight just hit that Retry button I guess. It ain't worth it.

And thus we once again return to the norm. You've completed the missions, you know how to handle Ordeals, your abnormalities are safe. And then the game starts throwing something else at you that pushes you to the brink. Suddenly you get a challenge where all your work Orders are scrambled. Your employee stats are lowered. Healing is disabled. A skilled player will not be used to putting out fires. They'll prevent the fires from happening in the first place through diligent management. And then the game sets off an inferno, and tells you "Adapt or die." These are some of the most fun challenges the game has to offer, but also the most difficult. These moments are stressful, tense, and you'll probably have to retry some of them several times before you clear the challenge, but at the same time the catharsis once you do is one of the best. And remember, all of the above is still in play during these challenges. Abnormalities still need work.

I could honestly say as much about the story as I've said about the gameplay. I found the characters endearing and charming. The abnormalities are as much a character as anything else in this game, and most of them are lovely. My personal favorite is probably CENSORED. An abnormality that pokes fun at all those childishly written SCP Articles where they try to add mystique and danger by just spamming [REDACTED] all over the page. The abnormality itself is a giant censor bar because it's so horrifying to look at that even you, the manager, would die just seeing it. Top class stuff. Despite its arguably horror roots and shocking, violent content, the game isn't afraid to be a bit cheeky and playful with it all. The game's setting is one that will sneak up on you. The true nature of the City, and the world they all live in is fairly compelling anti-capitalist stuff. One of my favorite Abnormalities is a blind birth with a crooked Scales of Justice hanging on its neck. The bird cannot tell that the scales are crooked because it is blind. Absolutely flawless symbolism.

The music is also great. There's only like 10 tracks total, but they're all wonderful and never get grating despite looping constantly. The graphics are clumsy, and the game is a bit poorly programmed and janky in spots, but everything else fantastic.

TLDR: Lobotomy Corporation is a tough, but ultimately fair game with lots of replay value wrapped in a great story with sometimes tedious gameplay. Surprisingly well balanced in spite of what others have said about vertical difficulty spikes or impossible challenges. 9/10, I could have gone on, but I ran out of space. Oops.

I do enjoy the large variety of monsters in the game and the story seems like it was going on an interesting direction, but I just got too bored and couldn’t keep going. Each day consists of sending your employees into a room with a monster over and over to do a choice of 4 options for studying it. This is doing trial and error to learn what the right choice is and sometimes if you start out guessing the wrong choice it can kill your staff member and you will probably want to restart the day and guess again. Skill points to increase the stats of your employees or to hire more and drip fed to you and cost so much so quickly it’s hard to feel like you are making much progress day by day. Sometimes various monsters will escape and there’s not much you can do to prevent that and you need to have your whole group gang up on them and hope one doesn’t get caught alone or you’ll likely lose that one too. It’s a loop of the same stuff that gets boring after a while.

Oh my goodness gracious this is one of my favorite games with an amazing story. It is just a shame the story can quite hard to fully understand. Really really really great characters and monster design with a BANGER soundtrack, 2nd Warning literally sends my soul out of my body. While this game has a special spot in my heart, it is absolutely not for everyone. If you have bad anxiety, this might actually explode your brain. I'm not into management games, but I made an exception for this one. If you are willing to suffer an incalculable amount of resets, maybe learning a bit of kabbalistic mysticism, and bearing with a decent bit of jank, you will have a very memorable experience (hopefully a good one)

It took too many years to clear this game, I dropped out once and after 3 or 4 years, I tried once more.
Last 46~49th days were brutal for me, in the end I lost 96% of my employees.
A challenging game is not a bad game but it needs too much of luck sometime to break through the ordeals.
Also without mods, the game was frequently laggy. It might be my system but the lag added another problem on the top of uncomfortable control. It is a definitely forcing to  use a micro-control to avoid certain enemies, but it does not even have a basic functions, such as a group set for specific agents (like an attack team for monsters or something).
The art style and atmosphere of the game is excellent. The story was hard to digest for me though. I understood the storyline but some details are a bit obscure. I had loved some characters but the temporal blank to clear the game made me lost almost all the memory of characters in the game, which affected my experience definitely, especially the glorious ending scenes...

Overall, if you want to experience the sorrows of a middle manager who stuck in the unlimited number of the time-loop, I can recommend to buy it. However, you should finish it without too much time-span, like me. Also, for me it is not a replayable game after the ending. Fortunately it is not a full-price game, so, it is acceptable.

Interesting concept, poorly executed. In many ways, it reminds me of Darkest Dungeon - while gameplay bears very little resemblance to that game (seeing as DD is a roguelike dungeon-crawler and Lobotomy Corp is a management simulator with heavy SCP influence), it has several similar concepts. Death is simply inevitable for your characters, even your favorites, and many circumstances may simply have no good outcome. Randomness is a huge factor, both in what you'll face and in your ability to deal with it. And of course, monsters are always, always, always dangerous.
Unfortunately...that's where the similarities end.
Darkest Dungeon, while it certainly isn't for everyone, is very carefully balanced. Once you understand the strategy, and perhaps progress through the game a bit, the game becomes at least manageable, if not easy. Randomness can be planned for. Death can be avoided. It takes thought and care, but it is feasible. And more importantly, neither death nor random chance can permanently screw over a run. Even if things go horribly, horribly wrong and you lose a great deal of progress, it's always possible to get back on your feet and keep going.
Lobotomy Corporation, on the other hand, is far less balanced. Randomness is inherent in everything - from what Abnormalities you'll get to how they're managed. You have very little information on an abnormality you've just got, and trying to learn about it is often very dangerous. Methods of taking care around it, of having sacrificial meeples to feed to it while you figure out what's up with it - nothing like that is present. You simply have to hope for the best.
But, you might think, at least once you HAVE learned about an Abnormality, interacting with it won't be much trouble. And you'd be right. However, the game's method of counteracting this is...interesting, at best. As the game progresses, combat events called Ordeals - which rapidly become unavoidable - plague your facility. These Ordeals are equivalent to an Abnormality escaping - something which the game insists, quite rightly, that you avoid at all costs - and are also entirely random. Some are easy. Some are all but unbeatable. And there's nothing you can do to affect which you'll get.
In addition to all of this, the game forces you along at a breakneck pace. Every day, you get a new Abnormality, which must be studied and worked with before the next day. Every day, you have no choice but to expand your facility, requiring resources to be stretched as thin as possible to keep it fully staffed, much less capable of dealing with Ordeals. You're frantically playing catch-up the entire time, trying to have even the slightest balance as obstacle after brutal obstacle is thrown your way.
And meeple death? Death is, in many situations, unavoidable, but always UTTERLY crippling. Hiring a new employee requires the use of currency, called LOB. This currency is also used to upgrade existing employees. But - in addition to the loss of a crucial worker - the penalty for employee death is that the already very limited LOB you're awarded at the end of the day is reduced. Meaning that having a meeple die makes it even harder to get another. May I remind you of the unavoidable, highly lethal combat events that occur daily. Not to mention that witnessing an employee die makes other, nearby employees go insane - something which often leads to more death, starting a cascade which can't be stopped.
The game does make some attempt to address this. At any time, you can restart the current day from scratch, or restart from a set checkpoint (which occurs every five days or so). However, much like the Ordeal events, this solution feels clunky and is rarely enjoyable - the only way to avoid character death is to reset over and over until all the numbers roll just right? Really? It quickly sucks any soul out of the game, transforming it from a management simulator into a game of balancing numbers, trying to keep ahead and fulfill the goals you've been given while constantly being provided with more and more blocks to progression and occasional victories that will disappear with the next reset.
Overall, I'd give Lobotomy Corporation a 5/10. It has a fun art style, interesting creatures, and an intriguing story and world. But the gameplay, which always has player enjoyment be its last priority, makes all of those features pale by comparison.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
A superb blend of the visual novel, management, and roguelelike genres!

[h1]Story[/h1]
I loved the story setup and gradual unraveling alongside the events happening in the factory itself. The characters, lore, and general worldbuilding were all intriguing and left many open questions that I hope are even further explored in the sequel (Library of Ruina). That is not to say the story was completely open-ended. I thought there was a concrete conclusion to this game itself which I thoroughly enjoyed even as it set up the sequel in the epilogue.

The story is short relative to the amount of gameplay time necessary to get the true ending. So, if you discover you do not enjoy the gameplay it is absolutely not worth the amount of gameplay required to see the full story unfold.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
I thought the combination of management with roguelike mechanics and some permanence (you keep a few things such as abnormality information and equipment across resets) made for a really fun experience. The retry/reset mechanisms also provided a ton of room for freely experimenting. The "boss" and "mini-boss" fights were all unique and provided some clever uses of all the game mechanics which could really require you to change up your strategy and adapt.

I do not typically play management games. I actually discovered this one due to finding out it was the prequel to Ruina. I have not yet played Ruina since I decided to play them in order. However, I do at least know the gameplay is completely different (card-based vs. management). 

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
The OST seemed quite small, but it blended really well into the ambiance considering it is on loop throughout most of the playthrough as you navigate each day. I never felt distracted or annoyed by any song despite hearing them countless times.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The graphics can look outright silly and goofy at times, especially considering the dark events going on. There is an in-story explanation for why things look the way they do and you even get glimpses of what things really look like as you progress.

That said, I thought the general graphics and designs were fine in the grand scheme of things. The more "artistic" pieces littered throughout which depicted the true gritty reality looked phenomenal!

[h1]Cons[/h1]
There was one big con which I thought was worth mentioning: some of the UI can be [i]too[/i] vague or lacking in certain information. Here is a non-exhaustive list of examples off the top of my head: 

1. The success percentage for each type of work does not show up anywhere in the in-game UI. I had to always look it up on the wiki if I wanted to know.

2. The game gives no indication of how many hits a weapon does per attack. A seemingly weak weapon might actually be really strong despite it showing low damage values because of a high number of hits per attack. The game only shows "attack speed" which is separate from number of hits per attack. I only discovered this one late into the game when I started checking the wiki.

3. There is no dashboard to easily check each agent's status, including shields. You can partially work around this one by selecting any unit and shuffling through the departments that way, although that view is lacking shield info or the ability to select an agent (as in the view you get when you click them).

I know some of the information limitations (especially agent statuses) may have been intentional and are part of the handicaps you get at times. Still, I wish they were more clearly visible when they were not intentionally being hidden as part of a challenge since information is a core part of the gameplay. The bright side is that the wiki is rich in information and makes it possible to get a lot of the missing in-game information easily.

One of the greatest games I'll probably ever play. Difficulty curve is probably nearly perfect in the sense that you're always completing some feat you imagined would be impossible 6 hours previous, and then doing so trivially another 6 hours after that. 

The only flaw this game has imho is the (sometimes) finicky real time combat controls - you are not able to direct which side of a room your 'units'(nuggets) should move to, and you must instead do so by directing them to an adjacent room and then canceling the move via another attack command so that they walk through an enemy then attack again. This is generally fine but there are some rooms that do not have an adjacent room to the left which makes things kinda annoying.
it hurts

I learned the Kabbalah, took a philosophy class, took a psychology class, and read an entire book of the bible in one incredibly manic night. The real joy of this game is in piecing together the story and then looking deeper to uncover what it's actually about. I don't like most video essays but this game is probably one of the few where looking into it to that extreme is warranted and one of the few pieces of media where it enhances the experience of playing it. I would recommend playing the first few days and then looking up the game's article on wikipedia, it has no spoilers but will point out one of the game's most obvious references and the one it commits the most to. The game's actual story is pretty good to but there's nothing like the feeling of falling down a rabbit hole this deep.

I hate this game, beyond measure. This game has made me cry several times, it has made me angry, mad, nearly break a keyboard, hate myself, hate this game, suffer, and wish for death as it would be kinder.

This game hates you beyond measure, it will screw you over in every possible way it can think of and delights in doing so. It will always be an uphill battle and almost never fair. Day 49 really makes me wanna tear my eyes out and put them into a blender, it would feel better then watching Day 49 happen. 

With that being said, one of my favorite games. The feeling of overcoming a challenge like this, the knowledge that you did it, knowing that you are better then the game, on that day, in that situation, is an amazing feeling. This game is an emotional roller coaster that I'm almost sad is over. But, there is energy to be harvested and abnormalities to be suppressed. Afterwards I will go and try to beat Library of Ruina. Lob Corp may be ending, but the story, nor the pain, is not over.

Welcome to the corporation, Manager.
Here you manage your team. generate energy for the world. Simple.
Things can go wrong will go wrong but nothing is too difficult for you to handle.
Remember your ultimate goal is to reach energy quota. Employee are expendable.

It is true this game suffer a case of micromanagement especially the difficult combat sequence.
"Employee are expendable" holds true except the contradiction here is that you need a high level employee to get the job done wether its for combat or day to day work. Which led to a grind that most managers will catch on quickly. 

Art direction is superb, everything goes together. I absolutely love this and the game itself isn't afraid showing the gruesome part of it. Sound is also great it complements the art style. Music ... oh boy another contradictory its like the game wants you, the manager to mess up and get the situation under control instead of taking an easy way out.

Gameplay has some learning curve but once understand it turns into a fight against the User Interface.
Micromanagement is there but macro is also present as some combat scenario discourage the use of big angry agent mob.
Feeling left out? The game will give you a tool to directly interact on your employee later as the game progress.

Minor spoiler tips. It is unrealistic to go through the whole game on the first playthrough. Holds very true on day 46-50. 
The game gives 4 ways for the manager to reset their progress 3 of which continue your progression.

A daily reset.
After everyday 5 reset.
All the way back to Day 1.
Use these to your advantage.

Last but not least the forsaken reset. Back to square one everything you've done, gone.

I adore this game quite a lot, its very charming and pretty brutal.
The overall theme is a depressing, unforgiving and lethal world but it does try to be a bit hopeful.
Pretty much you have to manage your facility as you gain more and more creatures to contain and you will need to trial by fire each one and you will 100% take casualties and later your entire facility will more often than not be in peril and RNG of which ones you get, with what, where and when can determine just how bad things really can get and let me tell you if your unlucky and still lacking strong E.G.O.(its the name of the gear, the name makes sense later) it can get BAD. Like my current facility is filled with things that can and will breach off each-other. 

Its actually has a big rouge-like element where you can reset to certain imprints or even the first day and keep your gear and research/upgrades (employees however are reverted/lost so screenshot the ones you like so you can recreate them)

From a few waifus to mostly freaks of nature, this game probably has quite a few of anomalies that may catch your eye in interest.
Certain combinations of abnormalities can fuck you really hard your 'first play-through' forcing you to reset early but i'm in my 1st 'reset to first day' play-through while running a "no death" policy where I will reset no matter who/how my agents (The controllable ones) die (This is way harder and way longer than just letting them die tbh) and I currently have a pretty freaking difficult facility and i'm still doing "just fine" so with a will there is a way but don't be afraid to reset it back to the first day(try to get as much gear as you can before that) as it can and WILL get much harder.

You will get pretty funny and unique EGOs like a powerful WAW sniper rifle that the agent wielding should be alone 24/7(kinda fitting) as he will shoot through everything in the room including the red paste across the floor of the poor squad that you accidentally grouped him with.(also fitting)

It does have some mods on the nexus and are pretty easy to install, and you can create your own character features like hair for example though a little annoying it seems.
Biggest complaint probably is performance as it.. runs really weird is the best way to describe it even with a performance mod.

So I think it personally sits at a 8.4/10


One last thing future run saving tip regarding the functions of a certain anomaly:
You may get an anomaly that is a red button DO NOT press it out the gate, don't think about it instead make sure to get its 'observation' via clicking on its 'details' tab a lot in 'deployment' first, but if you plan to see what it does face first I recommend taking all your gear off as that thing saves the game after you spam press it(not sure if its intentional either) as it grants its 'observation' which forces a save meaning all that gear your employees were wearing? Gone, no reset will fix it(It might be "safe" to press after getting its observation?). Spoiler you say? Very small but you would thank me for saving your gear. It does have cool effcts though and technically you can use its "save feature" beneficially.
Yea I spammed clicked it my first time I regret it, wasn't the worst problem(I didn't have hard to get event gear at the time) but holy fuck it was annoying

It is a tad time consuming to get 100% Upgrades and research.
Additionally this game has a sequel.

I have mixed feelings about this game. Wish there was a neutral review option.

The story and writing is great. Lots of abnormalities, each with their own little stories. The sound design and music is good too.

Gameplay is terrible, though.

You will need to restart in-game days and even entire playthroughs a lot, especially if going in blind. In the first few runs, you will not have much information to work with, and will have to resort to trial, error, and lots of failure to figure out the best way to manage what you've got. Restarting is major part of the core gameplay loop and is encouraged; it's even relevant to the plot. Rewinding to a recent checkpoint or even the start of a playthrough lets you keep the equipment, upgrades, and most importantly, the information gained from the previous runs.

The pacing is quite slow. Most of the game is spent sending your agents to work with abnormalities, waiting for them to reach the containment unit, waiting for them to finish their work, waiting for them to return back to their department's main room, and then waiting for them to heal before sending them out to work again. Even with 2x speed, this feels like a drag.

The worst part is that the optimal strategy involves grinding, by having your agents continue to work long after the workday is over to farm experience or gifts. This is further exacerbated by the fact that agents are not permanent (they can die and be lost forever, or lost when you start a new playthrough), and the fact that you can't check your leveling progress (only by ending the day can you see the stat increases). All that grinding, for a run that may or may not end in utter failure, does get tedious.

The game isn't very accessible either. Much of the text containing important information, like the stat requirements to equip an item or the notifications that inform you that yet another employee has died, are too small to read comfortably, with no option to change the font size.

There's also quite a few bugs caused by simple typo errors in the code, which to this day, have yet to be officially fixed, and need to be fixed by unofficial mods.

The only reason I still think this game is worth playing despite all its flaws, apart from the story, is the mods. While the game does not have Steam workshop support, there are numerous mods from various other sites, adding quite a bit of content and quality of life features.

Honestly though, their next game, Library of Ruina, is much, much better, and I recommend playing that instead before deciding if you want to get this. If you still want to play this though, for the sake of your IRL Sanity Points, I suggest at least getting a few QoL/bugfix mods, such as the automatic work macro mod, and once you're familiar enough with the game, a game speed increasing mod.

Very good game. Amazing soundtrack

A very interesting concept for a management game.

Your task is to train your employees and use them to study and extract energy from a bunch of monsters. Each monster has its own particularities about how it should be handled, that, if not respected, will lead to a bunch of also particular penalties. This complexity is, I think, the point that makes this game stand out from others in its genre the most.
Apart from this, the setting and characters are quite exceptional, and the story is pretty good.
While most of the game is actually rather easy, it also provides some very hard challenges here and there, so overall I'd say the difficulty is satisfying.

In terms of defaults, I guess the worst point is how it doesn't manage to fully use its mechanical complexity. Ok, every monster is very particular. But in truth, most of the time, the game will allow you to ignore nearly all monsters to focus on the few most convenient ones, which, in my opinion, kind of defeats the point of implementing all those monsters and behaviors in the first place. I also can't help but wonder if being able to easily unlock the full explanation of how individual monsters work was a good idea or not. Perhaps letting the player study them themselves would have been a better idea? Maybe not. I don't know.
It is also somewhat buggy, though not overly so. In my entire playtime I had a single crash, and a few other minor problems.
Throughout the game, there are lots of downtime between the actual challenges, meant purely for grinding. This time investment is meant to make you more engaged and tense during difficulties, as every mistake will come with the risk of permanently losing the resources you've grinded for. I'll admit this might be a necessary evil when done in moderation, but I honestly think this game goes a bit too far into wasting your time.

Thankfully, there are a few mods out there that can help you tailor the experience to your liking. I would definitely recommend checking them out 10~20 hours into the game, to see if there are any that could fix whatever problem you might have with the game at that point.

Overall I loved the game, so I definitely recommend it, though I expect that it will not appeal to everyone.

[b]Lobotomy Corporation[/b] ~ Artificial Samsara
Difficulty: Gets increasingly difficult as you progress.
Length: It took me 130+ hours to get the true ending + secret ending.
Enjoyable?: Lobotomy Corporation isn't just a game about managing monsters, it's a story of redemption, a tale of overcoming the [i]samsara[/i]. My frustrations with the game mechanics became somewhat alleviated upon realizing how greatly intertwined they are with the story. I won't spoil too much.

The premise is basically this:
>On the surface, Lobotomy Corporation an energy producing company
>Energy is extracted from working with "abnormalities". 
>Many abnormalities are harmful.
>Some can breach containment if mishandled or right conditions are met.

Depending on which abnormalities you select, you can make the game exponentially harder for yourself. Thankfully, the game gives you options to make it easier for yourself:
    1. Unlimited day resets. 
    2. Roll back to a checkpoint day. 
    3. If things are [i]really bad[/i], you could always roll back to day 1. 
For the last two options, any abnormality information, department upgrades, and EGO equipment you have at the time will be saved. 

You will start off with one department and will unlock more departments as you progress through the game. Each department has missions. Completing these missions gives you permanent upgrades and pieces of the story. If you're aiming for the true ending + secret ending, it requires completing all missions + 100% abnormality dissolution (full observation level of all abnormalities, exception of a few).

Good luck!

This game is weird and punishing but god, I love it a lot.

It has some pretty bad sudden difficulty humps but the writing is top notch, the art is great, the music is great, and the gameplay is really fun and addictive.

It's not the kind of game I'd recommend to everyone. It can definitely get frustrating at times. You can end up in unwinnable scenarios, or scenarios that are just so difficult to juggle that you don't even want to try and will have to rewind over. If you're okay with the concept of restarting your run a few times due to either your own screwups or wanting to play more optimally, and you're the kind of person who likes to micromanage the crap out of everything, play Lobcorp. It's a very unique, cool game.

I recommend you consider using mods - I used one for showing more exact stats, personally.
A very good monster management simulator! Although a bit pricey, it is very fun and challenging, so it's not your average easy game! Be careful!
amazing game but fuck this game

DAY SEVEN: I have this figured out after a week of managing this trainwreck. Sometimes an interaction with a new monster kills someone unexpectedly, so I re-do the day and have no fatalities the second time around, probably completing a research project while I'm at it. Employees level up slowly, but if I'm wise about it I can keep my top brass alive and productive. Challenging at times, surely, but I'm looking forward to seeing the story unfold. This game is pretty all right.

DAY TWENTY-ONE: I have spent hours in real time replaying one day in the hopes that even a single employee lives, though I know if I lose one of my senior hires I'm not sure what kind of hope I have to contain many of my research subjects. By the time I've met half of my energy quota I have a maneating mecha-dog, white noise that makes you insane, a bunch of buzzsaw robots, some kind of opium poppy pleasure god, a bulletproof shapeshifting meat golem, and some psycho with a hand cannon and a scythe loose in the hallways. People are screaming and being blown to bloody pulps by the dozens. A magical girl teleports into a hallway full of fleeing employees to help, killing many instantly before becoming a hysterical snake chimera as a giant aggressive swan-man materializes on the floor below. The company hasn't even opened all of its wings yet, undoubtedly full of further horrors. There are four unfinished research projects I can't hope to complete a single one of today without great luck, let alone two. Only the dead can know peace from this evil. This game rules.

In all seriousness:
>>>If there were translation issues, they have since been resolved- beyond the occasional weird grammar choice, the English language version is very comprehensible.
>>>There is the occasional visual glitch. Masks slide a bit off of a character's model, people listed as dead in the UI are just standing in the cell where they supposedly expired. The numerical level of the "temperance" stat is cut off in the weapon/armor selection menus, so I'll have to back up to identify that bit. It's not really an issue- but what is is the glitch that seems to make moving and zooming into the map impossible if you open the manager's guide from the pause menu, which pretty much forces you to restart the day. Other than that, I haven't run into anything egregious bug-wise yet.
>>>Sound and most of the art design is great in this. Every anomaly has its own encyclopedia portrait, character model (sometimes multiple...) and  suite of sound effects/ambient noise that will become louder or more distant depending on your proximity to the cell and if it is contained or not. There's a musical track for every situation, from choosing your next monster to watching everything go up in flames in various increments.
>>>UI does leave something to be desired. When a lot of stuff is happening in a hallway, it can be hard to select or even identify individual employees since they're all often stacked on top of each other during combat. It's easier to get the hang of the clunky selection situation when everything isn't going wrong, but obviously things go wrong. A lot. All at once. I end up using the click-and-drag mass selection to just move entire departments to handle stuff a lot, which probably isn't a sound strat by now, but I don't enjoy fiddling with finding and selecting individual employees. They're basically all just the same silhouette with different hair, expressions, and outfits, unable to be distinguished by department unless you select them or can see the tiny colored armband, which can get even more confusing when the random npc drones (same character silhouette) milling about get mixed up in the crowd and start littering the halls as corpses.

This game is HARD. It has a surprising amount of depth, but there is also an element of randomness that can make or break the periods between "memory repository" saves that happen every week or so. Whenever you acquire new research subjects you pick from three mystery choices identified only by some cryptic phrase and a number, and frequently end up accidentally killing people or setting monsters loose as you attempt to research how to handle them properly. The discovery of new details for every unique anomaly is part of the fun, but you will fucking suffer for it by the time you've fully expanded the first of the facility's three levels. It's similar to Darkest Dungeon in that you will hire a lot of cannon fodder and hope to Christ that your favorite senior hires make it through the grinder, but EVEN MORE punishing. The importance of having experienced people to handle the more dangerous stuff and the steep price of new hires, paid from the same pool of points that will improve your extant employees' training, makes losing someone a tragedy despite how inevitable it is.

[TL;DR]
This isn't so much a management simulator as it is an exercise in disaster mitigation framed by an explorative story and roguelite gameplay. It'll stress you out and stretch your brain thinner and thinner as the departments start piling on, though the goals of your daily routine don't change much. Still, the depth of story is as weirdly entrancing as the SCP Foundation content that inspired it. Haven't even finished it yet, but I'm prepared to keep smashing my head against this wall until I uncover the full narrative behind the drywall. If that's up your alley, LobCorp is worth the price of admission, especially for the hours of horrible, terrible, no-good fun you'll get out of it for 25 bucks. You'll get your money's worth by the time you rage quit.

Lobotomy cope

What you will need: a lot of time on your hands and a high tolerance for BS, RNG-based difficulty, occasional bugs, incredibly punishing mistakes, repetition, and grinding, and potentially a guide to understand the objectives necessary to get the desired ending

What you will get: a demonically creative, deceptively story-rich, and obsessively complex game you can have consume your life for weeks and weeks and weeks, the propensity to get attached to both the story's characters and your own employees, and an introduction to the Project Moon universe, which is well worth your time

I highly, highly recommend Lobotomy Corporation if this sounds like your speed - for some, it may not be worth taking the job, but if it piques your interest - good luck, manager!
