It's scary to look into a cell and see an abnormality. It's scarier to look into a cell and see Nothing There.

This game hates you.

No, really. It hates you. It hates your guts, it hates your attempts, it will chew you up because you decided to take in a new Abnormality (Totally Not SCP), send one of your agents in, and 30 seconds later, wonder why it mutated into a middle-tier slime that's currently infecting others and cascading into your 5th reset of the hour.

And when the hooks are in deep enough? You shrug it off. You reset. You start seeing your agents as disposable beings that are just there to survive until the next bit. You get to the next day with 3 dead. This is a good thing. 3 dead is easily replaceable. Dead people are replacable.

You watch someone grow for 10 days. Level 4. Researching the higher tier monsters. You screw up. You see them immediately die because the roulette hated them enough that they were chosen for a sacrifice to an Abnormality that hits way above your paygrade. You wonder if you can save them. You decide not to. You hit a wall. No matter what, this next part is impossible. Reset upon reset. A Memory Imprint a few days back; something's stopping, you're not lucky enough the list goes on.

That's fine. Day 1 reset. You keep the knowledge of the Abnormalities you researched. Certain meta tidbits are preserved. You go again. Try a few new ones. Fall back on the ones that you know won't screw you over. Repeat. And again. 

The game is jank. The game has questionable elements. The game has a few Missing Staircase things and Abnormalities that deliberately kick you in the nuts while you're down. The game's translation could stand to have stronger character voices, a clearer emphasis on how you're supposed to take this game, a combat system micro that isn't so finicky, on and on and on. It's the product of a failed kickstarter that somehow made it to the light of day in all its flawed glory.

And it works. The brainworms hit me. Even when every later day ended with a sense of dread at what's coming next, what the plot wishes to give, what the characters want to do, even when it'd be better to close it and relax...The agents get prepped. The Abnormalities are extracted. And the days go on.

What it gets right is the feeling. It has an atmosphere in mind, something intertwining directly back to the setting, the plot, the reason you're in L Corp in the first place, doing all this while an AI directs you again and again and again. It's the ludonarrative aspect that's the true king here, and your enjoyment of this is entirely predicated on understanding what the game wants you to feel and how much you buy into it. The gameplay and stress work so well with the plot that leaving it out for a plot video is a disservice. 

It's hard to emphasize how much this game gets right in terms of gameplay and plot working together without spoiling stuff. The barest knowledge is that you're there for a reason. There's a reason why the protagonist doesn't up and quit.

If it's too hard, mod it. Zero shame. The game is tough as nails. Get stuff from Nexus Mods. Super Agents (It will not save you). Infinite Points. Learn when your own wellbeing is better than cracking against this wall of a game and break it down with the mods to experience the gameplay interplay with the story at hand. The mods will not make this a 100% cakewalk, but it'll lessen some of the more demanding aspects...and not all of it. 

tldr Drakengard of Management Sims, mod it once you've hit your own personal wall, and get the true ending
watch the 100% True Ending on youtube afterwards, unless you want to go and roll for every Abnormality and learn about them all

So many bad gameplay decisions. So many things just instantly kill you with absolutely no indication they do. Entirely luck based, but not in a good way. This game actively discourages you from learning on your own, instead requiring you to have the wiki open at all times.
This would be fine, if the game TOLD you why you were killed instead of requiring you to get instantly killed first, before using the points you get to find out why you died.

Fortitude too low? You just lost someone.
Unlucky? You just lost someone.
Mercury in retrograde? Your entire force dies because of an event.

Do not purchase. I am serious.
If you are looking for a management game, there are ones that are skill based out there. 
This game is not.

If you do not heed my warning, then use the wiki at all times to make sure that you don't get instantly killed by something stupid that you could have absolutely no way of knowing otherwise.

Talking about Lobotomy Corp without spoiling anything is tough, so I made a list of positives and negatives to quickly sum up if you should get the game.

Get the game if you:
-Like a solid management-sim game with an SCP-like theme.
-Simple but stylized art that sets the game apart from others.
-A soundtrack that highlights a working day's progress (including horrible mistakes).
-A story that has a cast of really memorable characters, actually explains several core gameplay mechanics, and continually gut-punches your emotions as the plot develops.

Don't get the game if you:
-Are easily stressed in sim games and are not looking to change that; the game can feel [b]very[/b] overwhelming to 1st timers in management sims by the halfway point.
-Are turned-off by unorthodox art and UI styles; the visuals and menu systems are far from perfect, so I can see how some people can get frustrated from just looking at the game.

Thank you for making an amazing experience, Project Moon!

Amazing game, but tough to widely recommend. I will try my best to write about what I consider the features that this game shines best and might interest others.

The story, its characters and the world they live in, its an amazing experience exploring aspects of humanity as honest as it can be. This is the harder aspect to recommend avoiding spoilers, but also the most satisfying in my experience. The game builds up slowly, and gives no sign of being anything out of the ordinary for a good bunch of scenes, and suddenly it just all connects and there is no stop to wanting to know what is going on and how it will end.

(If its any clue that the writers are into something, day 1, [spoiler] they throw at you the terms Sephira and Malkuth and there is an obvious graph resembling an inverted tree of life on the department. [/spoiler])

The world building within itself is great, and its later further developed by the direct sequel Library of Ruina and the side story comics released. 

Its genre is very niche, a facility management game as the core gameplay. Depending on experience and certain abnormalities currently on the facility this aspect of the game can be overwhelming or very simple. 

A big challenge from this game is figuring out how abnormalities work, derived from how they look, the obscure lore they come with or other strange patterns they might show. As many would claim that the abnormalities are what make the game reach ridiculous levels of difficulty, its not a reason to fear picking it up due to the Memory Repository system, which lets you weed out abnormalities you do not wish to work on your current run, serving also as check point every 5 days ingame, reducing the difficulty by a whole lot if handled properly.

The game rewards restarting from day 1, you keep research levels, observations on abnormalities and certain events that happen during the story. Had a bad time? shake it off, learn from the experience and get ready to go back in next time.

The plague doctor will not help you, only make you cry.

What this game did that really stood out for me is meshing the gameplay with the story and setting for an incredible storytelling experience. A non spoilery example of this would be that the game frequently brings up how employees are constantly being killed in the facility, and as the game progresses you will pretty much inevitably become more and more comfortable sacrificing your employees lives for minimal gain. This type of stuff about the game really helps add weight to the story in a way only games can, and I wish more games made this part of the core of their design philosophy.


However, I find it hard to recommend this game in general due to the fact that this game is not only incredibly long but also in my experience the first ~10 hours or so of the game were not all that engaging. The game can be very slow and the appeal of the gameplay (which is essentially figuring out the rules of how to contain/deal with these spooky/funny monsters) is not immediately obvious. My best shot at explaining why I and so many people like the gameplay comes down to the really creative designs of the abnormalities (in terms of not only gameplay but visuals and lore) which can make obtaining information about them quite fun, and also once you start getting to the mid game you will have abnormalities that can interact with each other in interesting (or infuriating) ways which really forces you to evolve your strategies as the game progresses. 

Another interesting point about this is game is that while the early game is easy and peaceful, this game quickly starts putting larger and larger obstacles in front of the player to the point where it can feel daunting or even overwhelming. I actually really love this about this game because the difficulty is so unique, these obstacles are less often a numbers or rng contest and more so a change in how you have to play the game, and its so incredibly refreshing. This makes the obstacles all feel fair and unique not to mention super satisfying to overcome.

What can I say about Lobotomy Corporation that hasn't already been said? It's probably one of my favorite games. It perfectly scratches that itch in my brain - the one that loves management simulators, and the one that loves brutal difficulty. I've spent countless hours perfecting facilities, getting equipment, and crashing and burning horribly due to my own inadequacy. I hate this game. I love this game. Tales of woe paint the walls of this place.

If you love learning by bashing your skull against the wall, this game will capture your heart. It will capture it too hard. It will crush you in its iron jaws, and you will smile.

I had recently acquired a new Beast, whom I quickly was able to deduce became irritated as the overload counter increased. It inevitably escaped, and though quite tough, I could recontain it with my well-equipped staff. She, however, on her way out, did kill several lackeys, and thus irritated another entity, and it breached as well. This one, harder to deal with, but not insurmountable. Once the first was dealt with, the second was dispatched as well. Alas! The third act of this story led with it another abnormality, who raised hell when things escaped. This one, not so quickly dispatched. It was a beautiful falling domino of my own creation.

On the other end of the spectrum, however, was Frank. Frank was a boring, low-grade agent, whom I hired for the fate of certain death against something I didn't understand. Frank, however, did not die. He lived against that thing through luck. And through madness, through nightmarish events, through it all, Frank lived on, wearing nothing but a suit and wielding nothing but a baton. He got himself a nice promotion, fantastic gear, and retired to the upper levels for an easy career beating down weak anomalies.

Fortune favors the bold and the foolhardy alike. If you don't know anything about this game, and you've played management simulators and gotten bored from the ease of it, or if maybe you like Darkest Dungeon, give this a try. It might stick. It might not. Either way, Project Moon is a very interesting studio that I'm happy to follow in their future endeavors.

But I'll resurrect you, one last time, the original five, to complete the last day together, and my last day as manager. It's been fun.)

THE TRUE REVIEW OF THE GAME:

After 184 hours of playing this game, it has quickly become one of my favorite games of all time. The above was just a joke review for my entertainment but I think this game deserves something heartfelt. There are three things that I think this game does a great job at and that make it worthwhile.

SYMBOLISM: This game is so much more than it is at a surface level. The story is quite understandable, I'm sure if you went back and watched every cutscene you could put two and two together. But take a step back and try searching up the etymology of some of the words, the Sefirot, the names of the Sefirot, the Seed of Life, the names of A, the names of the abnormalities, what do they actually mean? This game is very symbolic and the message it delivers is so much more profound when you know where its inspirations come from.

MECHANICS DON'T GROW OLD: If there's one thing to complain about in games with many mechanics is that the way you play the game becomes obsolete once reaching the endgame. Mechanics that you would once use in the beginning of the game are replaced by overpowered endgame gear or abilities that leave those tutorial mechanics without purpose. This game does it different, if anything, it makes you consider more mechanics and expands on mechanics the more you play the game. Things like the stat level of your employees when working on certain abnormalities, the time it takes, if they're hurt or not, how many employees die in the facility, I mean, what do you think the point of the Sephirah meltdowns were? Completing each one added onto your mechanics, and benefited you. I mean, control team's mission reward literally establishes the mechanics you use to play the game for the REST of the game. That is, being able to see your employee HP/SP, speeding up the game, and having the ability to send employees to work in other departments.

THE GAMEPLAY COMPLIMENTS THE STORY: This one is awesome. I can't say if Project Moon made the gameplay compliment the story, or the story compliment the gameplay, but it goes both ways. The cognition filter gives the developers to make the game look cartoony and friendly, and it misleads you, you later grow to understand that this is a very fucked place. Even abnormalities like CENSORED take the cognition filter to a next level. The reason you're able to retry days and go back to a memory repository is all a part of the lore as well, it's very interesting when a game does that.

Ultimately, hats off to Project Moon, my journey with this game was a fun one, and I recommend it to anyone. Though, this is just one chapter of my journey, not the end of my story. So I must turn to the next title, Library of Ruina; this was one hell of a game.

This is the gateway drug for Project Moon games, and each characteristic of this game that you love is expanded upon in their series in this universe. The mystery only grows as more is revealed in LoR and trailers for LC (Limbus company), the gameplay becomes less random and more complex, the music (and I know this sounds nuts) gets BETTER. This game is like trying to get water from a cactus and while that can be painful at times; it's an amazing feeling to drink from the fruits of your labors. If you ever truly get stuck there's no shame in looking at the wiki, but only ever do it if you've tried to figure something out at least a few times. 

If you even remotely think this game is fun, get through the malding and you'll have a key to one of the best crafted universes I have ever experienced.

Now, to say that this game's rating is complicated is a bit of an understatement.

The game's story is phenomenal, and truly builds up incredibly to it's sucessor, Library of Ruina.
However, the game itself is *very* rough around the edges. It is poorly optimized, and does have a few glitches here and there. The gameplay loop is also definitely not for everyone, but that couldn't be more false for the bossfights; as tension builds up and you're in a mad scramble trying to get everything together, until finally, the "day finished" window pops up, and you take a sigh of relief, as you take the next few days to collect some more E.G.O. before the next bossfight.

I recommend this games mostly for it's highs, as it is a game of incredible highs and pitiful lows, unfortunately. If you're not much into story and moreso like braindead gameplay, you should try Ruina instead then. But this game, has quite a bit to offer. I'd recommend modding it with BaseMod and getting Optimization Mod and whatever quality of life mods you may prefer after playing it a bit, since apparently there's an on-going trend of amazing Unity games being horribly optimized. (looking at you, Valheim)

Overall, I'd give this game a solid 8.8; The story is fantastically jaw-dropping, and had me going "what the f*ck" and "holy sh*t" at least 17 times with it's several twists and turns, and I personally enjoyed the gameplay, even if it's not for everyone, but the downsides of poor optimization and lack of polish at times is a bit too detrimental to the game itself at times.

If you think this game seems like your type, don't be too bothered by my warnings, and definitely go for it. It's quite an experience. But if it doesn't look like it, then try picking it up on a sale.

I'll break this down into positive and negative categories.Firstly the pros, the story is nice and engaging, ordeals prevent the game  from becoming to stale in a run. The soundtrack is nice and I never found myself getting annoyed by it for the entire time I was playing the game. The tutorial at least for my explained everything I needed to know nicely so when I was in the game nothing was too confusing. Some of the abnormalities have quite interesting mechanics and trying to see what works and what doesn't is part of the fun of the game! 
Secondly the cons this type of game certainly isn't for everyone, it can be quite grindy at times and in some cases you may even have to restart all over to day 1 because certain challenges are exponentially harder in certain conditions. In my run of the game I've also experienced a few bugs, such as an abnormality going invisible, an abnormality deciding to up and teleport when they should have no ability to do so, and an abnormality not going back into its containment after killing it and just staying there to list a few. Another thing to note is that this game tends to lag when certain events occur, my computer rarely ever lags for anything even games like valorant, apex, and overwatch on high fps yet this game dropped frames quite quickly, but asking some people there is supposedly a mod to assist in dealing with the lag.  The game can also be quite repetitive at times. 
Whether this game is for you or not leads to one major question: How much are you willing to fail, redoing things countless times to the point of lunacy, do you enjoy a type of game where all your progress can simply be gone by a fingers snap? If you like the challenge the game shouldn't be too bad for ya.

"There’s no feeling more intense than starting over. If you deleted your homework the day before it was due, as I have, or if you left your wallet at home and you have to go back after spending an hour in the commute. If you won some money at the casino, and then put all your winnings on red, but it came up black. If you got your best shirt dry-cleaned before a wedding, but then immediately dropped food on it. If you won an argument with a friend and then later discovered that they just returned to their original view, starting over is harder than starting up.

If you’re not ready for that, like you’ve already had a bad day, then what you’re about to go through might be too much. Feel free to go away and come back. I’ll be here."

This is quite possibly one of the most fun, yet grindy and hard, games i have played, ever.

The story, especially when paired with this game's sequel, Library of Ruina, is phenominal. The characters are all well written with each of them getting their own story arc. At the start everything is shrouded in mysteries which are revealed bit by bit, ending in a phenominal finale.
The gameplay is unique and unlike anything i have played before. You need to command employees to work with monsters to produce a certain amount of energy each day. Every monster, dubbed Abnormalities, will do horrible things if you mess up. You ll learn how to manage each and every one of them in order to exploit them, get better gear, upgrade employees and then get the next monster to add to the collection.

This game is a 9/10 for me. It has some flaws, but they dont bother me too much so i definitely recommend you to buy this game!

Want to hurt? Want to live in pain? Dive into a pool only to find yourself in the middle of the ocean during a storm? or well take care of monsters because that's cool and interesting... then this is the game for you.

The importance of trial and error rings true within this game. You won't understand these abnormalities at first, toiling around as you either get dealt a wave of destruction or minor annoyance to your facility. Managing these abnormalities to just pass another day. The gameplay of each day can range from 10 - 20 minutes to an hour or so of managing abnormalities, making sure nobody explodes into gorefests or the facility getting completely destroyed. Your employees (besides the clerks), items you acquire, and power you gained can be completely lost if you don't suppress and manage the problems that occur throughout your sessions. 

Each and every day ending and beginning with a new set of challenges and a story being told overtime of your past with the department heads around you. Uncovering a dark but hopeful story underneath it all for an epic climax and ending near the final days of the game. There will be hard obstacles in the way though, world-ending scenarios impeding your progress,  and large scale events that could ruin everything; However, in the essence of it all you need to overcome them. You have to endure the onslaught of pain. You got to keep moving and fight back. You must "Face the Fear" and "Build the Future."

You might be intimidated by the managerial nature of this game. You might be intimidated by the hardcore aspects of the learning curve. You might even think it's just SCP but anime.

You're wrong and I want you to try this game out. Just try it. It's amazing. A story and world of unique proportions. It's not just SCP anime, but Monsters Inc. - you use these weird things called Abnormalities to produce energy, but with employee fatality rates most readily compared to the early days of the Industrial Revolution. And you have a time machine to try again if you fuck up too badly. Anyone can win this game and 100% it, it's not about skill or your ability to fulfill your goals; it's about decision making and perseverance. Whether you choose to continue and learn, or stop and start over with the knowledge you gained committing time crimes.

Oh, and Library of Ruina is waiting for you once you decide you've had enough of this. And go read the other things from the developer, Project Moon. They even have webcomics and other media related to this series, and it's all amazing. Wonderful, even.

I loved it and had a lot of fun, but the game is hard and unforgiving. You need good gear to manage strong abnormalities (the SCPs), but to do so you need good gear. You retry the day a lot and even restart the entire run (You keep infos about the abnos, gear and quests progression).

Then there is the fighting. At the beginning you either ignore it or restart the day if something terrible escapes because its you need to micromanage you little agents, dodging attacks or you die.
At the end of the game, the combat is mandatory, meaning you have to manage things on timers, monsters with unique mechanics and needs while fighting oneshot Killerrobots, god delusions and whatever an Arbiter is. Gets very stressful and a slight mistake means having to restart 30 minutes of gameplay because everything spiraled out of control.

Then again, same with Spelunky, and here you keep progress at least.

So yeah, if you like all that, here is your next game!

Also, the story is great. F*ck Angela tho, I don't like her.

The game's nature of constant trial and error (which can be very time consuming) may make this game frustrating for some. The lengthy tutorial does offer a LOT of information for you to digest and I understood most of the game's mechanics by experiencing it, but I'd still argue that going through the tutorial is absolutely vital. If anyone's worried about the game eating up a lot of your time, there are a few quality of life mods on nexus that can be installed including macros and boosted chances of obtaining gifts, which I highly urge you to use in late game.

Restarting/resetting the game seems to be encouraged, and will make each run easier because of the accumulated gear and rewards from missions you've completed. The fact that you are able to pick which abnormalities you can introduce into your facility solely from a quote in their origin is a big part of the fun, or your demise....... The story (which is really great, by the way) is slowly unfolded through each day you complete and you are expected to piece it together. Please play Lobotomy Corporation before Ruina

When I first played this game, I had never played any type of management simulator game. For someone who has not played any games of that type, this was definitely a rough start, but I was drawn to this game by the SCP-like entities that you have to learn about through trial and error and dying (lots of dying). I am currently on my third restart because if you get unlucky this game will absolutely screw you over and spit you out. If you can handle the brutality that it can hand you and enjoy the reward of making discoveries and progressing, this game is for you. This game is definitely not for everyone, but I have enjoyed every anxiety-filled minute that I have spent in Lobotomy Corporation and would encourage anyone who is interested in management type games and SCPs to give it a try. If you aren't sure about how you would feel about this game, I would recommend waiting for it to go on sale before you buy it. Better to be down $10 than $25.

im an avid enjoyer of project moons shenanigans, and this was one of the first games ive encountered that they made. tbh ive heard about the second game a lot too (do check library of ruina out very cool) and people were telling me that you cant really understand the second game if you havent played lobotomy corp. 
in a basic form this game is has pretty complicated lore and difficult gameplay (if you arent really into trial and error and arent very patient), you get to manage abnormalities with your employees and collect energy from the monsters as you work with them, and most of them (if not all) have some sort of adverse effect behind them. the game gives you information on the the more you work, and if you dont unlock that information and mess up with an abnormality, youll risk something in some way. every abnormality is unique and has varying threats, from no risk at all to lovecraftian horror. you also have an advanced artificial intelligence guiding you named angela, and you get to meet other people along your journey as a manager. you expand on your department and unlock new skills, this game really encourages progress and its really worth it if you push through. its really unmotivating if you fail, but extremely relieving and rewarding when you succeed. 
unfortunately this game is quite buggy at times and laggy, sometimes an employee will die for no reason whatsoever and can only leave you to assume said employee simply spited the world and leave you hanging. this game isnt originally english either, sometimes the translation can be quite confusing and theres gonna be some tidbits of korean left over in the game. theres also depictions of gore and some horror, but everything is in a cartoonish style so its not too horrible, you are dealing with the unknown after all. the soundtrack is absolute FIRE, love when the facility is falling apart and a dj party is going on
i recommend this game strongly and its given me plenty of fun times and pain, project moon really did it with this one. through all the polishing and fixes this game went through its pretty nice to see it where it is right now

to put it simpy, scp foundation mangaging but 2. to put it properly, contain strange abnormal creatures and hope to god your employee with the only stats that can deal with the aleph tier abnormality doesnt get killed

This is the game that starts you in the world that ProjectMoon wants you to be in. It will be full of difficulty and suffering. Things will go wrong. They will go wrong in the worst way possible. If you don't see it happening, it means bad stuff is happening somewhere. After a short time playing it, I admit I cannot go much further without having a real breakdown. It was certainly fun, but I suffered more. If you are like me, you will reset the day a hundred, a thousand times over before reaching a perfect ending that I did not reach. I feel all people should at least try this game before moving to its much better and slightly more fair sequel. Will you suffer with me for the story, the world building, the characters and of course the music that haunts you after repeating so many times. To me it was worth it.

Best game I've ever played. No, I'm not lying here. The unique and interesting gameplay style, the trial and error aspect, the dystopian yet original and completely amazing lore behind the game, the art style, the characters, and especially the abnormalities are all perfectly sculpted into a universe that you can really get hooked on. Now I know, "but why is it an anime game" and I understand that those kinds of games get a bad rap (and often, they kind of deserve it) But this game isn't about art style. You could perceive this game in any way you want, It's not meant to be an anime style game. It's corporate greed atmosphere is grounded in reality more than I would like to admit. If you like SCP, cabin in the woods, control, warehouse 13, or basically anything about containing anomalous beings, this is absolutely the game for you. And If you're not into that stuff, it still is. Sure, the gameplay is complex and hard to learn, which is fair, but if you just take the time, you'll find that you pick up on the game loop really quick. Thank you, Project moon, for this absolute masterpiece of a game.

SCP Foundation Clone Management Sim! Would be enjoyable to people who like playing management simulators and RTS games!

P.S. This game is a roguelite!

The sort of game where you need the wiki open in one tab, a list of console commands in another, and multiple mods to wrangle it into anything approaching playable and fun. That or waste dozens of hours of grinding through some of the most frustrating, repetitive and obtuse gameplay I've ever had to suffer through.

Lobotomy Corporation is the kind of game that says "treat your minions as disposable", and then makes each one represent a massive investment of time and resources, encouraging the exact opposite gameplay the devs intend. It encourages resetting, but the unlocks you bring back with you are so incremental they might as well be non-existent. Quality of life features are minimal across the board - if there is something that annoys you in management games, it's most likely in here. Minion died? Well, we won't tell you why, how, or where, so good luck finding the body

But it's the only SCP manager sim I know of, so I'm stuck with it until something better comes along
A punishing game, but also super fun. Things will always be going wrong, but you will feel powerful as you triumph.
bad game

The gameplay loop of "collect energy" got repetitive REALLY quickly, but the "puzzles" and "boss fights," for lack of better terms, were incredibly rewarding to figure out, as well as figuring out how to properly use a dangerous abnormality. The story was incredible, the abnormalities are cool and creative (for the most part), and recognizing the less obvious fairytale abnormalities from the source material and the Jewish-mysticism religious themes that the game so heavily draws from made me feel educated and intelligent (as opposed to feeling like I knew a bunch of useless trivia).

A fantastic game I don't regret a single hour spent on, the main flaws being that once you 100% know what you're doing and don't have an immediate progression goal to work toward, the gameplay loop gets boring (meaning that it, in my opinion, has little replay value once you've 100%ed it), and the game is HORRIBLY optimized; once you get your middle layer departments, the game starts lagging like hell even on a machine that was high-end when it came out, which is mostly just annoying, although it becomes a serious issue near the endgame, particularly during [spoiler]a "boss fight" that involves a LOT of multitasking on a VERY tight timer, while unable to pause.[/spoiler]

Overall, amazing game, with the caveat that it's SUPER not for everyone and its particular brand of difficulty can be extremely frustrating if you're not very patient.
the women are the scariest in this game

Lobotomy Corporation (or LoboCorp) is a monster management game with similar themes to SCP. You manage a facility full of these Abnormalities and research them, extracting energy from them in the process. As time goes on, you get more and more with their own rules. Some of them are very deadly! Some are very helpful. Sometimes, they will escape and try to wreak havoc, and as such you will need to have your employees re-contain them.

The game can definitely be difficult at times, but it is very worth it for the games thoroughly engaging plot and interesting world. There is also a comic that released after it taking place during the events of the game— Wonderlab, which I recommend reading! (although it's not required by any means.)

Overall, a lot of this game is best experienced blind. The game features some rogue elements, like how resetting back to Day 1 keeps the research and gear you owned. I will be honest and say the game requires some willpower, but that's part of the experience. 

Good luck, Manager!

(its very good but very hard and if you aren't into trial and error it probably isn't for you. there's a lot of bugs that do not appear as though they are going to be fixed and while none of them are game breaking and many seasoned players may find it adds to the charm, it is very noticeable and occasionally frustrating. the game suffers from performance issues and crashing when played for extended periods of time and you can't save during a day so I would recommend closing and reopening the game between days if you intend to play for a long session. you will not be given information about the mechanics or preferences of the abnormalities or other threats you will deal with throughout the game and must figure it out for yourself through simply trying things and paying attention to the results - this is intentional and by design. despite all of this, if you enjoy management games, don't mind trial and error or loss of progress, and can tolerate cartoon violence and gore, lobotomy corporation is a hard recommend. the game's story holds a special place in my heart, but even if you are not too interested in story the cutscenes are usually not very long and the gameplay stands well on its own.)

The game is rather rough around the edges - the music doesn't transition very well, the UI is a bit of a pain to deal with, many of the game's systems are needlessly complicated or overexplained, controlling employees is annoying as they can be randomly deselected and it times overlap each other making selecting a specific one difficult, text is not in a consistent font size or alignment which bothers the hell out of me as someone in publishing, and even post-patch there are still some translation issues, though I suspect this is not nearly as bad as before.

Having said that, the game is so compelling that it is easy to look past all of these issues.

The SCP Foundation is one of the most interesting creative writing projects on the internet, so playing a game where you're effectively managing a SCP Foundation facility and trying to discover how to exploit and contain dangerous objects and entities is very interesting. From what I can tell, these are all original entities, not copies from the SCP Foundation, though they are just as interesting. This is great if you've read tonnes of SCP write ups already and are worried you'll have an 'unfair advantage' going in.

The game describes itself as a Roguelite, and while that's sort-of true, in reality you can play it how you like. You can play until you accidentally choose an entity you cannot handle or figure out or which kills all your staff, and start over, where you retain the gear you manufactured and the entity information you uncovered, allowing you to more quickly catch up to where you were. If you don't want to go back to the beginning, you can rewind to before you selected an entity, or simply retry the level. This flexibility makes it easier the play the game the way you want without being tempted to look up spoilers, which you really shouldn't do.

As you get further into the game, it gets increasingly complicated, with you needing to handle more and more entities at the same time. You'll need to take notes and pause regularly to handle it.

Overall very interesting game and a great SCP Foundation simulator, which could use a little polish.

This is an overall good review/thesis, but there is some criticism. Everything involving the story is great, but gameplay has two flaws which not everyone will experience equally. The first is that the game provides little to no advice on when or even why to restart, which left me and likely many other players futilely trying to progress when we should have cut our losses. In roguelites, which is what Lob Corp advertises itself as, you are forced to restart (by dying) after a relatively short amount of time due to a lack of skill/upgrades. But in this game, you get no clear indication on when to restart or how it will even benefit you. It's more akin to an idle game where you intentionally trade in your whole run for special upgrades, but in those cases it's very clear what benefit you receive and when progress has slowed down. You also invest a lot of time in your first few runs in Lob Corp which makes it doubly difficult to throw it all away. The end of my first run around day 37 was definitely the most frustrating and terrible experience I had with the game which I wouldn't have eventually resolved if I wasn't interested in the story. If loading the game or starting a new day fills you with a combination of apathy, dread, anxiety, or stress to the point which playing becomes unenjoyable, just restart or rewind. Pushing forward will not help you, and upgrades will eventually come which drastically speed up the early game for future runs. The game should have better emphasized the importance of restarting and completing missions by actually showing to you what it is you stand to gain, or at the very least not locking it behind a difficulty spike. After I came to this realization, the rest of the game was substantially more enjoyable and progress felt satisfying.

The second flaw is that combat is wonky and information within the game is sparse on how certain things work. This can be seen as a good thing because it somewhat simplifies combat and emphasizes broad decision making over precise strategy, but the system is very finicky and feels very unnatural when facing tougher foes. It can feel like you're trying to grapple with the game and even cheese it, but it's truly the intended way for it to work. Sometimes the game expects certain specific responses from the player which are not easily supported by the movement system, which can lead to irritating struggles that only feel difficult because you can't move agents precisely. Admittedly, this problem is much less severe and can be circumvented with proper preparation or luck, but this preparation can be deceptively difficult due to the other information that the game hides such as the mechanics behind work success rate and work xp. I suggest that toward the end of your playtime that you consult a wiki or guide for info or even use an info mod like I did, but this is quite late into the game and you can probably decide for yourself. It's definitely possible to enjoy most of the game blind, which I recommend. No matter what, the game is repetitive and rewards grinding, but the atmosphere keeps it from feeling monotonous.

So, this is a highly subjective thumbs down.

Because there’s some joy to be found in Lobotomy Corporation: catchy music, fun lore, a great sense of mystery in the core plot, gameplay that encourages experimentation. And, most importantly, all these elements mesh to create a darkly whimsical tone befitting the SCP nature of the game.

But the gameplay is so. incredibly. repetitive. You click an anomaly cell, you click one of four mechanically identical options, you click an employee, you wait for the results. Rinse, repeat x 100000. That’s the gameplay loop, occasionally broken up by some gear, stat optimization and by an escaping anomaly (which, for me, were either ‘super easy to contain’ or ‘all my employees die’ with no middle ground). I just couldn’t escape how much playing this game felt like wasting time. Which, yeah, video games. But usually it’s not so nakedly obvious, y’know?

But in this game, oh yeah, it is. In this game, for example, if you have the train anomaly and forget to send an employee there every 2 minutes, the train will kill all of your employees and you’ll have to restart the day (which can be a 20 minute endeavor). And in that restarted day, you’ll do the exact same things you did the first time - which is mostly the same stuff you did on the previous day and the day before that and the day before that. Or you’ll have the magical girl anomaly, which takes some finessing to keep contained. And you’ll inevitably mess it up, so she’ll escape and kill most of your employees, and you’ll restart the day and do the same exact stuff you did the previous day (minus your one mistake, you hope).

And after this occurs enough times, you start to think, Why am I playing this game? Really, why? Because you’re too tired to do something more productive, and you want to relax and you have free time to burn.

But Lobotomy Corporation is not a particularly relaxing game because there’s too many anomalies that require micro-management (which can quickly add up if you get many of these). Nor is it very rewarding. It doesn’t provide any aesthetic reward - no beautiful imagery or soundscapes. Its lore and story has some plusses, yeah, but they’re nothing compared to story-heavy AAA games or even most story-heavy indies. And its challenge isn’t a test of intellect so much as perseverance, meaning solving the mysteries of an anomaly generally requires brute force and repetition, rather than careful thought or puzzle solving.

Which, again, maybe all these complaints are purely subjective? Maybe they’re all features of the manager sim, and I just don’t like them?

So I think that’s what it comes down to. I wouldn’t recommend this to someone else unless they *REALLY* like either SCP stuff or manager sims. Or, ideally, both. For everyone else, there’s just so many other better games out there.

Continued playing of the has improved my opinion of the game somewhat, specifically that using a wiki, to whatever degree is applicable to you, greatly improved the experience.

It is important to personally manage the amount of trial and error discovery that is enjoyable vs aggravating for you. Going into it you can make blind choices which will effectively kill a run but you won't know that right away. It can be helpful to think of the reset to day x button, not retry day, as a "start a new run" rather than thinking of your entire progression as a single run. If you can get through 5 days in good shape you've "won" a run.

The story has grown evocative and I appreciate how it is told. I don't think it would land as well if you just watched all the cut scenes.

I still can't say I strictly recommend the game. It's not something that can be picked up and enjoyed out of the box and it doesn't tell you what you need to do to enjoy it but it can be enjoyed.

Final verdict. I think the time management and figuring out anomalies aspects of the game are good but the combat aspect is bad which brings the final opinion down on bad if you want to finish the game, if your fine with just playing around with the first 70% of the game it's pretty good.
this game is absolute suffering

I got Lobotomy Corporation because I was really interested in playing ProjectMoon's newer game Library of Ruina when I first saw it for sale (I might still) and I heard there were tie-ins and callbacks to this game in LoR and some of the players were saying "you won't get the full experience in LoR unless you play LC first." Ok, that's all well and good, I love a good bit of worldbuilding and lore. 

However, from what I have played of LC so far I can tell it is not the game for me and that it is going to be a huge time investment, time I do not have to play a game I am not fully enjoying. It's not the difficulty, I love difficult games. It's not the management genre, I play my fair share and I love games like Crusader Kings and the old Tycoon games and have nothing but respect for the greats of the genre (which many of them, like this game, aren't my thing). 

If you love management games and you love challenging games, this is worth your time to at least look into. The story and the gameplay mechanics unfold beautifully like a flower, each day more difficult than the last. I can't tell yet if the game is satirical or self-serious regarding management and the corporate mindset. The decisions you make are cartoonishly sociopathic but it's also totally in line with how a powerful large corporation operates. Either way I was able to set aside my contempt for this mindset IRL and laugh at this goofy power fantasy video game. As you progress each day, more characters are introduced and management gets more complicated as you have to hire more employees, train them, delegate tasks, and deal with new abnormalities and their weird behaviors. It gets real sweaty.

The abnormalities (monsters you harvest energy from) are varied and interesting, and sometimes funny. The ones you get are picked from 3 random boxes at the end of the day with cryptic flavor text that hints at what is inside. Death is inevitable, replaying days is inevitable. If you love fiddly little numbers and boxes and systems in your games this is gonna give you the biggest hard-on. The soundtrack is nothing but BANGERS, which is great because you're going to be staring at this thing for 100 hours at least from what I hear. 

So do I recommend it? Yes, but with the caveat that you really look into it and see if it is for you first because this is about as niche as it gets. I'll end this by saying I have nothing but respect for ProjectMoon and what they have done here. I feel like I gave Lobotomy Corporation a good old fashioned try but I'm going to set it aside. Thanks for reading.

A friend said "It's a good game but hard to recommend" and that sums it up  Lobotomy Corporation perfectly. 

For context, most of the games bought and played on Steam aren't actually finished, as a matter of fact, I can tell just by looking at the review playtimes that the vast majority of people haven't finished the game. If Lobotomy Corporation had achievements to track how many people actually finished the game I would not be surprised if the completion rate was less then 3%.

Why is this relevant? Because if you want a fun and kind of addicting simulation/management game for the first 10-30 hours, then this game is good! You definitely get value out of it for the 10 or so dollars it goes on sale for. The story is amazing, I almost cried several times throughout the game, the music is great as well, but...

If you want to actually FINISH the game, then be prepared for agony, it takes around 100-130+ hours to actually finish it, and that's not because the story is that long, as a matter of fact, all of the dialogue can be read back to back in around 30 minutes or less. The reason the game takes so long to beat is that the endgame is absolutely BRUTAL and will require AT LEAST 2-3 repeat runs and by the time you're on the third one the game definitely becomes a slog. I was going mad, I thought several times about quitting the game and leaving a bad review because it was getting really hard and I couldn't stand the thought of resetting it again or trying for another day. Nevertheless with some help I pulled through.

And it's worth it. The pay off is worth it, not gonna say much obviously but do not be afraid to get help or tips during the last ordeals if you're at your limit because you should see this game to the end if you've made to that far anyways. 

So yes, if you do want to get this game, just understand that the late game  is absolutely brutal and will require at minimum 100 hours to finish. 

It's not for everyone, but in order to build the future, you have to face the fear and the ordeals that come with it, and only then will your core meltdowns be suppressed with enough time.

Bought this game and finally beat it after roughly 230 hours. 
In short: This game is well worth the base price and has a long runtime, especially worth the asking price if you have a thing for management sims or RTS games.

The game seems deceptively simple at first and builds upon itself in clever ways. Many times the game has made me smile thinking, "I didn't think the game was capable of this". Very good game if you have a soft spot for games that defy expectations.

Cons:
-Very long runtime (200+ hours if not looking up wiki information)
-Faux-deep/profound writing on most characters that was personally quite grating after a while
-Gameplay can be considered "trial and error" in many instances.
-Somewhat outdated micromanagement control scheme (have to send units to different rooms/abnormalities to get them to move, cannot select individual units when stacked on top of eachother via HUD, etc.)
-There is tons of stuff to remember as you get to later days. Your ability to multi task and your memorization ability will surely be tested as you progress. It is possible to be forced to retry days in this manner as one minor thing can set an abnormality off, causing a chain reaction.

Pros:
-Very good writing, adequate reward for passing challenges and unlocking parts of the story
-Money spent to time played ratio is off the charts, very good value if on a budget as the game frequently goes on sale
-As mentioned before, the game is very good at surprising you or making you think "just what is this game?"
-Gameplay is relatively simple and easy to get into.

I do have more cons listed than pros as you can see, but some of them are much more nit-picky than others. Overall the game was well worth the price tag. Please give the game a shot if strategy games are anywhere on your radar.

A solid, challenging experience of trying to figure out what measures must be taken for the proper containment of otherworldly abnormalities. These abnormalities start out relatively harmless and simple, but as the game progresses and you expand deeper into the facility, more dangerous and complicated beings inhabit the halls. Truly enjoyable experience experimenting on each abnormality and watching my workers die as I inevitably send them to their deaths.

"I wonder if I do this he'll get eaten?" "Yup, he got eaten."

A word of warning, however- this game, if you wish to complete it, is mercilessly grindy. You'll be restarting your run often as you as a manager obtain new skills and abilities after certain points, and each time, it'll be a long journey back to where you came from. Near the end, after defeating a certain black haired boss, I had to convince myself to play through the multiple weeks to get back towards the end, replaying content with the now-familiar abnormalities. As a first time player, you're not going to know which box contains which horror, meaning that you can just get screwed from the outset if you're unfortunate enough. Watching friends play and seeing they got some particularly tough combinations from the start sucked.

Still, if you're up to the challenge, I'd recommend Lobotomy Corporation. I had a genuine good time feverishly scrambling and being surprised whenever something escaped containment and turned my people into bees or whatever. The story is told at a slow drip pace, but is intriguing enough to keep you coming back until the very end.

Lobotomy Corporation is a game I do not think I will ever forget. There are several moments in this game that hit such a legitimate harmony of music and emotional investment that they live in my head rent free and will most likely do so for many years. That being said the game is what I like to refer to as a "Korean Autism Management Simulation" in that the concept of repetition is so core to the gameplay loop that it has direct plot relevance. The game is easy to learn and gets gradually more insane with one of the most rewarding skill and power curves I can remember in gaming.

The game is extremely frustrating, this is a game where 100% completion is not optional, as there is no way to properly beat the game otherwise. I can guarantee you it will take you a minimum of 100/125 hours. Do not use Wikipedia for this game, do not research strategies. Experimentation and discovery is beyond core to the intended experience of the game. 

This review may not be the best one, or even a necessarily appetizing one, but in all honesty I love this game with all of my heart. I will never do a playthrough of this game again and I do not even recommend it to many of my friends. It's amazing, please buy it.

Also if you skip this game to play Library of Ruina, I will tear your soul from your body and I promise you will be fundamentally unable to understand several characters

While I do recommend the game, just know Lob Corp isn't for everyone.  The game can have frustrating luck at points that can kill even the best employees.  Also Lob Corp does go into some heavy themes with suicide being a huge one that if you are even a little sensitive to you shouldn't play (Bloodbath, one of the abnormalities, has a really bad quote regarding suicide).  However if you can look past these flaws you will find a game with a surprisingly good story in which you have to strategize for each day if you want to get the best out of the day.

3 years later edit: Gave the game another try. English translation is much better though the issue of starting in Japanese was still there. Most of the issue now is just weird capitalizations.

The gameplay was fine but felt simplistic. It was simultaneously extremely punishing while also having the ability to restart the day if things go wrong. It seems like those would go well together, but instead it makes some of the punishing parts feel arbitrary. Trying to learn which method to interact with a new anomaly can be really punishing(potentially resulting in the death of whomever you used or the anomaly escaping which may get even more people killed), but then you rewind and just try something else which makes the punishing part irrelevant.

If you're really into the idea of running an SCP-esque facility then the music is nice, the menu's are nicely stylized, and the gameplay isn't bad, it just felt like I had experienced most of what it was going to offer pretty quickly and it didn't seem like something I'd be interested in long term.

I can't play this game for too long periods of time because of the sheer number of casualties and body count  of my employees that seems to accumulate over time. Their screams and mangled bodies weigh heavy on my mind.
However, Lobotomy Corporation is an absolutely fascinating game! A management/roguelike(lite)/horror game that consistently manages to stress and astonish. A cute and somewhat basic art style for the grunts, clerks, and agents at your disposal, and hundreds of intricate well-made portraits and designed "Abnormalities" causes a delightful contrast for the mediocre and macabre.
Every time something goes right in this game, you are wrong. Look elsewhere in your facility.

No annoying notification noises for when something bad is happening, a bona-fide S-tier soundtrack, and many distinct sound cues between the abnormalities give massive credit to the team for their sound design.
Surprisingly deep customization for those same previously mentioned grunts, and only hints and a choice to decide what abnormality is coming soon to your facility not only keep you yourself as the manager on your toes, but provide many options to pick and choose favorites, both normalities and abnormals alike.
Along with a surprisingly lenient learning curve, a handful of RNG elements, a challenge mode, and the ability to skip dialogue lends an intense amount of replayability between saves and accepted defeats.

The game has also received many an update, from the "Legacy" version to the more updated and refined version that is defaulted when you purchase the game.

This game is a 10/10 at its best, and at its unfathomable worst, it is only an 8/10, perhaps 7/10 if management sims or roguelikes(lites) aren't your thing.

A genuine steal on sale, but still worth a purchase if any of the above interests you.
(no this is not an SCP game, but it's in a similar vein.)
Also the default language is South Korean, and I must recommend changing it from the settings. There is also a wikia for general tips or outright strategy.

Easily one of my favourite games of all time now. Bought it on a whim after seeing some fan characters, and I liked the looks of some of the main cast. I don't normally enjoy management sims but this was totally different.

It's a hard game. I still haven't beaten it. But doing my best to get through the later days and the challenges is such a thrill and incredibly rewarding. The soundtrack is wonderful (if drum and base is something you enjoy, although there are some very nice piano and jazzy tracks). There are subtle details that really add to the tone of the game (the shift in "oh no things are going wrong" in the 2nd warning theme versus the "its all over now" 3rd warning theme? masterful.) 

The story is a lot more than I expected. I was anticipating SCP clone "just do it because we can." Instead it's this story about grief, regret, and what does it take to forgive someone, if you even can? All wrapped up in a cute exterior (which has a lore explanation too!!! Get to day 10.) I love SCP, but I feel I actually care about the world this game is set in. And so much of the lore is hidden in dialogue or monster files (as you learn more about a creature, you can access it's story files. They are just as fun to read as playing the game!) It took putting the pieces together from multiple character dialogues to finally learn what a Sweeper is in the lore. Everything has a reason here. 

Watching the gameplay does not help to get a sense of the enjoyment, it really is one of those games you have to physically try and feel the stress for yourself. Although that one video on youtube of the "full qligoth meltdown" does give a taste of the monsters ahead, the number of deaths expected, and the three theme songs you will likely hear many, many times.

I cannot stress enough how much I enjoyed this game. No, it is not for everyone. It's a strange style of game that does have it's hiccups (and certain very detested monsters. Fuck you, Plague Tree.) However, it is a rich, interesting world with fun mechanics, great soundtrack, and hours of enjoyable stress. You will love your employees and try to keep your faves alive. Additionally, there is a sequel game (Library of Ruina), a webcomic (Wonderlab by Project Moon. It can be read standalone, but many concepts will make more sense playing the game), Light novels (Distortion Detective) and soon an app game (Limbus Company.)

4/10 -- Not very fun. 

Gameplay: Constantly grinding your Agents' XP so that they don't suck is very tedious; if you use mods to try to eliminate this problem, you'll quickly realize that the majority of the gameplay revolves around incrementing your employees' levels by clicking boxes that hover over bootleg SCPs. 

Additionally, many Abnormalities are not viable gameplay choices because they are poor at leveling the Agents' skills: for example, I wanted to pick Warm-hearted Woodsman, but I already had an Abnormality of the same class that trained my Agents' Temperance skill, so there was no point in choosing it, and I had to settle for a boring one.

Also, like most management games, the goal is to 'do everything right' and successfully end the day with as few casualties as possible. It turns out that 'doing everything right' is extremely easy to figure out and do, and what ends up happening is... well, nothing. Nothing happens. You click on boxes for the entire day, and since you avoided the obvious pitfalls and ridiculous insta-kill conditions, nothing happens. It's extremely dull, and avoiding that blandness requires: A.) the player to intentionally make mistakes during gameplay, or B.) the Abnormalities chosen having unfair or ridiculous abilities that allow them to force a mistake to occur (i.e., Queen of Hatred becoming harder to contain because the player is playing too well; Singing Machine instantly killing an Agent that is too fortuitous, etc.)

In short: 
- The most fundamental gameplay concept is grinding. If you do not find grinding fun, then avoid this game.
- Accessing much of the game's content is discouraged, because it doesn't aid the grinding process.
- If you play the game competently, nothing of note will occur; nothing special will happen outside of grinding.

This game is pain, yet I can never stop coming back. Lobotomy corporation is a tough as nails management game, but has an extremely satisfying feeling of progression. You start off with relatively harmless abnormalities to contain, but over time you'll find yourself dealing with objects with terrifying god like powers. 

You'll find yourself failing again and again as you learn the ins and outs of each abnormality in your facility. Abnormalities that may have seemed impossible to deal with first will eventually just become a simple part of your daily managerial routine, as they go from overrunning your entire facility, to eventually just becoming a minor bother. Nothing really beats that feeling of overcoming the creature that wiped your strongest units 10 times over. 

Do be warned though, Lobotomy Corp will still continue to throw everything at you as you develop your facility even further. You will fail, a lot, often by things you couldn't even foresee. If trial and error isn't your cup of tea you may want to give this game a pass.

However, if you love the idea of uncovering the powers and backstories of incredibly fascinating abnormalities, I do suggest picking this game up and going in completely blind. This game definitely benefits from having you not know a single thing about what you have to contain.

This recommendation comes with a lot of caveats. Now, I love the game, I think the story is amazing and the characters are great. If you love horror with a little comedy or comedy with a little horror this game hits the spot, but...

The caveats:
1) The end of the game ramps up the difficulty by magnitudes. If you're not prepared for the grind or for all the attempts lost to rng or looking away from a critical portion of the facility for a second, this may not be the game for you. There are guides for the harder bosses out there on the internet, but it can take some searching to find them (I recommend the game reddit for strategies if you need them). And if you're stuck on Binah's fight for two months like I was: [spoiler] Use the Backwards Clock once her Phase 2 starts. [/spoiler]

2) The translation is rough. The gist of it is there, and sometimes there's some clever plays on words, but the translator is obviously not a native English speaker. It's better than Google translate but be prepared for odd phrasing and typos. For the most part I had no problems, but the more surreal the plot and the more metaphysical the topic of discussion, the harder the script is to parse.

3) It's LONG, mostly as a result of the difficulty. I got through it by pecking at it slowly over a long period of time, but if you want to just play the game and move on to the next one in your library, I can't recommend it.

But if those caveats don't deter you and you stick through to the end, the emotional payoff is worth it. It's just not a game for everyone.

Edit 9/16/2020: The English translation has been entirely reworked since I posted this review originally and is much, much better. It is no longer an issue with the game.

A very unique experience. This game seems to be a simple management game at the surface, but it has a large amount of depth. The story is very interesting, and the drip feed as you progress through the game kept me invested, wanting to progress. There is a lot of trial and error, and the game is very unforgiving, but it does make for a very rewarding experience whenever you finally do overcome the obstacle in your path. It is clear that this game was made with a lot of passion, and while it isn't perfect, I thoroughly enjoyed my time with it. Its sequel, Library of Ruina, is without a doubt the best game I've ever played, and it is made so much better if you've played this game first. Project Moon is easily my favorite game developer.

Lobotomy Corporation is an amazing and unique little game. It has extremely good lore and great music, the gameplay is extremely challenging but rewarding when you learn how to survive the day. I won't discuss the plot, its great, but I will say that, while the gameplay is extremely fun it has a bit of jank that I know would turn some people off. This a great game if you want the SCP manager style game. However, expect chaos as this game goes 0-100!!!! I mean one slip and the entire mission fails and all your employees are dead.

It's like trying to manage a Site 19 outbreak with a cute AI telling you about the multiple human casualties that are currently happening on the second floor. Shit hits the fan, you laugh, you try again and maybe you restart from Day 1.

The game actively encourages you to restart from Day 1, actually. If you can't make it past a certain day, your items and knowledge carry over from saves, giving you more room to work with every reset.

despite the crushing guilt and dread you get when you one of your best employees is destructive as hell, but this is irresistibly close to being my favorite game of all time. the most unique concept i've ever seen in a game with super unforgiving mechanics but forgiving enough to get your hope sparked again, delving right back into hell.

This game is really fun! It's a combination of management game, roguelike and even RT strategy. The gameplay is really good for my taste - there is a lot of things to uncover and do, and all of the elements work well with each other. If you enjoy first hours of game, you'd enjoy the rest.

The interface is hard to wrap your head around initially but you get how to play surprisingly quickly, so after initial frustration it works pretty well.

The anomalies is my favorite part of the game. Some people cheat by reading wiki, but I personally enjoy uncovering features of every anomaly on my own. It's really nice and interesting, there are a lot of passion and unique ideas in every anomaly and you never know when you're going to pick one that will genocide your entire staff. It's even quite scary at times, despite graphics being so cute, because you never know what to expect and sometimes everything can be destroyed and get really bloody and gruesome from a single wrong decision. 

Can't say much about plot yet, since my progression through the game is really slow since I keep trying and erroring (I find it quite fun and satisfying!) but it looks really promising and the lore of the game is really interesting to get into too! Seems like it's going to be deeper than it seems so far!

I wanted to like this one, but the gameplay didn't work for me. Things that feel like basic gameplay mechanics (like being able to see character health, without which your agents appear to die at random) are gated behind unlocks that can take hours to reach. Learning more about the abominations is interesting and presumably the story was going somewhere, but the basic gameplay loop just isn't fun. Its attempt to include roguelite permadeath mechanics is so un-fun that it seems to recognize this and defaults to giving you the option to restart days or revert to a save point... but doing that is almost more punishment than trying to limp along with nearly no agents left, because the only real point of interest in a day is learning more about the abominations, which you've already done if you're repeating a day. There's no new interesting information, just a grind where you see what you've already seen before.

This is before you get into the "random event" mechanics that unavoidably flood your base with monsters. I got through 4 or 5 days of this mechanic before realizing the entire game was going to be a series of just getting all my guys murdered and either slogging through re-doing the same stuff or trying and failing to work my way back up. I give up. If I have any further interest in seeing where the game goes, I'll just look up a playthrough so I can skip all the grinding.

Lobotomy Corporation is, as the game's own summary says, a monster management game with heavy horror undertones and very much inspired by the SCP Foundation series. You take command as the leader of a research facility that's here to extract energy, and apparently to learn about these monsters. There's a lot of fun to be found when reading the descriptions of these Abnormalities (as the game calls them), and the story sections slowly clue you in very well on how things are going, [spoiler] unless you skip them for some reason >:( [/spoiler]

The game has been said to be frustratingly hard, and this is especially off putting (other than it being a different genre of game) to folks who were told to play this game first, then Library of Ruina simply because of the lore and story impacts. Personally, barely a few hours into my playthrough, I realised that I would definitely quit if I kept going for a 100% blind playthrough, so I just looked up not-plot relevant spoilers on how to deal with (some of) the Abnormalities when I became hardstuck. Now that I'm currently 70% into my playthrough, I feel like this is the right decision, however the game is still really hard asf lmao, as in you WILL be retrying multiple times, and this is by design. You're supposed to be discouraged and frustrated, but that makes success all the more sweeter.

Some people say discovering the quirks of each monster is part of the fun, but I can't really relate when it takes so long and there's so many monsters to figure out, and time is precious to me. Of course, some other folks don't like the minefield-esque system of discovery while also not liking having to look things up when they hit a wall because people say blind playthroughs are more "fun". That aside, there's also people who recommend you to simply just look up the story on Youtube. Personally I still find the management and expanding the facility addicting even though I ruin the "fun" part for myself, and the story bits still feel deserved and more enjoyable when I "worked" for it.

Overall I recommend the game part of this game for people who like management games, and completionists who want to experience this (soon to be trilogy) series by the books instead of just watching the story on Youtube (which is also fine. People have different amounts of free time available to invest in things they're not 100% sure are worth it). Might edit this review later once I'm done with the game or leave it as is.

p.s: [spoiler] child of the galaxy is the best abnormality, also don't hesitate to sacrifice your employees, despite how cutesy the game makes them look. [/spoiler]

-------------------------
After a few more hours
-------------------------

I'd like to admit to being an absolute coward. [spoiler] Gebura [/spoiler] made me a little too frustrated and [spoiler] Binah [/spoiler] finally really broke me. I read that the later days are EVEN WORSE, so I simply just gave up and watched the rest of the story on Youtube. Seeing how insane they got made me a little regretful but at the same time glad that I didn't have to deal with that shit lmao. That said...

I'd like to preface by saying that when people say the artstyle/music is good, they're obviously being subjective and there's no need to say that its their own opinion. But it is amazing, and I enjoyed enough of the soundtrack organically that I can appreciate a lot of the music tracks outside the game way more (even though on Youtube/Soundcloud you'll find that there's literal tens of them, there's a lot). The characters are very stylish and the whole Hebrew naming scheme in a lot of the game's lore is something I've never seen before, so it was a very fresh and cool experience to the usual anime stuff I've consumed lately.

I can't wait to hop on to Library of Ruina now, which I hear is "easier", needing less reaction time and management skills (which isn't my forte). It being a card game is a big bonus since I like theorycrafting in those. Knowing nothing about LoR, I still think I enjoyed a majority of my time spent with this game. If you like a well written story and expansive lore world building (both distinct things), you'll have a good time.

[h1]Disclaimer:[/h1]

[strike]The developers' primary language isn't English, this game was originally demo'd in Korean so there are going to be some slight grammatical errors here and there. They aren't severe enough to really detract from the game though.[/strike]

As of May 4, 2020 this no longer applies. The game received a high quality overhaul of the English translation, and the game reads much better now.

[h1]Welcome to Lobotomy Corporation, Administrator[/h1]

Lobotomy Corp is best described as a management / simulation game with perma-death. You're assigned as the administrator of a facility hosting [strike]SCPs[/strike] Abnormalities. Lobotomy Corp has developed technology to harvest "energy" from these Abnormalities as a saving grace for humanity. Sounds easy right? Well, not really.

Every Abnormality is unique and has its own fully fleshed out character. But, just like SCPs, Abnormalities can wreak havoc given the chance. As the administrator, not only is it your job to keep these Abnormalities happy, but it's also your job to keep your employees safe. Easier said than done, every employee comes with an array of stats that will detail how effectively and efficiently they can perform their job; whether their job be feeding an Abnormality or caving the head in of one of their fellow employees.

The game itself doesn't give you much to go on in determining exactly how to handle Abnormalities which does make the game a tad more difficult (i.e. what exactly having an employee perform a "consesus" with an Abnormality actually does). There's also several mechanics in the game that are left unexplained and up to the player to figure out. It's a bit intuitive and there's a bit of a learning curve.

Progression for story mode is divided into "days" with each day becoming progressively harder as new challenges continue to be added for the administrator to handle. At the start of each day you're allotted a number of employees who you can assign to each section of the facility to perform tasks for the abnormalities in that area. This adds an element of strategy to the game as the player is forced to divvy up exactly who he wants where to match the preferences of the Abnormalities, etc.

To actually complete a day, players are required to (at least in the early days) harvest a specific amount of energy from the Abnormalities in the facility. This is done by keeping all of the abnormalities in a good mood. Likewise, abnormalities in a terrible mood will also detract energy from the gauge, along with going berserk on the employees.

The game is fairly straightforward with a slight undertone of complexity which makes for a very interesting game overall. To add, the story also presents itself through the administrator's accompanying AI who drafts notes and details logs about ongoing events throughout the facility.

[h1]Tl;dr[/h1]

I'd definitely recommend buying this game if you're interested in management / simulation games. I haven't had any performance issues though that's likely because the game is a smaller management game produced in Unity.

I'd also highly encourage fans of SCP to check the game out.

This game is so amazing! I love researching all the little abnormalities and learning how to manage all of them at the same time. The main story is also pretty interesting.

Game has gameplay for 20 hours.

It's like Miitopia, but instead of giving your sprinkles to a Mii you shoot your employees.

Around Day 21 is where it starts to get good and hectic, especially when you complete the requirements for the mysterious "core suppression" you keep seeing. Monsters that were once harmless suddenly release other, deadlier monsters. And you might accidentally teach some of your employees that letting monsters out of their enclosures is noble. And you start to figure out each tiny monster type ("ordeals") needs to be dealt with in a specific way - some of the weakest "dawn" class ordeals become serious threats if you don't place kill teams in anticipation of them, and the second threat level - "noon" - can outright wipe entire departments in under three seconds even if all your dudes have max stats. I am not exaggerating, it will happen in less than three seconds even against those weaklings.

Other than that, it's got the usual relaxing and addictive management sim vibes. But also the heart-pounding nature of roguelikes and RTSs.

[b]Edit after 40 hours:[/b] All my clerks are going to die anyways, so I now spend several minutes a day activating their kill chips so they don't leave bodies, as helpful as those would be for my cannibalistic agents.
