The art style and violent twist caught my eye and when I saw the positive reviews I thought I was in for a fun time. I was wrong.

-The UI is a combination of uninformative and unintuitive. 
The only way to see your health and sanity of a worker is to click on a room that isn't being worked on.
If they are in a fight, you can't see anything. You can't even move them away because they will run back into battle. 
The dialog during the game can be several paragraphs but it only stays on the screen for 3-4 seconds. 
Because it's a 2d game your workers often stack on each other, making it frustrating to locate people and give them orders.

-Music
There is ONE song the entire game. Just one. And it plays on about 2 minute loop. It's a cute lofi beat at first but after the first 30 minutes you're going to want to just turn off the music completely. 

-Story
The main story is full of lengthy ambiguous dialog that doesn't seem to go anywhere and the vast majority of the time it has zero impact. I'll choose one option, restart, choose the other option and the NPC's say the same things. It's not interesting either. A lot of it is just filler talking about someone's nickname or berating another employee for asking for paper. 

-Gameplay
The strategy in this game is to just throw people at the entities and watch them die until you get enough 'energy' to unlock hidden information text then restart the day and try again. I don't like that type of gameplay. I want to lose because I did something wrong, not from 100% rng. The entire game is playable with just your mouse. There's no control setting because there's barely any controls.

-Conclusion
It's too bad because I really like base building games and colony sims. I hate this game though. I refunded it after 2 hours but I purchased it on sale a couple years later to try it again and I regret it. There was no point in this game that I thought it was fun. Out of the 300+ games in my library, this is the only game I hate with a passion. This really does feel like an expensive, low quality, mobile game that was ported to Steam.

I was expecting more from game with 94% positive reviews.  I like the concept, it is very original, however the game feels very unpolished to me + possibly targeted to audience with different taste.

Here is the list of things which annoy me too much to prevent me from enjoying the game further and deeper:
- It sometimes crashes to Win10
- You cannot see HP and SP (hit points and sanity points) of your employees unless you're assigning them to work from room menu
- visual novel style between days/missions - to my taste they talk too much about nothing - could be good for those with same taste as authors, for me it was neither interesting, nor funny
- too much text anywhere on screen which quickly pops up and some of it dissapears too quickly to dissapear - it's more confusing than interesting or fun to read
- weird and very long tutorial - reading manual (F1) was quicker and more informative, that one was good
- day time not limited - it feels weird that you can complete a day within a minute or grind for hours in one day..
- weird music which wore me down, I had to mute it
- when zoomeed out, names and quotes from employees are so small that you cannot read them
- also font size being scaled differently in different rooms screens and zooms is weird and hurts the readability more than it helps it..
- weird UI, unintuitive, but possibly you can get used to it
- bad overview of your employees, as zoomed out you cannot read their names well, or see them well.. You also cannot see their list to have good overview who's hurt or so..

These things can be okay to people with different taste than I do, so I am not saying it is a bad game. I just strongly do not recommend it to those with similar taste I have.

This is a game that is designed to not necessarily be won, but be PLAYED. If you decide to get into it, you will play it, a lot, because it is that kind of game. Other than the most basic of tutorials, the game is an exercise in failure. You will fail, you will fail a lot. At 100+ hours into the game I can't even begin to remember the number of times I have failed, restarted days, rewound weeks, started over from day one. And that is the point. You don't lose everything when you restart from the beginning, with each run you learn more about the creatures, the events, the rules that govern the game. With each run you should be able to progress further and further, and learn more and more about the facility you run, the world around you, and exactly what you are doing in this ungodly hell where sneezing at the wrong time can get half of your employees ruthlessly massacred by all manner of horrific contrivances.

This kind of game is not for everyone, if you are not willing to fail, to reach a dead end, and to start again, don't pick up this game. If you're willing to take the time the game asks of you however, you can find a surprisingly deep, involved, and fun experience.

I can't stress enough how much I love this game it quickly became one of my all time favourites.

If you can overcome these things and get used to how the game works it is a blast though. The music is great, the story is interesting and the character and monster design is amazing, in my opinion. I had exciting battles aganist apocalyptic creatures, forcing me to figure out strategies to finally beat them. One thing to note is that it is advertised as a rouge like but I don't think it fits that category. It does scratch the itch of a hard and replayable game. But it is lacking permadeath and procedural level generation. If you come in looking for those this will not be the game for you.

...Seriously, though, I genuinely adore this game, if the time I've spent playing it hasn't made that clear enough. Even though there are improvements that could be made, I overall find it charming and intriguing.

The gameplay is difficult and stressful. It's also punishing for careless mistakes and not paying attention to what specific Abnormalities mean. However,  the mechanics are rather easy to learn and understand, and you are rewarded for making the most of situations and planning accordingly. Knowing when to restart, how to effectively use your employees, and the gimmicks of Abnormalities will be your key to victory.

The main draw for me personally is the story. The store page doesn't really delve into the characters you meet and the lore of the world, but trust me when I say that it's deeper and more interesting than it seems. I don't want to risk spoiling anything, so all I will say is that the backstory for the corporation, as well as the gameplay itself, make it clear that a player character isn't necessarily a good person just because they're the protagonist.

Of course, the game could be improved. By mid to late-game, restarting runs began to feel tedious since there isn't much to do in early sections, and some parts literally don't work (that one welfare research...). While these weren't enough to dissuade me from liking this game, they still stuck out to me. 

Overall, though, I love this game a lot. Recommended for people who are into stressing themselves out over nuggets.

(also, if you were turned away by the jank translation, you'll probably be happy to know that the revamped version (which was released in 2020) is much, much better!)

Lobotomy Corporation is a litmus test for how much a person weighs innovation against their own toleration for jank. There is little derision in this sentiment, I truly think this game is creative enough to be worth a persons time. But compromises are going to need to be made to run the final gauntlet and reach the ending of this expansive and mystifying odyssey through a unique take on the dystopia genre. 

I don't want to say too much about the game, as its best to go in blind (although there is an issue with this in that the tutorial is godawful, Ill expand on this later), but the gist is that you are the new manager of an underground megacorp who extracts energy by sending in employees to interact with a variety of monsters, most of which fit into the "new weird" classification rather than your frankensteins and draculas of old. This is purely a management game, which is not a genre I am well versed in at all, but despite this I found myself falling into the groove of things fairly easily. Most of your time will be spent trying to mitigate complete disaster, usually at the cost of your miserable employees lives, who only put up with the grueling task of being thrown into rooms with nightmare machines  because its somehow even worse on the surface.. This might sound stressful, and in a way it is, but whats compelling is learning more about the monsters themselves, as the more you learn, the easier they become to manage, and each monster also provides unique armor and weapons to give to your employees if you work with them enough (there's also upwards of 80 of them)

Despite being fresh and unique down to its bones, I do not consider Lobotomy Corp to be a timeless game. The hope is that someone will one day take the ideas in this game and present it in a format that both respects the players time and has a better player onboarding process. THAT game would be timeless. My 175 hours of playtime spanned the course of 3 years, which included completely walking away from the game several times over. By the end of my final run, getting 100% and seeing the epilogue, I felt satisfied, emotional, and wanting to see more of this world. But every time I think of that number, 175 hours, I think about how the bulk of that time was spent grinding my employees, resetting the week; resetting the entire game, and I cant help but feel that there is a way to deliver the meat of what makes this game special in less than half of the time it currently demands.

I'd like to add here that not all people will take this long to beat the game, but I trudged through without the use of guides or wikis, and I honestly believe that's the best way to compliment the games mechanics. Going into every day having to manage  a new monster you know nothing about, one that could potentially throw your ever growing ecosystem of monsters into a cascading nightmare of violence and horror, is at the core of "Facing the Fear" so to speak. The highs are extremely high in this game, and its slow and creeping dread cultivates some of the most organic "Holy s***, oh god no" moments I've ever seen in the medium. 

The other issue (that unfortunately this game's also fantastic sequel suffers from) is its absolutely abysmal learning curve right out the gate. "Just read the damn Manual!" withstanding,  a bunch of still shot images hamfistedly explaining the myriad of this games systems is worsened by using an esoteric vocabulary for pretty much everything. Within the first 10 minutes, mechanics with monikers such as E.G.O, Enkaphlanktyn, Quiploth Counter and P.E boxes are thrown at you as if you are already extremely well versed in Jewish Mysticism. I imagine more than 70% of the people willing to try this game will be put off by how overwhelming this all is. Combine that with the fact that its best to look up as little as possible to truly immerse yourself in the game's mystery, and you've got yourself a deadly dichotomy, at least as far as player retention goes.

This issue comes back to that phrase I used earlier, "jank". There's more than a handful of places where the mechanical flow and quality of life of this game could be greatly improved upon. Even down to just naming conventions, for example, the 4 employee stats are named Fortitude, Prudence, Temperance and Justice, which are all improved by doing the equivalent work types on monsters: Instinct, Insight, Attachment, and Repression.  There's no reason for these stats and works to have different names besides flavor. Don't get me wrong, I'm all about going to flavor town, but not when it comes at the cost of unnecessary obfuscation. Some things also just straight out aren't explained, and I didn't even find out until over 100 hours in that you could highlight an employee and then right click on a monster to send just that employee to go work on it despite that employee not being in the same department. Its also never explained that the more damage from a monsters matching attack type the more you will gain exp of that specific stat. 

In the end it comes down to what you're willing to put up with for the payoff. This game is HARD, and attempts to put you in the fetal position every chance it gets. There's a few things you can do to help iron out the kinks, such as the "more information mod", which gives you actual percentage values for everything in the game instead of  generalized phrases suggesting your work chance success. And while I didn't use it myself (and now wish I had) there's a mod that increases your chance of getting ego gifts (unique cosmetic perks given at extremely low odds, like 1%), which I think would balance out the games absolutely brutal difficulty for a lot of people. 

This game will probably always be niche, all of Project Moons games might be unless they figure out how to teach their players their games. But if you can trudge through it all and take the time to learn the game inside and out, upon reaching the end you'll look back upon one of the most unique and memorable experiences the medium currently offers. 

Its a weird position for me to be in, because on paper I would never just recommend this game to anyone casually. But if you're the kind of person willing to make the dive, face the fear, and build the future, then definitely try it out. I think you'll know in the first 2 hours if its something you'll enjoy.

I wrote the Jeff Bezos joke 164 hours ago, just when I was starting Lobotomy Corp. After finally finishing the game and thinking about the experience, I feel the best way to describe Lobotomy Corp is a "blood diamond." 

Overall, I disliked most of the time I spent playing the game.

The game itself isn't very fun, it's a very micro-managing heavy game with not a lot of options to actually make the game entertaining; you unlock some options thought the game, but most of them are options that you should've had from the very start. 

The difficulty ramps up constantly, and the random anomalies make your choice almost worthless since when you first start the game you won't know the monster that gives you a nice HP boost from the one that fucks everyone and everything up, and you have no way to appease it because you need an Aleph(highest level) armor to even TRY to without your employee ripping his eyes out. So yeah, go back to your last checkpoint- Oh, that was today? Too bad, don't pick a fucking Aleph next time dipshit.

As I said, there's a lot of blood covering up this diamond. But underneath all this gunk, the diamond shines like a sun.

The story is captivating and is the main reason you're going to want to finish the day, for those sweet, sweet 30 seconds of juicy L O R E. Every new concept that is introduced is more interesting and intriguing than the last, some revelations can sound very abstract at first, but as the story goes on they become more concrete. The characters are also a huge highlight as they are all an absolute delight, even minor ones that don't show up very often(looking at you Myo). The world Project Moon has created is fascinating, and it's no wonder the sequel takes place in this same derelict wonderland.

Which makes it even more tragic that the game that accompanies this world is not as grand. At the end of the day I wholeheartedly recommend Lobotomy Corp, but only up to day 45(do the core supressions if you want) or hell, until you get tired of it; then go watch all the endings in Youtube. With Lobotomy Corp I feel I experienced a 12 hour game in 170 hours. I'm glad I played it though

Lobotomy Corporation is one of those games that give you high lethality deeply founded on randomness like it's a feature people will enjoy rather than something that will make people quickload every five minutes. No one has yet seemed to figure out that combining this with RPG mechanics means no one will be stupid enough to choose to lose their upgraded agents when the quickload button is right there.

The unfun lethality is further exacerbated by the fact that your initial interactions with all anomalies will be ENTIRELY a random gamble since there won't even be HINTS about what's effective or what makes them kill people. So every time you fire up a day, the first thing you'll probably do is bounce everyone off the new anomaly until they die, to unlock some info about it. Then reload the day and use the OOC knowledge from the day before to perfectly exploit said anomaly.

On top of that, the UI is kind of a cluttered mess, and some extremely basic shit, like being able to see your agents' health bars or accelerating time, are unlocked abilities. I have no idea what that's supposed to contribute to the game except annoying me, the player.

I would possibly also be more invested if the between-missions writing wasn't... I don't think I can even call it bad, it's just really generic, motivates me not at all.

The writing for the individual anomalies is nice, though, generally the art works well, and the soundtrack is really atmospheric. 

I would skip this game, personally.

For being a minefield, it's a neat game. Yes, it appeals to a certain niche of people who are into trial-and-error and likewise into discovery. There are plenty of times where you're going to have to restart your days, and you will not clear this game in the first couple of playthroughs, one playthough alone can net you up to 30 hours it's looking like. I haven't even cleared all of the missions yet, so it's looking like one of those games where consecutive playthroughs are necessary. Thankfully, there's enough RNG in the game to keep it interesting, though I can't help but wish there was a LOT more abnormalities to keep things fresh and not make one playthrough feel like another when you get into the late game.

First off, let me prefice this by saying I hate horror games. And my biggest fear was that this was, in fact, a horror game. So I told myself that, after seeing some videos, to give it a try but if it played the jumpscare deal, I would refund it. End result??? Look at the amount of time played.

I love the game, and I hear allot of talk about how the game is comparible to SCP Containment Breach, but I never played that. But the premise is as follows:  You are the new manager in Lobotomy Corp, and you job is to manage your employees and collect positive energy from monster, creatures and other abnormalities. But these abnormalities can kill your employees, and hell, even escape and murder a whole department.

Now, this game is build on the idea of save-scumming. Allot of people dont like that, but to me,every abnormality is a new puzzle to solve. Plus, the backstories on some of these abnormalities is absolutely fantastic. As a bit of a hobby writer myself, I love the amount of detail some of these stories have, and its a big reason I have been playing this game for so long.

All in all, this game isn't easy. But the challenge, the stories and the main storyline is what keeps me coming back. Especially now that the bad translation is fixed. Its worth every cent!!

This game is immensely frustrating to begin.  I have tried to start playing, and subsequently quit trying, three separate times since I bought this game years ago.  Now, on try four, I finally have enough of a grasp on the gameplay to allow myself to get hooked.  So why did I come back time and time again?  The story, the presentation, and the concept of the world do a fantastic job of drawing me in.  Something nutty is evidently going on, and I can't wait to find out what.  Fans of thinking about the moral implications of authority, technology, and servitude (as well as people that like SCP) need look no farther.

DO NOT SKIP THE TUTORIAL.  The tutorial has three parts before referring you to an "optional but highly recommended manual".  DO NOT PLAY WITHOUT READING THE MANUAL.  It will probably take you about half an hour to work through the tutorials and manuals, but if you are anything like me you will burn out long before you learn the game through osmosis otherwise.  If you get to the point where you understand how to manage the gameplay, this game has magical things to show you.

EDITED AFTER I FINISHED THE GAME:

A hundred hours later, I still love this game.   I'd never played a management game before, but I enjoyed myself and eagerly await the upcoming sequels.

That said, the gameplay in particular has some imperfections that lead to tedium and unnecessary player punishment (days take a long time to complete even at 2x speed, and starting from day 1 [which you'll do at least once to finish the game] takes away all of your employees you've spent literal days training).  FREE MODS FIX THESE PROBLEMS.  They don't even have to make the game easier or harm the vanilla experience.  Take a look at the popular ones and give this amazing game a go.

Interesting idea to research monsters and the like.  My guys for some reason keeps either going insane or die in the hallway outside of the containment unit.  Unfortunately I have no idea how to handle this situation as the tutorial didn't go over this and it sucks to keep retrying day after day and just wondering if I'm playing this game correctly.

This game is in a really weird spot for me. Aesthetic and story wise I absolutely love the game but everything else about the game is incredibly taxing to do. If you are a perfectionist like me you will have to restart every day several times to have the perfect outcome you want. 

The game even though is great is concept really lacks mechanics wise, so many things you should be able to easily do is provided to you in extremely runabout ways, for example your employees are subjugating an anomaly, they will just stand inside one another with no way of being able to see their health or sanity so you cannot pull them back, the only way to do this is to click on an anomaly and open up a sub menu that can only display around 5 employee's status at once, if you have employees from different departments fighting one anomaly you will constantly need to pause the game scroll in the sub menu to different departments and view their stats individually. This game could be so much more but feels very unpolished due to inconveniences like this that make the gameplay extremely taxing to do, at middle stages of the game depending on your luck the game turns into a micro management simulation that will absolutely suck the fun out of it.

The game is so simple but barely provides you the tools to deal with most of the inconveniences that should be fixed in a single click. Due to the unpolished gameplay that you can't really even fix with mods I cannot recommend you this game, it is very taxing and depleting to play and essentially turns into a "Monitor X anomaly every Y second to make sure they don't do Z."

To play Lobotomy Corporation is to walk blindfolded through a minefield.  If that appeals to you, then ignore the rest of my review and buy the game right now.  You'll love it.

If you're still reading, then what's in store for you is to have your legs blown off over and over by threats you cannot foresee, cannot avoid, and very probably, will force you to reset your runs at the drop of a hat.  And it is by design.

That is, unless you cheat.  You can look up the Abnormalities (monsters) on the Wiki page, revealing all of their information with zero in-game effort.  Then, you can save scum to restart the current day, apply the perfect solution to beat them, and carry on unimpeded.  You can walk through the minefield without a scratch.  No skill, no talent, just blithely applying someone else's information in order to win.

This approach removes all of the frustration, but it also removes all of the fun.  If you know all the solutions without having to work for them, then why are you even playing in the first place?  What fun is a game about mysterious monsters, when the monsters are no longer mysterious?  By design, the game is equal parts maddening frustration and captivating horror.  If you remove the frustration, the horror stops being captivating.  You either swallow the pill whole, or not at all.

10 hours in, and this reality has finally sunk in for me.  I've been liberally reloading and reading Wiki pages so far, and I'm breezing through the game.  Until I hit the Singing Machine.  Even armed with the Wiki page, it kept killing my guys over and over.  I kept reloading and re-reading.  I thought the game was bugged at first, until I realized I was reading the rules wrong, and figured out how to overcome it.  I had one - ONE - dude in my entire base who could beat this thing, and even then, it would've been a coin flip's chance of success when his turn came.

Had I been playing truly blind, the Singing Machine would have ended my run.  Honestly it probably would have ended my next one too, that's how arcane its ruleset is.  It would have gobbled up all 15 of my dudes, no explanation, no apology, no remorse, and spit me out without any idea what had happened.

But that experience *IS* the game.  It's the whole point.  Being unfairly roflstomped by sentient woodchippers is the game.  Losing is the point.  If that doesn't appeal to you, then don't play this.

Anyways despite my own advice, I'm going to keep trying.  And no more cheating.  If it turns out to be fun, I'll change my review to reflect that.  If it makes me want to lobotomize myself with a spork, I'll reflect that too.  

For now though, I would not recommend this to anyone except people with infinite patience.

(EDIT: I put 20 more hours into the game, thoughts below)

I love the style, art, and theme of the game, but even after tripling my time played, I am even more convinced now that I would not recommend it to my friends.  That being said though, I can absolutely see how this game would appeal to a certain type of person.  I'm just not that type.

My biggest beef with Lobotomy Corporation is that it's a game that's based on knowledge, and not on skill.  You can't infer the stats or approach of a new abnormality based on past work with other creatures.

I quit at 30 hours, because the thought of putting in another 50, 100, 150 hours or whatever of stabbing in the dark and resetting days over and over after repeated failures didn't seem fun.  I hated the Singing Machine.  I hated the Woodsman.  How many more obtuse and punishing guessing games would I need to play to finish the game?  How many more times would I need to reset the day to avoid being punished for guessing wrong?  What's the point of avoiding the wiki if I was just going to reset liberally anyways?

Look I totally get why other people recommend the game.  It's a very intriguing and stylish guessing game.  But I don't like guessing games.

This game feels very unique in its design. Best way I can describe it is "Creepypasta SPC Management Simulator RPG". The overall goal of each 'day' in the game is to interact with objects or creatures brought to your corporation to harvest energy to power the world. Each of these creatures behave differently depending on both how your employees at the corporation interact with them, and outlying factors and events in the corporation overall. As you progress through days, the managers of each department slowly become unlocked, and they all have challenges for you to overcome before a small 'bosslike' battle with them is unlocked. It is a trial and error roguelike gameplay style, where it is expected you will fail and inevitably have to reset your overall run to start again with previously gained knowledges.

Overall, I have loved the game for a long time, and recommend it to anyone looking for a different gameplay experience that I myself have been unable to exactly find anywhere else.

[i]Best thing about finishing Lobotomy Corporation is that you don’t have to play Lobotomy Corporation anymore.[/i]

[b]Pros - SUFFERING[/b]
[b]The concept itself is really neat.[/b] 
Several of the anomalies have unique gameplay gimmicks, and every anomaly is also accompanied by a cool information page with their own artwork, their stats, special abilities and effects they have, and a story and threat level classification akin to an SCP page. Not all of them are random either and seldom have something that ties into the bigger story and setting of the game. The setting itself is a bit non-standard. On the other hand the story doesn't really focus on the anomalies themselves that much, more on the people working there, which might or might not be to your liking depending on how much you enjoy watching overpowered anime-people duke it out.

[b]The music is great.[/b] 
Hot damn the music is good. It’s a shame most of the game you only get to hear the basic management track, as the game has many real bangers, especially all the alert and the boss fight tracks.

[b]Cons - SUFFERING[/b]
[b]Positive feedback loop on steroids, which clashes with the narrative.[/b] 
The story constantly goes out of its way to show how every employee is supposedly expendable to the point characters simply decide to not even bother remembering their coworkers due to absurd casualty rates. However, gameplay wise it’s the exact opposite: employees aren't expendable, because the game requires you to have max level super-units with the best gear available to deal with high rank anomalies. This doesn’t simply mean “the newbies are less effective” and that you could substitute quality with quantity, it means they will instantly die if they work on an anomaly that’s out of their league, and if you have no units that are able to work with your current line-up the game’s pretty much over. 

This extends to combat as well, because un-upgraded units will instantly splat or soil themselves in fear and can’t use high level gear. To make matters worse, death not only means you lose units, all the gear they were carrying (until a VERY late-game upgrade) and RNG-traits, the game penalizes you even further by reducing post-mission LOB reward – resource required for hiring and upgrading units – making your new units even weaker and prone to dying, perpetuating the cycle. Which doesn’t even make sense plot wise because [spoiler]one of the later revelations is that the anomalies release MORE energy if they kill humans[/spoiler], which is your goal throughout the entire game. This is the one part where the game had an actual story reason to throw the player a bone, but no.

[b]You know what’s better than a positive feedback loop? Positive feedback loop with the most trial-and-error gameplay in the entire medium.[/b]
Stat too low when working on an anomaly? Insta-gib. Stat too high? Insta-gib. Your unit got a trait which disallows them from certain work types or working on other anomalies? Insta-gib. Worked on the same anomaly too often? Gib. Working on an anomaly deals one of the four possible damage types which the unit has no defenses against? Gib. Escaped anomaly or boss fight has a surprise AoE attack with one second wind-up that gibs your entire crew unless you manually order your units out of the way? Gib. An anomaly that spawns in random area when it escapes and attacks the entire facility every few seconds without any safe spots, with damage numbers that instantly make all but the best agents die on first shot? Gib-gib-gib. 

There's no way to know any of these rules before you [i]successfully[/i] research and fight an anomaly multiple times. This isn’t like XCOM, Invisible Inc. or many other roguelites / permadeath games that do often throw curveballs for players to manage. “Manage” being the keyword, as in you can figure out a counter through skillful play or ample preparation. Lobotomy Corp’s most used curveball is an insta-gib with no recovery other than save-scumming. These kind of brutal surprise mechanics in themselves would be fully congruent with the themes of the game and the supposed expendability of your crew – not to mention you get to hear the great alert tracks when things start going bottoms up – but combined with the aforementioned extreme positive feedback loop it means there’s no way you aren’t going to be constantly save-scumming to hell and back.

[b]You know what’s also fun in management sims? Functionally horrid UI? Shoddy controls? Combat that requires precision perfect positioning? How about all of them at once?[/b]
Units standing in the same spot have their sprites and HP bars cover each other and there's no quick way to find out their current status at a glance – a simple list with filters and “jump camera to unit” command would’ve been enough, or having the overlapping units’ HP bars stack on top of each other. There’s no control groups either, no order queuing and worst of all, units automatically unselect after you give them any order. 

This is especially bad if you send your units to fight enemies with attacks that affect the entire room, or when you get one of the events that spawn enemies in all parts of your base and requires you to spread out. It’s a visual clusterchuck that requires precise micro-management. The way you issue move commands is also not ideal since you can only designate rooms and not the exact spot where you want units to stand, which is paramount of importance when some late game threats unleash the aforementioned 1-hit kill AoE attacks that require your units to be out of way when it happens.

[b]Several bosses and threats end up turning into silly elevator shaft-pause boogaloos.[/b]
To elaborate, some enemies either only spawn in hallways and deal humongous damage or instagib your units if you’re trying to fight them from the front, or they have a massive AoE with a second or two of wind-up that hits your *entire base* horizontally at the boss’ current floor and kills all but the highest level and best equipped agents in one shot. The solution? Get everyone into an elevator and only fight near them so you can instantly teleport to another floor when the inevitable death wave hits.

[b]Few bugs.[/b]
I had one particularly infuriating one where after several retries and finally achieving two difficult side quests, one low tier anomaly's status effect couldn't be removed as it usually should ([spoiler]Void Dream’s sleep attack which you can remove by clicking on units[/spoiler]), resulting the game considering half my crew dead by the end of the day. To the retry screen it is.

[b]Iffy soundtrack placement.[/b]
Like I mentioned, the game has some real bangers and plenty of tracks, but most of them are used only for story scenes that last a minute or so, or boss fights that get not one, but several tracks. However, well over 90% of the playtime you’re going to be hearing the one exact same “everything is running smooth” track through actual gameplay assuming you’re doing well. They could’ve spiced it up a bit and have the later days have new tracks play during regular management, both to make the soundtrack less repetitive and to signify the increasing complexity you get with juggling lots of dangerous anomalies at once. A real missed opportunity.

[b]The game gets a tad bit grindy, especially on subsequent playthroughs.[/b] 
Especially if you’ve already fully researched your current line-up of abnos and just need to generate enough energy for day completion, all the while having fully memorized how all your abnos respond to different work types and other hijinks that require micro-management. When Lobotomy Corporation isn’t an infuriating save-scum fest it’s instead a numbing busywork galore.

I am going to preface this review with my opinion upfront; I do not like this game, neither the story nor the way the game explores game mechanics.

This does not mean it is a bad game and that is why despise me disliking the game personally, I still recommend it.

For those looking for an SCP style game, this isn't it. It comes close, though. Allow me to explain a bit.

You start off as a manager of Lobotomy Corporation; a company trying to solve the world's energy crisis by utilizing abnormalities. In order to collect energy, you must study the abnormalities, collect information, personalize each one's containment cell, and so on. You collect abnormalities by selecting from 3 unknown (boxes? Look like movie projectors but I'll keep going) each one with a clue or a quote to hint towards the abnormalities nature. 

I personally dislike picking from a set of boxes and would prefer to actually try to contain the abnormalities firsthand, but this is a minor gripe and nothing not easily overlooked. Besides; it must not be your department to try to contain them but another department entirely. 

And then that brings up the biggest issue, one that started small but slowly grew; you are a company first. Containment is merely the byproduct of needing the energy from the abnormalities. Enforcing quotas over study and research and so on. This slowly irked me until I could no longer enjoy the game itself as the company aspect and feel grew only stronger from there. 

If you want to play a soulless company that happens to study abnormalities, contain them, but whose primary focus is draining them of all their juice, this game will be for you and worth the price. 

One note I will add here is that you don't get to decide how your base is laid out. I feel like this was a massive wasted opportunity as deciding where rooms are, what corridors go where, and so on would play a wonderful strategic role when focusing on containment and defense against breaches and other Groups of Interest.
Very good game,makes you wonder what you truly are doing at times and how your surviving,and then you hear second trumpet.

I've finally beaten this game for the first time and decided to write a review. To preface this review, most of the issues pointed by the negative reviews are no longer relevant. The translation issues have been fixed. Optimization is still not the best, but there are no more memory leaks in my experience.

[b]Warning! This game is not for the faint of heart or people that lack patience. The game can become more difficult the longer you play and you will have a better experience if you treat it like a Roguelike as the game expects you to restart and there is a specific mechanic in the game that allows you to rewind time while keeping some of your progress.[/b]


[b]Overview[/b]

Pros :
- The only SCP-like management game that you'll ever find
- Story rich game in a cyberpunk dystopian setting with fantasy elements
- Roleplaying elements
- Unique monster mechanics and interesting lores
- The game will throw surprises at you
- Character customization for employees
- Hard game

Cons :
- UI is a little bit clunky
- FPS drops sometimes
- Gameplay can be a bit repetitive
- Training employees can be grindy
- Hard game

[b]Full Review[/b]

Lobotomy Corporation is a monster management game where you manage creatures called Abnormalities in a very SCP like fashion. You play as a manager overseeing Abnormalities by assigning your employees to work on the Abnormalities. Each of the Abnormalities has its own set of rules to determine how to best deal with it. These rules are hidden at first, so you must do a little experimentation before you can unlock them.

Each day that you complete a level, you have to pick one of three Abnormalities that are offered. As you progress more, the threat level for Abnormalities that you encounter will increase. You will also discover that not only you have to manage these Abnormalities on their own, some of them can also interact with other Abnormality. This is what I will call a "combo". Some combos can be helpful to you, but a lot of them are really deadly. This is where most of the difficulty comes in. 

As I mentioned earlier, the game can be really brutal and if you find yourself stuck on a day or level because you can't manage these Abnormalities, it will be better to use a feature called "Memory Repository" to go back in time. It will allow you to repick Abnormalities. Worst case scenario, you will have to reset to day 1, but don't worry as you will keep your Abnormalities informations and equipments. You will also find yourself progress the day a lot more quicker than before. The negative is the game can become a bit repetitive after a while, especially after you unlocked a lot of the informations and equipments, but the game will throw surprises at you and it was enough to keep me interested.

As for the story, I personally really like it. Without spoiling anything, the story takes place in a cyberpunk dystopian setting with a lot of fantasy elements thrown in, which I don't see that many of. It is presented in a style that is similar to a visual novel. This game also has a sequel called "Library of Ruina", so if you are interested in the story and world of Lobotomy Corporation, you might want to check that game out as well.

Changing my review since I have more hours on the game.

Lobotomy Corporation is a ruthless, gruesome, yet cutesy SCP-inspired roguelite. Similar artstyle to that of the mobile Fallout Shelter game with a hint of anime. Your goal is to manage and generate power by working on "abnormalities" in your expanding facility. Abnormalities are essentially creatures/objects that all behave differently. They require you to figure out how to handle them effectively yourself by unlocking information on it, this is done by completing work with them usually with trial and error. The game progressively gets more interesting and difficult when you're managing more complicated and dangerous abnormalities that can escape or cause absolute chaos in your facility.

Lobotomy Corporation is a fun and casual experience until late game, where the difficulty spikes up drastically. Late game you will run into some story-based objectives that feel borderline impossible at the start. This is when you realize where the rogue-lite aspect comes in, the game expects you to restart. Essentially a New Game+ where you keep things from your previous playthrough, to get more knowledge, more skill, and better equipment and unlocks to help you progress and beat the game. This adds a lot of replay value and since each playthrough you will be dealing with different abnormalities, it will keep the gameplay fresh.

The artstyle and soundtrack is very well made, even if at times it feels unpolished. The story is not terrible, it doesn't particularly grasp me personally but it's a nice touch to the game and adds some depth into the experience.

As far as complaints go with the game, the game can become annoying and unfair at times. I've gotten to a point I expect the worst possible scenario when I jump into new content in the game, because Lobotomy Corporation actually has zero chill and is willing to make your experience frustrating and ruthlessly difficult. This isn't a bad thing, but it can get very stressful and time consuming just to make progress. My second complaint is combat can occasionally get annoying when you want to manage multiple agents that are stacked on top of eachother, being unable to see their HP/SP bars without checking the suppression interface or knowing who has the shield you just gave.  My last complaint is the game does have some bugs, that will make you have to restart the day that you spent an hour on. As one can imagine that is very frustrating, but since I enjoy the game so much I still continue it anyway. The bugs are also not frequent enough to be a dealbreaker or gamebreaking, but they do appear occasionally and depending the scenario it can be extremely annoying.

TLDR; this game is fantastic and I highly recommend this game if you enjoy management games and/or if you like games that are willing to be gruesome and make you want to tear your hair out. Melting Love is cute and if you use repression on her you're just being mean.

I usually love management sims and was drawn to how weird and spooky Lobotomy Corporation seems. Unfortunately I just couldn't stand the game. 

Essentially, you keep monsters in cages and send your "agents" to interact with them which produces energy for your company. Your agents take damage from this so you need to make sure you don't overload them or they can die very quickly. Each monster has their own likes and dislikes (e.g. one monster may dislike when you visit any monster other than him) and if you annoy them too much they will break out of their cage and start killing everyone. The point of the game is to manage the preferences of all of the monsters in your lab so they don't go crazy, while harvesting as much energy from them as possible. Then they also add in some random events where you get attacked by hordes of enemies.

[*] While the game is actually fairly straight-forward, it took me several hours to figure out the basic mechanics. Everything is described in a really confusing, convoluted way so it's hard to understand even the basic concepts. 

[*] Once I figured out how to play, I quickly realised that it still wasn't fun. A lot of the difficulty comes from the fact that you know literally nothing about a monster until you have spent a decent amount of time interacting with it (at which point the game simply tells you the monster's preferences). So you can very easily annoy the monster and end up with loads of dead agents without having a clue what you're doing wrong. You can try to figure it out via trial and error, but there is a fair amount of RNG (i.e. a behaviour MIGHT annoy the monster) which makes it very hard to track the consequences of your actions. Even when you know a lot about the monsters, you can still piss off a monster through simple RNG, or even get a set of monsters in your lab with conflicting preferences that make it virtually impossible to keep them all happy. Additionally even if you have "unlocked" the preferences of a monster, it seems that you can only view them in the menu in between games, so you're forced to literally memorise them.

[*] The difficulty is very unfair. As mentioned above, keeping monsters happy can be very difficult and any failure at all basically means you need to restart. If a monster gets upset and escapes their cage, everyone is going to die. An agent dies while working with a monster, you lose all your stats invested into them and any equipment they were wearing, might as well restart. Agent goes insane and starts killing other agents, restart. In a tough spot and a horde of enemies randomly spawns? You guessed it.

[*] The translation is not great. Apparently it was updated recently but I still found it to be quite off-putting. It's written in proper English but the dialogue still feels unnatural and it's hard to tell what emotion a character is supposed to be feeling when they're talking. The game tries to be quite philosophical which makes it even more important to understand the nuances of what is going on. This is also a big contributor to why it's so hard to understand how to play the game. 

[*] When I started the game I had a big game-breaking error where none of the text appeared properly and I couldn't start the game. It took me 30~ minutes to figure out how to fix it. Then even after I fixed it, the tutorial wouldn't load up.

Sometimes an experience comes around that is, in many ways, kind of bad but still pretty good. The gameplay might be frustrating or the design isn't fully coherent, but underneath all that grime and rough shell is an experience that is interesting, unique, or fascinating unto itself. I haven't played something like this in a while, but after almost reaching the end of [i]Lobotomy Corporation[/i], I can firmly state it belongs in this category. 

The basic gameplay structure of [i]Lobotomy Corporation[/i] is simple. It's a management/RTS hybrid where you control a series of little doll-workers called "agents" in a massive underground laboratory. What's being researched here? All manner of eldritch abominations, godless horrors, screaming masses of flesh, and the odd "what if this fairy tale was fucked up" creature here and there, all collected under the umbrella term "abnormality". After selecting an abnormality for the day, you take your agents and select one of four "works" to perform on the abnormalities, such as Instinct work to feed them or Insight work to learn how they work, which produce "E-Boxes" that fill a daily quota that rises slowly with each new day. Once enough E-Boxes have been collected, the day ends, and you're granted a score that allows you to hire new employees or improve the stats of older ones. Following this, you're allowed to expand the departments where the abnormalities are kept and given research tasks by the A.I's who manage them to help gain an edge, and the next day begins.

However, working with the beasts and ghouls that are imprisoned within the facility is far from easy- If the monsters aren't trying to break free from their bondage, then they're doing some kind of horrible other thing to your workers. Each abnormality is completely unique in their containment measures, and much of the learning process of the game is figuring out how to keep each critter under lockdown lest they bust out. These containment procedures can be anything from "don't do this specific type of work" to "don't work on this abnormality if you have an Agent Level lower than V" to "working with this abnormality after working with this specific other abnormality will cause the former to breach", which makes each terror wonderfully unique and memorable. As you work on abnormalities more and more, you unlock greater details of their containment, from their true name, their disposition towards certain kinds of work, to hints on how to keep them contained. Even better, once you fill out the managerial guide for taking care of an abnormality, you can cash in the points you earn from working with them to craft E.G.O. armor sets and weapons, or receive powerful stat-boosting gifts. These look bad-ass, plain and simple, and it feels excellent to finally master an abnormality long enough to make a devastating new weapon or effective suit for your agents to wear. Watching your employee force go from barely-equipped bozos who can't even handle a single attack robot to a mob of freaks ripping apart anything that moves feels awesome and rewarding. The loop of getting a new abnormality, mastering its containment, and then reaping the rewards of keeping it in your facility feels very rewarding, though it does become very tedious after a while. 

You might be wondering, "if the entire game is about learning how to manage the abnormalities, what happens when you learn how each one works"? The answer is that the game becomes rote and tiresome as you go through the motions of assigning work and watching a bar fill up with little in the way of stimulation. There's little risk for each abno breaking out if you're diligent with your work, which makes for a management experience that is pretty darn tedious. Combat fares no better- While your agents can fight against the escaping abnormalities and the occasional invading force, the microgame of controlling your units mostly consists of left-click dragging your entire force, right clicking on an enemy, and waiting until their HP drops to zero. If the enemy is particularly dangerous, then you have to learn to highlight said allied force, click a room away to force your guys to move out of the way while the enemy attacks, and then left click them all again and move them back into place. It's like playing [i]Dark Souls[/i] in the form of an RTS, and it sucks. Even worse are the lack of assisting features. There's no way to select your troops and create groups (which would be VERY USEFUL since MANY difficult lategame encounters involve splitting up your attacking force into different damage types), no way to automate the work process with each abnormality, and nothing to do but watch your employees hit stuff until it dies while ordering them out of the way if things get spicy. Combat thus becomes more tedious than fun, which means the management and the combat aspects of the gameplay are both pretty boring. Combine this with a game design that emphasises grinding for hours on end and a difficulty scale that could be charitably called "schizophrenic", and you have a recipe for a game that loses its luster very quickly. The sheer tediousness with which the basic gameplay of LobCorp conducts itself is a major turnoff for me, and makes it hard to play the game for long period of time when meaningful progress is my objective for the day. 

Speaking of difficulty, lets get back to that subject. LobCorp is hard. Like, "a high-tier abnormality breached? Restart the day" tier hard. I have no problem with a game being tough, but I do have a problem with how often LobCorp sets up undoing progress as a means to punish failure. There's nothing quite as soul-suckingly frustrating as completing a day, only for a single high-tier abnormality to breach and either wipe out half your facility trying to contain it or force you to sacrifice a huge chunk of your upgrade points in order to suppress it. A single mistake is often all it takes to either instantly end your day with a restart, which can be very disheartening when days last thirty minutes or more, and this problem is exacerbated when trying to learn how the abnormalities work. While the game is built with restarting from day one in mind (as you keep your E.G.O. and abnormality logs, and can thus avoid ones you don't want for your current facility), it is no less frustrating to go all the way back to day one after putting so much effort into making it further than you did before.

Tedious gameplay, a grindy design and all over the place difficulty that uses the erasure of progress as a means of punishing failure are the signs of an game that lacks polish. LobCorp is truly jank, but underneath that jank is an experience that is fascinating and engaging. Learning about abnormalities and then mastering their containment always feels great, while learning about the world and the story of the facility and the damned souls who run it make for a story that is nothing short of enthralling. I haven't even spoken about how the game integrates story elements into the gameplay, which are so absolutely genius that I cannot even speak about them here for fear of ruining their impact in-game. 

I've chosen to be very upfront with LobCorp's problems in this review because I feel that anyone who wants to get into this game should know about them, but I think it speaks volumes for how compelling the good elements of LobCorp are that I've sunken more than fourty hours into the damn thing despite my eminent bitching. Even with all it does wrong, you can just tell that this game was the work of a team that really wanted to make something [i]interesting[/i] despite their lack of game design skill, which shines through in the compelling elements it succeeds in. I will commit to beating LobCorp in spite of it's flaws, because being the manager of this fucked up little slice of hell is too compelling to put down unfinished.

It's hard.
It's unforgiving.
It is, at times, unfair.

But it's worth it. The story is pretty damn amazing and gameplay is challenging, but in a fun way - it's like a puzzle that becomes more complex with every passing day. At the start, you only have to worry about 2 or 3 things, but before you know it you will be juggling dozens of different issues, each one with its own mechanic.
Just one word of advice - get yourself Cheat Engine and speedhack this game. If you want to play it safely, it's not uncommon for a day to last around an hour. Speedhacking can make it more bearable if, like me, you don't have that much free time to play games.

Finally - you will probably swear like a sailor more than once because of this game. But as I said at the start, keep at it - for the sake of the story. And because you owe it to everyone down there.

Very stress inducing game. If you are here because of Library of Ruina and played it before, imo skip it since the ending will be less of a twist. But if you want to try it out anyway, enjoy of the many torments you will suffer here.

It is a management sim that has horror and rougelike mix in together. Surprisingly, it works out just fine. 
It is one of those games where death is a common thing to expect so having a 0 death run is pretty much impossible on your first run without having to google who does what. So pray that your favorite employee comes out alive.

The best way to experience this game is to go 100% blind imo but there are certain abnormalities that can literally can end your run depending if you have the gear if for whatever reason if it escapes. Google will be your best friend. sure it will might ruin the surprise, but it will also save many head aces and potential run ender. Just remember to not chicken out and pick only the easy ones since they are usually tie to gear rank (i.e the harder they are, the better gear they will drop)

The story is okay and the casts are pretty good. Each being unique to their roles and how they view of their job, their co-workers, and their employees. It isn't amazing as LoR but it is decent.

The game does suffer frame issue in the late game unless you have some godlike processor because of how many things are on the screen at ones and movement may be clunky at times and could cause your group to get killed because of how targeting works.

Combat system can be hard and confusing at first but they are easy to understand and to master ones you get the hang of it.

But overall it is a great game and it will make you feel like you are the SCP director of the site. If you enjoy the story of LC and want more, then Library of Ruina will add more story into it.

Summary: you play as a manager of a laboratory facility that study monster. Initially you won't know anything about the monster that you gain each day; however, as you order your workers/employees/minions (whatever you wanna call it) to work with the monster, you gain resource to unlock knowledge about that monster. As the day goes on, the monster you unlock became harder to manage with the capabilities to wreck havoc on your facilities as well as killing your employees.

Pro:
     Simulation
     Hard
     Great Soundtrack
     Infinite Retry on day
     Interesting game mechanics for each monster and events
           Strategies?
     Employees gain exp and stat for working with monster, making it rewarding for you to keep them alive
     Mysteries... and mysteries
Con:
    Hard
    Require constant attentions on higher days
    Lack of resources usage once you unlock everything about that monster.
    Infinite retry

Honestly, this game just felt really lukewarm to me. 

Gameplay-wise, it gets repetitive really fast despite them slowly hiking up the difficulty.

 Visually, it's okay. You play as the director, and the cartoony design is supposed to prevent you, as the director, from becoming traumatized. Not my cup of tea, but not bad necessarily. 

The soundtrack, despite supposedly being large, sounds repetative and immemorable. However this again may just be personal taste.

As far as the story goes, as you may have guessed this game has a SCP-ish vibe. I want to give them benefit of the doubt, but my gut tells me this game was trying to emulate an SCP feeling. This in and of itself is not a bad thing, but it sets a standard. And this game does not meet that standard in my opinion. The story alludes to things becoming more interesting as you go on, but after playing for 3.8 hours, I have not reached that point. 

My verdict: If this game looks interesting to you, I'd wait for it to go on sale.

Lobotomy Corporation was a game that I bought years ago, under the pretense of supporting an indie with a good idea, with very little expectation. Thankfully, the game ended up being pretty good, and Project Moon is now one of my favorite developers, period, though I admit this has more to do with Library of Ruina, their recent release and direct chronological sequel to Lobotomy Corporation. But we're here to talk about Lobotomy Corporation, so let's do that for now.

Lobotomy Corporation describes itself as an SCP sim, and while that isn't a bad or unhelpful description, I think if you go into this game exclusively expecting SCP, you might end up a bit disappointed. Monsters ultimately are very simple (for the best), with all of them being able to be worked in one of four ways, Instinct, Insight, Attachment and Repression, with additional conditions being used to make them more or less difficult to manage. 

They additionally have a Qliploth counter, which reduces as you mess up or, occasionally, succeed; some monsters are prone to breaking out and managing the breakout is a part of managing the monster. Some common examples of wrinkles are having certain stat thresholds (employees must be below/above 3 of a particular stat, for instance), or wanting the work success to be good, neutral, or bad specifically. Some monsters cause radial effects after some trigger is set off, some monsters just break out, some monsters heal people when you do a good job, some monsters aren't monsters at all and are rather static artifacts that generally won't bug you if you don't bug them.

However, if you think you can avoid combat forever, you are sorely mistaken. There are also Ordeals, which pop up after a certain number of monster interactions, which create sort've combat trials for your employees through the day, and serve as a soft timer to how long a day can run in early game, and as a challenge to be overcome in late game. Additionally, the game has ways of forcing interactions with certain monsters tied into this mechanic, meaning that for a while, every monster is a risk, even if you never intend to touch them.

Employees are also a mechanic, and, to keep it short, they have four stats corresponding with the work types, and gear which you synthesize from monster energy, which you get from working monsters. Gear has four elements, also roughly corresponding with the work types, and armor as a result has four resistances. This part, at least, should be fairly simple to understand. Combat takes place in an almost sort've 2D RTS style, with you shuffling your little nuggets around the facility to engage, and pulling them back if the thing you're fighting is about to do something nasty. You are going to do a lot of room to room dances.

If all that sounds like a lot to take in mechanically, it is. It is a difficult game, and you will absolutely lose employees to forgetting to do a certain thing, or act a certain way around a certain monster, and it's a part of the design. At some point, you're just going to have too many plates to spin and too many variables to consider, and you're going to slip. Eventually these slips will overcome you, and you'll have to reset the timeline. Literally. There's a mechanic in the game where you start from the beginning of your run, with all the information that you've gathered on monsters up to that point recorded, and all the gear you have. Except you're back at day one, the plot has reset, you have no monsters, and one employee.

You will have to do this a lot. I think I reset too much on my first run, but you will absolutely have to reset at least a handful of times, and you shouldn't burn yourself trying to avoid it, because due to the plot and requirements that show up later in the game, you will have to. Your eventual goal is to fully record every abnormality, and get to the final day, day 50. Without spoiling the plot, which is excellent, presented in a visual novel format, and unfortunately only mostly starts making any sense in the latter half of the game, the final five days is... brutal. You don't have enough context to understand why. If you get that far, you will, and that will become a part of the difficulty. I have to admit, nobody makes a challenge that makes me feel like I am completely and totally overwhelmed and incapable of beating something like Project Moon, and Lobotomy Corp is no exception. I can't say I didn't enjoy the ride, though!

TL;DR: Very mechanically dense game due to sheer variety of variables, a game where perfect runs are very difficult, a very difficult game in general, some employee management and very light RTS elements, mostly in micro/macro being helpful terms to describe how you maneuver your employees. Don't buy this game for the RTS elements, I stress it's mostly a terminology thing. 50 days, gets brutally difficult near the end, you will have to soft reset the game using an in game mechanic for the plot, if you don't like playing similar content repeatedly I'd skip this one, you'll be doing a lot of it. I enjoyed the plot, it worked for what it was trying to do, though it kicks in too late for it to be something I'd suggest as a primarily purchase decision.

If you want a sort've rough around the edges resource management game, you could do much worse, and you'll get a nice plot and some good monster design to go with it.

GUIDE ON HOW TO GET BEST ENDING IN LOBOTOMY CORPORATION:

STEP 1: On the abnormality selection screen, look out for an abnormality with the description "I shall heal you, curing you of all disease and injury you possess." and pick it. It's up to chance on whether or not it will show up, so it might take a while.

STEP 2: Send in one of your best employees to work with the abnormality until they are blessed. You'll know it worked when it shows a short cutscene of that employee's name appearing on a clock.

STEP 3: Repeat Step 2 until 12 employees are blessed.

If you have done all of these steps correctly, you should have reached the best ending. Make sure to bless your best employees to get the best possible ending.

Lobotomy Corporation is essentially a new take on the SCP styled horror or stories. While most of the SCP related games tend to be based almost solely on escaping, usually as a low-to lowest ranking, Lobotomy puts you in the shoes of the manager of the site. It shines an amazing light into a role many forget exists; the one that has to make the big calls around the facility.

What it did good:
+ Fun sweet cartoonistic designs keep the game lighthearted while still having the disturbance of SCP natures.
+ The soundtrack, although fairly repetitive, is fitting throughout the game and is well handled.
+ Rogue-like elements that encourage the user to adapt as they go along, while also taking risks.
+ Customization of agents that [strike] causes you to reset 200 times so your look-alike lives [/strike]
+ A balanced sense of resource management with risks/deaths

What it could do better:
- Weapon choices felt fairly lack-luster, certain types had only few notable and some types had no player usability at all
- small Aleph pool, [spoiler] some even fake being other risk levels [/spoiler]
- As stated earlier, depending on playstyles music could get very repetitive
- [spoiler] unavoidable deaths because the plague doctor thinks the 12th guy needed drowned [/spoiler]

In the end, I say it's one of my favorite games, and it even has mods, albeit few and many aren't English, and the modding scene isn't the most supported by the game.

You know what I really like? Failing a day because suddenly the screen starts to bleed for no apparent reason.

Basically I don’t enjoy repeating days over and over again to hope that I might pass only to return to the same loop when I do.

This really triggers the fear of unknown,  like said, face the fear, and build the future, taking the risk may be rewarding, but so is the catastrophe that would emerge after failing to succeed, the concepts of the monsters you manage are actually nice, but as days pass, you will see yourself panicking from a butterfly effect. Not to mention the story, you may skip it and have the gameplay, but it is fairly interesting, but there will be actual challenges for you to see the ending. And you will be given reward for it. 

On one thing to note, do not grow too attached on agents, they will die sooner or later. It is just the matter of time.

CENSORED (O-03-89) is an ambiguous Abnormality which its visual form is conformed by red 'Censored' bars. While in containment, a tall censored bar is in the middle while other smaller ones are spread on an horizontal way on it, moving slightly. Its actual form is forbidden.

Der Freischütz (F-01-69) is a humanoid abnormality that wears a large cloak and grey clothing. The color palette of its cloak consists of a black, yellow, and blue. It has a black wispy form with no discernible features besides its eyes, head, arms, and legs. It carries a large gun, most likely a musket, with it.

Funeral of the Dead Butterflies (T-01-68) is a humanoid abnormality which has a white butterfly for a head and possess five arms, two at each shoulder and one coming out of its neck. It wears a black suit and coat with a single white sleeve for its middle arm. It carries a black coffin with a butterfly engraved on its lid behind its back with two of its extra arms. According to the flavor text, the coffin is full of butterflies.

Nothing There (O-06-20) is an Abnormality that does not resemble any sort of human being, but instead a creature made of varied human parts. It has a large rectangular head with 2 mouths - a pink tongue coming out of the biggest mouth. It has 4 blue/light-blue eyes on its face, and a light blue arm with sharp claws at the top of its head. It stands on 3 legs; the two front legs are made of bones and the hind leg is a red intestine in the form of a leg with a 'foot' at the end. Its torso is made of a transparent material, revealing red, blue, and green intestines. A dark liquid drips below it. The rest of its body is made of bones or muscles.

The Mountain of Smiling Bodies (T-01-75) is an Abnormality taking the form of a big black spherical mass, encrusted with different parts and debris. It possess a big mouth with visible teeth with some tips covered on blood; and has 2 limbs to support itself. Part of its body is covered with white masks with twisted expressions, all with two black eyes and a mouth.

You play as an iteration of an overburdened and broken man, the manager, who is tasked to meet energy quotas, provide therapy sessions to spiteful personalities trapped in tin cans, take care of said tin cans throwing a fit towards you, fend off creatures, calamities, balding and The Rapture. All while trying to keep your little nuggets - employees alive, so you can move on to the next day.
LobCorp initially pulls you in with the opportunity to explore and learn about its abnormalities, but this curiosity evolves into sort of a responsibility to carry out and see the finale of a staged play. The world building, lore and motifs in this game are great. The art style is appealing. Music fits the setting in-game. The gameplay doesn't require you to be a good multitasker or RTS savant. The game can be completed by memorising all your failures and learned countermeasures(you are expected to fail, a lot). 
The game is unpolished in some areas, such as, bad performance on the later days, clerks bugging out, sometimes employee E.G.O. visuals defaulting, the savefile can have corruptions and the art can be not-so-HD under a magnifying lens. But that is really it for the flaws. Difficulty in LobCorp is justified, simple as.

Once upon a time, three happy birds lived in a warm and lush forest. 

Small bird decided to punish the creatures' wrongdoings with its beak. 

To keep the forest's peace, Long Bird weighed the sins of those who entered the forest. For Long Bird's scale was fair and just, and could weigh any and all kinds of sin. 

Big Bird, with it's many eyes, decided to watch over the forest for intruders. For Big Bird's eyes could see very far, and see things we cannot see. 

Then, in the middle of all the chaotic cries, someone shouted:
"It's the beast! A big, scary monster lives in the black, dusky forest!"
This game is great. If you like management sims, reading, and can stomach the existential dread you feel every time you make a decision, this game is for you.

I adore this game, the brutality and dark aspects of some parts of it are just a couple of the aspects of this game that have lead me to love it. I'm a definite fan of how some abnormalities places that classic Lobot brutal spin on fairytales and just how great some of the other lore is in general, the way in which it doesn't fully explain how some of these things came to be retains a sense of mystery around them.

Later on in the game, it still is able to retain a stressful, yet somewhat calm atmosphere (at least until people start dying). I love the idea of ordeals and their different tiers. 

There are only a few issues I'd be able to highlight with the game: The first is a lack of easy modding support, it'd be great to see what the community could come up with through steam workshop if given the chance, (which could also lengthen the life of the game as a whole). The second is simply the lack of replayability, with 216 hours in the game, I've seen and suffered at the hands of all the game's anomalies and, I would love to see some more anomalies be added into the game at some point (though, this is likely just wishful thinking as I know the devs are preoccupied with other games). My final issue is with customisation, I would definitely enjoy more customisation options to be added, as well as the RGB for hair to be working better.

To conclude, I would definitely recommend this game to those who would enjoy its dark aspects, such as those who like the Scp Foundation.

Monster management simulator that was inspired by stuff like SCP.

Goods;
1. Story is awesome
2. Amazing soundtrack
3. Beautiful game
4. Hard

Bads;
1. Hard. Sometimes the game can feel unfairly hard

Some things to note;
1. The monsters in this game act like puzzles that you will have to bang your head against the wall to solve
2. The "restart day" button is not a last resort in this game and is more like a 2nd or 3rd in line response
3. Did I mention this game can be hard? And I'm not talking "yeah it can be hard for some people", the game has a set difficulty and the game takes itself seriously, and expects you to pull yourself up to its level. I personally don't mind the challenge, I think it makes every encounter you overcome worth more, but some people might not like the difficulty.

After its re-translation in 2020, the game is a near-perfect state, I've heard some people have memory leaks but I have never had a problem with this. The game also now has a sequel that expands on the story but not the gameplay.

If you're on the fence I'd recommend that you just go for it and give yourself a bit of a new experience and challenge. It's seriously a great game.

+++++ A game that actually deserves it's age rating, it's dark, no it's quite frankly fucked up. But it's not trying to be edgy for the sake of it or doing it merely for shock value. There's a deep and dark story here that is well worth the hundred+ hours you'll need to see it through.
++++ Complex and Unique gameplay, if I were to give it a genre I'd call it "Anxiety Management"
+++ A wonderful blend of gameplay and narrative, your actions are informing your perspective on the game. The game wants you to become heartless, to let that one employee die so you can progress. And are you going to restart and try that boss again just for that one easily replaceable employee? I hope so, you monster.
+++/--- This game is long, you've been warned. This is either a good or bad thing depending on what you want from a game. But this game uses a time rollback mechanic that encourages you to restart the day/week/whole playthrough while retaining everything you learnt like a modern roguelike. Getting the true ending requires multiple rollbacks. You can do it in one playthrough but only if you consistently rollback every week in order to get access to all the encyclopedia.
++ This game is brutal and it doesn't care about your feelings on the matter. It consistently defines your limitations and then like a good game should pushes the goalpost a little past them and out of your reach.

------- Game has a memory leak, playing for long periods of time will consume memory until your PC crashes. Check task manager occasionally to see when it breaches 4gb and restart the game to surpress it's urge to take over your entire computer.
------ In my game I only encountered one bug... But that bug was nasty, undoing the win I made against one of the games hardest bosses and killing all of my team and losing me their gear. This would have been bearable but it was on day 43 on my final run to the end.

This is a game with overflowing levels of thought.  Perhaps an odd dichotomy for a game with lobotomy in the title, but I stand by it.  Project moon has a great talent for incorporating story concepts seamlessly through gameplay and lobotomy corporation is an experience I would recommend to anyone who can face the fear.

Preamble aside Lobotomy Corporation is a management game of sorts, the basic gist is that you are managing the day to day of a lobotomy corporation facility and that involves telling people how to make monsters produce green energy while also having those monster handling people sometimes survive this process.  A large draw to this game is the cadence you get while one learning what each monster does and simultaneously improving your own detective work for future monsters  so that you can more quickly figure out how to efficiently make batteries of them.  This cadence lasts for most of the game and is later overtaken by various side challenges that drive the main plot of the game.  

Once you reach that mid game and you'll know it, the game will slowly but steadily ramp up the challenge and the pressure until it culminates in one of the most satisfying endgames I've ever experienced, maybe even the most satisfying.  If this sounds like a fun time to you, then I recommend this game wholeheartedly.

But I do understand this isn't a game everyone would enjoy, but anyone who would enjoy this game will really enjoy this game.   So I do recommend this game, but I'll give a warning: this game is not easy, this game is long(~100 hours and then some) and some of the abnormalities are tedious and stressful to work with, and there are many easy ways to ruin minutes of effort in a few mistaken seconds, but even so I found it worthwhile as it is and would change nothing about it.  

Also includes character customization so that you can grow attached to your employees before the game makes you choose between their lives and your convenience.  At the very least you can make sure your employee will look cute before they are killed/lobotomized/sent to at least three different forms of hell/converted to watts/change careers to go to the fishing industry/or worse.  Also soundtrack is top tier.
