Lobotomy Corp is a SCP management sim. With a heavy focus on the management part. The objective is to work on various monstrosities to meet a daily energy quota, through 4 different "works" your agents preform on SCPs. Working unlocks SCP specific equipment(needed for survival and "suppression") and also the guidelines and weaknesses for dealing with said SCP. After a successful day you can replace fallen agents, level-up, and generally prepare for whatever is added on the next day. 

And that’s essentially it. The actual playing of the game is pretty straightforward. It’s mostly pausing, assigning agents work, and then speeding up until they’re either done or dead. With some supression hear and there. A real less is more approach to its mechanics. 

Most of the fun comes from managing various murderous and unusual quirks. And by managing, I mean actual management. Who can do what, when, where, and with what equipment. Sometimes it’s as simple as a being stat is too high or low (or both). But often its hoping that the Claire assigned to the giant fetus doesn’t make it cry, because that causes the Meat Lantern to escape and you have to find that one manually to suppress, with ranged red damage of course, but then River in Safety just dropped dead for something you probably did and also someone else put on the red shoes while you weren’t paying attention. You'll be restarting a lot in this game. It’s fun, frustrating, and a bit tedious. 

There are other things like ordeals (enemy invasions), meltdown levels (SCPs require immediate care), "optional" objectives, grinding works to level agents, and other stuff I didn’t get to. These too, are all part of the managerial puzzle. I find it vaguely exhausting and but couldn’t stop thinking about it. It's a lot to keep track of and it doesn’t get easier. 

The UI exacerbates this. Keeping track of everything means frequent pausing and scrolling. Selecting agents stacked on top of each other is annoying. Text is sometimes too small or too quick. Little issues like these are sprinkled throughout this game. Easily ignorable if you like the game or gently grating, depending on how much you're enjoying yourself

Now the story and writing I like ,but the difficulty of the game made it feel almost tangential. The actual SCP writing didn't wow me but it’s fun to read when you have actual firsthand experience. The visual novel portion is interesting but, there is no way in hell I'm seeing the end of this. I only got to day 22 out of 50. And that’s probably the biggest shame about this game. Despite its cool premise and interesting story, it still wasn't enough for me to push through. Neat game though, recommend for people who like the dark, sorta cheesy, SCP horror stuff. Or for people with extreme amounts of patience.

Good game, good soundtrack, good story.

The video showcased is a little old though the most notable feature that has been changed is that the elevators are instant now and the game was retranslated recently.

If you like facility management games you'll like this one if you like a good story you'll like this one, or even if you like SCP-like games this is also good for that.

If you liked the story the most I would recommend their second game Library of Ruina which continues this one but it throws away the facility management also.

But this game gets really hard as you get into the further days. This isn't meant to be a shorter game this game wants you to restart to get an advantage, the early abnormalities are pretty easy but late game it gets to when a hard abnormality escapes you have to instantly restart the day. To combat this I recommend restarting to day 1 or restarting to a few days in the past. When you restart everything but your characters stay meaning you can keep all the info you gathered about abnormalities, items you've gained from them, and quests you might have done making it easier to focus on other abnormalities and quests to get them out of the way.

A lot of the older reviews about translation are not true to today where it was retranslated, there was also a big update regarding mechanics after it wasn't early access which divided the game between "legacy" and normal which changed art, UI, all kinds of stuff so watch out for those reviews too.

To sum it all up, this is a hard, facility management, SCP-like, story game that can get repetitive at times but you can always restart to make your run easier and better. This game takes a lot of learning so be ready if you do buy this.

Here is my spoiler free review of the game. Lobotomy Corporation is a management sim/visual novel with an engaging story and somewhat addictive play loop. The game takes place over the course of a certain amount of days, during which you have to gather boxes from these things called abnormalities. If you've read anything on the SCP wiki, it's like that. Between each management day you get at least one cut-scene that gives the game the visual novel identity, with more cut-scenes happening the more objectives you complete. Before each day starts you get one new abnormality, the danger level of which ranges from literally harmless to "just reset now it'll save you a half hour of anguish". Lobotomy Corporation is best enjoyed completely blind. If you enjoy SCP, Management sims, and a sense of mystery throughout the entire game, I highly recommend. That being said, prepare for a bit of grinding. Stats are a very important aspect and grinding for high stats will always be a good idea. Also be prepared to reset; it's nearly impossible to get everything on your first run, in fact it's literally impossible to get everything on your first run. There's not enough days to get all the abnormalities fully understood. My advice is to reset whenever you start to feel stumped and take what you learned and apply it to your next run. This game is a rogue-lite after all, like Hades. 8/10 would recommend.

The following is a spoiler based review addition. Venture at your own risk:
[spoiler] There are five levels of danger in Lobotomy Corporation. Zayin: baby's first abnormality, Teth: friendly hello hi?, He: doable, but god am I scared, Waw: getting spicy, and Aleph: oh got why is everything on fire? Use this to gauge if you can handle an abnormality. The story is fantastic, and I haven't even finished it yet. So many twists and turns and mysteries to solve. On another topic, god does this game drag down sometimes. The first day you get a new Aleph or even a Waw, prepare to reset 3-4 times just to learn the basics about it and eventually get it right. Some abnormalities need specific levels to work and some are fucking bullshit like Alriune and the Silent Orchestra. Fuck those two in particular, I want to get good results not normal! Anyways, if you really need help with an abnormality, the wiki has everything you need and the Subreddit is always welcoming. Finally, let's talk about EGO. The weapons and armor you make from the boxes of the abnormalities are insanely useful. Just getting one of the higher rank means taking way less damage from everything below. A teth armor with 0.8 on white will take more damage than a waw with 1.2, despite 1.2 being weak to white and 0.8 being resistant. Weapons work the same way, but in reverse. You'll deal a lot more damage to breaching abnormalities of lower levels with a higher level weapon. The weapon's damage also matters, but you'll figure that out as you play... This was less a spoiler-y area and more of a "here's some tips from a guy who's put in 50 hours to this game." sort of thing. btw there's a sequel called library of ruina that you shouldn't play until getting the true ending here. [/spoiler]

probably the closest (and best) you can get to an SCP managing game out here (ofc, with it setting in it own universe, there are slight difference on naming stuff, but the basic like classification, containment procedure, data log, all that fancy stuff you know and love still exist, just with it own twist)
you get hella complicated, manual book that explain kinda everything but you understand basically nothing and you will forget everything and realized you fucked up stuff (kinda like paper please)
puzzle like strategy because containment placement do, in matter of fact, matter (a lot)
a rouge-lite element (because boi you gonna fail a lot, and need to grind the hell-out stuff to even stand a chance for endgame content)
RTS (because mid-to-endgame content actually need you to micro bunch of your unit going into battle)
and bunch of other stuff because each abnormalities give unique mechanic to manage properly.

proly you also need decent system to run the game, because boi, the insanity of endgame chaos is amazing, and fps drop right to the ground too, just like the facility i manage after bullshit abnormalities breka loose.

the story is pretty ok, enjoy the world building, but i mostly here for the anomalies, so i able to sit through most of the narrative stuff

the artstyle definitely not for everyone, but it not really distracting, and in my case, it actually grow on me slowly (or, you can push it by saying that the artstyle relate to the lore of the actual story)

though, i quite worry when you already experience most of the anomalies the game has to offers, becuase while it has quiite a lot, you will not able to re-experience the initial wonder that the game offer, and just became another "pick your best gear for the run" kind of game, while it still have a lot of replayability thank to it randomly picked anomalies to be able to choose each time, it can get old after many reset.

so yeah, if you got interest on any of that aspect, definitely a worthy game to pick up (and hey, it's pretty cheap too (and the sequel also planed to launch from it early access next April or so))

while i understand that its meant to be a hard game, i cant get past the fact that sometimes your whole team will be slaughtered just off pure chance, and its not even a very rare chance.

now that alone i could live with but to top it off, when they die they take the gear you spend hard points on too, leading you to make swarms of lemmings to test everything out but even that backfires with just how broad the rules are for certain things to insta kill without warning, its pure chance if you get a base thats playable.

If that sounds good, I'd reccomend it. But if you have other things in life besides gaming, I would not.

I have torn opinions about this game. I will say this is a good game under some conditions, which can be tough to fulfill. I will skip the obvious stuff and go through some more important points (for me).

1. This is a very~ long~ game~
The game has 50 in-game days, but if you actually want to finish the game in the correct way (without bad endings), you will need to go through far more days. LC is one of the few games that by design encourages you to "reset" the game (probably for multiple times). (The "reset" here is different from what you may understand but digger deeper will spoil the game, so take your own risk.) This can be converted to at least 100 hrs (very bare minimum) real playtime. So only jump into it if you want to invest such long time here.

2. You'll need to do research
You know nothing about the abnormalities and the LC universe itself. When you start the game, a whole new world is open to you and this could quickly overwhelm you and worsen your game experience if you insist on trial-and-error. First piece of advice is to take your time and read carefully the manual the game throws at you at the start. You will refer to it constantly during the first few days anyway. Second piece of advice is to do research on wiki and guides and such for the immediately upcoming abnormalities and challenges, while trying not to spoil yourself further. Trust me. Doing research for this game won't ruin your game experience by making the game much easier. You will still fail a lot due to your carelessness and such.

3. You need strong skills of control and management
Into the late game, the game will put you through mountains of challenges, sometimes to the point that you will feel unfair. If you want to challenge your limit of concentration and management skills, this game is perfect. Otherwise, take your chance. (Of course you can choose to bypass some of the challenges, but you'll get bad endings which I consider not game completion.)

4. You're up for a brain exercise.
Let me try to talk about this without spoilers. As I said, you don't know anything about the abnormalities and LC universe at the start, and those sometimes depends on the things that the characters tell you. Talking to the characters is like playing a guessing game, since they can constantly confuse you in the early game (since you don't know anything) and further confuse you philosophically in the late game (since they think you can dig deeper into the universe by then). Even its appearance does not tell you, I assure you the story element in this game is heavy. Very heavy. Just a teaser, every abnormality has its own backstory, and there are eighty-sth abnormalities.

5. Bugs and dev support
This is not a new game. There are still bugs and optimization issues that remain unsolved to this date but I don't think the dev will solve them anymore. (For example, the game sometimes shuts itself down if you play for too long. This once made me so mad since I just finished doing a difficult task and the game didn't save before crashing.) Luckily there're some mods that can solve those problems and you can easily find these mods from Internet. Nonetheless, don't expect dev support since they may just only focus on LOR (the sequel to LC) by now. 

6. One thing that I hold a grudge
As I said, the game encourages you to "reset". In fact, it is still technically possible if you want to finish the game without bad endings in one go (without "resets"). However, to do that you have to avoid doing a specific thing (I won't spoil it here) that the game never even tries to hint at. So, if you didn't spoil yourself about a specific thing about the endgame, you will probably get to a point where you soft-lock your game progress and have no way but to "reset". Personally, I feel that's a bad and unfair game design since it potentially gives you the freedom to finish the game in one go but screws it up afterwards (unintentionally?). I used multiple mods and commands to cheese that but that's still frustrating.

7. After all these... still a positive review
After all the technical problems, I still give a positive review because I believe the dev has put a lot of effort into this game. The stories of the abnormalities and the universe are rich and amazing. The challenges, though beyond tough, are well-thought and make you feel rewarding if you actually complete them. I can't ignore the effort and creativity here. To me, this is a game with excellent insight and idea, yet may be "technically unsatisfying" if you're unlucky or unprepared.

I'm writing this review two weeks after 100% completing the game so maybe I miss sth that I will add to this review in the future. But for now, I hope my review helps some newcomers who're considering buying this game.

Really interesting game concept, it's pretty much an SCP game but everything is original so don't worry about being spoiled if you're already familiar with SCP stuff. I find the controls to be a bit clunky and the tutorials can be a bit hard to understand but it's a solid and interesting game.

Highly recommend this game, of course it has it's pros and cons but every game does. In case you're on the fence or just want to know other people's experiences then here's my list of pros and cons! 

Pros:
-The game plays very well, I have never experienced lag or a crash other than when the game closing out was scripted. I can have all of my employees doing things at once and it still runs smoothly
-Game play itself is very smooth, a little hard to get the trick of which can cause some frustration but when you do get it the game becomes much easier 
-All of the abnormalities are amazing and fun, even the ones based off existing stories like wizard of oz or fairy tales 
-The soundtrack is absolutely amazing. In the game you get warnings called trumpets to set the mood for when something goes wrong and you'd think that a blaring alarm would be horrible on the ears but I even listen to them outside of when I play the games 
-The translations are really good, I haven't really spotted any errors in the structure of the sentences or spelling errors 
 
Cons:
-This game is abysmally long. I've put over 64 hours into this as of this review and I haven't even gotten 10% of the story, not to mention the sheer amount of different abnormalities prevents me from being able to glide through different loops easily 
-Speaking of loops, this is a game where you'll have to start over constantly. When you start over you get to keep most of the objects and information you got from the previous time but you have to work your way back up and hope you don't end up with bad abnormalities that will seriously damage your run
-The difficulty curve is kind of confusing. I had to have other people explain to me that you have to start over every time things get difficult to get better gear so you can pass that bump, the game only explains the basics 
-Even if you do have what you need one little slip up can destroy an entire day, it's a game that requires a lot of attention and no errors
It's good.

I’m going to try to avoid spoilers at all costs because I went into this thing completely blind & I think you should too! I have never experienced anything that is anywhere as ambitious, interesting or intense as this game is or can be at its peak difficulty levels. 
You are the manager of a grand facility in charge of producing energy. How? By performing what appears in the game to be benign research experiments on various types of monsters! Some v cute, some absolutely terrifying with each having its own unique backstory. Your research will unlock valuable information as to how to work with each individual monster for maximum :), :/, or :( results depending on their specific needs and Qliphoth counters as well as armour & weapons (EGO) to deal with the various Ordeals or emergency type situations that might arise amongst your staff and abnormalities should you not meet the specified stat requirements. The mechanical systems in this game go Bananas. Pay attention to everything. 

[b]Employee Assignment Needed:[/b]
You may think, “ah yes... rogue-lite, monsters, this will be a silly little procedurally generated game. SURELY I won’t become attached to these characters or care about their silly little tasks ^-^” Listen... the way in which you are completely wrong..... Oof. These tiny round-headed, bug-eyed, sad, sweet characters GOT to me. *you see someone you know, and they ask you how you are, and you just have to say you’re fine when you’re not really fine, but you just can’t get into it, because they would never understand*
Don’t talk to me about Hod, don’t TALK to me about Netzach, DON’T even mention Tiphereth. Trust me the missions the department heads give you are worth it. Terrifying. But 100% worth it.
Regular hireable employees, v cute. Mostly v dopey. My partner calls them babies. Rest in peace to all the little ones you Will lose.

[b]End Management:[/b]
Persevere. 
This game will not hold your hand but it does give you exactly the tools you need to excel. Should you run into difficulty, lose extracted EGO that was especially hard to aquire, or simply have a monster that you don’t feel you can adequately handle, the game allows you to restart from a save state called the Memory Repository (every 5 days game time). This is a valuable tool if you extract a monster who only seeks to wreak havoc on your facility OR maybe you want to spend more time assigning your employees to specific work types to level up those specific stats before going further. 
Additionally, you are always able to restart from day one. In fact! Utilizing the Memory Repository or beginning anew from day one are quite encouraged! Should you choose to rewind or restart, you will keep all research done on the abnormalities you have worked with as well as unlocked EGO. This makes the beginning of the game much more manageable and (imho) more fun! My only advice would be, if you fail a day early on (with all employees dying) do NOT immediately rewind to Memory Repository as all of the gear that your employees had equipped at time of death is now gone with them. 
Lobotomy Corp does not WANT you to fail and thus there are no true fail states IF you use all of the tools provided.

As they say, “Face The Fear, Build The Future”

I wanted to like this game and was excited to play, but honestly it's just not that fun. It comes down to a few things:

* The interface is clunky and makes you go out of your way to access basic information about things like employee health or equipment. For a management game, that's *really* bad. See games like Oxygen Not Included or Rimworld or even Fallout Shelter, this isn't an unsolved problem. This also leads to using some of the UI being janky or difficulty keeping track/controlling your units.
* Games usually introduce RNGesus as a way of spicing things up now and again, making plays unique. This game is just chock full of it. Virtually everything that happens is random in this game and in a really frustrating way. You can do everything right and just... lose half of your employees. Not because you did anything wrong. Not because you didn't plan for it. Just because a qlipoth meltdown kept going off in a room that can kill an employee instantly. Admittedly, the game is liberal with letting you restart days that go wrong.
* I love the idea of an SCP-like world... But I didn't dig the world building and creatures in this. This may just be chance, but most of the creatures I saw were just obsessed with sins. Why are the AIs and abnormalities so preachy?
* And on that front, SCP has tons of harmless entries. But in this world you'll have lore saying "this creature loves people" and then it will escape it's room and slaughter everybody unprovoked. It contradicts itself several times in just the few hours I played. And not just with lore - actual manager tips conflicted with one another or outright lied about the mechanics of a creature.

I'm honestly not sure why this game has such great feedback, I have to believe it's just me. I recommend watching some gameplay online before playing.

10/10 would see my entire facility get massacred again.

In all seriousness, the game is a very interesting SCP-esque management sim that has a very solid narrative and method of storytelling that sort of reminds me of Nier/Drakengard. You will make progress, you will approach the end... you will fail. And then you will start from the beginning with more knowledge and tools at your disposal... you will approach the end and likely fail again, but this time you make more progress... and the cycle repeats until you are strong enough to overcome your next challenge, and it is so satisfying each time. All the while, you will unlock more of the story each time you do this. The characters will even mention this may not be your first time talking to them.

I will not lie, however, this is a tough game if you want to actually reach the end of it, even tougher if you want the true ending. But I must say, you'll get plenty of hours out of this one for the price, and if you like management sims and dark fantasy stories this is right up your alley.

If you've ever wanted an SCP management simulator, this is the game for you. It's style, narrative, and soundtrack are great too. Even if the 'anime-esque' characters turn you off a little, I'd seriously give this a VERY strong recommend. Even if you only enjoy the management sim, it's still worth your money, easily. FYI, don't spoiler yourself on the wiki or youtube, though, if you wanna have fun. Oh, and expect a little bit of buggyness, not too much thankfully.

you keep doing the *same thing* over and over and over and over and over. I can't really elaborate without going into hardcore specifics of the gameplay, so let's take this hypothetical scenario as a replacement:


imagine you are the owner of a pet store. you get your first pet, a Siamese Fighting Fish who lives in a small jar. you don't have to do much but feed it, and eventually the day ends and you've beaten day 1

day 2 comes in - and now you have a hamster too
no big deal, its just a hamster. you give it food. the sun sets and you feel accomplished.

flash forward to day 5, you now have 3 hamsters, a fish, and a REALLY angry monkey. like he's EXTREMELY angry. if you don't go over to his cage and give him a high five every 5 minutes he'll start screaming in agony.
so you spend most of the day feeding your other furry companions, but now there's this constant, uncomfortable *buzzing* reminding you that this monkey NEEDS to be high fived. 

flash forward to day 10, you have gained 3 enraged, hollering chimps, another hamster, and a large animal of bovine descent
all the animals must be fed, all the monkeys must be high-fived, and that cow detonates random gas leaks if you ever look at it funny. so you pull your big boy pants up, and get to high fiving those monkeys, and after a while you forget why you even started a Littlest Pet Shop (Littlest Pet Shop is a toy franchise and cartoon series owned by Hasbro.) in the first place




so yeah about 7-8 hours into this game I could feel half my face start to sag, don't recommend

A nice feature of this game is that every "level" you do counts as a day and every few days you get a checkpoint, if you progress a few days and really realize you are in a bad place with abnormalities you picked or how you built your employees you can rewind back to the last checkpoint (you can also retry your current day as well). The research you did on abnormalities will remain and you have any employee who died after the checkpoint return and lose any you added. There are missions in this and when you complete a mission and rewind the mission is still completed. Do not be afraid to do this, it's quite handy at least for me. Also try to do your missions as soon as you can because completing a mission provides you with a nice upgrade that you can choose.

Okay, this part is going to be entirely in spoiler tags because I am going to tell you about two abnormalities I would NOT recommend picking. One because it is something that you need to be later in game to handle and the other which is just tedious and I reset when I realized how it worked. Here's the one that I got way too early in game: [spoiler]There is an abnormality called Magical Girl or Queen of Hatred, she can actually be pretty helpful but if three employees or clerks (AI controlled employees) DON'T die within a certain amount of time she goes on a rampage and can decimate your entire facility. Eventually you can get an item called "execution bullets" so I would recommend avoiding getting her till then. Her teaser line is "In the name of Love and Justice~ Here comes Magical Girl!" so if you see that don't grab it till you're ready.[/spoiler] Here's the other that is just tedious IMO. [spoiler]It's called Express Train to Hell and is actually a "tool" type abnormality that when used can heal or buff your agents. The thing is every two minutes or so if you don't interact with it a train will run through your facility slaughtering everything in its path. It's easy to get focused on something else in the facility and only realize you forgot about the train until it's too late. Happened to me until I reset to a previous checkpoint. The teaser line for this one is "When the time comes, the train will chug down the tracks and sound its mighty horn."[/spoiler]
Nothing will make you feel more like a pro gamer than getting to day 50 on your first playthrough.

Maybe I'm the idiot for not realizing what kind of game this was. This game is actually a secretly disguised weeaboo game. Not the kind where women get naked in order to help you learn to feed your parakeet, but the kind where the cutesy anime women talk on, and on, and on, and on, and on, and on, AND ON, AND ON, about NOTHING. It's so fucking frustrating when in-between gameplay segments people decide this is a great time to pontificate endlessly about the meaning of life and other horseshit that they have no valuable insight about. 

However, the gameplay is also bad. See, you study monsters. Not in a fun way, but by sending in interns to fill up a Monsters, Inc. scare-o-meter (not kidding). Unfortunately, these interns die all the time. This would be funny, except it causes the other interns to freak out and you have to put them all down. This wouldn't be such an issue if they weren't wearing valuable equipment and their training was very expensive. So, you feel like you're getting nowhere in the game. The only reason to keep going would be to collect more monsters, but most of them are poorly defined anyway like 'spooky radio static' WOW. How creepy. Sure glad a werewolf wasn't on the budget. Radio static is much more interesting. What a joke. The game barely costs anything and I still feel ripped off

A management game that test your nerves (and patience of your employees) to contain anomalies similar to what the SCP project entails.

Get ready to deal with constant restarts, panic inducing escapes from the specimens and an absolutely raving plot. Don't even research the stuff that happens and let the game take you on the wild ride of insanity managerial tasks

I absolutely adore this game. Even from the time I didn't have it, I would spend hours watching others playing through it, and reading up on the creatures that lurk inside the containment units. And yet, even after being spoiled most of the time from videos and researching, it never stopped me from actually playing the game. And I do not regret it.

If you're a person who loves in depth worlds with interesting characters and plenty of creativity to unpack, as well as stories that are rather grim and horror-based, than this is a perfect fit. The amount of detail put into every abnormality, the uniqueness they all have, each character being lovable in their own way, and the ability to customize your own employees to help shape your own idea of their story, it's very inspiring.

It's a challenging game, but extremely fun. However, it can be seen as a bit repetitive, but with new abnormalities to explore, and even if you have uncovered them all, it never ceases to be entertaining. It takes a lot of careful attention to details as you learn more about the creatures your employees are caring for to prevent them from escaping, and each little quirk they have to them. But the more you play the better you get at remembering. It is fairly slow paced though, so if you're someone who prefers fast combat or game play over story it might not be what you're looking for.

Overall, if you're an artist, writer, creative person, or anything really who loves unique otherworldly creatures and lots of lore, this is the right choice for you. I can't express enough how much inspiration this game has given me, and it saddens me that it isn't as popular as it should be.

An amazing, underrated game in which you take care of monsters known as Abnormalities. These creatures have a similarity to that of the SCPs of the SCP Foundation. Care for them properly and they'll give you energy to run the facility and export power... treat them poorly however and watch as your facility is destroyed in less than a couple minutes if you piss off the right ones.

It is simple in nature, but please, PLEASE give it a try sometime. It's a game with fantastic gameplay and a really good story with little hints and pieces to put things together along the way. The English translation is still being updated, but for now it's sensible enough and makes for a good game.

EDIT: Okay so since my review I've doubled my time into the game and I have to say, please get it if you enjoy trial-and-error survival gameplay with a deep story to follow. Look at the screen shots, the video's, and consider all this.

-The Game since full release has full English translation completed.
-Is now mod compatible.
-Takes little space, and requires no internet to play.
-The game has a lot of replay-ability and several techniques to be learned that can help your management life easier. It's even made to be replayed a couple of times, you'll understand in time!
-The games difficulty is scale-able and controllable (to some extent), this won't make sense right away but you'll figure out eventually that you can use this to make the game easier OR harder for yourself!
-The soundtrack is amazing and the storytelling they make with the team and budget they had is beautiful.

Please, I encourage you give it a try if this sounds promising to you. Don't take just my word for it, make sure the game appeals to you in its imagery, themes, and in gameplay. Don't look in too much though! This game can be a lot of fun blind, but be ready for some trial and error and remember; don't be afraid to restart!

Harvest energy from monsters with dubiously-ethical science. Learn about new critters so they'll stop breaking out. Kill Clerks by the dozens so the corpse mountain can't smell them bleed. Augment your Agents until they're unstoppable forces of nature. Forget you left someone in a cursed bunker until half your facility has breached. Read the manual. Travel back in time to escape your mistakes. Confess your sins to a floating Jesus skull. Meet again as stars.

An amazing game with an excellent lineup of creatures to research and contain, a very strong sense of tone and atmosphere, enjoyable core gameplay, and a really intriguing story with a lot of deep lore to uncover. The early game is rather simple, but things quickly develop until you have a fascinating mishmash of monsters whose management conditions you all need to keep in mind, and challenges later on will really test your skill as a manager.

Now, the gameplay itself is fun, but where I think Lobotomy Corporation really shines is in its story - you wouldn't expect much of a narrative from most management/simulation games, and its slow start here might make you think LC is the same way, but the story is what takes what would otherwise be a neat SCP-esque monster containment game and turns it into a masterpiece. I don't want to spoil anything, but there's a lot more going on in L Corp than "morally dubious energy corporation", and there are a lot of mysteries and twists you'll uncover along the way. The worldbuilding is also quite intriguing - you may never leave the facility (not until the sequel, at any rate), but the writing does a really good job at painting a picture of the world outside and why things in the facility are the way they are.

The soundtrack also slaps. I don't have anything eloquent to say here, it's just some real bangers that are great fits for the scenes/days they play in.

Probably the best game I played in 2019, and the sequel has so far proven to be a worthy successor. Cannot recommend this highly enough if you're a fan of management games or story-driven RPGs. Goes on sale fairly often, if you're unsure about buying it full price. The early days are a sort of "soft tutorial", if you're not sure about the game at first I really advise trying to get to at least Day 21 or so, that's around when things really get going.

If you're thinking of picking this up, here's some spoiler-free advice:
- Read the manual! I'm not joking, it tells you almost everything you'll need.
- You don't have to end the day immediately as soon as it lets you, and it's often beneficial to continue working to train stats and get more gear. Just watch out for Ordeals.
- Buy the Managerial Tips first. Usually.
- Read everything! The floating white flavor text that appears above an abnormality during work can offer useful hints.
- Don't be afraid to retry the day if something goes wrong. 
- Try to avoid the wiki - learning things for yourself is part of the fun!

Good luck, Manager!

I love Lobotomy Corp, I have nothing bad to say about it. It has an interesting story line, fun game play with interesting mechanics and "boss battles", adorable art, and most importantly, many abnormalities with unique lore and backstories. It even has multiple endings, but if you don't want to stop there you can keep playing and going on with the days. You may wish to avoid restarting days so you can learn about each abnormality, in which case I recommend the amazingly polished and very informative wiki. If you're concerned about the translations, they did a full English translation rework after someone Google Translated it and ran off with their money, so now you wouldn't even know it was a Korean game.

I've gone back and forth on this game a few times now.  It's a lot of fun if you enjoy figuring things out through trial and error.  It also has a strange mix of humor and horror which is a lot of fun.  

It is a grindy technical game about figuring out the quirks of the creatures you are trying to contain, in order to keep your team alive and extract energy / gear from them.

It starts off deceptively easy, but soon becomes hard as you start dealing with dangerous things you are not prepared for, then tapers off once you get the hang of that, before getting brutally hard for the end game content.

In truth, I liked the original form of this game more than the way it ended up.  It used to be more of a real-time juggling act than the present almost turn based style it has.  It used to have actions staff could take that were distinct and made sense (Cleaning, Consensus, Amusement, etc.) as opposed to the generic actions that are hard to keep track of in the present game, and have similar looking icons aside from their color.  

The things that abnormalities react to also became more generic with the redesign they did.  There used to be for example personality types and genders for the employees, and there were dramatic consequences when certain combinations happened.  The current game mostly just punishes you for sending someone in with low stats.  Occasionally it punishes you for sending someone in with high stats, which really sucks for the late game.  It just isn't as interesting as it was though.

Some of the abnormalities are not fun to deal with.  I hate things where I can make all the right decisions and still have there be a chance for my team members to die. 

I also wish they had mod support.

I also wish it allowed you to have multiple saves.

The worst thing though was that the game teaches you to play it slowly and strategically, making ample use of the pause button to micromanage for best effect during tough situations.  Then suddenly it will punish you for pausing.

Still, there is not a lot of that in the game now, and it also lets you choose which abnormalities you want to bring into your facility, so I find that I can still play this for enjoyment even if I find myself missing the way it played in the early builds and find myself frustrated with pause thing when it appears.

In the end, I have come around to a soft yes on the recommendation.  There are negatives, but the game itself is a lot of fun.  It's just B- fun right now.  

There are just a lot of missed opportunities and I wish I could still consider this an A+ game like I used to.  If they kept developing this and releasing new DLC monsters for instance, or open it up to the workshop, I think it would be a much better game.

This game has a lot of promise, but needs some serious work

The anomalies that you work with in the game are its best feature.  They are each creative and unique, and fit well into the setting and work well with the game mechanics.  The game is truly enjoyable when you are figuring out each new anomaly.  

Once an anomaly is figured out, however, the only gameplay left is to farm that anomaly for resources and keep it under control.  That means that the game has extremely poor replayability, which would be fine, except for a major problem with the gameplay.  The game will repeatedly force you to use the "replay day" button, which rolls back time and allows you to basically cheat by gaining foreknowledge of how your "new" anomalies will work.  The game does this in a few different ways.  The first is a grading system that you need to use to gain points to hire employees and upgrade them.  When an employee dies, you lose points in this system, which means that you not only lose the points you spent on them, but you lose points that you need to spend on the next day as well, which can lead to a failure spiral unless you use the replay day button to ensure that your losses are few to none.  The second is an event that kills every employee in your main room of each department.  Typically this will catch every employee not actively working with an anomaly.  It can only catch you by surprise once, and you can avoid it by moving your employees out of the main room before an event (these are the morning/noon/midnight events), but it is such bad gameplay design that I am putting it in the review.

The game also has a story, but it may as well have not been there and might even have been better without it.

Fallout Shelter that tries to be less in the rut at the cost of constant frustration.

The unexpected element is discovering new abnormalities and their quirks, most of which have lethal consequences. Since the price of failure is high, you will abuse "Retry the day" button a lot.
This removes the element of surprise. You just develop a routine of taking a new abnormality, unlocking its information, restarting the day knowing it all.
Some other emergent qualities of abnormalities can be approached similarly or require resetting to an earlier save checkpoint.

Still in the end, the game starts to feel repetitive and not that surprising after all.
To take the player out of their rut, there are story and challenges you need to complete to unlock the full story. It is totally not necessary to follow the story to play the game, but it exploits the completionist mind. You need to beat one-time challenges to unlock the story, and this makes the regular facility management much more challenging.

Still, in the end you will need to restart the game completely, since you will want to unlock all the abnormalities the game has to offer. Luckily, by that time the game has supplied you with a variety of permanent cross-save buffs to make the grind faster.

Very similar in spirit to Darkest Dungeon, but with much less unpleasant grind or moments when you feel like you are just getting farther away from your goal. Still probably too reliant on the restart aspect, to the point when you start to suspect play-time spoofing.

A good choice for those who like a challenging game and do not mind failing a lot until they succeed.

This game starts as an interesting sim game but after a while becomes a chore. First of all, this game has a huge memory leak issue which means your computer will have a performance issue even after you turn off the game (you need a restart to fix it) and this issue persists for a long time which means fix will be an unrealistic expectation. Other than that, this game has a huge lore and abnormality variety with stories (see below). Gameplaywise, there isn’t much to do sadly. This game could have been a mobile game easily. There isn’t much to do as macro management while micro management is too limiting. Unfortunately, all of these abnormalities are random while they have different difficulty levels with a certain limitation and that limitation isn’t enough but apparently developers didn’t care; because you can’t finish the game with true ending in one playthrough (if you don’t save scum of course). You can see my playtime above for one playthrough; I had to start-over because of the two alephs I picked around twentieth day (same day). It was an instant game over. After that, I started to check the abnormalities before picking them but even with that, end game was too annoying and repetitive, especially with the leak. Lastly, AI is pretty dumb and unresponsive some times which can mean losing all of your agents. And this will be pretty annoying, because there is no save feature in days, even though they will get longer, more you progress.
At my last run, I was so annoyed of daily abnormality satisfaction pile, after dying to midnight waves. So, I uninstalled the game at day 42 and watch the end game. Definitely, it isn’t worth it, like the story of the game. Story is just a visual novel with fanfiction writing from a website, it seems. However, plot is like this: You are a manager and you produce energy from these dangerous abnormalities. While there is an AI which helps you (not a tiniest bit) to manage the facility, there are some floor managers. You talk to these managers and learn their stories and question some of the things but they are not relevant to gameplay at all. And at the same time, their stories are so abstract and short. [spoiler]At the start of the game, you think that you don’t know the background of your character, sadly your character doesn’t remember anything too. So, what does he do? Nothing, just nothing. You learn it from the AI, just terrific. [/spoiler] What about huge lore though, is it good? That is just mediocre with lots of holes, like it just happens logic. Lastly, music is decent but the game is too long for its limited selection, you will mute it after hating it.

Absolutely one of the best management sim genre game i have ever played, but sadly will forever stay in the "Best game i can't recommend to anyone" folder unless the devs do something about it.

I will just overlook any technical issue and focus on the gameplay on this review.

First problem is the game hardly give off any sense of accomplishment at all unless you are a closet M or have incredible will power. The game gonna punish you hard for any mistake you make. Mess up on a job? Retry the day. Mess up on an ordeal? Retry the day. Forgot about that one guy that will steal all your hard-work of the day once he got out? Retry the day. Oh right, here is a bird that will broke out when you let too many of your employee die and he will call out all his bird buddy too, better retry the day fast then. It's gonna get frustrate real fast if you can't keep your head cool, to the point that when you win the day the only feeling you gonna get is "Thanks f*ck the sh*t show is over"

Second problem is the game give you a lots of ability that don't work or doesn't matter. Protection doesn't matter unless it's a 1vs1 fight. Call in a bunch of special force rabbit that can't even keep one abnomality busy. Some enemies have the power to literally stop you from pausing the game (yes, no pu**y out you filthy casul). And lastly, just a head up, always hit retry the day before rewind memories if you don't want to lose all your hard earned E.G.O (i learned this the hard way, if that was an intended feature i would say that one hell of a feature)

And lastly, could have at least put a "point of no return" sign at that day 46 because if you are like me: On your first playthrough, you are open minded, you willing to forgive all the flaw and just decide to have fun jumping in that end game sequence thinking what could go wrong at this point? Well congratulation, you just efficiently lose like 30~40 hours of your life because you are horribly underestimate the thing that lie ahead. Better... restart the game from day 1 then.

Well, apart from all that, this game is still a blast and the music is absolute banger. I had my fun with it and i believe many are/will too.

Lobotomy Corporation isn't a particularly happy game but I love it. I got it on sale for cheap and I definitely got my money's worth. It's a very difficult game that rewards you with some pretty cool lore every time you manage to complete a day or a mission. It slowly builds up a world beyond the corporation the more you play, and gets you invested in finding out more. The monster designs and concepts are neat, and there's more to the characters than meets the eye. The character creator isn't a big system like other games, but it's cute and you get to equip the characters with gear based on the monsters you work with. You also get to customize death and panic faces lol

It's not a game I can recommend to everybody, but if you like or are okay with horror (scary monsters, light gore, a little bit of psychological stuff), like management games, or really want to challenge yourself, definitely give this a try. If the lore gets you interested but you're having difficulties with the game, there are mods to help make it more manageable. If you decide to play, good luck to you.

Lobotomy Corporation is a game unlike any other, sometimes for better, sometimes for worse. It's primarily for this novelty that I overall enjoyed it and recommend it.

The core gameplay loop revolves around assigning a growing number of agents to a growing number of abnormalities to gather a growing amount of energy each day. Agents will level up from this work, but each abnormality has its own mini-game (of a sort) to learn. Sending the wrong agent in (wrong could be due to their stats, timing, or a variety of creative reasons) can get them killed. This could potentially set off a chain reaction where you lose all of your beloved workers.

That's where the roguelite element comes in. You can always reset the day, or use a memory repository to revert back to the last fifth day. This usually means you can solve whatever problem, though it's possible for some very bad luck to put you in an unwinnable position. As you play through the game, the challenge becomes juggling a ton of things at once, and dropping the ball on one could potentially set off a chain reaction where you lose all of your beloved workers.

But if you find something utterly impossible, you can restart from day 1, with almost everything you've earned except for the agents themselves. You'll use this knowledge to build a better laboratory next time, and progress a little faster. At key junctures, you'll face the equivalent of bosses. Saying much about their mechanics would spoil them, but suffice to say they're very creative. For me, they were the highlight of the gameplay. However, bear in mind during these fights that it's pretty easy to make a single mistake that could potentially set off a chain reaction where you lose all of your beloved workers.

Luckily, there's a banging music track to maintain your interest during these ordeals (literally, ordeals are another mechanic, but they're worth discovering on your own). A good story, with fantastic lore on all of the abnormalities, rewards you for all of your trials and tribulations (though don't expect it to be clear cut, even by the end). Like the gameplay, the story is fairly unique, building on this truly unique experience. The atmosphere is wholly engrossing. Even the boss fights have a compelling and unique manner in which they pump atmosphere in the game. These elements help temper frustration from an accidental click which could potentially set off a chain reaction where you lose all of your beloved workers.

Adding to that frustration in a less fun way is the element of grinding (and the awful UI, but we'll get to that. It just deserves to be mentioned in more than one paragraph). This comes in two forms. One is where players can continue gathering energy past the limit each day in order to enhance employees. This is the optimal strategy, but it's boring. Fortunately, it's not necessary to win. With careful management, I found going 1 cycle past the cap each day sufficient. The second issue is more bothersome: on subsequent replays (where you start from day 1), it's really tedious to return to where you were. There are some bright sides (like seeing new abnormalities and crafting a safer laboratory), but it's overall a chore, further worsened by that time you zone out, and make a mistake that could potentially set off a chain reaction where you lose all of your beloved workers.

Finally, both last and least (in terms of what LC does well) is the UI. I can honestly say the UI is in contention for the worst ever in a game. You might think that's hyperbole, but I assure you it's not. The game constantly obfuscates information, forces you to click quadruple the necessary times, and stresses out the wheel of your mouse. You will absolutely lose agents because of things like a pop-up telling you the agent is calm, all the while hiding their health bar. Hotkeys are lulwut. At best, you can see a list of 5 of your agents simultaneously, out of a number that's eventually [spoiler]10x that size[/spoiler]. And missing one thing could potentially set off a chain reaction where you lose all of your beloved workers.

If you can handle losing all of your beloved workers over and over, sometimes due to ignorance, sometimes due to difficulty, and sometimes due to bad design decisions, then Lobotomy Corporation might just be for you.

I don't even know how to review this game.
I feel like anything that I say will just give you pointless expectations. 
I am very biased because this is with no exaggeration one of the very best games I have ever experienced. To me this game is right at the peak of what video games as a story telling medium can accomplish, standing  next to titans like Planescape: Torment and Silent Hill 2.

Most reviews already describe the various aspects of the game so I'm not sure I can add much here.
You are the new manager of Lobotomy Corporation and it is your job to extract energy from abnormalities.
Read the manual(!), plan your workforce and meet your daily goals. Deceptively simple.
The game slowly reveals more of itself to you as you play. The longer you play the harder the game gets and the more you begin to understand the world, the purpose of Lobotomy Corporation and your place in it.
The game marries gameplay with story in such a natural and harmonious way that it can really only work as a video game, something that I have very rarely seen.

Don't read about the story, don't cheat by reading the wiki, just go in completely blind. I promise that if you put the effort it will be worth your time. Very few games left such a strong impression on me, and if I can get at least one more person interested in trying it out then this review is already worth it.

*One thing to note is that, as you can probably tell from the game time of most people, this game is long. It requires endurance to complete and it took me a long time playing on and off to finish it. If you are looking for a quick 20-30 hour game, this is probably not going to be your cup of tea. And I would still recommend you to at least give it a chance.

It's a rather meticulous management game that gets rather mindbending after the first few in-game days. Luckily, I rather like this sort of game. Made me think of XCOM except the base management is the entire game. I get the feeling that I should be trying to "Iron Man Mode" the game and not use the built-in option to retry the current day at any time, but the loop is rather punishing and trial and error is the name of the game. I should probably try that approach on my second playthrough before I inevitably come to master all the many weird and wonderful creatures the game has to offer.

The game seems to have been designed to do one of two things: put you in a sense of security at the start only to spring something on you; or by choosing the wrong little snippet and putting you forever on edge. Once I got to the six Abnormality, I watched with awe as, through no clear fault I could understand, the damn thing slaughtered all but three of my poor little agents. I don't know if I'm lucky it took that long or if the game has a guaranteed hell beast waiting for you. So yeah, very fun and probably one of those games where you DON'T look at the wiki. Probably good for a few playthroughs' worth of suffering.

While appearing to be a casual management game, Lobotomy Corporation in fact presents brutally difficult challenges to its players. Thankfully, the game spans over 50 days of facility management and allows you to retry each day as many times as you want. Under some occasions, it even allows you to rewind to earlier days while maintaining certain progress (to undo some grave mistakes you might have encountered). Combined with the intriguing plot, Lobotomy Corporation makes the process of "trial and error" a pleasant experience.

PS: Here is a piece of friendly advice for first-time players (mild spoiler):
[spoiler]Do NOT pick O-01-45 unless you are ready for it. This abnormality's effects on your agents CANNOT be undone.[/spoiler]
Gives me immense anxiety 10/10 great game

“Goodness, why are you making such a face? You're making others feel gloomy too. Please be more considerate, you don't live in this world alone after all.” 

“You are very poor at expressing your emotions. You must be quite shy.” 

One sunny day, just like that day they sincerely dried the laundry, they dried their own skin.

"Everyone was finally satisfied when they showed a bright smile. If they met people who asked what was wrong, they would respond: “I'm just shy, that's all. Just shy...”

Lobotomy Corporation is a real time strategy game that hinges upon your ever expanding facility that exploits creatures known as “abnormalities” for energy. I haven’t played much like it, so there’s no easy comparison here. Anyhow, the gameplay revolves around understanding the quirks of each abnormality and being able to juggle more and more as the game progresses. Beyond that, the story is shown piece by piece as you clear days and objectives. While it’s rather long and can be difficult at times, I’ve been impressed with just about every aspect of this game. If you’ve got the time, it’s probably worth a try.

And with that out of the way, onto all of the details.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]

Simply put: abnormalities are dangerous, but profitable. The more of a threat they pose, the more energy they’ll generate in interactions. Your job is to dictate who handles which abnormality and how they do it. The trouble is, you get these things in black boxes with nothing more than a brief sentence to suggest what it could be. While the text might motivate your choice of which one you get, it won’t tell you how to handle it safely, or even give you an accurate depiction of how dangerous it is. Figuring that out is a matter of trial and error on your part. In other words, send someone in there and see if you can learn anything valuable from it. There are fair odds that they’ll die in the process. Most abnormalities can be lethal if you don’t understand them, and that’s the crux of it all. Information is your greatest asset. Your job, at its core, is to find and apply it.

While Lobotomy Corp. is an RTS in the sense that stuff happens in real time, you’ve got a pause button and two fast forward settings. What this amounts to is that you need to pay attention to where people need to be and when they need to be there. The time for fast decision making will come when you’re more prepared for it. As you accumulate more abnormalities, the time settings help you to increase the scale of your orders without slowing the game down. Even if all hell breaks loose, you can always rewind to the start of the day, or to the most recent checkpoint. If you make a mistake, you can always try again.

While the game eases you in real nicely, don’t expect to see it through from start to finish in your first run. There will come a point where there are too many things that can go wrong, and progress will become infeasible. While it’s important to understand where to accept mistakes and push forward, it’s equally critical to know when to go back and take it from the top. Each run is easier than the last, though the final days will always be a trial.

Overall, the gameplay is built upon a simple system of interaction that introduces different rules for each abnormality. The game is paced in such a way that the player will always be handling something new, and will eventually be overwhelmed by the later game stages. Upon reaching these stages, the player is meant to restart with what resources they have, and make it further the next time. The core of the game is solid, and there’s easily enough content to fill multiple playthroughs with unique encounters.

Aside from all that, I really enjoyed the character customization in the game. While you are the manager known as “X”, you’ve got full control over who gets hired. In other words, you get to customize your employees to look like cartoonish versions of your friends, among other things. It’s the best kind of character customizer in my eyes, mainly in that it doesn’t influence the story. Especially because it doesn’t. Your characters are free to develop their own stories and traits without compromising the world they exist in. That’s the magic of it.

[b]Writing:[/b]

The story of this game is generally presented in the visual novel format at the end of each day. While I can’t say too much about it without spoiling anything, the story focuses on giving many trails for the player to follow. As mentioned earlier, you won’t see everything on your first attempt, but you’ll certainly tug on different threads with each playthrough. The story is well thought out, as the events all work in their own ways to paint a picture of the world, its people, and their dreams.

The character writing certainly holds its own too. Everyone’s lived a time in the world and has come to work in the facility in one way or another, “X” included. The present is founded upon the past, and it shows in every interaction you see. Everyone’s haunted by a shadow of sorts, and it hides in their words and actions. Beyond them, every abnormality has a story behind it too, some of which relating mechanically to others with similar backstories.

What really made this special in my eyes was the story’s willingness to get into grey and even dark areas. The road to hell was paved with good intentions, and we’re beyond the point of asking if the ends could ever justify the means. What counts is seeing it through to the end.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]

Lobotomy Corporation is a long game that has a lot of unique systems and is positively bursting with creativity in its story and designs. If you’ve got time to burn, all the better. This is a good one for sure. At the very least, I can recommend it.

There was an employee in the corporation named Frank (not related to me by coincidence)

Frank was somewhat of a shut in, he didn't prefer to talk to others and instead spent most of his time talking with a bird that was being contained within the corporation instead. It was named the punishing bird, but it never really tried to punish anyone from what he saw. They talked about many different subjects, including, but not limited to, philosphy, art, science, maths, and more, this inspired Frank to become a researcher, one day however, Frank was moved from the Control Team down to the Central Command Team 1, he was a bit sad to have to say goodbye to his bird friend, because he wouldn't really be able to visit, but there wasn't anything he could do.

Frank found solace in talking to an anamoly referred to as "The Snow Queen" there, their conversations  were also rather insightful, but Frank never felt like they quite lived up to the conversations he would have with his old fowl friend.

One day however, Frank was delighted by what he saw, Punishing Bird had escaped from it's containment unit and was down in Central Command, Frank tried to spark conversation, however the bird seemed to ignore him and instead pecked at him while yelling "This is for never calling!" It didn't really hurt that much, and after a few minutes the bird left, presumably to go back to containment.

It was a...strange experience to say the least, but Frank was still happy to see his old friend...little did he know it wouldn't be the last time.

This game seemed interesting at first. Unfortunately, however, I quickly realized it wasn't exactly as advertised. Then I got distracted without closing the game out, putting my "playtime" past the point where I can count on a refund. In that case I think an explanation is in order.

What you've got here is really a mobile game. There are extremely few management elements, basically limited to four stats that each character has, and their equipment which alters their damage resistances, and the type that they deal. These can only be modified before each "day". The stats can also only be modified the first time, as retrying a day does not allow you to reallocate the "points" you spent before that day. So while you can mix-and-match equipment all you want, once you use a "point" to either hire someone or modify a stat, that change is permanent.

You are given a terribly laid-out base containing not!SCPs in designated rooms. You send an employee to work with the not!SCP, using one of their four stats which have varying success rates depending on their level and, the particular not!SCP, and potentially other factors. By working with them you gain "boxes" which you can spend to learn more about the not!SCP, and purchase equipment that can be equipped between days. If the work is unsuccessful, bad things happen. However if the work is successful bad things also happen. Given this setup you must meet a quota of total boxes produced each day.

Your development is completely railroaded. You see that nice image they've got there with what would appear to be a branching, research-like system? That is an outright lie. The truth is that only one of those "research nodes" is available at any given time, and at least thus far in my experience, they must be fully upgraded before another is available. It's a case of "Choose which upgrade you will select from the single option available!".

The Not!SCPs aren't very interesting at all. These are the sort of bad SCPs that wouldn't actually make it onto the wiki.

The gameplay is a slog of boring "select a worker, then select a destination", irritating music I just found myself muting, and unappealing visuals.

And as your characters die, the game doesn't give you any leeway. If your best guy dies you just need to retry the day, because you're fucked without them. But if anyone else dies you learn that you should just retry too, because you need as many characters as possible to deal with some challenges. It's very possible to lock your game in an essentially-unbeatable state. In this case you must restart the entire game from scratch, which means losing many hours of progress.

How very apropos that this game's punishment is more gameplay.

[h1]WHILE I AM RECOMMENDING THIS GAME, PLEASE NOTE IT'S NOT FOR EVERYONE[/h1]

The music is excellent. While some tracks may get repetitive just off the sheer amount they'll be played (looking at you, Neutral01 and First Warning), not a single one is particularly 'bad', while others make certain moments all that more memorable. 
The story is phenomenal, doubly so now that it has a proper translation and doesn't devolve into Engrish. While it may start out as a pseudo-SCP, it quickly evolves into something more interesting and compelling. I could go on for paragraphs about the sheer accuracy and detail Project Moon put into the more esoteric aspects of their story and how they tied it to the compelling characterization, but then we'd be here all day. 

But while the gameplay is relatively simple and starts out easily enough, I can definitely say the end-game is unironically some of the most difficult and challenging gameplay you will experience. The best way I can describe it is: Each monster has their own unique mechanics, as to what they like/don't like and what happens when you finally make them mad enough to escape. Some don't like it when someone with a low stat does a work type. Some don't like it when someone with a high stat does a work type. Some don't like it when you get a bad work result. Some don't like it when you have a good work result. Some have a combination of the above. Some don't like it when employees die, while some don't like it when no employees die. Some have extremely specific triggers, and god help you if you set them off. The end-game monsters you'll face are especially specific and punishing. It's easy when you only have 5 to juggle, but by the end you're juggling ~60, all the while having to face 'mini-bosses' every once and a while, whose difficulty ranges from easy to 'just restart the day'. Then certain events that will deliberately screw with your core game mechanics, but give permanent rewards across your persistent save file if you finish them. The end-game cranks all this up to 11. 

I cannot stress how absolutely, ball-bustingly hard this game is.

I still cannot recommend it enough.


Some aside notes though.
The game does suffer from memory leaks. 8gb will save you for a little while, but generally the longer the days go the more likely you'll suffer worse and worse from them. One trick that does work a bit is to mute the game music.

[b][i]DO NOT USE A WIKI[/b][/i]
Half of the enjoyment of the game is blindly experiencing the chaos of a new monster. Spoil yourself at your own peril.

Please for the love of Skull Jesus, read the in-game manual. It explains every mechanic in the game phenomenally well, even the hidden mechanics the game doesn't explicitly tell you about.

This game doesn't explain half of what you're supposed to do.

I understand I'm a manager for some SCP-like facility and that I move employees to "work" on [strike] anomalies [/strike] abnormalities to generate energy, but I have absolutely NO idea what occurs in there. I don't understand what employee health is, I don't understand what makes the boxes on the left of the abnormalities go up or down, etc.

Here's a fun thing that happened: An abnormality, 1.76 MHz, was constantly screwing up my employees. Ok, fine, that's part of the challenge. Here's the issue: YOU CAN HEAL EMPLOYEES AFTER THEY'RE PANICKING. Does the game explain this? Hell no. You wanna guess how you heal the employees? Is there a first aid kit somewhere? A medic? Nope. You hit them with white or black weapons. What's a white or black weapon? Read the wiki, like I had to; I still don't get it to be honest. It's similar to Pokemon, I think, with the different types of attacks (special, physical, status) that utilize various stats to back them up (such as a higher special attack making a special type move stronger), but NOTHING in the game explains this.

Nothing is explained beyond basic UI, and I just don't have the patience for a game that does that. I'll stick to reading SCP entries, at least they make sense.
This game is awesome. It's best to go in blind and ignorant so that you get the best possible experience.

There are some reviews on this page which will tell you that Lobotomy Corporation is a monster management simulation. I am here to tell you that this is, in fact, a blatant falsehood and, having reached an ascended state of being, can now reveal the truth:

[b]Lobotomy Corporation is a monster dating simulator game.[/b]

With almost every day, you can pick an additional monster's route to unlock. There are four options to do stuff with them but the only important one for waifu purposes is Attachment. There are so many different options to romance, from cute AIs and robots to slime girlfriend, the [CENSORED] which also features NSFW scenes (still have not figured out how to bypass this filter but I am sure this is an option somewhere), a tsundere Bloodborne girl, and also a bishonen sparkly enough to rival Edward Cullen, amongst many others. If you have a foot/leg fetish or hand fetish or happen to like dogs, that's also covered! Also birds. There are so many birds in this game it's untrue, I counted at least six.

Many monsters are a bit tsun-tsun and will try and smack you around little before admitting any kind of affection. However they may also like to give you presents as a token of affection. Just be warned that too much waifu will ruin your laifu, and if you try and pursue too many different routes at once, then they may follow you out of the containment and fight over you, and if there's one thing that nobody wants, it's multiple prospective monster gfs/bfs duking it out in the facility. Or maybe you do, it's kind of entertaining to watch. Also sometimes these random jackasses will show up out of nowhere and try to ruin everything, but you can ask Ms. Bloodborne to beat them all up so it's OK. 11/10 would date again.

(On a more serious note this game does have an excellent and meaningful story line and is a great monster management simulator. That being said, go into it fully accepting the facts that a) you are most likely going to have to restart from day 1 if you want to 100%, and b) a lot of stuff is going to blow up in your face the first time you deal with it so don't expect a oneshot run or anything. The translation errors have since been fixed thanks to the many efforts of the fanbase, too. Only remaining issue is the occasional tendency for memory leak to build up on long days; you can usually help avoid this by closing the game and booting it up again on failed attempts, and letting it run until it resolves the end-of-day section. There are also mods which should help with this issue, available on the NexusMod website.)

This game is a management simulation, but dialed up to eleven. It is in no way, shape or form a casual management sim. Mistakes are usually severely punished. Chaos is routine, and death is common place. 

The lore and the storyline are very impressive, which further adds to the immersion. The story explains about the things you will see as you progress.

The gameplay is quite intense, despite being a management sim. As the game progresses, you will develop muscle memory and your own tactics in order to advance. At some point, micro-management will become crucial in order to overcome certain ... hiccups you will inevitably encounter. The management part is also demanding. The Abnormalities that you will manage will have unique and sometimes distinct traits, each and everyone of them, forcing you to assess and allocate suitable and sufficient attention to each and every one of them. Some are relatively passive and harmless, and can be left alone without consequences. While some requires constant attention and extensive manpower to manage. [spoiler] Frick you WhiteNight[/spoiler]

Overall, the game is really well-made, and it has earned a special place in my heart.

For new players, you can either go in blind or you could prepare yourselves with guideline, info and tricks. Either way, it will still be a fun and immersive gameplay. ( if feeling an intense amount of frustration and despair is your thing, go in blind)

It gets really boring very fast. Not to mention how glitchy and clunky it actually is. Not worth it at all, if you wanna know more of the story, save yourself some time and watch a video of the lore online.

Ah, [i]Lobotomy Corporation[/i].

Amass a collection of curious entities from realms unknown!
Harvest "Energy" for reasons that aren't clearly defined!
Hire a staff of adorable little employees, and become deeply, emotionally invested in their well-being!
Watch in [i]abject horror[/i] as they are butchered in droves by otherworldly abominations!
Frantically mash the "retry" button, because you [i]will not[/i] accept the death of a single one of your precious babies!
Repeat until your nerves are frayed!
