This game is something to behold tbh. It's a Monster Management Rogue-Lite Simulation game in which you study things called abnormality's, and as you study them you create power for the facility that you work for. I'm not going to lie this game is very hard at the beginning of the game and you will die a lot early on. After a while tho you do learn how to study things better and you learn where to send people,  and where to put them. Tho the difficulty of the game might make you reconsider rather if this game is for you or not. If you can't accept the fact that your going to need to restart runs because of certain abnormality's being together and just royally screwing you this game might not be for you. There are over 100 different abnormality's in the game and each are ranked in which how hard they are to keep locked up and the amount of death they can cause 

ZAYIN- The easiest to keep locked up and are most of the time nice to you but still are capable of death 

TETH- They can break out if your careless but still not to bad to deal with if you got gear and don't make to many mistakes 

HE- They are more then capable of killing so many people if not looked after,Might need to hire special people just to keep one of these in locked up. They will put up a fight so be careful 

WAW- The ones that can end your day in seconds if not looked after and are really hard to keep locked up. They are really hard to study sometimes and will will kill people as soon as they enter there box if there not up for the job and escape. And some are super strong ready up the group if one escapes if you don't have good gear from past runs.

ALEPH- and then there are these guys, if one gets out you might as well just cry and restart your day or even run depending on the one ALEPH you get, these guys are god like and are almost impossible to kill

So why would you pick ALEPH class abnormality's then? Because the stronger the abnormality the more energy it makes also you don't get to pick the abnormality you want because you won't even know what your picking. Yep at the start of each new day your given 3 options to pick one and all you get is the abnormality's tag number and a faint description of what it is. After when you learn about it tho you keep it's info for future runs so you will know it's name when you pick from your daily 3.

other then that your given the whole idea for the game there are some other things about the game that are best found by your self when you play like the characters and story also do note this game is not originally translated in English so there might be some mistakes when your reading stuff but it's mostly bin fixed out.Also people are saying there is a memory leak problem in the game,I haven't had any issues about game after 70+ hours but I could be wrong plus I have heard there are mods to fix that issue again idk if that's true or not heard it from a bud. Would honestly recommend this game if your a fan of the SCP Foundation and or like creepy creatures.Tho for the price I would wait for a sale if your hesitant of buying it. Tho this game does have a lot of replayability for the price since you need to study everything to get the best ending.

So to rap things up 

-Game is very hard in a lot of elements
- lots of replayability
-All of the abnormality's are unique and original in most ways 
-characters are cool and you learn to like them as the story goes on
-would wait for a sale if your hesitant of buying it but still not bad for the normal price if your looking for something new to play

also a huge tip for new players if they don't want to die rate away and this is spoilers for one SCP [spoiler] Do NOT trust the plague doctor if you run into him he is one of the few SCP'S that can and will ruin your whole run if you run into him trust me [/spoiler]

If I wrote a review for Lobotomy Corporation a year or so ago, my main issue would be how the story is hard to understand due to the translation issues, along with translation issues in the gameplay itself. However, now that all the text has been fixed to be clear and understandable, I gotta say that I really don't have that many issues with it anymore.

The gameplay is that of a management game where you control different characters to do different things, but it takes a whole new approach to this formula by adding in the "monster management" aspect. Your characters are tasked with working on different monsters, called abnormalities, and you need to figure out what you need to do in order to maximize the output, or just to prevent the character from dying.

The game starts out simple but over time you have to deal with more and more abnormalities of increasing difficulty that can be set off by the simplest mistake. Even some of the earlier abnormalities can cause significant trouble if you don't pay attention. This can also result in domino effects in which while trying to stop one abnormality another one escapes and so on, resulting in you being almost required to restart the day.

While talking about having to restart the game, this brings me to how these retry mechanics work. The game rewards you taking what you learned from a failed day and putting it to use when retrying it. The game also lets you load your save from a "memory repository", which happens every five days. These bring back all of the dead characters and resets the facility to what it had been on that memory repository day, with the only exception being that you keep the same gear and information on abnormalities that you had. If this still isn't enough, you can reset all the way to the first day but keeping all the gear and info.

Another feature carried over by the resets is the boss battles defeated. There is multiple boss battles throughout the game which I won't go into detail, but they add plenty of difficulty to your playthrough. And Lobotomy Corporation has a lot of difficulty. At points the game will just not hold back, throwing lots of increasingly hard stuff at you. It feels incredibly satisfying to beat this obstacles.

The story, on the other hand, is done in a way in which you gain more info about the world in between each day, and from completing quests you can get more story focused on specific characters. This helps break up the gameplay and allows you to slowly get more and more information. The world itself is also very interesting, but is more heavily built upon in the sequel game, Library of Ruina. Even without that, you can still be engrossed in the plot.

All in all, Lobotomy Corporation offers a new take on an old genre and is a very enjoyable experience. Definitely a favorite of mine at this point, even with the issues it can have.

An absolute masterpiece when it comes to any sort of game that centers around research and management, with you actually doing the work of figuring out how things work and how to avoid disaster (although, it's still up to you to make the calls whether to listen to your notes or not). You quickly go from a stable, small, and simple facility to a massive complex filled with employees specialized just for certain anomalies, some people hired just for suppression of breached entities, and a quadrillion things you must keep track of or else everything will come crashing down hard. Though said quadrillion things aren't too complex; it's not like you have to keep track of inventory (save for which "boxes" you got from certain anomalies which can make armour and weapons for your agents, and the number of these things you have on hand for them to use).

It well demonstrates the inspiration of the game, namely SCP, in terms of how it is represented. Though, unlike the Foundation, you don't have death row inmates doing the science, but rather your agents interacting right with the potentially game ending beings that may or may not take a few lives should things turn out for the worst.

It combines elements of horror quite well and each of the abnormalities are original in almost every aspect, save those inspired by something (which, even if they are, they always have an original twist to their stories, [spoiler]such as the Warm-Hearted Woodsman, who is a twisted, vile version of the Tin Man from the Wizard of Oz[/spoiler])! If you enjoy SCP, you will LOVE this game!

The only major critique I have for it is the English translation, seeing that Project Moon self-translates these instead of going through a professional translation team. However, as I have observed, the game's English translation is actually higher quality that other games and media that have been self-translated from Eastern Asian languages. The use of pseudoscience terms is also a bit difficult for newbies to get a grasp of, though it will click with the player at some point what these mean, if anything at all.

8.1/10!

Edit: Thanks to the work of Cool Kids Club, a translation team who is chill and good, I'm bumping my score up to a solid 9.6. Their translation is excellent and even makes a few callbacks to some mis-translations from the old version that have become beloved community memes, e.g. the bear-themed beer. While the pseudoscience terms may still throw new players in a loop, I feel they've justified it. I'm bumping up the score a little more as, after playing it, I did some research and discovered a lot of the symbolism that ties this game together, in both religion and philosophy. It's grown into a proper indie franchise given lots of care by a team with so much ambition that they released a webnovel, a comic series, a sequel, and even a restaurant around their game.

Lobotomy Corporation is a great management game, filled with intrigue and confusion, with your job being managing the employees who contain, use and probably die to the many varied Abnormalities.

With an underlying story that continues into the sequel Library of Runia I suggest Lobotomy Corporation if you want to test your management skills both micro and macro.

As a final piece of advice, if your facility is beset by a great being who brings medicine and it looks grim, pray for there is one sin among 12.

So, while I have yet to beat this game, it rules. Lobotomy Corporation is a game with a lot of heart, soul, skill, talent, and Enkephalin put into it. Each and every Abnormality is a treat, or sometimes shock, to obtain and experiment, some better than others, and the missions give a reasonable, but difficult, challenge. It may not be for everyone, but hey, this is the first game in the "Management" genre I've enjoyed and haven't gotten bored off! While the asking price is a bit steep, due to the history Project Moon has had, what with being screwed over by a bad translator, they deserve every drop of support possible. Face the Fear, Build the Future. Welcome to Lobotomy Corporation.

An amazingly crafted game! This is compared to SCP a lot, so if you're into that I think you'll like this too! Imagine that you're the manager of an SCP facility and you oversee your "guards" (Agents) collecting energy by working with the "monsters" (Abnormalities) that you can pick yourself in this game, okay? The game has quite a bit of replay value, especially if you want to see what ALL of the Abnormalities do (and get the true ending while you're at it!) I won't spoil too much, but the Sefirot meltdowns have interesting gimmicks that add risk with LOTS of rewards if you're up for their challenges, so prepare for the loss of your poor Agents and clerks! Talking about Agents, there's a lot of customization options for them like hair and eyes, you can even give them fighting, panicked, and dead expressions! The Abnormalities can also give you great suits, weapons and various "gifts" if your Agents are lucky, so Lobotomy Corporation also has great "original character" making potential! If you don't have the money, I recommend watching Sinvicta so you can see the chaos this game has to offer! The game also occasionally goes on sale (as of 11/27/2020, it's only $9.99,) so you REALLY should purchase it! All in all, me and many others are obsessed with this game, so you should come and join us in this eternal hell! :)

Game's a pretty rough gem, but it's still a gem. As of this writing, the game's on sale, and it will be until December 1st 2020. It's safe to say it won't go on sale again anytime soon, and $10 is an incredibly generous price for it. If it's no longer on sale by the time you read this, it's still a pretty damn good game for the price, though unfortunately this is a game you have to play for more than 2 hours to appreciate so it's impossible to give it a fair shot and then refund it if you didn't like it. A very good game to keep yourself busy. The game has good music, the abnormalities are very creative, and it gets very challenging. Not to mention the story is unique.

I'm on my third or fourth play through. The game mechanics are solid, the soundtrack, characters and plot are much better than I had expected, and there's incredible creativity on display. Mechanically, the game is simple: you have these creatures called Abnormalities. You send in employees to interact with them in one of four ways and somehow, it generates energy. Your goal each day is to obtain a certain amount of energy. Sometimes. these abnormalities escape, so you send employees to beat them up to get them back in their cages.

This game falls into the management sim genre, so make sure you like these kind of games before buying. I very, very, very, very strongly recommend that you do NOT watch a play through of this game before buying. One of the main features of this game is that every abnormality is different and has certain quirks that you have to discover. The more you know about the game before you go in, the more you spoil it for yourself.

Lobotomy Corporation is IMO one of the best games I've played in the management sim genre.

But I can't recommend it.

Although the developers nailed the game aspects, they did a much poorer job on the technical part of the programming. This game is a ticking time bomb with huge memory leaks problem that will crash your game and your computer if you aren't careful. Worst of all, these bombs tend to go off during boss fights, days that go over an hour, or right before the game saves after completing special events. It is extremely frustrating to devote an hour to accomplish something just to watch the game crash and lose it all.

Because of this memory leak issue, even though I love the game I will not recommend it to anyone. If it ever gets fixed (unlikely due to the age of the game), I will happily turn this into a positive review.

To start with I'm only giving a negative review in the case of paying full price for this game. I do not personally believe the game is worth a 25 dollar price tag. I do not recommend paying full price for this game, nor did I pay full price for it myself. If you can get it on sale for under 15 dollars, like I did, than you can get your money's worth out of it. Otherwise just watch a let's play for the lore/story, which is the part about this game that is pretty cool.

The gameplay itself is extremely basic and virtually non-existent, and you don't have very fine control over your agents by any definition. There is also no difficulty settings so you can't just play it for the story, for those of us more interested in the story than the gameplay. You have to deal with what little mechanics there are if you want to explore more of the games lore/story and see more about all the characters (which is the really interesting part of the game), and spamming the restart button on a day because your agents are suicidal maniacs is just getting tedious.

Basically a case of "The writers were A class but the programmers were C class". The gameplay itself plays like an old flash game you'd see on Armor Games or something (the kind you'd play for free in your computer class in high school instead of doing the assignment... or was that just me?).

Overall, if you can get past the mediocre gameplay it's still very much worth it for the story and exploring the characters/anomalies and their lore; however, I bought the game on sale for like 10 dollars. I would never recommend paying full price for this game, but I do have to say I think I'm getting 10 dollars worth out of it.

This game is not for everyone, but do not mistake it for an obtuse grind fest. It is a managerial simulation game that relishes not knowing, and rewards reading the manual and patiently investigating the world and its denizens. As a manager of the corporation, you are in charge of sending employees to harvest energy from Abnormalities. You will absolutely lose employees in horrible accidents, but that is okay because you can retry with almost nonexistent penalties. The objective is to gather enough daily energy from possibly surly Not SCPs to meet the quota while keeping your employees sane and alive. Doing well will reward you with points you can spend on learning more about the abnormalities, and also eventually be used to generate gear that you can give to employees to extend their lifespan. You will eventually soft restart through an in universe mechanic and encounter new creatures to die horribly to as you perfect your facility and learn more about the company.
Buy Lobotomy Corporation.

I've come to revise my original joke review into an actual one.

 Upon reflection I think Project Moon have made a game that scratches a lot of my particular itches. I've fallen in love with the artstyle, music, world, story and gameplay. It has very little to offer in the gameplay department of your typical conventional management game tropes. The dialogue and worldbuilding, after having been re-translated, of course, is actually quite well-written. It lends itself to crafting a world outside of the small one of that the player character sees, yet is still entirely believable and interesting. 
 
   Unfortunately, however, the game's control methods and odd quirks lend it to being unable to hook new players and keep it from gaining the mass-appeal that it more than certainly has the potential for. It's control methods for your agents themselves are odd at best and frustrating at worst and are more of a suggestion than order. It has a lot of things about it that one definitely needs to spend more than a few hours past steams refund limit of playing to really begin to get the full gist of or get used to as a player.

    I love this game through and through, but I don't think it's something that everyone will give a fair chance, but I can't really necessarily say that I could blame them given the above reasoning. If this game wasn't your thing but the characters and world still interest you, then please, by all means, give the sequel, Library of Ruina a shot. It's an entirely different genre of game while still making many callbacks to this game, and recounts the key plot elements from Lobotomy Corporation.

This game is good. Quality. It's not a legendary product, but it's enough for most people. However, what really carried me (and probably most people) forward was the amazing story. It's seriously well written, and such quality is taken over in the sequel Library of Ruina.

Oh yea, did I mention this game has a sequel? If you wanna see what they made from the funds of this game, go look at that game.
Anyways, regarding the gameplay- you take over as a Manager of L Corp, also known as Lobotomy Corporation. Your company is in charge of generating power in a very clean way- by interacting with special creatures known as abnormalities and making them happy. This happy energy they produce is then used to keep the city alive with power. The only problem is; most if not all abnormalities enjoy munching on your employees, splattering your clerks into paste, or just enjoy seeing your entire facility fall into ruin. I fully, 100% recommend playing this game with as little to no knowledge about the abnormalities as possible. The game shines best when you're playing it blind and are stumbling through the darkness.

The gameplay itself is fine. Initially, it's easy, but once you reach mid to late game, the difficulty starts rising sharply, showing itself as a well made management sim (especially if you picked the needy abnormalities). There are a few bugs here and there, but overall it works well. Just be warned though, endgame (the final 4 days) have a MASSIVE difficulty spike, and the game encourages you to reset until you make the game easier and easier to deal with. And by reset, I don't mean the day or the past five days, I mean back to square one. I understand that can be a turn off for some people, so I thought I'd say as much.

Music is all right, nothing too special besides the ones used for cutscenes and the last day. I recommend listening to Library of Ruina music to see what they're capable of in the future.

Visually, it's simplistic. 

Storywise, it's absolutely amazing, and you'll find there is a justification for damn near everything in the game. There are a few hints about it strewn inside abnormality lore as well, so it's really cleverly made.

All in all, I recommend this game. I'm not a fan of management games, but this one caught my attention.
8/10, would recommend beating the game just to play Library of Ruina, which is a masterpiece. (Of course, the story also makes sense for those who haven't beaten lobotomy corp, but it helps you appreciate it more).

I love this game, but it hits a very specific part of my brain that makes me want to just try one more thing, play one more day, to the point where I'm not sure if I'm having fun any more. Around day 24-25 I hit a bit of a difficulty plateau (even with restarting from Day 1) and I decided to take a step back. It's very fun, the new English translation is really good, and it's super creative.

This is highly innovative and unique game. It is unlike anything I've ever played before. All of the Abnormalities (monsters) are all different and you are forced to experiment. Would recommend to anyone who doesn't mind having to learn some info by trial and error. Can't wait until more Abnormalities come out. Fun for hours.

75% of the time it's a chill management game where you assign people to do things with off-brand SCPs such as figure out what exactly their deal is.

25% of the time it's not a chill management game because everything has immediately gone to heck due to having done The Wrong Thing with a given off-brand SCP because you didn't know any better.

these percentages change as you add more stuff.
~

Memery aside: It's a fairly straightforward concept. Game's divided up into days, days have an energy quota to meet, you get energy by poking things in a variety of manners (most of which will go wrong until you get more information on a given thing), bigger Things give more energy per go. You get some events that kick off to prevent you from just mashing the work button on the easiest abnomality, and so on. Later things are trickier to work with and will probably kill most of your employees outright.

Major Upgrades (and plot) are doled out via milestone objectives and typically add new mechanics or information to leverage, each new thing added to the facility has a set of equipment you can make for smaller, per-employee upgrades (or just outright is something you can use if you know how, though a lot of them have drawbacks)

There's some light RPG elements, people with the right stats generally makes work go better, and you can grind to raise them in a pinch though I'm not sure if that's actually worth it or not.

The plot goes places and some of the stuff that can happen is rather intense in all senses of the word. 

The soundtrack ranges from one of the most relaxing general themes I've ever heard to PTSD-inducing when some of the bigger stuff breaks out.

Overall: It's a good time, if a bit slow-burning until you get to the good stuff. Also it can get a bit rough if you're trying to keep all your guys alive.

So this game is a management clock spinning game.  That is to say, there are essentially a lot of things going on with tight timers you need to watch, and sub rules that you need to learn (e.g. don't send this employee anywhere else after working with that anomaly because they will instantly die, don't send an employee with temperance under this level to work with that anomaly because they will instantly die.  Don't approach this anomaly from the front because... they will instantly die.  Do I detect a trend here?).  It reminds me of cultist simulator actually, but more chaotic and with much worse writing (it is translated from Korean though, and Alexis Kennedy is an amazing professional writer with English as a first language, so it is comparing apples to oranges.  No insult to this game).

There is a lot to like here, but ultimately this game is INCREDIBLY repetitive and grindy and pretty RNG till you have played it enough to know what is manageably bad and what isn't and even then to some degree.  It is so incredibly easy to end up with a cascade failure even with a dozen level 5 agents with good gear.  The whole game is just frustratingly over-whelming in the later stages with so much going on, and even a small mistake or bad dice roll means you need to restart the day or accept terrifying losses that means you are stuffed in the days ahead.  Of course if you know enough to pick the right mix of minor anomalies and waw/aleph ones to farm, while also dodging certain really 'orrible and annoying ones, then all good.  But that takes a lot of repeats and I just can't be bothered anymore.

In the end I just got sick of starting again and again and giving the same orders again and again, and then making a mistake or having a bad RNG ordeal trigger and having to start over again.

So, I probably got my money's worth, but I came out feeling as frustrated  as happy after any play session.  So, I don't think I can recommend.

This is a game similar to Getting Over It, if you are not into being beaten down, and then completely restarting the day and having another go, save yourself some cash, and just go read the Lobotomy Corporation Wonderlab comics, and some of the wiki articles if you want just to get to know the lore.

When you make a mistake, it is usually a bad one, and when there is a change it is usually for the worse. It is not heavily luck based but if you were to say it's entirely skill you'd be clowning yourself as well. There aren't many games like it, besides like I said the popular art game "getting over it". Both games turn relatively monotonus activities and what should be boring gameplay into some dramatic, angering, sometimes heartbreaking feel. You absolutely will rage quit, and not want to come back to this game.

It's entirely about the odds being stacked against you, and if you will leave the game or not. Now granted most people don't want to play a game that punishes them for playing, but there is definitely an audience for that. Hell I'm one of them, so buy this game if you enjoy games that punish you for playing such as Getting Over It, Darksouls, etc...

LC is a game about managing monsters to produce energy. You produce this energy by sending agents with unique stats, equipment and accesories to interact with them in their containment cell. If you have ever been through the SCP wiki then the monsters (called abnormalities, or abnos) would feel at home with the better of them. These abnos can breach their containment cells and wreck all kinds of havoc or possibly help your facility, the abno called One sin and hundreds of good deeds can for instance instantly kill the most dangerous abno in the game for the small payment of one of your agents. You start the game on day 1 with just one abno (the afformentioned one sin) and a couple of agents all crammed into a single department and you get more of every one of these as the days pass. At the start everything is VEEEERRY slow but it picks up the pace as you get more abnos with different containment procedures to jugle, as well as "boss battles" that start to appear halfway through that can be realy hectic and fun.

The paragraph above is a lie. the game is actually about the story of X (you), Angela and the sephiroth (AI managers) of the different departments as well as the strange workings of the facility and titular Lobotomy Corporation and the motive of the absent founder of the corporation Ayin. The monster management turns into a break/challenge between story sections. Some readers might recognize some names there, namely sephiroth and maybe even Ayin. These are ideas from jewish mysticism, specifically the Kabbalah. While most games skim the top of weird concepts for a unique aesthetic, LC and the story (but not gameplay) sequel Library of Ruina unlike most games dives deep into their theme and it works oddly well. Characters, character relations, layout, names, symbols and so on all tie back to jewish mysticism and it is quite facinating. You don't need to know anything about the Kabbalah to enjoy the story but it is a rewarding deep-dive to read up on.

TL;DR: Came for the gameplay, stayed for the story

con's

Lobotomy Corp. shows potential and is interesting, and even fun, for the first few dozen hours. I want to be able to recommend it, based on what it could be, but for what it is, I'd have to say save yourself the time and just look up the dialogue if you're interested in the lore, which is the only real reward the game has to entice you with. It's an unconventional game about trial and error, and when I say unconventional, I mean it. The game is designed to waste your time if you don't know what you're doing, and more importantly so, even when you do.

That initial Fear that you're made to face turns to absolute Dread once you realize what you have to do to beat the game, and just how uncompromising and unfair to the player the system ultimately is. I don't like saying this, but in all honesty, this is the biggest waste of time I've spent on a game. The lore and everything interesting about the game is out there. There is no justifiable reason to waste your time playing this if you value your time.

Edit: Elaborated on in the comments.

[h1]Welcome to Lobotomy Corporation![/h1]
Get comfortable, and prepare to face the fear and build the future [b]at great, great cost.[/b]

Lobotomy Corporation, also subtitled "Monster Management Simulation," is a weird and wonderful roguelike strategy management simulator.
Drawing inspiration from the works of the SCP Foundation and numerous sources in scifi, sci-fantasy, folklore, horror, gaming and more, LoboCorp initially presents a very simple premise to the player : Manage a facility focused on research of abnormal entities, and translate that work into energy. More successful work, more energy produced. 
Simple in theory, fascinatingly touchy in practice - you're applying a very loose version of the scientific method here, and spoilers! LoboCorp has very, [i]very[/i] loose definitions on "employee safety protocol."

The entire game is rendered in a fun, cutesy bubblehead [i]'moe'[/i] aesthetic; very charming, no eyesore to look at for long periods.  You won't feel a thing when the staff dies! Look how cute they are when they scream!
Of note is the English translation, which used to be much choppier (being translated from native Korean); the recent (as of writing) update has since cleaned it up dramatically. (I'll note I don't entirely approve of the translation cleanup, as some of the Engrish actually helped accentuate how strange and esoteric the game is).

The music is superb, though you'll be hearing two or three tracks far more often than the others; the inclusion of a diegetic music system rating you based on current panic level really does help you keep solid tabs of how well you're keeping the facility under tabs -- and conversely, how boned you really are when things truly hit the fan.  
Of special note is the [i]"Second Trumpet"[/i] theme. You'll know it when it happens - and you'll learn to love/hate the level of chaos that provokes it.

Being a roguelike game built on a 'days' system LoboCorp does a lot to try and balance the level of stress it ekes out of the player with some nice quality of life features, both built-in and unlockable. It is mechanically rich and thematically saturated, with subtle and not-so-subtle hints to Hebrew scripture and Kabbalah teachings, alongside its varied references to exterior sources.

[h1]A few tips for the prospective player![/h1]
The wiki exists, but please refrain from using it until necessary. This game thrives on uncertainty and study.
Never be afraid to fail, as you learn more from failure than success.
Never be afraid to restart; unlockables stay unlocked through playthroughs, even equipment (until death!)
If it sounds bad, it's probably bad. If it sounds good, it's [b]definitely[/b] bad.
Do look over the provided manual and attempt to parse the four-color-coded stats system, as the terminology used is a little intentionally esoteric. Red is physical stats, White is mental stats, Purple is workspeed and success, and Blue/Pale governs speed.
Trust the manual. But don't trust it too much. 
Spread the love with equipment, and avoid the urge to overspecialize departments.

  [*]Try to bond with Reddit!

The game is a very ambitious and interesting idea, but the execution ultimately fails, for the following reasons:

1. It suffers from poor controls, which are a serious issue when tightly micro-managing your employees is necessary to managing/suppressing many of the abnormalities in the game.

2. Losing individual employees too detrimentally impacts the fun of the game. 

3. The game lacks serious graphical polish.  The artstyle seems somewhat unique at first, but you quickly realize it's pretty low-budget, apart from the story-ish driven NPCs you encounter (who are, admittedly, well-drawn and beautiful).   

4. The gameplay loop is not fun.  Unless you really enjoy pointing and clicking with poorly-drawn employee dolls and telling them to go fill-up progress bars, you aren't going to enjoy this game.  The trailers make it seem like a lot of frenetic, gruesome, fun stuff is going on often, but that's not the case 90% of the time.  And even if it is, it usually means your employees died and you have to immediately restart the scenario you're on.

Those are the most serious flaws of the game.  I understand the dev team is tiny ( I heard just 2 devs?) so perhaps it's unfair to be so harsh, and it's a great and ambitious idea, but the scope is just too wide, the execution leaves a lot be desired, and ultimately it's not worth your cash.

The beginning of the game holds your hand, shows you what to do, and if something breaks out you can tap it  a bit and it goes back to its containment. After a while you are working at a steady pace, know what to work with and are fly through days. Then you get your first Aleph on day 18 and it's liked being being hit in the nuts with a chair. This game shows no mercy for people who make many mistakes and easily forget. You slip up, let CENSORED escape and unless you know what your doing (which is most likely not going to help), you are forced to reset the day (which has no penalties!) The music matches the mood of the game, and the only problem I have is how early you can get and Aleph on your first play through, which doesn't even really bother me since it teaches me how to handle harder abnormalities and "puts me in my place". I wouldn't give this game to people who only like action and fighting, since if you know what your doing you most likely won't have to face problems early on. You WILL hit the reset button a lot, and you WILL have to reset a run, but don't worry because all items and skills you learned will be kept, you just lose employees and abnormalities. I haven't even finished the game, but will 100 percent give this to a friend (plus I heard there are multiple endings, come find them with me!)

Imagine having a strict, bitter father. This man looked down at you at your birth and said one sentence, the only sentence you have ever heard from him.

"You are a failure, and you always will be."

That father is Lobotomy Corporation, and as you read this review right now you have a choice to make. You can, if you wish, accept that this man is in his heart a cruel and evil individual whom you have nothing to prove to and no desire to pretend you seek his praise. If that is your opinion then please, disregard this game, it is not for you.

If however you are insulted by this man's lack of faith in you, or feel you can prove to him you are more then he sees you as, with nothing but the chance, ONLY a chance, he will one day gift you with a pat on the back and a firm nod, then you have a difficult road to follow.

You will fail. You will fail again. You will fail so many times it looks hopeless. You will fail over and over and over. But each failure you will look up at this man and see he has not noticed. He already thinks of you as a lost cause. To him, it is no surprise you are in your natural state. He ignores you. Lobotomy Corporation does not judge you for your failures, it has no need to heap insults on you or question your determination. It has decided to let you do as you will and expects nothing from you.

I, like you, fought against that indifference. I worked and worked and did all I could to earn the recognition of my worth. But  just as was expected of me, I failed. I am 90% through this game, but I can't go one step further. 150 hours and I just can't do it. My father was right.

Maybe you're better then me. Maybe you can make it to the end and see what I couldn't. Maybe you can finish what i'm choosing to leave behind. I don't know. but it will be hard, and you WILL fail before you make it there. So how determined are you to prove this man wrong?

You purchase desperate people off the dystopian streets and force them into little rooms to touch SCPs in your underground bunker. You collect new SCPs every day for the people to touch. Touching SCPs generates [REDACTED], which we need for [REDACTED]. Everything is fine and dandy for a very few, precious days. Slowly, you come to the realization that certain SCPs do not like to be touched and will, in fact, rip and tear when given the slightest opportunity. We do not talk about [CENSORED]. Still, we must complete our noble charge of generating [REDACTED], so some of the little people will just have to be forced to touch the dangerous ones. Repeatedly. As [CENSORED] inevitably envelops the fragile flesh of even your most steadfast and valiant operatives and continues to spread across the underground bunker, utterly out of control, you slowly pull your eyes away from the glass viewport and inject the [REDACTED] directly into your bloodstream with your main man netzach. Brooo, that's the way. Sometimes you just need to chill out.

The days turn into weeks and the underground bunker turns into an unrecognizable hellscape ruby goldberg machine that triggers the instant somebody passes gas in the wrong direction. You spend your precious moments before dawn, ruthlessly executing every single civilian lab worker who had the audacity to show up to work today and disposing of the corpse, lest they become meat fodder for the rapturous SCPs which now populate the bunker and may become alerted to the slapping of thicc employee thighs at any moment. That's enough slaughter for now, time to touch the accursed bull[REDACTED]. Why do I hear trumpets? Oh frick oh heck everybody get out of there. Looks like safety team wasn't very safe after all. Well, so be it, the rabbits shall graze upon this filthy grass once more. Safety team hasn't evacuated yet? Necessary casualties, as excessive as they may be. We must seal off the breach. Secure. Contain. Protecc. Ok, somebody stop the screaming baby before it causes the apocalypse, again. Ok, clearly what we need are some anti air guns. You then proceed to stuff the big seven into an elevator shaft and utterly buttblast the invading SCPs before they can buttblast you.

And then it gets harder. Why is THIS ONE so difficult to buttblast? What in the secured contained protected heck are they doing on the other side of the plexiglass? Excessive casualties are a regular occurrence now. Many, many of you will die, but a few may make it through, this time. Was the game always like this? The past month feels like a blur. Where is my cute little SCP management game where nothing bad happens? Truth is, the game was rigged from the start. It's a buttblast or be buttblasted world, which is extremely easy for me to appreciate. The music's pretty good as well. Wait a second, there's ANOTHER ONE?

Look, the game play itself is boring. All you do is click for one character to go to one monster box, and then they're done you click for them to go back. However when that doesn't happen it's just telling people to do the same thing over and over again. The monster boxes don't even get changed out that often. 

The one thing I did like about this game was the lore behind the monsters in the monster boxes. It was well thought out for all of them and really interesting to learn about monsters from other cultures.

The game is incredibly fun. If anyone wants to try it out, however, I suggest to keep in mind that, while you'd want to try to keep any and all employees alive, especially for the first few playthroughs, that will be almost, if not completely, impossible. Although you can plan for things, and set things up nearly perfectly, RNG can always appear to ruin that plan. It's best to always be lenient, and allow one or two employees to die as you near later days. However this won't let you stay safe, and chances are, due to some of the Abnormalities you'll end up with, you'll have to start a New Game.
But that's why you'd want to sacrifice employees... Everything you learned about those past Abnormalities, and all the equipment you got from them, is still with you. You'll know when they show up, and be able to plan things out even better thanks to having more knowledge than you would've ever had before, and even be able to take on stronger Abnormalities without any casualties.

So, if you're into the idea of managing a bunch of mysterious, maybe-deadly-maybe-safe creatures not bound by the laws of reality like you're in charge of the SCP Facility, this is definitely the game for you. Just remember, you most likely will have to restart your first playthrough.
I'm a sucker for SCP content and management games so my friends will probably never see me again.

Ignore the time here. I have played and finished the game, and want to sing its well deserve praises. Lobotomy Corp is what happens when you take a management game, mix in SCP style monsters if you filed the ID numbers off them, and put them in a universe that is deeply rich with lore, twists, dark humour, and a utterly beautiful story that wouldn't be far off in a game like SMT. 
You play the new manager, who is tasked with gaining enough power from the abnormailites to help the world keep power. These come in randomised SCPs that you don't know anything about till you gain information on them by looking after them. This isn't so much in the way you look after a pet though. Some have exact tells you need to watch for. Some need constant attention. Some require hugs. Some are ...censored....Either way, you will be looking after an expanding team of X-com like "Name your friends and murder them" "EMPLOYEES" that will help you tackle the daily life in this utterly safe, not dangerous at all murder box of sin and depression. 

Give this game a chance. If you like Roguelike ideas, mixed in with a story that will keep you compelled. You will ADORE this.

This is a very dubious recommendation. I wish steam had a neutral review setting.

This game's design is Hearts of Iron 4 levels of convoluted. But now at least the translation is comprehensible and makes sense. Everything is properly translated so it is easier to understand. There is a lot of mechanics to weigh and understand. It's promising so I'm going to continue to play it more after this review and if my opinion changes I'll update this.

The justification for the entire game premise is 100% an excuse plot and the presentation is very much "anime-esque" not just in visual but in the tonality of how things are presented, which is to say, very weak. This is very disappointing... but the game quickly glosses over it and moves onto the SCP/RPC material so you can handwave the nonsense story away and just get to playing an RPC like game.

My biggest grievance with LobCo so far is the game has only one theme which plays on repeat ad-nausium
I muted the music and just put on some iron cthulhu apocalypse which very seriously changed the atmosphere and theme of the game from something relatively light hearted in its handling of heavy subject matter into something dark and menacing. Which was much more enjoyable. This game's music is its biggest weakness. The tonal shift in the theme from the subject matter is cognitive dissonance and not only is the song annoying but it really distracts from the game's narrative.

Once you get around the incredibly heavy handed mechanics of the game it has a lot of potential. I like the risk of exploration that's involved. This is totally how the RPC/SCP groups would handle their entities. It's all about the danger of trying to understand something that is outside conventional understanding. Things will go wrong, stuff won't make sense. You will have to risk staff and they will die as you try to figure out what it is you're dealing with. Some of these entities get so weird and unknowable that there's a real challenge in disassembling their nature. I wish this was better explored, however, where you'd spend more time understanding something than what the game has. The system in place I feel makes it a little too easy to comprehend something over time. I'd like it more if it was, I guess, more rogue like and the anomalies were more difficult to understand with a much more involved process to debunk them with the risk being your entire game. That would add much more tension to the experience.

So far, so good.

This game is interesting, its mechanics good, its gameplay solid and interesting, and its story is creepy and fun.

I can't recommend it.  It has a nasty tendency to crash-to-desktop.  I have tried lowering its graphical settings, switching to 32-bit, reinstalling, verifying game file integrity, everything.  It has a horrific memory leak that will take place after about an hour.  The fact that it is a roguelike means that a game crash means all of your progress is deleted.  Do yourself a favor, watch a playthrough of this game.  It's a really cool game.  But do not buy, install and play it.  It is far too unstable.

It is an impressive title, that is to be sure.  And I will purchase the developer's next game.  Just don't purchase this one.

It's kinda hard to write about the story which is really the main focus of the game without spoilers, all I can say is that it's not one I will soon forget. It can get really dark and uncomfortable but it's not at all edgy. While I think reaching the ending can take too long, I haven't lost interest in what's happening for over 120 hours which I consider really impressive. I love the themes and characters, it's a story I don't think will age badly, if anything it's the opposite. I honestly wonder how Library of Ruina can top this. It's sad the game was badly translated for so long, you can't just google translate a visual novel.

Okay so here's the part about the gameplay and the management part is really not that hard lol, one monster likes white work, other one will kill your agent if you try it. Trial and error is the name of the game, do it right and you will unlock info that tells you how to work on an abnormality without ever losing employees. Ordeals are different but you can always retry to do it again or get a new one. People are just really forgetful and not willing to admit their mistakes, they make this out to be Eve Online level of micromanagement or something when it's really not. Yes, there are hard parts I didn't mention but there's not that many of them.

Some tips: Get a few mods to lessen the grind(Full-Time Employees is one I HEAVILY reccomend). Don't listen to Angela and take care of your agents(guys you control), you need them to progress and while I don't encourage trying to be jesus, if they keep dying every day you will not have a good time. Abnormalities are really cool and creative but try to keep them in their boxes, the first time an abnormality escapes is really fun, the second time is a sign of your failure. Want to finish the game legitimately? Prepare for a heavy grind and like 100 hours of box clicking.

Check out the soundtrack, there are some amazing tracks in there. I have listened to No Warning for over 100 hours and I still like it. If that doesn't convince you the soundtrack is a 10/10, I don't know what will.

Management game taking place in a SCP like facility. Your job is to send your precious employees to interact with various abnormalities ranging from barely dangerous to expert nuggets eater. 
They come mostly in two groups, items that you can wear or use, giving you various bonus but at a price usually, or monster like ones that can potentially breach and start causing havok. On top of this daily routine, accumulating more of these abnormalities as you go on with your days, you will be faced with ordeal events, potentially messing up with your plans by summoning annoying creatures areound your facility, boss fights and completing various objective to gain more abilities and growing into a better facility.
I don't think this game will be for everyone, there is a bit of farming required, it heavily plays on die and retry, and sometimes you'll have to start from day 1, which can be kind of a chore because you'll be stronger every time. It's also pretty hard and gets harder the more you progress at an exponential rate.

This game is super challenging if you're not used to these types of mechanics. But I don't think I'd call it unfair; rather, it's as heartless as it presents itself to be. 
When they say you're acting as the manager, they mean it. You have to send the right employee to perform the right task at the right time. If you don't, the consequences can range from mostly simple to catastrophic. In addition, you also have to be prepared for unpredictable events; if your teams aren't balanced in stats in equipment, they're as good as dead. 
And yet, these challenges are what make this game so interesting. I especially appreciate that you can restart days in the instance of achieving total failure or unsatisfactory results. You can also go back a few days if you want the chance to make different choices.

This is probably one of my favorite management sims. Apparently there used to be an issue with translation, but they re-translated it in English and that's all I've seen, and it's very good.

This is a fairly decent management game, with a fairly simple management idae, you get one new thing to manage every day, you pick 1 of 4 ways to manage it, and you learn how it reacts. Your people get stronger based on the ways they help manage your new monsters, and can equip things to help deal with escapes.

Where this game shines is that the monsters that you manage all have their own very specific intricacies/guidelines that you need to both learn and follow, and these make them all feel like their own interesting SCP's to manage. The extremely different ways that these may require handling beyond the 4 ways of management, and the ways they can react, make them all interesting to learn. As the game progresses you learn more about how to deal with your new "abnormalities", whether naturally or unlocking information about them. 

That said, this game is definitely not meant to be completed your first time in. Mismanagement of the abnormalities will kill your worker, which may lead to escapes and further deaths. Challenges you are required to beat may lead to over half your staff dying. If you have too many people die, you won't be able to manage some of the abnormalities correctly, which will lead to further deaths. Information of the specifics of how to handle your abnormalities can be unlocked by managing them at any degree of success, and sometimes it can be hard to understand what you're doing wrong until its directly told to you.

That being the case, this game has a wonderful reset feature, where you can either reset to the last 5 day increment, or from the very beginning, with all the information you have unlocked and equipment you've gained. You also have the option of resetting the day completely, as if it hadn't happened yet. This resetting is key to the game and you're going to want to do it at least once if not more, even from the beginning. The challenges you complete give you permanent upgrades that make resets far easier to start out on.

As you get through the game, the story will slowly be told to you from various perspectives, all leading up to a larger picture. I thoroughly enjoyed reading this story, but because it is based on your progression through challenges (which only need to be completed once), it will come in very uneven chunks based on how well you are doing. The abnormalities all have their own descriptions as well that are fantastic to read, and give the guidelines of how to handle the abnormalities more context.

I fully recommend this game to anyone who likes management games or the concept of SCP-like things. 
But turn off kickstarter abnormalities starting out. They are significantly harder to deal than the rest, which when starting out can be incredibly awful to deal with.

Great game. Excellent aesthetic, great music, 10/10. Fun for the whole family. Management sim, with cool horrific monstrosities with their own little backstories. Fun, and TONS of replay value here. You could easily get 200+ hours out of it.

Maybe a neutral rating would be more proper. Then again I might be lucky I stopped playing as soon as I did. The game is challenging, dark, hard and challenging. Its not really a roguelike, a major part of the gameplay is restarting days and trying to figure solutions to problems to get to the next day.

Worst part of the game is the UI. Game relies a lot on micromanaging which is made very hard by horrible UI. You cannot cycle monsters, you cannot cycle your own troops. The game tells by sounds that somewhere is a problem but there is no message which would help you locate the problem. The game also does not do good job on telling where the focus should lie in general. How valuable is your agents? What stats to train? Should you focus on the missions or rather push days forward? And for a game like this, I wouldn't really want to use outside wiki to tell me what to do.

Lots of the above might be design choices, that player is supposed to advance trough trial and error alone. And that the UI is supposed to be poor to make the game harder. The problem with that is that it takes a huge amount of time and effort to play the game. Solving a problem does not remove the said problem, you may very likely encounter the same problem in following day. Every day takes more time than the last, every new monster takes longer to figure out than the last and every day there is increasing chance for the day to fail.

I did enjoy this game quite a lot at first. In the end the UI and the amount of time this game requires made me not enjoy playing this game anymore.

Cut to almost 100 hours of screaming, crying and begging my employees to "just please stay alive" over and over I can wholeheartedly say this game is definitely the most enjoyable thing I've ever come across. 

It starts out overwhelming - the machanics are a lot of things thrown at you at once, but thankfully the tutorial makes a fun way to get to grips with things, and you are always gifted an "easy" abnormality first time around to help you get the hang of things. Then it quickly starts to ramp up the action with the trial-and-error nature of learning about each abnormality and how to best get energy from them to progress your game. Even if it's grindy and requires restarts - you'll come across new abnormalities each time around and there's lots to think of and consider in how you need to build your facility to better suit your objective for the run. (Eg: I need ALEPHs for Gebura or I want non-breaching abnormalities for the Suppressions).

The Characters are full of twists and genuine emotion, and all lovingly designed. Must say, getting the art book absolutely added to the enjoyment as I can see all the details and sketches that have gone into the facility and the abnormalities themselves. Each creation has its own story and it's a genuine pleasure to discover each one. It's also neat that one can customise the employees themselves so adding in your friends/family/OCs/self to see how long you/they survive before something eats (or worse) them! 

All in all, the fact that it took me almost 60 hours to unlock 10% towards the true ending (and now, 100 hours in I'm only at 40%) shows it was absolutely worth the £20 i spent on it and then some! I've even gifted it to friends so that they might share this glorious hell with me.

Lobotomy Corporation is one of those games that might not be for everyone, but for those who enjoy these kinds of games it's pretty great.

Basically, you are hired to be the manager of a facility for studying different things called "Abnormalities". These things range from weird doodads that can turn back time or make you completely bald, to horrifying monsters that will either eat you or do some other horrid thing to you.

You're tasked with sending your employees to study these Abnormalities in 4 different ways, with each having their own results. Some may be more effective than others, but until you actually fill out the information page of the Abnormality, it's basically up to chance. (That is if you don't just have the Wiki up in the background)

It gets harder over time as you deal with more Abnormalities at a time, which could end up working together to cause maximum chaos if you're not careful. However, if anything were to escape from their rooms, you can send your employees to suppress them. Studying these Abnormalities can grant your employees interesting equipment for combat and protection. There are also missions you can work on throughout your average day, these are linked to progression in the story, so do that.

The story is...interesting, and not really something I can go over in this review. Everything's not as simple as it may seem, and you might even have to bend the rules a bit and turn back time to have more than the default amount of days you have until reaching the neutral ending.

Whilst the gameplay might not be too amazing for those who enjoy action focused games, the lore and world building this game provides is fucking great. You will grow to love the many different horrible and wonderful things you'll encounter.

My feelings for this game are kinda complicated. If you want a tl;dr just read the last paragraph. If you want to know my personal thoughts as someone who 100% this game then give the rest of it a read.

This game is unfair. There are many different mechanics that you have to juggle involving the abnormalities to avoid disaster, each unique and most of the time incredibly difficult to keep track of. On top of that, there are some cases in which you end up getting abnormalities that have rules that contradict another, so you end up having to either put up with the horrible things that entitles or reset a few days to hope you get a better roll. By the way, resetting is also an integral part of the game. You'll most likely be forced to sacrifice progress to go back and grind better employees or equipment to have a fighting chance, meaning having to redo hours of work in some cases. Then after that, the game has boss fights that make trying to get through a normal day into a nightmare by instilling EVEN MORE rules.
This game is rigged against you. It will beat you up. It wont forgive you for missing even a single beat. It will get you no matter how well you think you know the game and it'll expect you to either persevere or try again for the 10th time. To be brutally honest, it's massively unbalanced and the devs know it because that's exactly what they want, while at the same time expecting you to get through it. It's stressful and infuriating 
...but, even after countless retries, over 100 hours of trial and error, and chipping away at this game on and off for over a year and only finishing it today, I can't say I hate it. Even though the devs didn't pull their punches when designing this game, they don't necessarily insult you for your failures either. It's a hard game and they know it, but they also know that with enough time and patience, they know you can win. It's reflected with the themes in the story and the dialog written; no matter how bad things are, it's still possible to get through it. That's why I like this game so much. It doesn't patronize you by making things do less damage, it doesn't make gear cost less when you lose too many employees, it doesn't do any of that. It gives you a difficult challenge and you try to conquer it. This ties incredibly well with the story too, but I'd rather not spoil anything. Personally, I don't really care too much for stories in games, but this game has so many layers and a lot of thought put into it's world that I couldn't help but get invested. The more you learn the more you realize just how deep the rabbit hole goes. There really isn't anything quite like this game.

It's honestly hit or miss. It's incredibly difficult and it doesn't get easy. The best way to gauge if you'd like it or not is by watching a video on the first few days and see if it interests you at all. Probably to like up to day 10. You might not like it and that's okay; just pass on this game, but if you DO end up liking what you see, then you'll no doubt enjoy what this game has to offer.

Summary: 
This Game will not be suitable to people that lack determination and the ability to endure pain and frustration over and over again (unless you've beaten a Dark Souls-like game). It is a Korean game which theme is based off the SCP universe, with Fallout Shelter-like management mechanics, and anime-like design. As of recently, the Revised English translation has been added which improved the dialogue (I only recently bought it after it came out, so I don't know how bad it was before), and for the most part, not many complaints coming from me.

Story: (No spoliers, just very basic run down.)
You are the manager for this facility. The facility is divided into different departments, with a different Sephirah (essentially the Head of the Department) that report to you. You command employees (essentially D-Class, but not criminals, just people who needed work) who directly follow your orders. There are Abnormalities which you must work on using employees and gain energy boxes from them until you reach your daily quota. Overtime, you unlock more difficult Abnormalities and more departments, which allow you to gain more equipment and special abilities to maintain order. There are three different endings to achieve and a number of varying Abnormalities you may or may not meet (depending how many playthroughs you do to unlock them all).

Mechanics:
As explained above, essentially it is similar to Fallout Shelter. You can create and customize employees to hearts desire (or as much as you can compensate if you are trying to create a certain replica of a character). Hairstyles are kinda of limited to Asian hairstyles and you can't change skin colour. Overtime, if they still live (gets hard to keep them alive), they will level up their stats which, for the most part, will make them better prepared to deal with the Abnormalities. You can also stack points you earn from how well you do the other day to either upgrade an employee or create a new one. Abnormalities not only provide you with energy, but with equipment, weapons, and gifts. These can be acquired after you research the Abnormality enough times and bank up enough spare energy to create them (gifts are earned by probability when working with them). As you pass more days and unlock and complete more missions/tasks from the Sephirahs, you can respectively expand/open more departments and unlock new abilities as mention above that can be used to help maintain the peace. Moreover, as days pass, you unlock new Abnormalities. You generally get to choose one of three per day with their serial number and a quote of theirs which give you a small sense of what they might be.

Difficulty:
This game is designed to be frustrating. There is a reason why you can restart a day or rewind to a memory repository (didn't mention this, but every 5 days, it saves it in the repository [For example: Day 1, 6, 11, 16...]. It basically reverts you back to that day as the same but with knowledge kept of the Abnormalities you unlocked after the memory day. It gives you a way to avoid a certain Abnormality and a potential to choose a new one). It is possible to keep all you employees you have alive throughout the game (which I am currently doing) but from personal experience, it can be really difficult and time consuming. Overall, if you can't handle this or would prefer to keep your sanity, then go ahead and avoid the game. But if you want something challenging and interesting, then this game might be for you.

Price:
The price of this game is $28.99 CDN, which may seem a lot. For someone who likes the SCP universe, anime, and management/strategy games, it is worth. You can get a couple of different games with the different endings which makes it playable for hours to come. However, eventually you will unlock everything and the sandbox mode doesnt add much to it (from what I heard). You could also wait for a sale if you need to save money, but for the most part, this game is worth what you get (especially with all these bad AAA games trend going on, thanks 2019, 2020). Overall, if you believe you will play the game to the end, then it is worth.

In conclusion, this game of interesting and diverse cast of characters and abnormalities makes the story intriguing. Frustration can arise as you encounter more difficult circumstances but as you play, you can retry multiple times and devise new strategies or plans that allow you to be creative on how you personally will run the facility. Their lives are in your hands. Good luck.

Welcome Sir/Ma'am/Miss/Mr,
If you've received this, congratulations!! We have reviewed your CV and determined you are the one to take on the position of Manager at our Corporation, you fulfil all the criteria and skills that we feel will be your most challenging task. 

As you are aware, we at L Corp are the largest energy companies in fact the only company appointed to power the world we live in. We strive for excellent delivery of energy to our homes and humanity due to this purpose, and our founder A has placed high expectations on us to achieve this every day. But before we continue, please examine the L-Pad we provided that details the contract's terms and conditions that you must accept. If not, press 'Refuse' and step away from the L-pad's blast radius of one kilometre.

....

Thank you for accepting your contract's terms and conditions. Level manager clearance acquired.

To continue, we must first address the rumours surrounding the corporation. Aside from the two prominent rumours that states our employees engage in after hour orgies and that we are a greedy, soulless corporation sucking the lifestream out of the planet to power humanity all rumours are true. Our energy source come from monsters we call Abnormalities, who either come to us or have been captured for their threat to the world at large and we interact with them to acquire the Positive Enkephelin boxes which stores the power siphoned from them. 

Your duty as acting Manager is to take care of these Abnormalities we secure, contain them in our facility, then siphon the energy. Simple, right? However, we should not forget to mention that we've gone through 35 managers in the past month before coming to you, and that's not including employee casualties from things such as: 

Possession and the urge to wear red shoes
Insanity from looking at incomprehensible beings
Sacrifice lottery draws
Mental breakdown
Suicides
Testing tools and machines
Participating in blasphemy and heresy of other kinds

As you can see from the above, your new job provides the appropriate challenge you crave. To survive, we will give you the first steps:

Work is divided into four categories: Instinct, Insight, Temperance and Justice which enhances your employees' health, mental fortitude, success at work and work speed. Abnormalities that are new bring unknowns so it is recommended you send your employees to prod and determine their threat level and what they respond to the best. Don't be afraid if they die, your subordinates are paving the way to discovery.

We classify our creatures from least to most dangerous: Zayin, Teth, He, WAW and finally ALEPH who are contained securely in their cells for you. As we bring in each abnormality at the end of each day, we give no indication of their threat level but only brief quotes and numbers to keep you guessing. Why? In the spirit of exploration and setting your own challenge against creatures unknown the next day for the most energy of course! Note that the more dangerous they are, the more energy you can afford.

If the creatures do get out, our staff are equipped with the most basic riot gear though with research time and energy, our Welfare team can create EGO weapons and suits to defend against these monsters, but only through sacrificing PE boxes to unlock Abnormality information fully so we can get a full profile of what they do. Trust me, you don't want to see what happened when we used incomplete information to make a suit, the employee's remains had to be torn from the parasitic suit. Angela will explain more.

With this advice given, we again extend our welcome to you, the new Manager of Lobotomy Corporation!! With the threat of death everyday out there...what do you have to lose with us?

By the way, before this review starts, you don't need to put nearly as many hours into this game as I have. Great game overall. Not perfect, of course, but still good and difficult. The concept is that you are the manager of a company that contains and harvests energy from abnormalities. You manage your agents and their work as well as try to keep the abnormalities from causing chaos. The best part of the game is just encountering new abnormalities and learning about their quirks, as you have no knowledge of them upon your first encounter. Sometimes, nothing horrible will happen and you will be relieved about the danger you avoided. Sometimes, something unknown and horrible happens, and it's your job to deal with the situation. You also have to figure out how to go about your day to day stuff collecting energy with the new threat inside the facility. The game also has plenty of quests, optional challenges, and surprisingly fun boss fights to spice things up. This game is not easy, and lots of chaos will ensue as you play through, but if you can get past some of the frustrating moments, this is a game I recommend.

I was expecting a game similar to fallout shelter but that isn't what I got.  You have very limited control of what rooms are placed.  The group research choices ultimately don't matter as you unlock all of them fairly quickly.
It does have a bit of a rogue-like approach to it that every time you start over you carry your research, group and monster, as well as your equipment with you making each following trip through easier.
But then there's the RNG and hidden details.
You have 2 choices: 
1. Check the wiki in advance so you know which monster the different numbers mean and plan your approach accordingly with the data sheet on a second screen.
2. Choose with what the game tells you and when it kills you the first few times restart the day until you know what it does. Then unlock the research for that monsters so it tells you what it does so you don't have to remember or re-check the wiki.  After the monster is fully researched by either approach you can move on to the next day.
As for the RNG you can do the same action with the same character and get a good result one time and a bad result the next (there is a normal/medium result in between there).  While some RNG can be fun this just pushes it a little further than I like.
It is very much a unique game and I wish I could give a better choice than yes or no for recommending the game.  I would honestly say watch a lets play of it if you can find one just to see it.  Despite saying I don't recommend it I am glad I took it for a spin.  I just won't finish it.  It isn't difficult, it's just chaotic and frustrating.  It really is like FTL and Fallout Shelter had a baby... then the baby may or may not have been dropped a couple times... depends on your RNG :-P

The game in its current state is absolutely fantastic. You are your worst enemy in this game. (90% of the time) The abnormalities have decent stories behind them and definitely give you the SCP feel as you initially observe their documents and attempt further research. A day in the game can go from 0 to 100 very fast depending if you fail to follow managerial tips or send inadequate staff to tend to the ungodly creatures and tools you have trapped in your containment units. Try to avoid guides initially as half the fun is figuring out what caused sudden chaos throughout the facility. The game can be very difficult and punishes the hell out of you for rushing things and losing focus. Certain abno's have timed effects that if you fail to tend to them can cause catastrophic damage to the facility. There are also helpful abnormalities that while can still cause damage if used incorrectly, generally benefit the facility. These helpful abno's can range from almost no draw backs to absolute carnage if used improperly. The music is great, from calming almost elevator like chimes in times of peaceful work, to some of the best combat osts in a moments notice when you screw something up.

While there are a few annoy things here or there like when you give agents an order it deselects them, making it harder to micro some of the harder breaches/ordeals this can be fixed with a mod thankfully. Additionally some of the later game abnos can be quite annoying such as [spoiler] a certain railway driven abno or a certain crying creature and dont get me started on the button. (It can wipe out a huge chunk of progress permanently so for the love of god dont click it) [/spoiler]

All in all, a fantastic game and well worth the price tag in its current state.

It's hard, it's challenging, and it's the Anime portrayal of SCPs from around the world- Lobotomy Corporation is the definition of farming and keeping your prized employees safe and sound. Let them die, you'll end up with such eradicating results to force a restart on the day- but don't take my word for it, look up ArcAngela on this game via YouTube. Enjoy.

This game is REALLY good. For the amount of budget it had, i'm surprised at the very high level of quality this game has. I'll try my best in this review to avoid spoilers, but disclaimer right from the start, do NOT look up anything about this game or some of the cool mystery will be taken away from you.

Lobotomy Corporation is a game where you manage a joint SCP containment facility and power company. I think it perfectly captures the feel of just how dangerous and weird working in such an environment is, while maintaining that amoral corporation feel. While the game is difficult and involves some trial and error, it never feels tedious since you can immediately retry the day if you don't like the outcome. Or if you feel like you've fallen too far behind, you can go to the last 5 day milestone you've hit to try and come up with a different gameplan for the week.

Although there are some legitimate complaints to be had about this game, I think they can be excused for the most part.
-The english translation is passable and does its job, but there are a few immersion breaking flaws here and there along with the occasional unnatural-sounding sentence. 
-The nature of dealing with new abnormalities and the fact you are very likely to do something wrong and kill one of your employees until you learn more about it could be frustrating. However, I do think this can be excused due to the fact you can restart the day whenever you want and the nature of the game.
-Customization, something purely cosmetic that doesn't give you any gameplay advantage at all, costs currency. Granted, it's only one LOB which is nothing later on in the game, but the fact it costs something at all is a bad choice IMO. Just let me customize my people.
-You will not beat this game on your first run. The odds are just far too stacked against you to possibly beat the game on your first try due to lacking EGO gear and likely not having optimized employees. But there is the upside that there are enough abnormalities so you will be seeing new ones very often on a restart. Also, you keep all EGO gear and abnormality information you unlocked on restart.
-Some stuff that should be in the game by default like a fast-forward button has to be researched as well as the ability to see health bars. This is like the only big complaint I have though besides customization.

I'm not good with ratings, but I seriously love this game. I would easily give it an 8/10. If and when the english translation has only a few flaws, i'll easily bump this rating to an 8.5/10. Very good job, Project Moon! I only wish I knew of this game when the kickstarter was active.

EDIT: The game was re-translated on May 4th, and the translation is good. I'd easily give this game an 8.5/10 now, it's absolutely worth your time to check out.
