Let me first start off this review by saying that I have yet to complete this game though I believe I have played enough to formulate an opinion on it. Also this is a [b][u]SPOILER FREE[/u][/b] review.

Lobotomy Corporation is [u]not easy[/u], it starts off deceptively simple but then the difficulty ramps up exponentially as it continuously introduces new abnormalities for you to extract energy from and manage all the while you also have to keep in mind the various ordeals (these ordeals usually spawn monsters and whatever else) that make themselves known as your "Qliphoth Counter" increases from extracting said energy from abnormalities.

Even though this game is extremely difficult I wouldn't outright call it unfair, it's possible to pass each day as long as [b][u]YOU[/u][/b] haven't messed up massively e.g. you haven't hired enough people to cover a particular section of the facility and then you struggle to handle the meltdowns because of it. I feel as though the large level of difficulty in this game makes it feel much more rewarding when you end up beating one of the days with no employees killed, this isn't purely a psychological thing as the game itself also rewards you with LOB points to spend on hiring employees and upgrading existing ones.

The fact that it's so difficult to reach the next day (at least with no casualties) makes you much more invested in the story, at least that's what I found as I felt that I had earnt the progression in the story. This is amplified by the fact that some of the things you do and see in the facility have an impact on the story or are tied into it which I won't talk about any further due to potential spoilers.

In terms of gameplay it can get quite tedious later on like day 25+ and it normally requires you to play the game at normal speed due to the sheer amount of abnormalities you have to manage but earlier on you can get away with playing at 2x speed. The gameplay (sort of) loop can get repetitive as I've mentioned but I always found myself coming back and playing again regardless, the standard day normally involves you consistently dishing out work to employees to go and do a specific type of work on an abnormality this can be Instinct, Insight, Attachment and Repression though with some abnormalities one of these types of work may be replaced with a special type.

Abnormalities respond to certain types of work better than others so this is where information gathering comes into play, you need to spend the special P.E boxes you get from working on a particular abnormality to get access to information regarding how well it responds to certain types of work + any other actions the abnormality may take and under what conditions e.g. what happens when it's individual "Qliphoth Counter" reaches 0?

If you find that a certain abnormality responds better to Instinct work then you would send in an employee with a high level of instinct.

In terms of music it can get very repetitive after an hour of playing so it would probably be better to turn it off at this point though the changes in music give critical information like if a abnormality has escaped containment or not so there's a trade off with this.

Overall, I greatly enjoy this game the great story and interesting mechanics paired with the fair difficulty of the game keep me coming back to it.

I got this a year or two ago, and I played it for a few hours maybe. I’m a huge fan of management games and horror (in particular SCP, which this game is unashamedly inspired by). I can’t remember exactly why I found it so hard to get into, but my guess is it was the incomprehensible English translation. So I shelved it as a game that I wanted to like, and just couldn’t. 

A few weeks ago, the game was entirely retranslated, so I reinstalled it. In those two weeks I played something obscene like 50 hours of it. I am so hooked. 

Don’t get me wrong, the writing still isn’t anything outstanding, but now that the game doesn’t have an impenetrable fog of truly abysmal localization, the gem in there shines through. The game is about managing a prison full of nightmares, monsters, and anomalous artifacts - it’s really the “SCP Tycoon” I had always hoped it was. When you get an Abnormality for the first time, you’ll have no idea how to manage it, and your employees will die - a lot. Slowly you’ll earn a series of entries which explain its rules: some Abnormalities are simple, like it hates a certain kind of work procedure. But some of the rules are fiendishly clever - requiring you to come up with your own real world procedures to stop you from making mistakes (my desk has a few index cards with counters and notes for various containment techniques). By the end of a run you’ll have dozens of creatures, all with different demands - one wrong move, and you can start a chain reaction of breaches which will end your game. 

The structure of the game is really unique as well. It’s kind of a rogue like, in that you are encouraged to start over but with persistent upgrades which make each run easier, but there’s no permadeath, you can try any day over. It’s sort of real time, but kind of turn based - explaining what I mean would rob you of the fun of figuring it out, but it reminds me of Dungeon of the Endless. It has the fun XCOM feeling of growing attached to your little guys, whose humanity is eroded as they work in your facility, but they die so frequently you have to get over that. Besides, it’s the Abnormalities who are the real cast of characters. And even though the writing never grabbed me, the plot did start to get compelling. And I just could not stop digging deeper into the earth and growing my prison full of horrors. 

The experience is playing wack a mole while memorizing and internalizing an ever growing set of rules to follow. If that sounds stressful, well, it absolutely is. But it’s actually really satisfying to throw up your hands and watch your ant farm get devoured by eldritch abominations. And there is so much to discover - this is a huge, really generous game which takes a long time to show you everything it has for you. Not for everyone, but if it sounds like it’s for you you have to give it a try.

this game gave me depression

I want to recommend this game to people, I have 23 hours in it which is great value. Except they're not fun hours.

They're grindy, miserable hours of trying the same level over and over again. Retries are free, encouraging you to hit the retry button whenever you lose a good agent which is basically necessary in a game where so many random bullshit deaths occur. There's anomalies in this game that can quite literally, instantly end the run out of nowhere and it's very obvious the retry button is a clumsy way to account for those moments. The progression system is just inordinately terrible and punishes you for expending resources you've acquired to try and meet the in game goals. Replacing those resources can be a matter of hours and it basically just encourages a 1 playthrough mindset. 

The secret of this game is most things are not inherently harmful. There exists a handful of bad choices you can make (which you won't know about until you've picked them) but that is basically the only threat in the game. There's very little genuine experimentation or discovery because you're handed everything you need to know without discovering it for yourself. Much of the game is performing the same rote actions over and over. 

I can see why people enjoy this, hell I have derived some enjoyment from it. It's definitely the best (and only) SCP Foundation simulator on the market. But that doesn't hide the fact that the game is just inherently bad. It's a badly designed, boring game. It has innumerable flaws that make the play experience miserable and I cannot in good faith recommend it to anyone.

Send a dude to a box to do a color thing to the box which generates victory points. Score enough, clear the day. Of course, the boxes have otherworldly monsters in them and they're picky. The rules keep piling on as you get more and more monsters. It should be simple, clean, and fun.

The problem is each day drags on forever. You don't know the rules of each new box, so you send someone in and they get killed instantly. Restart the day. You play along a bit, the meter fills, the monster busts out, you don't have the gear for a fight, restart the day. A botch is almost always a restart and these aren't quick days. The game just ends up being the longest most tedious game of Simon Says which each single new rule requiring a bunch of restart trial and error.

The theme of the game suggests you should expect your dudes to die, and in practice you get enough cash to hire quite a few, but most botches are worth entire sections of your team wiped out, including the high level guy who is the only one who can handle reliably the high level monster that just showed up so that's a restart too. There are no small screw ups. 

This just adds up to a giant fucking waste of your time. You're doing the same crap every day just slightly longer and with one more stupid rule but you're going to only be hitting the 3 most lucrative and needy monsters a day so you're just watching three meters go up over and over and over again and then you position everyone for the monster that spawns after X turns and then back to meters.

The straw that broke the camel's back was me getting a timer button. In practice, it is literally a button with one rule: Press every 30 in game seconds or else everyone in your base dies. After ten hours the game wants to throw an egg timer at me so now I can't veg out watching the boring meters fill because I have to hit the button every 15 seconds (in x2 speed) or else everyone will die. Fuck you too game.

On a side note, there's combat and it's just a gear check of your mans swinging at the monster until a meter goes to zero. You would think because it is VITALLY IMPORTANT to retreat the person getting focused by the monster as their health drops, the game would make it easy to see the health bars of everyone in a fight and select them individually. You thought wrong. They all stack atop each other because it's a 2D game and you have to page through the employee roster by department to see their health, and you can't pick them out from there apart from "Cancel attacking" which works wonders if and only if their last order was not to "hang out in the hall currently being attacked."

Also just because there is nowhere else to put this, for some stupid reason this game has two different meters called Qliphoth that represent two completely different tracks, increment in different ways, and have different results. So if you have trouble understanding the rules, just think of one as a time track until something happens and another as the monster mood

That said, compared to the monster box gameplay, that crap is manageable and intuitive. I appreciate the theme but honestly this overlong, tedious, terribly paced game can go jump in a lake. While I can't pretend that having to work around the moodswings of some of these ridiculous monsters isn't cool, their quirks wear out their welcome well before you finish the first of many required clears. I have had quite enough, thank you.

One of my favorite management sims. Love the style and design, especially all the abnormalities. The game can get a bit difficult and sometimes need to look up some guides but overall a really great game!

This game can and will make you question your ability to multitask. At first it'll all be learning the ropes, what does what, but eventually it'll become micromanaging a dozen different abnormalities, all with their own gimmicks. Don't send someone with low stats here, ONLY send someone with low stats there, make sure to stop using this tool before it's too late, and whatever you do, DON'T SHOOT THE BIRD. If this sounds stressful, it is, and that's not even the worst of it. If you're playing blind, this game can and will kick your ass, and employees will be dying almost every day. But when you finally get the hang of things, that stress turns to euphoria as everything starts falling into place. Despite how much I criticized the game earlier, I highly recommend it, if only for that feeling you get on the later days.

The Lore and unique "Monsters" are the main draw of this. The game gets really creative and keeps introducing things to keep it interesting.

The random events and pseudo random "Monsters" you get can and will straight up force you to reset and maybe even force to abandon an entire run when you get really unlucky. I don´t mind "hard" games, but this is the bad kind of hard.

You straight up take a 1 in 4 guess whenever you encounter a new "Monster". Sometimes nothing bad happens - other times it straight up instakills you which is highly frustrating.

Other times you get punished for using a "known good" way a 2nd time or some other unforseeable b/s.

Yes, the lore/writing explains these things, but usually when this happens you didn´t have those "hints" unlocked yet. So you just die and have to restart the day. At least that part is somewhat forgiving. You can just do that and then won´t fall into the same trap again. Leaves a sour taste in my mouth though. I´m sorry, but when i am supposed to metagame from the get go, that is just weird design. it is actually intentional that people die and i understand that.

I really dig the general idea of the game and the lore is really the main draw to this. After several frustrating runs i ended up watching some lets play to get an idea what i maybe doing wrong. That somewhat helped with the experience.

Having the Wiki open negates a lot of the "unfair" insta kills, but that straight up ruins the experience.

The game is a lot like XCOM in that regard. You can customize characters and get attached to them, only for the game to take them away from you after a while. Personally i handle this really poorly and that will most likely result in me dropping the game REALLY FAST, but that is just me.

The "boss fights" i saw in the let´s plays later on are really creative and i can see why people like this game. I can tell a lot of love went into this project and the buisness model is straight forward. 

Didn´t like the "equipment" management aspect between the days. That was about the worst part for me next to the cheap instakills. Don´t want to give a negative review because of the "unfun" stuff, it is not that bad.
scarecrow is the worst abnormality

1 hour in, I was wanting to throw in the towel due to how creepy and difficult the game was. Despite that, deep down I felt like I was lying to myself and went back to play more. Soon enough I got over my fears and surprisingly became a huge fan of this "SCP" management theme where we send employees to work, studying and trying to contain these abnormalities (while harvesting energy from them). I became unusually addicted to this indie game to the point where I eventually achieved 100% completion a couple days ago after so many hours.

Only things that were rough was:
- Farming for EGO and your employee stats could be a bit tedious (Not too bad for me since I would usually be doing other things while playing the game).
- That one bug that really annoyed me where an employee would become permanently out of control, then when you end the day...they would usually instantly die.

Other than that, I adore this game a ton. If anyone wants to try it they truly should but just know it might be frustrating/challenging in the beginning depending on what abnormality you get. You totally WILL have to restart all the way to the 1st day later on (a couple times at most), but you keep everything you worked for so it is all uphill. But the most important thing is you really should try to keep people alive in the early run because if they die they can lose that superior gear you worked for UNTIL you actually get the better upgrades in the future. But don't sweat it too much, you probably get enough to re-acquire the lost goods.

Personally I would give this game an 8.5/10 mainly due to still persisting bugs, but the game play and challenge is great, the art style is lovable, the music is absolutely astonishing, and the story is pretty rich. It is quite a unique game and very captivating. This game will always have a place in my heart, and I look forward to their sequel in the works as well.

Interesting games, you can play as a SCP officer. You need to observe the behavior of "the things" you have contained. The game mechanism is near to fallout shelter with SCP story line.

PS. (Wiki) The SCP Foundation is a fictional organization documented by the web-based collaborative-fiction project of the same name. Within the website's fictional setting, the SCP Foundation is responsible for locating and containing individuals, entities, locations, and objects that violate natural law (referred to as SCPs). The real-world website is community-based and includes elements of many genres such as horror, science fiction, and urban fantasy.

On the SCP Foundation wiki, the majority of works consist of "special containment procedures": structured internal documentation that describes an SCP object and the means of keeping it contained. The website also contains thousands of "Foundation Tales", short stories set within the universe of the SCP Foundation. The series has been praised for its ability to convey horror through its scientific and academic writing style, as well as for its high standards of quality. 

example : SCP-055 is something that causes anyone who examines it to forget its various characteristics, thus making it indescribable except in terms of what it is not.

I used to say that the translation was bad but they fixed it in the latest update. So now it's all good.

It's a bit arcane, but probably by design.  Fortunately the stats are color coded so you don't need to memorize that, say, an employee's Justice stat helps them perform Repression work.  And they expect you to fuck up repeatedly as every day ends with a "redo day" button, which is a helpful addition even if it hurts to move onto the next day with a couple corpses that you could have maybe avoided, but in several attempts have not managed to.  :P

Honestly though, I'm kind of digging it even though I have some issues with the core gameplay loop - every day you need to perform a certain amount of successful interactions with Abnormalities in order to, uh, produce energy? but certain Abnormalities tick down their "Qliphoth Counter" towards escaping just by virtue of you interacting with other Abnormalities, to the point where the stupid little bird has been escaping nearly every day in my current run.

Helpfully - or perhaps as another attack on perfectionists - you do have the option of starting the game again with all your current research still completed (if I'm reading the description right) which probably means you can avoid picking certain Abnormalities that are significant pains to house (oh, right, every time a new Abnormality is housed at your facility, you're given a choice of three with cryptic descriptions), or singularly useless like the one I chose that *always* kills the employee assigned to interact with it, meaning to complete the game in it's entirety you'll probably have to make a few goes of it or check out a guide.  Still, while it's an imperfect game it's definitely trying some fun shit and it's definitely worth checking out, just probably best to grab it on sale.  :P

This game is basically SCP with waifus and lots of trial and eroor mechanics. But that is not even bad. This game makes so much fun and after some time you kinda forget that this is not an scp game because this is exactly what I was thinking about how the work in the SCP-Facilty works. But let me explain the game for you because it is not that easy. There will be alot going on at the same time.

In Lobotomy Corporation you play as the manager and take control of every worker in the facility. Your goal is to harvest energy by working with the various paranormal entities which are called "Abnomalities". This can be done with ease. There are 4 different methods that every worker is capable of: Instict, Insight, Attachment and Repression.  But not all methods are equally good. Every abnormality has a preferred method to be worked with. You can read everything at the information screen of the abnormality. But there is the twist. You need to unlock those things little by little with the energy you gain by working with them. So basically you need to let a worker do his work completely blindfolded. You do not know if the chosen method is the best. The abnormalities will behave different depending on their mood after someone worked with it . If you are unlucky you will have a negative result which can cause various things. From losing energy to killing of your workers or an insane worker who is doing mad stuff. 

Expect to retry the day after messing up. And you will mess up a lot. After you finished your goal for the day you can retry. 

Once you get used to the basic mechanics of the game you will have alot of fun. Every abnormality has its unique and scary design and story behind it. Also they are sort by a ranking system, telling the player how dangerous the abnormality is. 

The game is super fun not only for SCP-Fans but for every fan of manager games.
re-bought this game because the old version was fun and had heard it was improved upon further, missed the challenge so much and love it to bits

"Experimenting" and "learning" (which consists of randomly assigning staff to 1 of 4 attributes until something works, then doing that thing forever) about monsters seems like an afterthought, instead theres some sort of story that didn't translate well, and watching workers slowly walk to rooms, then stand in that room. There are few stats and upgrades for staff that you are forced to manage but that just seems to take you further away from what I wanted to be doing in this game.

4/10. I ended up refunding.

Edit: A few days after I posted this review the developers released a major translation update, a few comments have said that the translations are pretty good now. For me, the gameplay is still different enough to what I want it to be that I will be sticking with my refund, I can't justify the game at full price.

Also, insert preemptive 'Hey hey, people.' here.

Now that this game's English has been properly translated, I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys management and multi-task games.

The general experience of the game is getting new monsters and objects and learning how they work. Some trial and  error is required, often resulting in the deaths of employees. Once a monster is understood, its threat is greatly reduced and it becomes manageable. The more dangerous monsters will enact a greater toll before this occurs. While inherently not a bad system, it does have a few glaring flaws. The penalty for losing important employees is quite severe, often game-ending. The more dangerous monsters are likely to simple devour crappy employees, so you have to use your more experienced ones. Since you can restart any "round" as many times as you want, learning different monsters becomes a tedious process of feeding them your best employees until you understand them and then retrying the level with this knowledge. In other words, this game starts to break down when you try to meta-game it. This would normally be okay, but since losing a couple important employees can end a run, there's almost no incentive to play the game the way it is "meant" to be played.

The longer the game goes, the more you have to manage. Some monsters will kill any employee who worked on them if that employee goes to work on another monster. So while you're dealing with a problem and assign such an employee without thinking about it, you can kill them. Some monsters can only be worked on by employees with very specific stats. This can be fun, but it can also be overwhelming. This is made worse by the intentionally clunky interface and lack of basic commands to make controlling your employees easy. The interface is intended to be basic to force the player to use more focus, increasing the danger of monsters that require focus in order to prevent disaster.

In order to win a round, you have to generate enough resources. So in the backround while you're managing disasters, you still need to generate that base income. It feels like macro play in an RTS in a lot of ways (which isn't that surprising considering the Korean origins of this game.)

You will probably enjoy the game if the following applies to you:
1. You like SCP
2. You like games that force you to multitask
3. You like trial and error
4. You like starcraft or similar games where player focus is a resource

You probably won't like it if any of these apply to you:
1. You like to "metagame," meaning you like to figure out how a game works and use that against it. This game is not good for this at all
2. You expect a polished experience
3. You want an interface that makes controlling everything easy
It's good!
Have you ever wanted to control the SCP Foundation? If Yes your insane but this is the game for you.

I always seem to find myself consumed with games like this in a good way. Lobotomy Corporation isn't the kind of game where I could just namedrop another and say "this is a lot like game x, except y and z are different." It plays like a management/tycoon-like game, but the depth (and intensity) of the gameplay gets really high up there the longer you go. This is not an easy game. Expect employees to die, resets to be done, and day 1 restarts to be made (which are pretty much necessary for the true ending). The art style, music, and the story are phenomenal. I want to say so much about the story, but it'd be spoilers galore, so I'll just say the story goes from 0 to 10 to 100 to 100000 to 10000000 the longer you play. [strike]The translation is passable at times, good most of the time but haltingly bad at others, especially later on in the game. It isn't enough to detract from the ending though, in my opinion.[/strike] (EDIT 5/4/20: They redid the ENTIRE English translation. It's beautiful now.) The intense difficulty spikes (ESPECIALLY NEAR THE END) are something I love in a video game, but it felt almost cheap at some points, and almost like glitches until I realized the game was supposed to work that way.

Overall, definite 9/10. I can see this game becoming somewhat of a cult classic because of its unique design and difficulty. After beating the game twice, however, I can confidently say that I want in on that Lobotomy Corp cult. You should give this cult a try, too. Also, fuck you Hod

I will say it is NOT a tycoon like it says it is. you get very little choice in how to expand or what parts you expand. but it is definitely a management game. every day consists of you getting a increasing amount of PE-Boxes from researching the various monsters you hold. once you get enough PE-boxes the day ends. but its not that simple, you also have to deal with raids, breakouts, and whatever else go's wrong. and trust me something WILL go wrong.

I think that perhaps the best aspect of this game is the way it scares you. while the artstyle and some of the monsters are less then scary. the REAL horror comes from you as the manager having to poke and prod these monsters to figure out what the hell they do. and you cant just ignore them or else they'll escape potentially causing mass havoc. this leads to the decision of risking a employees life or playing the lottery and hoping its a "non-escapable" object which cant escape.

luckily the game allows you to redo a day with no consequences if you completely mess up meaning that with time you can learn how to counter these monsters in a single day of work. but the initial fear and stress of what that monster does is more then enough to make you think twice before sending in just anyone on the next monster. while the reward for researching these monsters is PE boxes, special gear, and the history of these monsters. starting a new game also allows you to get different monsters on different days while keeping all research on previous monsters intact and still having access to their equipment. and you WILL need to reset atleast once because you'll most likely hit a wall where you cant care for a specific monster and it just destroys the facility everytime you start the day

I do wish monsters had more unique parameters to research them. most of them boil down to sending in a guy with stats catered towards them. overall its a pretty solid management game.

Allow me to just say, this game is really well made. From the art, to the music, to the UI. All of it is good.
I would 100% recommend to anyone who might need something to just relax a bit, or maybe even tryhard ;).
The only downside to this game in my eyes is two things. One, the game can get really difficult, and may almost always require you to restart your play through so you can pick the easier "monsters". My second, is that the console should be let out to all the players, not just the developers. We all are not skilled enough to surpass all the days, and some of us (like myself) just want to look at all the weapons and "monsters" and have fun with it that way.
Despite that, I do recommend it, and I really do enjoy the game.

Have you ever wanted to run a site in the SCP foundation? Then this game is for you! The key to winning in this game boils down to your knowledge and handling of the various SCPs that come your way. Have fun and don't be afraid to reset! Losing is part of the game!

A novel approach to creating a SCP style game, Lobotomy Corporation does a better job of simulation the process of learning and containing these mysterious creatures than any of the "official" SCP projects I've seen to date. While the basic mechanics are relatively simple, the layers of complexity that the various abnormalities add results in an interesting, and difficult, management sim with a lot of spirit. There are definitely some issues I had during my time with it: even after multiple updates the translation is pretty rough (particularly in the lategame scenes), a lot of the UI isn't as intuitive as I would prefer, and going for the true ending involves a heavy amount of mindless repetition as you grind out the abnormalities you're missing and prepare for the endgame run. But even with these in mind, Lobotomy Corp is a game worth experiencing for anyone interested in management sims and SCP style of horror and storytelling.

Extremely fun management sim. If you like monsters creatures and doing testing to discover what makes things Tic, this is a game for you. My only real complaint is that the game can be unforgiving for tiny mistakes, which can lead to resetting a day of work (and the days can be long), but the game does allow you to reset your progress while keeping a lot of your earned Bonuses, making it easier the second time. Even despite this frustrating I've found myself pressing further and further, just to find out what happens next, and what weird new Thing I'll have to deal with.

A meaninglessly repeating micromanagement hell for the first 20 days. A many-people-in-outlandish-costume-fight-with-crankish-weapons game for the rest of the game.

You will easily lose everything for a little mistake or misclick and then have to restart the entire day over.

I recommend this game if you like management simulators like Sims or Fallout Shelter, and like SCP. This game may not be for everyone. Sometimes your employees will die. Sometimes you will fail. Sometimes you will need to start from Day 1 - but don't let that discourage you. Starting over is not a complete restart - it saves all of your research, your progress, and most importantly the items you've created. This game is hard, it isn't perfect, but it's definitely enjoyable in my experience.

Feel free to ask me questions on the game, I will answer.

If you want to use wikipedia to pick your abnormalities optimally, and not have to research them, then I wouldn't recommend buying the game. Alot of the fun comes from not know what you're getting/sending a person into a room with a abnormality that could be a Teth(weakish) or could be a Waw(insane boss) 
Use wikipedia only if there's a managerial tip that is lost in translation otherwise you risk ruining a great game on yourself.
Also the story is pretty good too so if you want to get this (which i highly recommend) try to go in completely blind.

Cross SCP with Fallout Shelter and you've got this wonderfully challenging and fun game. Great to play when you are bored.

I've only played this game for a few hours and I'm in love with it. The game centers around risk management and this part of the game is handled really well, basically the first game I've played were I am constantly weighing the risk and benefits while keeping the quota of the day in mind and my own self-set goals. The game also has a lot of interesting lore and character development. There's also a lot of mods for this game on top of it's normal replay value. There are a few things keeping this game down,the main complaint I hear is about stability issues but I haven't had any problems with this and I'm willing to bet most of it is because of mods. There are also some quality of life issues like the fact that you have to unlock being able to see your employees health and have to go to a different menu for a wile, this isn't the biggest issue because seeing employee health doesn't become important till later anyway but this is just one of a few UI improvements that could be made, you can fix most of these problems with mods but again stability issues. I have more to say but this review is getting long so i'll just say to summarize this is a really fun management game and you should definitely buy it if you like that kind of game.
If you like SCP and Fallout Shelter, you'll love this game.
